DOC.HEAD: What Gets a Media Mogul's Attention? A Regular Old Chain Letter
DOC.TEXT: It seems that some of America's most powerful media barons _ the biggies whose outlets influence public opinion and public policy _ can themselves by influenced by the anonymous warnings of a simple chain letter. A few of the moguls are sheepishly passing along a chain letter that has been circulating through broadcast and newspaper executive suites in Washington and New York since early this year. The anonymous letter, which purportedly originated in the Netherlands and claims it ``has been passed around the world at least 20 times,'' promises good luck in four days to every recipient who sends it immediately to five friends. ``The one who breaks the chain will have bad luck,'' warns the letter, which is accompanied by photocopies of cover messages written by those who kept the chain unbroken. Arthur Sulzberger Jr., deputy publisher of The New York Times, sent copies of his letter to five friends, including Random House executive Peter Osnos. ``You'd think I would have more courage than to send it on to you,'' Sulzberger wrote. ``A man will do anything out of fear,'' wrote Benjamin Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, who once tangled fearlessly with President Nixon over his newspaper's Watergate exposes. Bradlee received his letter from Shelby Coffey III, editor of the Los Angeles Times, who passed it along with a brief note asking, ``How can it hurt?'' Syndicated humor columnist Art Buchwald sent his copy to five woman friends, including Cosmopolitan publisher Helen Gurley Brown and columnist Ann Landers. ``I've been asked to send this chain letter on to my five dearest friends,'' Buchwald wrote. ``This is the best sex I ever had.'' He added a warning that ``the last person to break this chain was seated next to (talk show host) Morton Downey Jr. at a dinner party.'' Buchwald had gotten his copy from Pierre Salinger of ABC News in London, who wrote in June: ``Having received this letter on my 65th birthday, I have no choice but to send it on as ordered. I am getting too old to take a chance of breaking the chain.'' Albert R. Hunt, Washington bureau chief of The Wall Street Journal, attributed his complicity in the chain to his superstitious nature. ``I don't fly on Friday the 13th,'' Hunt wrote his friends. ``I don't walk under ladders; when my favorite baseball team, the Philadelphia Phillies, are winning I don't change my underwear (thank God they've had a string of losing seasons) and I'll be damned if I'm going to break a chain letter.'' One of Hunt's recipients was Tim Russert, the NBC News bureau chief in Washington. ``Keep Hunt and his voodoo journalism away from me!'' he wrote. ``Look,'' Newsweek magazine's Howard Fineman pleaded with his five friends, ``I know you've already gotten one of these and you threw it in the wastebasket. But take pity on a guy near the end of the food chain. Besides, it's August. What else is there to do?'' Fineman's letter was dated Aug. 1. His journalistic dog days ended the very next day, when Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait. At least one media heavyweight has been brave _ or foolish _ enough to break the chain. Jack Nelson, Washington bureau chief of the Los Angeles Times, said he received the chain letter from two friends, but was too busy covering the Persian Gulf crisis and writing a book to pay any attention. ``So far my luck's been pretty good,'' he said. ``Maybe it's working the other way for me.''

DOC.HEAD: Theatre Poster Designer, Former Life Magazine Executive, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Gilbert Lesser, one of the country's most prolific theatre poster creators and former promotion director of Life, Time and Money magazines, has died of cancer. He was 55. Lesser, who did posters for shows including ``Equus,'' ``The Elephant Man,'' ``Frankenstein'' and ``Morning's at Seven,'' died at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center's Milstein Hospital on Tuesday, said John Toland, a longtime friend. Eighty of Lesser's posters were displayed at the Louvre in Paris in the summer of 1987 and the new Design Museum in London in December 1989. The collection included his logo for the Manhattan disco Studio 54 as well as designs for the Martha Graham and the Jose Limon dance companies. Lesser, who lived in Manhattan, also designed costumes and stage sets for ``Threepenny Opera,'' ``Zoo Story'' and ``The American Dream'' at the Berkshire Playhouse. He was also responsible for several promotional programs for Charm and Mademoiselle magazines and the Smithsonian Institution. Lesser in 1987 established the Gilbert Lesser INCR Inc., an international group to help organizations create and plan special events. Lesser, born in Baltimore, graduated from the Maryland Institute College of Art and from Johns Hopkins University.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Death Sentence, Rejects Psychiatric Claims
DOC.TEXT: The death sentence of Robert Alton Harris, the man closest to San Quentin's gas chamber, was upheld Wednesday by a federal appeals court. Harris, now 37, was convicted of the July 1978 murders of two San Diego teen-agers whose car he used in a $3,000 bank robbery. He sought a new penalty trial on the grounds that the psychiatrists who assisted his trial lawyer were incompetent for allegedly failing to detect a longstanding brain disorder. Judge John Noonan of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals stayed Harris' execution March 30, four days before he was to die. He said Harris may be entitled to a hearing to determine if his constitutional rights were violated. But over Noonan's dissent, the appeals court ruled 2-1 Wednesday that Harris' claims were meritless. The majority ruled in the prosecution's favor on every disputed issue, at least two of which are important for future cases. The justices said courts aren't required to evaluate the competence of a defense psychiatrist's performance. And they said a defendant such as Harris, whose first round of appeals was rejected before the U.S. Supreme Court established the right to psychiatric assistance in 1985, cannot even raise the issue under federal law. ``A judicial evaluation of a psychiatrist's opinion or advice is not essential to the accuracy and fairness of the criminal process,'' and if applied to past trials ``would frustrate the legitimate goals of the criminal justice system,'' said the opinion by Judge Melvin Brunetti. ``Harris cannot now obtain a `second bite at the apple' because he believes a new group of psychiatrists would offer a different defense,'' the opinion said. Defense lawyers can ask for reconsideration by an 11-judge panel of the court, a procedure the court has used several times recently in capital cases from other states. It can be authorized by a majority vote of the court's 27 active judges. After that, Harris' only remaining appeal is to the U.S. Supreme Court, which has ruled against him four times in the past. No new execution date has been set. Out of 286 prisoners on California's Death Row, Harris' case is the only one to advance beyond the first stage in federal court review, which commonly lasts several years. No one has been executed in California since 1967.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Held For Sailor Killed During Persian Gulf Posting
LaserPhotos BX4-5
DOC.TEXT: Daniel M. Jones was buried with full military honors Wednesday as friends and family grieved for the second member of the armed forces to die since the Persian Gulf crisis began. Jones joined the Navy after graduating from high school in 1988 because ``he wanted money for college, to serve his country, and most of all, to have everybody be proud of him,'' said Christina Russell, a friend. Nearly 300 mourners, attended morning services at the First Baptist Church in Wakefield, about 13 miles north of Boston. After a 21-gun salute, the body of Jones, an electrician's mate, was buried in nearby Forest Glade cemetery. Leith A. and Arlene Jones were too overcome with emotion at the gravesite to accept the American flag taken from the casket of their 19-year-old son. Jones clung to his sobbing wife, while another mourner accepted the flag for the family, which includes Jones' four brothers and two sisters. Jones was electrocuted Aug. 21 aboard the USS Antietam while performing routine maintenance on the ship's ventilation system. The ship had been sent to the Persian Gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield, which was deployed to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Report Details Effects Layoffs Would Have on USDA, Farmers
DOC.TEXT: Stephen B. Dewhurst is one of many Agriculture Department employees who were notified this week that they would be taking an unpaid furlough later this year. In all, some 2.4 million federal workers are being told of the layoffs that will come if Congress and the White House fail to solve the government's budget problems. Dewhurst is USDA's budget director and feels closer to the technical aspect of the problem than most. But a report Tuesday by his office showed the plan to save money under a ``sequester'' plan to cut spending would have far-reaching effects. There would be lower subsidies for major commodities, and needy farmers would have less of a chance to get housing and operating loans, the report said. Perhaps as many as 90,000 USDA employees, roughly 90 percent of the department's permanent work force, would be affected one way or another by the layoffs. It would affect chicken inspectors and economists, scientists and file clerks, highly paid executives and those at the bottom of the scale, the report warned. The layoff notices and other measures are in the works just in case Congress and the Bush administration don't come up with an 11th-hour rescue for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Citing the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law, the White House has ordered an across-the-board cut of federal spending to begin Oct. 15 if no budget agreement is reached. About $22.9 billion of USDA's projected outlays would be affected. Food stamps and child nutrition programs generally are exempt from the cuts. The USDA study anticipates cuts of 31.9 percent, or $7.3 billion from affected programs. ``Farm price support payments and many other USDA loan and grant programs would be severely reduced,'' the report said. The report added: ``The necessity to lay off employees would disrupt USDA services throughout the world and especially at USDA county offices throughout rural America. Producers and industries dependent on the availability of USDA programs and services would be severely affected.'' For example, so-called deficiency payments to farmers for next year have been projected at about $3 billion; a 31.9 percent cut would be more than $900 million. Dairy farmers would be assessed approximately 8.7 percent per 100 pounds of milk marketed, which would reduce cash receipts by nearly $130 million. In state and county offices of the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, where the programs are administered, salaries and expenses would be reduced by the same percentage. More than 20,300 employees of the county offices would be furloughed. Offices would be closed Mondays and Fridays. Dewhurst said he and others in the USDA budget office had received letters that they would be furloughed three days out of every 10. ``You can get a 50-50 bet, I suppose, from people who think it won't happen at all and those who think (cuts) will be 40 percent,'' he said. The Office of Management and Budget has already boosted its estimate of spending cuts to 32.4 percent, and Dewhurst said that could balloon further. Only about $600 million of the $23 billion in food programs would be subject to the cuts. Food stamps alone account for around $16 billion or so. But the current food stamp law runs out in 1991. ``If, as everybody expects, the food stamp program is reauthorized, it will drive federal spending up,'' Dewhurst said. ``You'd see the (cuts) go to somewhere between 38 and 40 percent.'' That would put a further bite on commodity price support operations, the Farmers Home Administration, food aid to foreign countries, conservation, research and the other eligible programs. According to the report, using the ``planning'' cut of 31.9 percent, farmers also would see their government checks for price support loans reduced by that amount. The loans are commonly made at harvest time so farmers have operating money to tide them over. If market prices rise later, farmers usually pay off the loans and then sell their products for cash. If the cuts are carried out, it will mean about $1.8 billion less for farmers taking out crop loans next year, according to 1991 budget projections. ``A 31.9 percent sequester would greatly complicate program administration and would introduce instability into commodity markets,'' the report said. In the case of meat and poultry inspection, where most USDA spending is vested in the salaries of employees, a 31.9 percent spending cut was said to ``result in the absence of inspection services during a furlough of about 137 days,'' effectively shutting down the slaughtering and processing industries for that amount of time. ``The economic loss from a shutdown would result in the loss of billions of dollars to the American economy,'' the report said. Further, it said, the limited inspection that would be available would not be sufficient to prevent an erosion of ``the high level of safety'' in the nation's meat and poultry products and ``would focus public criticism on the federal government.''

DOC.HEAD: TV News Gets High Ratings During Gulf Crisis
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has created a thirst for news that has lifted the ratings of everything from ``Face the Nation'' to ``60 Minutes.'' CBS' ``60 Minutes'' was the most-watched show on prime-time television for the second consecutive week, its first back-to-back No. 1 victories since 1983, when it was the top-rated show for the year, the A.C. Nielsen Co. said Tuesday. Viewership of six Sunday news and information programs _ ``Face the Nation'' and ``Sunday Morning'' on CBS; ``This Week with David Brinkley'' and ``Business World'' on ABC, and NBC's ``Meet the Press'' and ``Sunday Today'' _ rose 27.7 percent since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Nielsen reported. Last Sunday's ``60 Minutes'' featured a Dan Rather interview with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, a segment on chemical warfare and a report from the Soviet Union by Morley Safer. The weekly ratings also showed high marks for NBC and its early fall preview week. The premieres of ``Ferris Bueller'' and ``Parenthood'' _ both spun from feature films _ landed in sixth and seventh place, respectively. Fox Broadcasting Co. fell flat with its impertinent move to put ``The Simpsons'' up against NBC's ``The Cosby Show.'' The sugary Cosby family and ``Unsolved Mysteries'' tied for No. 3. The squabbling Simpsons were No. 54. NBC won the overall ratings race with a 10.5 average to ABC's 9.4 and CBS' 9.1. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. The most-watched nightly network news program belonged to ABC and Peter Jennings, with a 10.4 average. CBS and Dan Rather were second with 10.2 and NBC and Tom Brokaw dragged into last with 8.9. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 16.5; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 15.4; ``The Cosby Show,'' ``Unsolved Mysteries, NBC, (tie) 15; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 14.9; ``Ferris Bueller,'' NBC, 14.2; ``Parenthood,'' NBC, 14.1; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 13.9; ``Matlock,'' NBC, 13.8, ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 13.6.

DOC.HEAD: Reservists Say Middle East Missions Tiring, Sometimes Scary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `Early Wednesday...,' with 2 grafs to update with 10 killed, that most of crew was from 433rd Wing.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ramstein Crash
DOC.TEXT: Air Force reservists making round-the-clock cargo flights to the Persian Gulf said Tuesday the trips are tiring, sometimes frightening journeys into a hot, strange place. ``The glare off the sand flying over it is ... almost blinding,'' said Staff Sgt. William Salter. ``You almost get the impression you're flying over another planet.'' Salter and other volunteer reservists from the 433rd Military Airlift Wing at Kelly Air Force Base have flown supplies to the Middle East aboard giant C-5 cargo planes for Operation Desert Shield, the U.S. response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Early Wednesday, a C-5 flown by a crew of 17 crashed and burned at Ramstein Air Base in West Germany, reportedly killing 10 people. Eight crew members and two maintenance personnel from the 433rd were aboard the plane, said Maj. Donna Pastor, spokeswoman at Kelley. The other seven were from other Air Force installations, she said, adding that she didn't know which bases. She didn't know how many of the dead were from the 433rd. The reserve wing at Kelly has not been activated, but volunteer reservists have been working beside active-duty Air Force crews. ``We've probably had in excess of about 200 people (from the 433rd) help out,'' said wing commander Col. Michael J. Quarnaccio. ``We've had more volunteers than can be used right now.'' The 15 C-5s operated by the 433rd at Kelly have flown to other bases, where they were loaded with supplies, Quarnaccio said. They then fly to Europe and on to Saudi Arabia. The trip takes up to 27 hours. Quarnaccio and airlift wing reservists refused to discuss specific destinations or details of their trips, but some said Air Force and Army troops were aboard their planes. ``What they're actually hauling, we don't know,'' Quarnaccio said. Maj. Dennis Means, a C-5 reserve pilot who has made three trips to the Middle East under Operation Desert Shield, said the crews sometimes were apprehensive. ``There is a fear factor when you do go into a situation where there could be combat,'' said Means, a pilot for Southwest Airlines who has taken unpaid time off to fly the missions. Crew members said one of their biggest problems was battling fatigue during the trips, which sometimes included stopovers in Saudi Arabia as short as six hours. ``It's tough. You're just real tired,'' said Means. Staff Sgt. George Hernandez said his job was to make sure the C-5s were in good shape. That meant overcoming obstacles like sand and searing heat. ``Where ever it's flying, you still have to check the tires, the oil,'' he said. ``Going into any extreme weather _ whether it be hot or cold _ it's going to have its effect on an aircraft.''

DOC.HEAD: Journalistic Question Raised Again: Do You Edit Saddam Hussein?
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Once again, Saddam Hussein met with some of the Western ``guests'' he holds hostage, an Iraqi TV crew in tow. And again, Cable News Network aired the Iraqi satellite transmission live, enabling CNN viewers to watch along with the Iraqi public. So again, a journalistic debate emerged. Should news operations give Saddam live access to American television? ``We would not do that under any circumstances,'' said Bob McFarland, NBC deputy director of news. ``We made that decision the first day they pumped it out. We decided it was pure propaganda.'' None of the big three American networks _ NBC, ABC and CBS _ aired the Iraqi transmission live on Tuesday, as CNN did. Instead, they showed portions somewhat later. CNN said the meeting was important enough to show as quickly as possible. ``We make these decisions on a case-by-case basis,'' said CNN spokesman Steve Haworth, adding that CNN understood that Saddam would be speaking with American hostages. ``There was no question in our minds this would be newsworthy.'' CNN explained to viewers that the broadcast was an Iraqi TV feed. And afterward, CNN featured a debate over the wisdom of the decisions it had made. It's a decision the other networks see differently. At NBC, ``we would not put Iraqi TV on the air without first knowing what it was,'' McFarland said. ``We took every frame of it into the house, looked at it, and then selected two or three bites.'' ``Wherever there is a hostage videotape, a captive videotape, it's a decision we don't take lightly,'' said Sherrie Rollins, ABC director of news information. The president of ABC News has to approve the use of such video, she said. When Saddam appeared on television on Thursday with Western hostages, ABC joined the Iraqi satellite feed live for a few moments after first viewing the transmission to gauge the content of the material. ``We did air the material; we did feel it was newsworthy,'' Ms. Rollins said. But when Saddam appeared with hostages again Tuesday, ABC taped the material and showed only a brief portion during a special report by anchorman Peter Jennings, she said. After Tuesday's coverage on CNN, Pati Heath of Detroit, the sister of an American hostage, called the Atlanta-based network to say she had seen her brother on TV. CNN then put her on television, too. ``I'm just happy to be able to see my brother's face,'' she said. ``I hope Hussein sees me talking right now.'' During Tuesday's meeting between Saddam and the hostages _ whom he calls ``guests'' _ a woman with a British accent was heard asking Saddam why he was using foreign children ``in something they can't understand.'' He responded with a long answer about the threat to his nation from Western troops. But later Tuesday, the Iraqi News Agency reported that women and children held in Iraq would be free to go, and that Saddam had changed his mind because of the concern expressed by the foreign families during the meeting. ``I don't think it's coincidental,'' Haworth said.

DOC.HEAD: Countdown Begins for Columbia Launch
DOC.TEXT: The countdown started today for this weekend's launch of Columbia, NASA's first attempt to send up a shuttle since the fleet was grounded by hydrogen leaks. The newly repaired shuttle is scheduled to blast off on an astronomy mission at 1:17 a.m. EDT Saturday. Columbia's seven-man crew arrives at Kennedy Space Center tonight. ``There's an extra sense of anticipation, that we're anxious to begin flying again,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. ``It's been a dry summer.'' Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight will be the first shuttle mission since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. That's the longest gap between missions since flights resumed after the 1986 Challenger accident. Leaking hydrogen kept Columbia from lifting off with the $150 million Astro observatory in May, then grounded Atlantis. The leaks are believed to be in different spots. NASA also has been haunted this summer by Hubble's defective mirror and the malfunctioning Magellan spacecraft. The space agency on Tuesday delayed Magellan's mapping of Venus until late September to find out why the spacecraft keeps losing touch with Earth. NASA plans to roll Discovery out to another launch pad after Columbia lifts off. Discovery must be launched with the sun-probing Ulysses satellite between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23 because of the alignment of Earth, the sun and Jupiter, whose gravitational field will slingshot Ulysses back to the sun. Otherwise, the $750 million mission must be delayed 13 months. Columbia was supposed to have gone up May 30, but the launch was called off because of leaks detected during fueling. A month later, hydrogen also was found to be escaping from Atlantis, prompting NASA to ground all three shuttles. NASA replaced Columbia's leaky plumbing. Atlantis' secret Pentagon mission has been rescheduled for November. Columbia's flight will be the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. Four astronomers on board will operate the Astro observatory, which will remain on board. Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope will probe some of the hottest objects in the universe. The approximately 150 targets include a supernova and Comet Levy, which is making its first pass through the solar system in recorded time. Scientists have had to revise Astro's observing schedule numerous times because of the delays. The mission originally was scheduled for March 1986 but was postponed after the Challenger disaster.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq A Formidable Foe, But US Confident Of Two-Generation Tank Weaponry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pentagon ground rules for covering US military operations prohibit the disclosure of the location or strength of U.S. forces. ^By JOHN KING
DOC.TEXT: A desert tank war with Iraq would provide a formidable test of an American ground war strategy that relies on a combination of Vietnam-era weapons and costly, ultra-modern systems never tested in combat. Should the desert standoff come to blows, U.S. military planners believe the American forces would win but only after a bloody fight. It is also a fight they would rather wage at night. Until Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the U.S. military had never trained with Iraq as its mock opponent. But the weapons and tactics of Iraq would not be unfamiliar _ its tanks are Soviet-made and it has adopted the Soviet tactic of massing huge numbers of tanks and supporting them with heavy artillery. ``We've trained since the beginning of the Cold War for this fight,'' an Army source said recently. ``The only difference now is we'd fight it in the Saudi Arabia instead of Germany, against Iraq and not the Russians.'' Iraq's strengths are its sheer numbers _ roughly 5,500 tanks _ its familiarity with the terrain and experience from eight years of war with Iran. The United States, outnumbered on the ground, is said to have superior missiles, air power, and ground-level sighting, guidance and weapons systems. The troops and weapons that make up the United States' tank war arsenal have been arriving gradually since the U.S. deployment began three weeks ago but much of the force is now in place. The Army's heavy M-1 tanks began arriving Tuesday and are being sent into the northeastern desert, where several anti-tank units already are in place. In a tank war with Iraq, the United States would seek to counter Iraq's greater numbers with a massive air assault, first targeting Iraqi ground-to-air missile systems, according to dozens of commanders, pilots and tank crews interviewed over the past two weeks. Iraq has modern, Soviet-made anti-aircraft systems, but U.S. planners are confident they could be significantly damaged by American, British and Saudi planes. The next phase in the air, according to the interviews, would involve the Air Force's A-10 tank killer jets and the premiere American anti-tank weapon, the new AH-64 Apache attack helicopter. The A-10 flys as slowly as 100 knots, carries missiles and a 30mm seven-barrel cannon. It is vulnerable to enemy fire but has several redundant systems to keep it flying after hits and also a titanium tub around the cockpit to protect the pilot during what one A-10 commander, Col. Sandy Sharpe, refers to as ``air to mud'' warfare. The Apache carries up to 16 Hellfire laser-guided missiles, like its carrier untested in combat but said to be highly accurate. It also has two 19-rocket pods and an anti-tank gattling gun. ``The Hellfire will destroy any known armor in the world,'' said Lt. Col. Don Vinson, an Apache pilot and commander. Apache's are considered an ideal tank killer at night, when they can sit back well beyond Iraqi range and fire missiles. ``They can't see us, but I can see and kill them,'' said Armt Lt. Col. Dick Cody. Army and Marine Cobras, Vietnam-era choppers that have been refitted with new weapons and electronics, also could be called into any large tank war. Cobras are armed with Tow missiles and gattling guns. The major cog in the ground strategy, the 24th Infantry (Mechanized) Division, began rolling its M-1 tanks northward into the desert on Tuesday. In an all-out battle, the untested M-1s and their 105mm cannons would be riding into the desert accompanied by Bradley armored infantry carriers, which has a 25mm gun and slots through which passengers can fire their M-16s. Despite their size _ an M-1 weighs 60 tons _ the tanks can travel at speeds of up to 45 mph or more. The other tanks in the U.S. arsenal, the M-60As belonging to the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade and the M-551 Sheridans deployed with the 82nd Airborne Division, both date back to Vietman. The Sheridans, which carry Shillelagh missiles, saw combat duty then and when dropped into Panama during the December U.S. invasion. The M-60s date back to Vietnam, but never have been tested in combat. Iraq's huge tank army is led by modern Soviet-made T-72s, which are considered by many experts a rival to the Ameican M-1. ``Make no mistake about it _ they've got more tanks than us and they've got some damn good tanks,'' a U.S. tank commander said. U.S. military planners are counting on their superior air power. The triple-digit heat and terrain of the Saudi desert would be a factor in any tank fight. There are some high dunes but for the most part it would be difficult for any great number of tanks to hide. ``Tow heaven'' responded one weapons specialist when asked about the desert. ``We'll seem them coming for miles.'' The ships carrying U.S tanks were asked to bring additional filters for the M-1s, which need to be cleaned frequently. And higher viscosity oil was put on supply lists because of the heat's wear and tear on the equipment. ``It will make it a lot tougher out there in the heat,'' said Sgt. Ronald Ruff of Hinesville, Ga. ``But when you're cleaning or changing a filter or something in combat you learn to speed up a little.''

DOC.HEAD: Furlough Warnings Sent to FBI Agents, Other Justice Workers
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents, federal prosecutors, prison guards and other Justice Department crime fighters are being told they could be furloughed if Congress and the White House don't agree on a budget. The Justice Department is notifying most of its 80,000 employees that they could be furloughed up to 22 days in the coming fiscal year if automatic spending cuts mandated by the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law take effect Oct. 1. The Office of Management and Budget has ordered a 32.4 percent spending cut from the government's operating budget in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, if lawmakers and the Bush administration fail to agree on other ways of reducing the budget deficit. Officials at various federal law enforcement agencies said the furloughs could make operating extremely difficult. Running the nation's federal prisons on a reduced staff would be ``incredibly challenging _ that's a euphemism,'' said Douglas Lansing, assistant director of the Bureau of Prisons. ``We don't think we could do it.'' The furloughs could affect all 9,800 FBI agents, including those assigned to investigate foreign spies, said FBI spokesman Carlos H. Fernandez. No decision has been made whether to furlough agents working on undercover investigations, he said. ``We will try to do our duty as best we can, but to say if won't affect operations would be a mistake,'' Fernandez said. Furloughs at the U.S. Marshals Service ``would have a serious effect, probably a drastic effect'' on the agency's ability to chase fugitives, transport prisoners and seize assets from accused criminals, said spokesman Bill Dempsey. ``We would continue the vital life-or-death functions of providing security for the federal judges all over the country and protecting government witnesses,'' but the other activities would have to be curtailed, he said. The furloughs of 3,800 federal prosecutors in 94 U.S. attorneys offices will have to be juggled to accommodate trial schedules, officials said. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, FBI Director William Sessions and other presidential appointees, such as assistant attorneys general, would not be affected. The notices sent to employees this week raised the possibility of additional layoffs if Congress and the White House don't reach agreement. A memo sent to employees of the Justice Department's management division said the unit would have to lay off each employee 70 days during fiscal 1991 if the automatic spending cuts are not restored. The Bureau of Prisons plans to furlough each of its 18,500 employees for 3{ days per two-week pay period, Lansing said. Similar arrangements are being made at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which employs 4,082 Border Patrol agents and 1,400 investigators. The Drug Enforcement Administration has no plans to furlough any of its 3,000 agents but will stop paying overtime, cut out all non-essential travel and purchases and stop hiring new employees, said spokesman Bill Ruzzamenti.

DOC.HEAD: Following Nicotine Protests, Moscow to Begin Rationing Smokes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT that people to get five packs a month, sted 15. Pickup 4th graf `However, nicotine...'
DOC.TEXT: Facing a tobacco shortage that has produced street protests and rioting in some cities, Moscow's City Council decided Tuesday to ration cigarettes starting Sept. 1. When Moscow residents pick up their monthly coupons for sugar, which is already rationed, they will also get coupons for five packs of cigarettes per person, the newspaper Vechernaya Moskva said. That means Muscovites officially will be limited to just over one pack a week _ not nearly enough to satisfy the cravings of many Soviets, a nation of chain-smokers. However, nicotine addicts with money will be able to buy more cigarettes on the thriving black market, where a medium-quality brand that officially sells for 30 kopeks (about 50 cents) a pack goes for up to $8. Higher-quality foreign cigarettes fetch up to $32 per pack. Tobacco coupons apparently will be issued in the same indiscriminate manner as sugar coupons, which means that every resident _ including children and non-smokers _ will get the same amount. People who don't use their coupons will be able to give them to friends, sell them on the black market or trade them officially the following month for an extra 4.4 pounds of sugar. The cigarette shortage, which began in early summer and accelerated this month, has forced Muscovites to queue up for hours _ even in driving rain _ at tobacco kiosks. Irate smokers have blocked traffic in Moscow's central Revolution Square, and street protests also have been reported in Leningrad, Gorky and Yaroslavl. Young people demanding more tobacco, food and alcohol rioted Friday in the Siberian city of Chelyabinsk, smashing shop windows and throwing gasoline bombs, according to the Soviet news agency Tass. Authorities have announced price increases that will triple the official cost of most cigarette brands starting next month, but Moscow is believed to be the first city to resort to rationing tobacco. Official spokesmen have blamed the shortage on factory breakdowns, hoarding by black marketeers and the near-depletion of the nation's reserves of foreign currency, which has forced the Soviet Union to buy 5 billion fewer cigarettes from Bulgaria this year than it did last year. The shortage was predicted months in advance by an American expert, Laura R. Davis. In a March report for the U.S. Agriculture Department, she said demand for tobacco was rising in the Soviet Union, which now has an estimated 70 million smokers, and harvests were not keeping pace. She predicted that this year's Soviet tobacco crop would be only 215,000 tons, unchanged from 1989 and down about one-third from the peak of 350,000 tons in 1985. Although the Soviet Union is the world's third largest tobacco grower, topped only by the United States and China, it imported about 55 billion cigarettes in 1988, with more than 95 percent coming from Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Yancy's Death Toll Reaches 216
DOC.TEXT: The death toll from typhoon Yancy, which lashed China's southern coast last week, has climbed to 216, an official newspaper said today. The paper, the China Daily, said latest reports reaching Beijing also indicated that 59 were missing in the wake of the typhoon. It said direct economic losses caused by the typhoon were estimated at $170 million. The report did not give a breakdown by region. Earlier reports said 111 people had died in Fujian province, many of them crushed by buildings that collapsed under torrential rains. The reports said the typhoon slammed into the province's coast three times in 24 hours last week. The region had already been hit by four destructive typhoons in the past two months.

DOC.HEAD: Rise in Heart Troubles Since Crisis Began
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis appears to be taking a toll on some weak-hearted Israelis. Shahal, a private company that operates a 24-hour telephone emergency service for Israelis suffering from heart conditions, on Tuesday reported a 20 percent increase in the number of calls since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``When subscribers call Shahal we don't ask them their political opinion on the situation, but it is difficult to give another reason to what is happening,'' said Erez Alroy, deputy head of the company, which has more than 15,000 subscribers in the Tel Aviv and Haifa areas. ``We see an apparent link between the situation and the anxiety. Part of their release of tension is by calling the hotline,'' Alroy said. He said Shahal has received 170 calls compared to the average of 140 daily and that intensive care units have been sent out 25 times a day as compared to the usual 20. He could not say how many people had suffered heart attacks but noted that 70 percent of those treated by intensive care units were taken to hospitals, an increase of 10 percent.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with varying official counts of the dead, more expected, picks up 16th graf of a0751, `Commonwealth Edison...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CX6,7; LaserColor CX106. LaserGraphic.
DOC.TEXT: Tornadoes ripped through several northern Illinois towns Tuesday, blowing residents out of apartment buildings and leveling at least 100 homes and a school. As many as 26 were reported dead and the death toll was expected to rise. Local hospitals said at least 290 people were being treated for storm-caused injuries. The tornadoes touched down at least four times just after 3:30 p.m. CDT along a seven-mile southwesterly path from the community of Plainfield to Joliet, about 40 miles southwest of Chicago, Illinois State Police said. In Crest Hill, on the outskirts of Joliet, eight people were killed when the twister flattened an apartment complex, said Lockport Fire Chief Dave Martis. Four bodies, including that of a 4-month old baby, were lying in a cornfield next to the complex, and four others were pulled from the collapsed buildings and a car. ``When the storm went through, some of the buildings disintegrated,'' Martis said. ``High winds blew some of the people into the corn field.'' Guy Allton, 16, watched the storm from his house near Plainfield High School. ``We went outside, and there was picnic tables flying past our faces and stuff,'' Allton said. Afterward he helped pull people from nearby houses, including two badly hurt babies. ``Everything was messed up,'' Allton said. ``Lots and lots of people hurt.'' Officials' counts of the dead varied from 20 to 26, and some said they expected to find more bodies when searching resumed Wednesday. Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Agency spokesman Lynn Bobo said late Tuesday that 26 people were killed. The Will County coroner said 20 bodies had been brought to a central morgue as of 11:45 p.m. CDT. Others might be in transit, but some may have been counted twice, said coroner Duane Krueger. Five people died in Plainfield, said John Watson, ambulance services chief for the Plainfield Fire Department. Four people were killed in Joliet, including three in a subdivision under construction, said Police Chief Dennis Nowicki. ``I'm not confident the death toll won't rise,'' said Will County Executive Charles Adelman, noting that it wasn't known how many people were inside the heavily damaged Plainfield High School. There were several arrests for looting, Adelman said. It wasn't immediately clear where the others of the 23 were found. The National Guard was called out Tuesday evening to help state police prevent looting and control crowds in the area, said Ms. Bobo, the emergency services spokeswoman. Commonwealth Edison spokesman John Hogan reported 17,000 customers without power in the area hit by the storms. Judi Mack, a spokeswoman for St. Joseph Hospital in Joliet, said the hospital had received 157 storm victims. Only 25 were admitted with injuries ranging from minor to severe, she said. Thirty-five people were taken to Silver Cross Hospital, where they were in serious to fair condition, said spokeswoman Susan Larson. Several other hospitals also reported treating storm victims. Plainfield High School was destroyed and some teachers and students were injured, said Steve Schernerhorn, who with other teachers and student athletes crouched in the halls as the roof was blown off. ``We had some very short warnings. We immediately took cover,'' he said in a telephone interview. He said about 25 houses near the school were destroyed. Dozens of athletes were in the gym shortly before the tornado hit, but coaches moved them to another part of the school just before the gym roof collapsed onto the floor. Principal Jim Waldorf said as many as 175 people were in the school at the time of the storm, and a number of them suffered minor injuries. Teacher Mike Salisburg said some cars in the school parking lot were thrown as far as several hundred yards. Major damage was also reported at St. Mary's Elementary School nearby. Eric Curtis, 24, who lives a half-mile northwest of the high school, said he was at home when the twister hit. ``I felt real bad pressure in my head,'' Curtis said. ``I saw my dad running toward the house.'' The Curtis house suffered only minor damage, but others in the neighborhood were wrecked. Michael Hejka, 28, arrived at his friend's house five minutes before the tornado hit. ``I saw trees bending, and I said to my buddy, `It's a tornado!''' Hejka said. ``I said, `Jump into the bathtub.' He jumped in, and I jumped in right on top of him. The whole house lifted up, and then came down.'' Phone lines into the area were jammed; many were reported down. At least nine emergency shelters were set up by local disaster agencies and the Red Cross. The Red Cross was supplying clothing, toiletries and food. Will County is part of a frequently hit ``tornado alley,'' the National Weather Service said. A tornado hit Plainfield Township in April 1984, injuring six people and demolishing 14 homes. In June 1976, a twister hit Lemont, 10 miles northeast of Plainfield, killing three people and injuring as many as 40. That tornado damaged 375 houses and businesses. Commonwealth Edison spokesman John Hogan reported 17,000 customers without power in the area hit by the storms. State Police spokesman Robert Fletcher said at least 50 houses were leveled, about 30 of them north of Plainfield and 20 or 30 near the Louis Joliet Mall just outside Joliet. Other State Police officials reported 15 to 20 houses damaged in unincorporated areas of Will County. Watson, of the Plainfield Fire Department, said emergency workers found 40 homes flattened southeast of the city. At least six people were injured in pileups on Interstate 55 caused by violent winds, said State Police Lt. Clifford Mann. The interstate at U.S. 30 was down to one lane of traffic because of a semi tractor-trailer rig blown over, he said. Crops were flattened west and north of Joliet. Many roads were blocked by trees, and toppled electric towers and downed lines sparked fires in Joliet, Mezera said. In Plainfield, a dumpster was lodged in the upper branches of a tall tree, an empty dump truck was on its side and an empty van was found after it fell off a bridge into the DuPage River. Seachers were combing the banks of the debris-clogged stream.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Aims for Restraint Despite Worries Over Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Israel is trying to maintain a restrained stance on the Persian Gulf crisis despite growing fears its own interests will be undermined if Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein is not toppled. A low-key posture is not easy for Israel, and strong rhetoric keeps cropping up from military analysts _ often voicing leaks from the government _ and from officials themselves, sometimes followed by hasty reversals. The dilemma for Israel is that it is the United States' best-armed and closest ally in the Middle East but has been sidelined in this crisis by political necessity. Washington does not want its friendship with the Jewish state to undermine the coalition of moderate Arab states it has brought together in response to Saddam's Aug. 2 lightning seizure of Kuwait. Stuck on the sidelines, Israelis are increasingly uneasy that diplomatic efforts to end the crisis and political maneuvering by Saddam will lead to a military stalemate. ``There is concern building here that somehow Saddam may get away with his aggression,'' Eytan Gilboa, a professor of international relations at Hebrew University, said Tuesday. ``That leaves us still facing his military machine.'' A similar view was expressed by the Hebrew daily Yediot Ahronot, which said in an editorial that ``A diplomatic compromise for the Kuwait crisis ... would mean that we would remain here alone with Saddam and his mad ambitions, only four minutes away from his missile launchers and chemical bombs.'' Saddam, an implacable foe of Israel, has a million-man army and has threatened to turn his chemical weapons against the Jewish state. He also has championed the goal of Palestinians to form an independent state in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, sparking pro-Saddam rallies in the territories and neighboring Jordan. Fear of Iraq's potential military menace prompted reserve army Gen. Avigdor Ben-Gal, a hero in the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, to advise that the United States turn its ``tactical nuclear weapons against Iraq.'' Ben-Gal told Israel radio: ``I think the Americans made a mistake by not acting quickly and taking chances. ... Those who want to take minimum risks could find themselves in a situation where they cannot act even though they are ready.'' Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has tried to keep the lid on, saying that Israel has no intention of getting involved with Iraq unless it is attacked. He reacted angrily on Tuesday to allegations in U.S. publications that Israel was using its alliance with President Bush to war-monger. ``Who are we to push the biggest superpower in the world?'' Shamir told a Parliament hearing. ``We are not pushing the United States to any war.'' Still, it was Shamir himself who caused a storm last week when he hinted that a pre-emptive Israeli strike against Iraq was possible. He told a gathering of American Jewish donors that ``In the circumstances, our major task is to prevent war, or to pre-empt it and if, heaven forbid, these two fail, and there is no alternative, we have to win quickly and decisively.'' Under questioning from reporters, Shamir quickly qualified his statement and said Israel's aim was ``to prevent any military involvement of our country.'' Defense Minister Moshe Arens, too, has retracted hawkish statements. On Monday, Arens told Israel television that Israel would not be pleased by a solution that left Saddam in power. On Tuesday, standing before two U.S.-made F-15 jets during an air base news conference, he denied he called for Saddam's ouster. ``We're not involved in managing this crisis and we're not setting the conditions for how to handle it,'' Arens said. Yet the question of whether Israel is or should advise the United States to go to war is being widely discussed by Israelis. Mordechai Gur, a former army chief of staff, told state television Tuesday that Israeli officials should be careful of what they say because some Americans consider their remarks provocative. ``If we would not go to war, let us not send other children to war and let us not bereave other families,'' Gur said. ``It's their right to try to end the crisis by political means.'' The Israeli government has already stated its own ``red lines'' for war _ a direct strike or entry by Iraqi forces into neighboring Jordan, which serves as a buffer between Israel and Sadddam's army. Israel, America's largest aid recipient at $3 billion annually, also made it clear that it is concerned with the advanced American weaponry being supplied to Saudi Arabia and other Arab states confronting Iraq. ``Israel is against the sale of arms to countries which refuse to enter the peace process with Israel,'' said a Foreign Ministry official, who insisted on anonymity. ``Israel wants to remind (the United States) of the necessity of preserving a qualitative edge.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Eileen Alt Powell has been an AP correspondent in Israel for the past two years.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Scowcroft, Cheney, Powell Form New Inner Circle
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has altered the dynamics of President Bush's inner circle, bringing three top advisers to the forefront and diminishing the role of others. Bush's key advisers of the gulf crisis are National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, Defense Secretary Richard Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. These are the three men with whom Bush consults over and over each day as he monitors the Iraqi stalemate _ whether vacationing here at his oceanfront home or on forays back to Washington. All three are old Washington hands with whom Bush worked in previous administrations _ a familiar pattern for the president. Scowcroft is a constant golfing and fishing companion _ the one aide Bush sees the most frequently at work and at play. And, although Scowcroft has told friends he sometimes has trouble keeping track of the names of the first family's multitude of grandchildren, insiders says he has in recent months evolved into almost an auxiliary member of Bush's family _ and possibly his most trusted adviser. By contrast, Chief of Staff John Sununu, who in other times is constantly at Bush's side, has faded into the background in recent days. Sununu's strong suit has always been domestic policy, not foreign or military affairs. Sununu's role in the current military and diplomatic crisis has been so minor that his presence wasn't even needed this week when Bush returned to Washington for two and a half days. He's heading a delegation of White House officials who are in Moscow helping show Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev how to administer an executive office. Early in Bush's administration, there was speculation that Scowcroft, a soft-spoken retired Air Force general who was President Ford's top national security aide in the 1970s while Bush was CIA chief, was unhappy with his job and wanted out. The speculation went that Scowcroft felt a diminished role in light of the fact that Bush himself was deeply interested in foreign policy and had made one of his oldest and best friends, James A. Baker III, his secretary of state. However, a Scowcroft departure never came to pass. And today, he has evolved into an adviser many White House officials suggest is closer to the president, in some ways, than even Baker. Oddly, Baker's role over the past few weeks in the Persian Gulf crisis has been largely behind-the-scenes. Until Tuesday, Baker had been on a vacation of his own in Wyoming. Administration officials said Baker worked privately to rally support in the United Nations after the United States called for a full blockade of Iraqi ports, and to coordinate U.S. actions with the Soviet Union. But otherwise, his profile has been a low one _ while Scowcroft more and more was the official that the White House selected to appear on television talk shows to elaborate on gulf policy. Baker cut short his Wyoming vacation to meet with the president at the White House on Tuesday. ``He (Baker) is back and you can believe he's not going anywhere now,'' said one administration official. Bush also had a previous working relationship with Cheney and Powell. Cheney was former President Ford's chief of staff while Bush was CIA chief. Powell was former President Reagan's national security adviser when Bush was vice president. The two talked almost daily. Scowcroft ``bridges both worlds,'' serving as an intermediary between Powell and Cheney, said one key aide. While Bush talks with Baker on the phone _ sometimes several times a day _ he's constantly with Scowcroft. The national security adviser has an office close to the Oval Office in the White House, and the two drop in on one another frequently. Scowcroft's emerging high profile has much to do with the fact that the U.S. operation in the gulf is primarily a military one. But aides say that it also reflects Bush's trust in him. ``Over the past few months, there's a special affinity that's developed between the president and Brent,'' said a White House aide who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``Both share the same kind of philosophy. And over the past year or so, the relationship has developed a lot closer.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Expelled Iraqi Diplomats Feverishly Packing to Meet Deadline
With PM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Judging by the nervous commotion inside the Iraqi Embassy, the 36 diplomatic employees and their families ordered to leave the country probably won't be ready to move until close to the Thursday deadline. Inside the orange-brick embassy Tuesday, about a dozen Arabic-speaking men gestured excitedly, shuttling in and out of several rooms. In the reception area, a small knot of people watched an Iraqi television broadcast relayed by CNN. The sparsely furnished room was dominated by two huge portraits of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein: one in military uniform with a beret, the other in a blue suit. There were no apparent signs of papers or other effects being moved at the embassy Tuesday evening. Earlier in the day, a request to interview some of the departing diplomats was denied. Security at the embassy appeared lax. An Associated Press reporter entered the front door, rang the buzzer next to the inner locked door and was let in without identifying herself. A mailman went in with an Express Mail package from California. For the 36 embassy personnel and their families who were ordered to leave, the Persian Gulf crisis has been reduced to one overwhelming imperative: packing up, and fast. ``It's a hell of a problem now,'' said Ahmad Alkiassiy, an Iraqi consultant helping the envoys with the move. ``Seventy-two hours, it's just impossible.'' On Monday afternoon, a U.S. diplomatic message was delivered to Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat, serving notice that the 36 must be gone from the United States within 72 hours. The move was in retaliation for a series of Iraqi actions, especially the ``illegal order'' for the closure of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. The 19 Iraqis permitted to remain at the embassy, including Al-Mashat, reflect the number of Americans still working at the U.S. embassies in Iraq and Kuwait. For the diplomats ordered to leave, the U.S. message meant they had to feverishly stuff their belongings into boxes. Alkiassiy said the embassy had to rent three large trucks to haul between 200 and 300 boxes of possessions to New York for shipment to Iraq. The abrupt move is taking an emotional toll on some of the diplomats, said Alkiassiy, an Iraqi citizen who lives in Washington and describes himself as a friend of the embassy trying to help out. ``Some of them are sad because they're used to it here,'' he said. Outside the embassy, an officer in the Secret Service's Uniformed Division stood on the sidewalk in the 90-degree heat, chatting with a city policeman. ``At least it's not as hot as Saudi Arabia,'' the Secret Service officer quipped to a reporter. About a dozen photographers and television cameramen maintained a vigil. They tensed at the slightest movement, snapping to each time someone emerged from the embassy. It seemed they might have a long wait to see a caravan of departing diplomats. The disorganized atmosphere at the embassy gave the impression that the complicated move would come at the last minute, close to the deadline. ``It's hell getting out, believe me,'' Alkiassiy said.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Adds 106 Sites to Cleanup List
With PM-Superfund-List
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency says it has added 106 hazardous waste sites, including 23 federal government facilities, to its national priority cleanup list. Tuesday's action brings the total number of sites on the list to 1,187, including 116 federal facilities, mostly Defense Department installations. Another 20 sites _ all non-federal _ have been proposed for listing, with decisions expected within a few months, the agency said. Placement on the list makes non-federal sites eligible for cleanup aid under the federal Superfund law.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,894.79, down 815.97 points, or 3.17 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Altovise Davis, widow of Sammy Davis Jr., says there is no truth to rumors circulating in Hollywood that the entertainer died a pauper. British and American tabloids have said Mrs. Davis and her 14-year-old son, Manny, were to be evicted from their home by the Internal Revenue Service. ``If you were to believe the alternative press, the IRS is sweeping down on her (and) Altovise is emotionally very disturbed,'' her lawyer, Visilios Choulos, said at a news conference Tuesday. ``All of those things are totally untrue.'' Mrs. Davis did not attend the news conference. Choulos estimated the Davis estate, consisting of a mansion, antique guns, books and jewelry, is worth $6 million to $8 million. David died of throat cancer May 16.

Bob Hope says if asked he'd take a road show to Saudi Arabia to perform for soldiers stationed there. The 87-year-old comic, who has entertained American troops around the world since World War II, also said at the South Dakota State Fair on Tuesday he hopes the Persian Gulf crisis is over soon. ``We've sent too many wonderful men over there. I don't want to see any of them hurt,'' he said. Hope was honored at the fair with a bronze statuette.

Oscar-winning actress Diane Keaton will debut as a prime-time TV director in an episode of ABC's ``China Beach.'' The network Tuesday said Keaton will oversee an installment about the return home from Vietnam of nurse Colleen McMurphy, the show's lead character. Keaton will report to the set for eight days of work on Sept. 5. In the episode, McMurphy, played by Emmy-winning actress Dana Delany, comes home to Kansas after the war and grapples with civilian life and a drinking problem. Keaton's directing credits include the feature film ``Heaven'' in 1987, a music video and a CBS Schoolbreak Special. The actress, who has appeared in a number of Woody Allen films as well as ``Looking for Mr. Goodbar'' and ``The Godfather,'' won the Academy Award for best actress in 1977 for Allen's ``Annie Hall.'' Her newest film, ``The Lemon Sisters,'' opens Friday.

Fans at a Toto concert over the weekend were infuriated when they discovered the band was not the Grammy-winning group whose hits included ``Rosanna'' and ``Africa.'' Singer Bobby Kimball, who left the group in 1984, and a few other musicians performed at The Starry Night club, said Ellen Lynch, a spokeswoman for Toto's management company. Toto currently features guitarist Steve Lukather, brothers Jeff and Steve Porcaro and David Paich. All are original members. Lynch said Monday that Kimball has used the band's name before. ``We've gotten reports all over the country, from Florida and now the Northwest and Europe,'' Lynch said. ``As far as I know, he doesn't own any rights to the name. It's now become a huge legal matter.'' Kimball's whereabouts were not immediately known. Club owner Larry Hurwitz said he will offer refunds or tickets for another show to those at Saturday's performance. ``I feel like I was slightly deceived by Kimball and his manager,'' Hurwitz said. ``We had 900-plus people and within the first three songs we had 100 people leave.''

Elizabeth Dillenbeck, a 68-year-old amateur poet from Kansas, is the new World of Poetry Laureate. Eleven judges chose her ``Sea Wind, South Wind'' over several thousand entries during the organization's sixth annual convention. Dillenbeck, of Pratt, Kan., received a prize of $15,000. The organization claims 1.4 million poets. The convention attracted more than 2,500 poets from around the world.

Prince's new movie, ``Graffiti Bridge,'' opens at theaters Nov. 9, less than one year after production began. ``We did the film as quickly as we did because there was the need for a story on faith in these troubled times,'' Prince publicist Jill Willis quoted the rock star as saying. Filming took place in 36 days and was completed two days ahead of schedule, she said. The musical's soundtrack was released last week. Prince recently completed the European leg of a tour and is headed for Japan.

Chilean author Jose Donoso, a member of Latin America's literary ``boom'' generation, has won the National Literature Prize. A seven-member jury unanimously awarded the distinction to the author of such best sellers as ``The Obscene Bird of the Night'' and ``This Sunday.'' Donoso, 64, came to international prominence along with Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel Garcia Marquez of Colombia, Julio Cortazar of Argentina and Peruvian Mario Vargas Llosa beginning in the 1960s. He returned to Chile in 1986 after living for two decades in Spain, Britain and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Strict Moslem Society Separates GIs From Saudi Women
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A random sampling of Saudi female opinion indicates it's unlikely GIs will be taking home ``Desert Shield'' brides: they'd need permission from Saudi parents and the government first. And that assumes an American would ever meet a Saudi woman in this regulated society where females usually cover their bodies, heads and faces in black, don't drive or drink, never go to nightspots and often accept arranged marriages. Oh yes, and the groom would have to be Moslem. Three women _ all professional, full-time workers who have studied abroad _ said in interviews Tuesday that they accept the strictures on their conduct as part of their culture and religion. ``You might think that we are not free, but the definition of freedom is different,'' said Nahed Al-Omari, 26, a computer specialist. The women, all of whom were older than the typical unmarried Saudi, live with their parents or relatives. Nahed, dressed in Western clothes and spiked heels under her abaya, said she would like more freedom _ particularly to drive and travel _ but was confident the rules would loosen up in the future. The women in this male-dominated society did not think the presence of thousands of American soldiers of both sexes _ the Desert Shield defense against Iraqi forces in neighboring Kuwait _ would spark broad cultural changes. ``Will it have an impact on my life? No,'' said Soulafa Al-Nasser, 22, a management trainee. The women said they would not dare mount a public protest against the customs for fear it would bring shame on their families. ``You could bring the whole family down with you,'' Soulafa said. Despite the restricted environment, the women said they resented the image of all Saudi females as appendages of their men. ``Most Saudi females are educated,'' said Nahed. ``Education is becoming essential for all women.'' As in the United States, many women continue working after they have married and had children, the women said. They frequently keep their own names and have their own bank accounts. Finding a husband is the goal of most women, they said, even though they might have to share the man with his other wives. The Moslem faith allows men to have four wives. But the women doubted strongly they would ever marry an American. Mixed marriages _ for men and women _ require approval of the minister of interior. But Laila Al-Kholari, a 30-year-old librarian, said she and her friends might get special treatment because of their age. Though their culture is alien to most Americans, the women said there are benefits to their way of life. Their families were close-knit, and men viewed their women as ``precious,'' said Laila. ``If you could take the best of our culture and the best of yours, you would have the perfect woman,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: `Butler in a Box,' Spy Stuff at Security Expo
DOC.TEXT: Burglars, spies and cheating spouses, beware! They're plotting your doom at Security Expo. Some 350 purveyors are showing off their security devices through Thursday to a projected 9,000 customers at the trade show, including corporate security directors, law enforcers and home security installers. Homeowners are the marketing target of Mastervoice of Los Alamitos, Calif. The company's Butler in a Box offers security and a whole lot more. ``As you wish!'' ``Right away!'' and ``Yes, Master,'' responds this model of good, old-fashioned electronic servitude, dubbed Alexander by sales and marketing administrator Linda Zazueta. Tell Alexander it's ``party time'' and he'll turn on the porch lights, hot tub and CD player. Remind him it's ``bedtime'' and he'll lock up and shut off the lights _ even let the cat out, if there's an electronic pet door. In the morning, he'll start the coffee and turn on the sprinklers. If burglars enter the house, Alexander asks to ``hear'' their voices. They don't sound familiar, an alarm goes off. The butler can be programmed to answer to any name _ and in a variety of voices. Whimsical homeowners may have their orders taken by a cowboy or wicked witch. It can understand any language and recognize commands from up to four people. The system, which costs about $5,000 installed, is also a boon to handicapped people, said Zazueta. About 6,000 to 7,000 were sold worldwide last year, she said. Other customers saw how Surveillance Technology Group, of London, Paris and Rye, N.Y., hides a ``micro-miniature'' camera lens in a car or TV antenna, allowing ``totally discreet, undercover photography and videotaping of virtually anyone or anything.'' Carol Products Co. of Ocean, N.J., puts its closed-circuit cameras inside exit signs, radios, smoke alarms and clocks. ``Please allow one of Carol's video design experts to assist you in choosing the hidden camera and accessories that best serve your surveillance needs,'' beckons Carol's glossy, silver-and-lavender catalog. Then there's Communication Control Systems' Security Blanket, a $200 ultra-bright flashlight ``strong enough to immobilize and allow you time to escape, yet gentle enough to cause only temporary blindness,'' its literature says. The light is actually a small-ticket item for CCS. The Port Chester, N.Y., company sells to law enforcers, security firms, consumers and corporate users who need bulletproof cars or ``discreet recording devices'' hidden in the lid of a leather briefcase. The company's display case contained a 6-inch plastic device labeled Voice Stress Analyzer. Translation: lie detector. ``It's meant to be used covertly,'' mostly by corporate types, said CCS' Gregg Graison. But, then again, it might fit handily into a pocket or purse at a singles bar. International Electronics Inc. offered a door unlocker that can record the voices of up to 500 people. It costs $1,200 to $1,400 installed. Enter an ID number, then speak. If it recognizes the voice, it will open the door. But don't tell it to ``Open, Sesame.'' Commands must be three or four syllables. Robert Fuller and Harold Patrick were selling EyeDentify. The device won't unlock the door unless it recognizes the blood vessels in the back of the user's eye. Its memory holds up to 1,200 eye patterns; everyone's is different. The company has installed about 500 units worldwide in six years _ including at the Defense Ministry in Kuwait, said Patrick. The list price is $4,995 plus installation.

DOC.HEAD: Choked-Up Judge OKs Exhumation of Proposed Saint's Body
DOC.TEXT: A judge nearly wept as she gave the Roman Catholic Church permission to exhume the remains of a former Haitian slave who has been proposed for canonization as the first black American saint. Acting state Supreme Court Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob on Tuesday granted the request from the Archdiocese of New York to exhume Pierre Toussaint's body for identification by a pathologist and church officials. ``It is rare that this court has an opportunity to participate in such a historic event, if only tangentially,'' the judge said. Church records show Toussaint, who died a free man in 1853 at 87, was buried at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral. Court papers referred to him as ``a model of charity'' who is considered the founder of Catholic Charities because he helped the needy for 66 years when no formal systems of assistance existed. Gangel-Jacob said that Toussaint had lived ``a long and apparently virtuous life,'' giving money to the poor and nursing the ill during the yellow fever plagues that swept New York City before antibiotics. ``In those times the only consolation may have been the miracles of faith and trust,'' the judge said, her voice breaking. ``Indeed, for the thousands of victims of the scourge of AIDS, Alzheimer's disease, melanoma and other currently incurable diseases, the same may be true today.'' Monsignor Robert O'Connell said the church is investigating two miracles attributed to Toussaint: a Haitian man's claim he was cured of lung and stomach cancer by praying to Toussaint, and a Miami woman's claim he cured her breast cancer. The Congregation for the Causes of Saints in Rome, which is responsible for canonization, will hold investigations and a hearing that could take years, O'Connell said. Toussaint was born into slavery in Haiti in 1766. At 21, he was brought to New York by a Frenchman and his family. After the Frenchman's death, the master's family fell into poverty. Toussaint secretly supported them for 20 years until the widow remarried and repaid him by arranging for his freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall, Dollar Stronger on Interest Rate Speculation
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped sharply Wednesday after three consecutive trading days of increases. The dollar closed higher. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 815.97 points, or 3.17 percent, to close at 24,894.79. The dollar closed at 144.35 yen, up 1.15 yen from Tuesday's close of 143.20 yen. After opening at 143.10 yen, the currency ranged between 142.98 yen and 144.45 yen. Securities dealers said the Nikkei index moved lower with local news reports Wednesday that the Bank of Japan has started discussing an official discount rate increase with the Finance Ministry. A spokesman for the central bank refused to comment on the reports. The Asahi Shimbun newspaper said the central bank is considering an increase in its key lending rate by a range of 0.75 to 1.0 percentage points to stem inflationary pressure because of rising oil prices caused by the Middle East crisis. The bank is expected to decide on the rate increase possibly by early next month. The discount rate, the lending rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks, stands at 5.25 percent, among the lowest of industrialized countries. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive to investors, but discourage stock investment. On the currency market, the dollar slipped in early trading on speculation about the interest hike but later the currency regained ground on a market rumor that the central bank did not plan to raise the discount rate, said Toru Umemoto, a dealer with Fuji Bank. North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $26.50 to $26.80 a barrel, compared with $26.68 dollars a barrel quoted in London late Tuesday. In bond markets, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slid to 82.18 points, down from Tuesday's finish of 82.68. The yield stood at 8.310 percent, up from 8.190 percent.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Transport on Saudi Mission Crashes, 11 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with 12 dead. Picks up 4th pvs, `The plane's ...'
DOC.TEXT: A huge Air Force plane ferrying equipment to U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf crashed on takeoff early Wednesday at Ramstein Air Base in West Germany, and officials said at least 12 people on board were killed. Air Force spokesman Doug Moore said the C-5 cargo plane, which had 17 military personnel aboard, was part of the round-the-clock deployment of U.S. troops and supplies to Saudi Arabia and the gulf to deter Iraqi aggression. He said 10 on board were killed. Air Force officials said later that one of the five people hospitalized had died of injuries and that they had found the body of one of two soldiers who had been unaccounted for. The plane's cargo included food, medical supplies and aircraft maintenance equipment, according to Moore. The cause of the crash was under investigation. Ramstein, the largest U.S. Air Force base in Europe, has been a stopover point for the steady stream of U.S. planes headed to and from the gulf. Another Air Force spokesman, Capt. Ed Worley, said the cargo plane, headed for Frankfurt's Rhein-Main base, crashed and burned after takeoff, one-quarter mile from the runway at 12:30 a.m. Wednesday. ``It crashed in a field right off the west end of the runway,'' Worley said by telephone from Ramstein, about 300 miles southwest of Berlin. ``We don't expect any civilian casualties.'' Worley said the C-5 belonged to the 60th Airlift Wing at Travis Air Force Base in California. He said it was flown by a crew from Kelly Air Force Base in Texas. At Kelly, base spokeswoman Maj. Donna Pastor said 10 reservists with the base's 433rd Military Airlift Wing were aboard the C-5 _ eight crew members and two maintenance personnel. She said the other seven on the plane were from other Air Force bases in the United States. The 433rd had not been called to active duty, but some reservists with the wing were voluntarily participating in Operation Desert Shield after arranging time off from their civilian jobs. The C-5 is the largest transport plane in the Air Force fleet and costs about $148 million. A military reference book, Jane's All the World's Aircraft, says the C-5 can carry up to about a quarter-million pounds of cargo. Under Desert Shield, begun after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the United States and other Western and Arab countries have sent troops, equipment and warships to the gulf region to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraq and to pressure Baghdad into withdrawing from Kuwait. The crash Wednesday occurred a day after the second anniversary of a mid-air crash during an air show at Ramstein that killed 70 people. On Aug. 28, 1988, three Italian planes crashed during maneuvers and flaming wreckage flew into the crowd of spectators.

DOC.HEAD: Need for Repeat Caesarean Deliveries Questioned
DOC.TEXT: The traditional view that women who have given birth by Caesarean section must always deliver that way is being challenged in a new survey. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists said it found in a survey of 2,213 physicians that 63 percent of women who attempt vaginal delivery after a previous Caesarean section succeed. Results of the study were released Tuesday. ``Strides certainly have been made'' to persuade women and their doctors that vaginal deliveries are safe, successful alternatives to repeat Caesareans, said Dr. Mary Jo O'Sullivan, secretary of the organization. However, O'Sullivan said, because about 42 percent of the patients surveyed chose to have another Caesarean, ``there is a need to further educate women'' about the benefits of vaginal deliveries. O'Sullivan, associate chairwoman of obstetrics at the University of Miami in Florida, said vaginal deliveries are less risky than Caesarean sections mainly because the latter is a surgical procedure. In addition, she said, vaginal births are less expensive and the patient spends less time in the hospital _ an average of $4,334 and two or three days compared with $7,186 and four or five days for a Caesarean, according to 1989 data from the Health Insurance Association of America. The rate of Caesarean deliveries rose from 5.5 percent of all U.S. births in 1970 to 24.7 percent in 1988. But O'Sullivan noted that the increase from 1986-87 and from 1987-88 was 0.3 percent, the smallest rise in five years.
DOC.HEAD: Federal Court Overturns Eyeglass Ruling
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court says the Federal Trade Commission lacked authority to prohibit states from banning shopping center stores that combine optometric practice with eyeglass sales. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Tuesday ruled that the FTC had ``acted beyond its statutory authority'' in its March 1989 ``Eyeglasses II'' ruling last year. ``An agency may not exercise authority over states as sovereigns unless that authority has been unambiguously granted to it,'' Circuit Judge James Buckley wrote in a ruling agreed to by Chief Judge Patricia Wald and Circuit Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg. FTC attorney Lawrence DeMille-Wagman said the commission had not yet decided whether to appeal. The FTC's ruling never took effect because the California State Board of Optometry and others sought and received a stay from the appellate court moments after the ruling would have become effective last Sept. 1, said California Deputy Attorney General Thomas S. Lasar. The states had imposed restrictions that the court said ``tended to discourage the `commercial practice' of optometry _ such as partnerships between optometrists and laymen, use of trade names, and chain operations combining the practice of optometry with the sale of eyeglasses in shopping centers _ in favor of `traditional optometric practice' typified by sole practitioners operating in professional office buildings under their own names.'' The FTC began investigating the restrictions in the mid-1970s and in findings published in 1980, ``indicated that these restrictions resulted in higher prices and reduced the quality of eye care available to the public,'' Buckley's opinion noted. Nine years later, the FTC adopted ``Eyeglasses II,'' even though FTC Chairman Daniel Oliver voted against it ``based on principles of federalism and his view that the FTC was without authority to promulgate it.''
DOC.HEAD: Senator Urges Contacts With Vietnam, Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The United States should consider reopening commerce with communist Vietnam and Cambodia as a prelude to United Nations-sponsored Cambodian elections, Sen. Richard Lugar says. ``We ought to sketch conditions for easing restrictions on commerce with Vietnam and Cambodia,'' said the Indiana Republican, who added that developmental loans for Vietnam could be a first step. Lugar, who spoke Tuesday with reporters, has just returned from a two-week, seven-nation trip to East Asia. In Vietnam, he met with foreign minister Nguyen Co Thach, who sought to highlight market reforms made in his country's economy. Lugar said he was assured by Thach that all Vietnamese forces have been withdrawn from Cambodia, where they had fought to push the feared Khmer Rouge from power. He said Vietnam supports current United Nations peace efforts and would accept any government installed in Cambodia through free and fair elections. He said also that Vietnam would agree to continued non-lethal U.S. aid to the non-communist resistance now fighting the Vietnamese-installed regime of Hun Sen in Phnom Penh.
