Lugar said he found a clear interest among American business interests in Thailand, Hong Kong and Seoul in reopening commerce with the two countries, and said other nations already are quietly doing so.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Voters in Oklahoma, Alaska Pick Gubernatorial Nominees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Stevens winning primary, PICKS UP 14th graf, `In Oklahoma ...'
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. David Boren trounced two challengers in Oklahoma's Democratic primary Tuesday, taking the first step towards re-election to a third term. In the Democratic primary for governor, the Oklahoma's House speaker and a businessman were locked in a tight battle for first place. A restaurant chain owner held a strong lead in the five-way contest for the GOP nomination. Republican Gov. Henry Bellmon is stepping down. Alaska voters also narrowed the field of candidates seeking to replace a retiring governor, and Republican Sen. Ted Stevens won his party's nomination for his fourth full term. In Oklahoma, Boren drew 124,237 votes, or 84 percent, with 780 of 2,359 precincts reporting. Perennial candidate Virginia Jenner had 16,435 votes, or 11 percent, and newcomer Manuel Ybarra had 7,091, or 5 percent. Boren will face Republican Stephen Jones, a lawyer. In the Democratic gubernatorial primary, House Speaker Steve Lewis of Shawnee had 54,733 votes, or 34 percent, to 51,704, or 33 percent, for Oklahoma City businessman David Walters, the 1986 nominee, with 815 precincts reporting. U.S. Rep. Wes Watkins of Ada, who'd been considered the front-runner, had 40,319 votes, or 25 percent. In the GOP race, restaurant chain owner Vince Orza led with 36,694 votes, or 38 percent, with 806 precincts reporting. Former U.S. Attorney Bill Price of Oklahoma City had 24,197 votes, or 25 percent, and former Human Services Commission Chairman Burns Hargis had 17,897, or 19 percent. Truck stop operator Jerry Brown of Oklahoma City had 12,751 votes, or 13 percent. Two other Democratic candidates and one Republican candidate had 5 percent or less of the vote. Runoffs will be held Sept. 18 unless one candidate of each party gets a majority. Gambling and marijuana were issues in Alaska, where Democratic Gov. Steve Cowper declined to seek a second term. The top Democratic contenders were Lt. Gov. Stephen McAlpine and former Anchorage Mayor Tony Knowles. Among Republicans, state Sen. Arliss Sturgulewski was heavily favored to win her second consecutive nomination. Stevens had 22,448 votes, or 71 percent of the vote, with 168 precincts, or 38 percent, counted. He was opposed by Bob Bird, a high school teacher and anti-abortion activist, who won 8,992 votes. A Democratic primary pitted Tom Taggert, a Hyder resident who supports legalizing cocaine and Alaska secession, against perennial candidate Michael Beasley of Eagle River. In Oklahoma, Watkins raised a record $1.7 million to help win the front-runner tag. Watkins and Walters accused each other of mudslinging and negative campaigning. Lewis sought to take advantage of their fighting with television ads saying he had taken the high road. Watkins ran an ad spotlighting newspaper headlines about a controversial campaign loan Walters made in 1986. In his television ads, Walters stressed that he was not ``a career politician'' and endorsed a state question to restrict legislators to 12 years in office. Walters also chided Watkins for sitting on a pillow during a televised debate, saying Watkins did that to make himself look taller. Watkins responded that he was ``shocked that Mr. Walters is so sensitive about his height'' and said the pillow was to ease his back. Alaska is one of three states with an open primary in which all candidates appear on one ballot regardless of party. Voters are free to vote in one party in one race and another party in another race. McAlpine tried to paint Knowles as soft on drugs because of the former mayor's opposition to a measure on the November ballot that would restore criminal penalties for possessing small amounts of marijuana. Alaska is the only state that has no criminal penalties for possessing less than 4 ounces of marijuana at home. Two initiatives were on the Alaska ballot: Measure 1 would change the way the state-owned Alaska Railroad is operated, and Measure 2 would allow local-option casino gambling. There was virtually no campaign in support of the gambling measure, and a poll conduced last week showed voters opposing it 2-to-1.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``If I were in your place or my family was in your place, I'd have the same feelings.'' _ Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, speaking in a televised meeting with Western captives at an undisclosed location.

``Tonight you'll see more police coverage than you've ever seen in any city you've ever lived in.'' _ Police Chief Wayland Clifton of Gainesville, Fla., where a ``maniac on the loose'' has killed and mutilated five college students.

``I saw trees bending, and I said to my buddy, `It's a tornado!' `I said, `Jump into the bathtub.' He jumped in, and I jumped in right on top of him. The whole house lifted up, and then came down.'' _ Michael Hejka, who arrived at his friend's house in northern Illinois five minutes before a tornado hit.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages' Families Hopeful But Cautious About Promise of Freedom
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of about 3,000 Americans trapped in Kuwait and Iraq said they were encouraged by Saddam Hussein's promise to release women and children today, but they had doubts about whether he would keep his word. ``I'll believe it when I see them home in this state. Until then, I'm just praying,'' Margaret Nuzum of Hutchinson, Kan., said Tuesday. Her daughter, son-in-law and their two young children last got a call through from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait on Aug. 19. Shortly after Saddam's televised meeting Tuesday with foreign hostages, he decreed that women and children would be free to leave Iraq today. Some Americans said Saddam's TV appearance was a propaganda ploy. ``I would love to see my husband,'' said Patricia Hale of Spring, Texas, whose husband, Edward, is trapped in the Middle East. ``In another way, I wish they would quit showing them (American hostages) because it's just propaganda and we're playing into Hussein's hands.'' Saddam's vow broke the monotony for relatives who have kept a monthlong vigil for Americans caught in Iraq or Kuwait. News of those trapped has been hard to come by since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. Kathy Majerek was dealing with housework and two young children when the television flashed her brother, hostage Kevin Bazner, face to face with Saddam. Just then the State Department called to tell Majerek: Sorry, no news. ``I told them to take a look at their TV,'' she said from Ogden, Utah. ``Kevin had the mike for about three minutes. It was hard to hear, but he said something about a peaceful solution.'' In the Detroit suburb of Farmington Hills, another of Bazner's sisters, Patricia Heath, said, ``We're waiting with bated breath now.'' She said the family had not heard from Bazner since Aug. 14. ``Hearing him and knowing he is safe and comfortable, of course that makes me feel good,'' she said. When the Gerards of New Harmony, Ind., heard of Saddam's vow, they reined in their emotions. ``I don't want to be a downer, but he's said things before. ... He said he was going to let all the diplomats go,'' said Pauline Gerard. ``Everything hinges on this ... and I don't want to be crushed.'' Mrs. Gerard had been waiting for good news since her pregnant sister got trapped while visiting Kuwaiti in-laws. ``I don't want to get my hopes up too much because I don't want to fall down too far if it doesn't work out,'' she said. Michael Saba, founder of the Coming Home Committee, was more effusive. ``It's just an excellent sign,'' said the Champaign, Ill., businessman, who escaped Iraq shortly after the invasion. ``Whether the men are soon to follow or whether that's something that has to be worked out isn't clear, but I'd say the signs are good,'' he said. ``I think we're seeing some signs that say there's some ... interest in de-escalating the situation.'' Saddam also agreed Tuesday to talk to President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher about ending the Persian Gulf crisis. Despite the conciliatory gestures, Baghdad hardened its position on Kuwait, declaring it a 19th province of Iraq. That concerns Jo Ellen Buehler, whose sister is married to a Kuwaiti air force officer. ``I'm going to stay excited and keep everyone's spirits as high as I can because that's all we have to clutch onto,'' Buehler said from Memphis, Tenn. ``(But) I don't want to jump the gun.'' Buehler said she's worried that Saddam means only to free the estimated 500 Americans trapped in Iraq. ``He didn't say anything about Kuwait,'' said Buehler, who hasn't heard from her sister since Aug. 3 when she and three young nephews were among about 2,500 Americans stuck in the annexed country. ``What about Kuwait?''

DOC.HEAD: Students, Teachers Take Cover as School Blows Away
With PM-Illinois Tornadoes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Students romped in a gym one minute and huddled in fear for their lives the next as a deadly tornado tore their school away around them. Plainfield High School was razed in the path of a cluster of tornadoes Tuesday that killed more than 20 people in a eight-mile swath in northern Illinois. At least 175 students were at the school when the tornado struck. Classes were to have begun today. ``All of a sudden we heard a big boom on the roof and then everybody got down and the roof came off the small gym,'' said Shawn Mazzoni, who was inside with dozens of students practicing for fall sports. The crash was the only warning for the teachers and students preparing for the school year. In minutes, winds ripped the school's roof off and toppled the outside walls. Hail and whipping winds were precursors to the tornado, said Principal Jim Waldorf, who was in the school. Students and teachers suffered minor injuries, Waldorf said. ``I was inside, and things went flying by the window horizontally,'' one teacher said. She did not give her name. Steve Schernerhorn, the soccer coach, said he and a group of teachers and student athletes crouched in the halls as the roof was blown off. ``We had some very short warnings. We immediately took cover,'' he said. He said about 25 houses near the school were destroyed. Cars were flipped over around the school. The roof was scattered in pieces across the campus. A few interior walls teetered without support. Broken glass littered the hallways. The spot where Mazzoni huddled for cover may have been the only area left standing. ``The whole big gym fell down,'' he said. ``There was stuff flying all at us. The place where we were at was the only thing standing still.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Leave, Parents Worry Over 5 Slayings
With PM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of University of Florida students left school or demanded answers from police on how to protect themselves from a serial killer preying on young men and women in their off-campus apartments. ``I don't feel safe here. I'll be back when this is over,'' said Shirley Sapp as she and a roommate left their apartment Tuesday. Police said the victims _ four women and a man attending either the university or Santa Fe Community College _ were slain in three attacks since Sunday. Police Chief Wayland Clifton said only that the evidence indicated the slayings were the work of one or two killers. ``I feel there is a good chance the individual or individuals may still be in town,'' he said. Students armed themselves with pistols, stun guns and Mace, went home to their parents or took shelter with friends. ``My father bought me a gun,'' a student confided, refusing to give her name out of fear. ``I'll stay for awhile, but I'm thinking of dropping out for a semester.'' University President John Lombardi said officials ``thought long and hard about canceling classes'' but decided not to because those who didn't go home would be left without ``the safety and support of the university.'' Lombardi said all penalties for non-attendance would be suspended. No university official could say how many students had left or planned to leave, but they did not dispute reports of several hundred. Out of the university's 34,000 students, only about 9,000 live in university dorms and married-student housing. The rest live off-campus, most of them in apartments within four or five miles of the university. Student body president Mike Brown joined school officials in trying to reassure students that they would be safe if ``we just stick together.'' ``Be tough. Stay safe by staying in groups,'' he said. More than 1,200 students jammed an auditorium to hear Lombardi, the police chief and others explain what had happened and what precautions they should take. The chief came under fire for holding back information on the killings and refusing to say whether they were the result of break-ins. ``At least tell us that so we can know what we should do,'' said Karyn James. ``Here we are, buying all kinds of locks and deadbolts, and we don't even know whether we should.'' While some students who live in Florida or nearby were going home, others expressed concern because they could not. Carol McCormac of Scio, Ore., said she and her boyfriend had moved in with friends of his in Gainesville. ``I just arrived a week ago,'' said the graduate student in forestry. ``Welcome to Gainesville.'' All students, particularly women, were told to call home to assure their parents they were all right. The school offered counseling to anyone needing it.

DOC.HEAD: American Journalist Escapes After Being Trapped In Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Washington Post reporter Caryle Murphy willingly traveled to Kuwait in late July to cover an unfolding international news event. She escaped a month later, holding preciously to her stories and her life. When Murphy arrived in Kuwait City, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was amassing thousands of troops from his million-man army along the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border, but still promising he would take no military action against his tiny neighbor. However, in the early morning hours of on Aug. 2, a week after Murphy's arrival Iraqi soldiers quickly rolled over Kuwait. One failed escape attempt and 25 days later, Murphy arrived in Saudi Arabia after a tense journey across the bleak desert. The journalist related her trials in a lengthy article published in today's Washington Post. Despite the turmoil in Kuwait after the invasion, Murphy said she hadn't expected to be trapped. ``... Like most foreigners, I assumed that in a few days time the borders would be open for those who wanted to leave, and that the exodus would start. But it never happened,'' she wrote in the first-person account of the ordeal. Murphy recalled that she and two other Western journalists spent the first week after the invasion conducting interviews on the streets, in hospitals and over the telephone, ``as if we were covering any story.'' However, she soon discovered that there was no way to dispatch material to her newspaper. After leaving her hotel to live with an American family, Murphy decided to flee the country as the two other journalists already had done. Murphy and two other Americans set out by car on the morning of Aug. 14. They were back in Kuwait City 90 minutes later after being turned back by Iraqi soldiers. But Murphy decided to try again after she learned of a convoy that was planning to leave at 9 a.m. Monday. ``I decided in a minute, mostly by instinct. I reasoned that the worst that could happen was that I would be detained if the Iraqi's spotted me,'' she wrote. Nearly seven hours later, Murphy arrived at the Saudi border. Once there, she learned from a U.S. diplomat that she was the first American to arrive at the outpost in eight days.

DOC.HEAD: Sketches of Gainesville Victims
With PM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are sketches of the five victims in Gainesville:

Eighteen-year-old Christa Leigh Hoyt attended Santa Fe Community College while working at several jobs, including a clerical position with the Alachua County Sheriff's Office. She failed to show up Monday for her midnight-to-8 a.m. shift at the sheriff's office, prompting a deputy to check on the usually punctual employee at her home. She was dead. ``She was a fantastic, dedicated employee,'' said sheriff's office spokesman Spencer Mann. Miss Hoyt was an honor student at the community college, majoring in biochemistry. The Miami native also was involved with the sheriff office's Explorers group, a program aimed at helping young people begin police careers.

Manuel ``Manny'' Taboada, 23, attended Santa Fe Community College and planned to transfer to the University of Florida to study architecture. The 6-foot-2 Carol City resident had been a guard on the football team at American High School in the Miami area, where he also was a member of the National Honor Society. He graduated in 1984. He attended Miami-Dade Community College from 1984 to 1989. Taboada, whose father died several years ago, had one older brother. His mother, Gladys, lives in Miami. ``He was just the kind of son that every mother would love to have,'' said Art Stevens, principal of adult education at American High. Taboada and another victim, Tracy Inez Paules, were friends for at least five years. They shared the apartment where they were killed but were not romantically involved, friends said. ``They were the kind of kids every parent would want their kid to be,'' Stevens said.

Tracy Inez Paules, 23, was a senior at the University of Florida and planned to enter law school after getting her political science degree. Miss Paules, who shared an apartment with high school friend and fellow victim Manuel Taboada, had been the homecoming queen at American High School in the Miami area and president of her 1984 graduating class. Miss Paules had been a member of the National Honor Society and played for the girls' soccer and softball teams at American High. ``I talked to her mother one month ago and she said (Tracy) became interested in law,'' said Art Stevens, principal of adult education at American High. He described her as a ``very, very bright student.''

Christina Powell, 17, along with fellow victim and roommate Sonja Larson, had attended the summer session at the University of Florida. The Jacksonville resident was a freshman who went to college to study architecture. She was a graduate of Episcopal High School, where she was described as an outgoing, popular student who loved softball. ``She'd want to play every inning,'' said Ted Pina, head of Episcopal's upper school. ``If things were going badly, she'd be the one who thought the team could come back.'' High school friend Alison Emery described Miss Powell as ``the kind of person everyone would want to have for a friend. She was somebody you could lean on and trust.''

Sonja Larson, 18, described by friends as having a soft spot for children, was pursuing a degree in elementary education at the University of Florida. The Deerfield Beach resident was an active member of the First Baptist Church of Pompano Beach, where she taught Sunday school, sang in the church choir and worked in the church's day-care center. Her goal was to operate her own day-care center after graduation. ``She told me she was going to be sitting in my desk one day,'' said Gail Guyton, First Baptist director of childhood ministries. Miss Larson, who graduated with honors from Ely High School in Pompano Beach, had tried to get into a dormitory at the university but ended up on a waiting list, said sister-in-law Monica Wesolowski. So she moved into an apartment with fellow victim Christina Powell.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply today following reports of a possible increase in Japan's official discount rate, traders said. The rumors later were denied by central bank officials. Meanwhile, the dollar climbed against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 815.97 points, or 3.17 percent, closing at 24,894.79 in light trading. The index rose 569.00 points on Tuesday after gaining 976 points on Monday and another 428.13 points Friday. Dealers said the Nikkei index began dropping at the start of the day's trading because of local news reports that the Bank of Japan would increase its official discount rate, possibly early next month. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a news conference this afternoon that the central bank was not discussing a discount-rate hike at the current time with the Finance Ministry. The newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported the bank was considering a hike in its key lending rate by 0.75-1.0 percentage points to stem inflationary pressures caused by rising oil prices due to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Prices remain stable at the present time, but higher oil prices are a new factor in the situation, which must be watched closely,'' Mieno said at his first news conference since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Mieno said there would be no immediate changes in monetary policy. The central bank governor said he does not expect the rise in oil prices to undermine Japan's three engines of economic expansion _ strong spending for housing, capital investment and personal consumption. Japan's discount rate, the interest rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks, now stands at 5.25 percent, one of the lowest among major industrialized nations. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive to investors, but discourage stock investment. But dealers said Mieno's comments would not necessarily boost stock prices. ``The governor's denial of an interest rate hike will not become a buy factor because the market environment itself remains bad'' because of the stalemate in the Middle East situation, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. In foreign exchange trading, the dollar closed at 144.35 yen, up 1.15 yen from Tuesday's close of 143.20 yen. After opening at 143.10 yen, the currency ranged between 142.98 yen and 144.45 yen. Spot volume was about $6.4 billion. The dollar slipped in early Tokyo trading on speculation about the interest rate but later was bought back by a reported denial of the hike by financial sources, exchange dealers said. ``Then the dollar moved higher on short covering, coupled with cross trading'' in which investors buy European currencies by selling the yen, said Shigeru Tamaki, a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan. In bond trading, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 82.33 points, down from Tuesday's close of 82.68. Their yield stood at 8.275 percent, up from Tuesday's 8.190 percent. Meanwhile, North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $26.50 to $26.70 a barrel, compared with $26.68 a barrel quoted in London late Tuesday. An official at a major Japanese trading company said today's oil market remained quiet.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Initiative Thrusts U.N. Chief into Spotlight
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, known more for discretion than dynamism, suddenly stepped forward this week and seized world headlines with a bid to personally mediate the Persian Gulf crisis. The U.N. chief often goes weeks on end without attracting much notice outside the glass facade of U.N. headquarters, relying on low-keyed diplomacy to solve conflicts. Then came his weekend announcement that he will meet Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Amman, Jordan, on Thursday to try to bring an end to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait and free all the foreign hostages caught by the Aug. 2 invasion. He followed up with a rare news conference Monday and capped that with live interviews with U.S. television networks on the evening newscasts. Diplomats and U.N. officials pondered this unprecedented outburst by an official who is fond of the French saying: ``The melody makes the song, not a loud voice.'' Up to now, his style has been a study in understatement as he labored quietly to bring recalcitrant enemies into peace negotiations. He was Peru's ambassador to the United Nations in 1971-75 and special U.N. representative to Cyprus from 1975-77. In 1979, he became undersecretary-general for special political affairs. U.N. insiders say that as special representative to Afghanistan in 1981, Perez de Cuellar sketched the framework for the superpower settlement that led to Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, completed last year. Perez de Cuellar spent many hours with the Iraqi and Iranian foreign ministers in 1988 to solidify the U.N.-mandated cease-fire in their war. The relationship he established with Aziz may prove useful on Thursday. Another long conflict, the guerrilla war in Western Sahara, appears headed to an end soon after years of unobtrusive U.N. mediation. The new cooperation between the superpowers is the key to the United Nations' recent successes; Perez de Cuellar owes thanks to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for taking the first steps to end the Cold War. For years, East and West tested each other in proxy wars among their client states and used their veto power in the United Nations to block effective diplomacy. During the ``lean years'' from 1982 to 1986, Perez de Cuellar could only lay the groundwork for future successes, Brian Urquhart, the former chief U.N. peacekeeping offical, said in a 1988 newspaper interview. In Perez de Cuellar's first year as secretary-general, Argentina and Britain fought their 74-day Falkland Islands war. While that conflict was still going on, Israel invaded Lebanon, defied Security Council demands for a cease-fire and withdrawal, and bypassed the 7,000-member U.N. peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon. ``The years 1982 to 1986 were awful; nothing was going right,'' Urquhart said. ``But he used that time to build up a negotiating position in Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq and all those places. When the climate changed, he was in a position to go forward quickly.'' U.N. insiders also credit Perez de Cuellar with recruiting a small, but highly effective circle of key aides to draft U.N. policy in Cambodia, Latin America, the Middle East, Afghanistan and other trouble spots. He doesn't upstage them by launching unexpected initiatives, which is why his move this week caught so many U.N. observers off guard. Iraq had dug in its heels, rejecting Security Council denunciations and calling the world body the ``pawn'' of the United States. The U.N. chief was away on a South American tour. Many wondered why he didn't rush back to headquarters during the crisis. After the Security Council voted Saturday to allow military force to enforce the economic blockade on Iraq, Perez de Cuellar suddenly announced his peace initiative and returned to New York. While supporting Security Council resolutions demanding immediate Iraqi withdrawal, he carefully drew a distinction between his role and that of the council. The Security Council, composed of 15 nations, cannot mediate in a crisis; only the secretary-general can do that, he said. Perez de Cuellar was not in his usual seat at the council table when it passed five resolutions faulting Iraq for its actions. Now he could offer himself as an honest broker to Iraq. Some officials and diplomats believe Perez de Cuellar's new, higher profile paves the way for his successor to be a more active international mediator after his term ends in 1992. Perez de Cuellar has said he will not stand for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Firms
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in quiet European trading this morning. Gold prices were firmer. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.35 yen, up 1.15 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar fell back to 143.95 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.5555 West German marks, up from 1.5525 _1.2825 Swiss francs, up from 1.2815 _5.2135 French francs, up from 5.2065 _1.7540 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7470 _1,148.00 Italian lire, down from 1,149.25 _1.1395 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1416 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9470, unchanged from late Tuesday. The dollar slipped in early Tokyo trading on speculation about interest rate boosts but later was bought back by a reported denial of the hike by financial sources, exchange dealers said. ``Then the dollar moved higher on short covering, coupled with cross trading'' in which investors buy European currencies by selling the yen, said Shigeru Tamaki, a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan in Tokyo. DOC.HEAD: Fighting in East, Army Inches Foreward to Besieged Fort in North
DOC.TEXT: Troops and helicopter gunships killed 34 Tamil rebels in the east while government troops in the north inched forward along a heavily mined causeway toward a rebel-besieged fort, officials said today. By the eighth day of the government's offensive against the Tamil Tiger guerrillas, the army was about two-thirds of a mile from Jaffna Fort, where 250 soldiers and police have been surrounded by rebels for 10 weeks, the military officials said. They said progress had been slow because the Tigers had blown up three culverts on the causeway leading across Jaffna lagoon to the star-shaped fort, located on the northern tip of this Indian Ocean island nation. Government troops have moved about one-fourth of the way up the causeway, according to the officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. In the east, fighting was reported in several areas as the Tigers pressed their 7-year-old campaign to carve a Tamil state out of the predominantly Sinhalese island nation. Gunships killed 14 Tigers preparing an attack on a Sinhalese village in the Ampara area, the military officials said. They said the rebels had already killed a soldier and wounded two other soldiers and three policemen when the gunships opened fire. Nine more Tigers were killed in a government ambush in the northeastern port city of Trincomalee, the officials said. In addition, 11 Tigers, one Tamil civilian and one soldier were killed in a series of clashes along the east coast, they said. The government did not indicate whether there had been new casualties in the north. The Jaffna reports could not be verified since communications with the north were cut after the Tigers broke a 13-month-old cease-fire on June 11. The Tigers themselves issue statements only periodically, usually from exile offices in Europe. The government offensive to break the siege of Jaffna Fort has a far greater symbolic value than any practical military application. Even before the siege started, the government garrison inside the fort was not free to move into Jaffna town, the chief stronghold of the Tigers. Except for a couple other isolated government posts, the entire Jaffna peninsula is held by Tigers. About 850,000 Tamils live on the peninsula 185 miles northeast of Colombo, the capital. At least 14,000 people have died in the Tamil insurrection, which began in 1983. Tamil militants say they need a separate homeland because they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who control the Sri Lankan government and the military. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people; Tamils comprise 18 percent. Most other Sri Lankans are Moslems, who trace their descent from Arab seafarers.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in East, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms early today rumbled across New York state and the Midwest. In the South, thunderstorms also were reported early today in Key West, Fla. Thunderstorms also moved across the Ohio and mid-Mississippi valleys early today. Illinois and other Midwestern states were expected to have hot weather today. A high pressure system in the region was expected to push temperatures in the 90s and 100s. Thunderstorms were possible in southern Texas. Today's forecast called for a low pressure system to form from Arkansas to northern Maine, with showers and thunderstorms expected along its front. The remainder of the East and South was expecting continued sunny skies and humid air, the highs in the 90s and 100s. More than 20 people were reported dead after tornadoes flattened scores of homes late Tuesday in northern Illinois. Nearly 300 people were treated at hospitals. The twisters hit Joliet, 40 miles southwest of Chicago, neighboring Crest Hill, and Plainfield to the northwest. Showers were likely in the Pacific Northwest, where highs in the 70s and 80 were expected. Sunshine and temperatures in the 100s and 110s were predicted for the Southwest. The high for the nation Tuesday was 109 degrees at Borrego Springs and Needles, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Syrians Quell Pro-Iraqi Violence, Mass Troops Along Border
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Syrian troops have put down violent pro-Iraqi demonstrations in cities along the eastern border with Iraq, killing dozens of people, Arab diplomats and security sources reported today. Diplomats described a massive deployment of troops _ perhaps more than 50,000 _ to maintain tense order in the southwest along the border with Iraq. Western embassies in Damascus, the Syrian capital, could not immediately be contacted by telephone. Syria's state-controlled media has made no mention of any trouble. But the sources, speaking on condition they not be named, said crowds of Syrians poured into the streets of eastern towns on Sunday to protest President Hafez Assad's stand against Iraq. People waved Iraqi flags and huge portraits of President Saddam Hussein, Iraq's strongman. Assad and Saddam have been locked in a bitter ideological feud for more than a decade. The two countries are ruled by rival wings of the Baath Socialist Party. Following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2, Assad has sent at least 1,100 troops to join an Arab expeditionary force gathering in Saudi Arabia to protect the oil-rich kingdom from the Iraqis. Saddam's army is confronting a major buildup by U.S. and other forces in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region. The diplomats said some of the weekend demonstrators demanded that the eastern sector of Syria separate from Damascus to be merged with Iraq. ``Troops tried all day to stop the demonstrations and reports from our Damascus embassy said dozens of people were killed,'' a senior diplomat said. By Monday, the rioting had been put down, but the mood remained explosive, he said. Diplomats and intelligence sources from other Arab states confirmed the information. Assad postponed a scheduled trip to Egypt on Sunday without explanation, but he flew to the Egyptian city of Alexandria Tuesday for a day of talks with President Hosni Mubarak. The violence appears to be the worst outbreak of political unrest in Syria since February 1982, when Assad mercilessly crushed a Moslem Brotherhood uprising in the city of Hama, north of Damascus. Assad's troops razed parts of the city in three weeks of fighting in which thousands of people were killed. The sources regarded the outbreak of violence in Syria as a serious threat to Assad, a former air force commander who has held a ruthless grip on the country since he seized power in November 1970. The diplomats also saw the trouble as evidence of Saddam's growing appeal to the Arabs generally in favor of his stand against U.S. and allied forces in the Persian Gulf. Travelers arriving in Jordan from Syria reported clear signs of high tension. But none who had visited the turbulent eastern part of the country was prepared to speak with reporters. ``I know nothing. I can't say anything,'' one trucker said, hurrying away, visibly frightened.

DOC.HEAD: Bangladesh Bars Iraqi Tea Buyers; No Iraqi Tea Takers in Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi tea drinkers may soon be looking at empty glasses. Bangladesh, adhering to a U.N.-ordered ban on trade with Iraq as punishment for its invasion of Kuwait, has barred Iraqi agents from its tea auctions. Sri Lanka, which wants to continue selling tea to its biggest customer, says Iraq made only minimal purchases at Monday's tea auction and none at all on Tuesday. Tea, sipped sweet and dark from small glasses, is the most popular drink in Iraq. Bangladesh barred Iraq from participating in Tuesday's tea auction at the port city of Chittagong, a Tea Board official said today, speaking on condition of anonymity. Iraq is Bangladesh's fourth-largest tea customer and normally buys about 10,000 tons of the country's crop each year. In Sri Lanka, which welcomes Baghdad's tea trade, Iraq purchased only 100 tons at Monday's auction _ one-fifth its usual level _ and made no bids on Tuesday, Tea Board Chairman Sepala Illangakoon said. This prompted fears the Iraqi market may be drying up. Iraq, said to be feeling the effects of the international trade embargo, purchased 30,000 tons of Sri Lankan tea last year. Sri Lanka and Bangladesh are among Iraq's biggest tea suppliers.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Praise Handling of Gulf Crisis, But No `Blank Check'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7-8, Sen. Richard, and 16, But Sen. John, with further reaction.
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress are praising President Bush's handling so far of the Middle East crisis, but some who interrupted their summer break for a presidential briefing are wary about the future. ``I don't think there's a question of a blank check here'' for the president, said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. But during an hour-long meeting Tuesday with Bush and top aides, ``there were really no overall reservations'' by the 170 or so lawmakers present, he said. Both Democrats and Republicans were effusive about Bush's diplomacy: the garnering of international support for an economic boycott of Iraq, the winning of United Nations backing for military enforcement of the blockade and his enlistment of Arab military forces in the regional show of strength. ``For the moment, among professional politicians, there is a sense of awe at how brilliantly Bush has handled this,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House minority whip. Congress will continue to support Bush's actions ``provided that we do not get into a protracted struggle where the goals are not clear, where there's loss of life and there does not seem to be an opportunity for victory,'' said House Majority Whip William Gray, D-Pa. But there were worries, as well. ``There was concern about where the line in the sand is,'' said Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich. ``There is no sense of how long it will last.'' Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said merely getting Hussein and his forces out of Kuwait will not be enough. ``I think that leaves us in a very unsatisfactory situation,'' Lugar said on ``CBS This Morning.'' ``We are left at that point with Saddam Hussein building potential nuclear weapons, having chemical capability which he has used before, an enormous army that could be a threat once again very rapidly. It seems to me important that Saddam Hussein must either leave or be removed. Likewise, those nuclear facilities and the chemical facilities should be destroyed,'' Lugar said. Others said Bush avoided the crucial question of whether the Iraqi president can remain in power in his own country even if he pulls out of Kuwait, which his forces overran on Aug. 2. ``I am concerned about what it is that we want to leave there,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J. ``What happens when all this is over? I think it's very important that (Iraq's) military machine be rendered inoperative before we can call this mission a success.'' Other lawmakers said they believe the administration intends to wait for Saddam's own people to overthrow him, or that the world will rely on a long-term multinational peacekeeping force to rein in Iraq. Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., said he worries about the lopsided nature of the international force in Saudi Arabia. ``The Germans think they have constitutional problems in sending troops outside the NATO area. The Japanese just send cash,'' said Obey, chairman of the House Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee. ``If we don't watch it, we'll have a 90 or 95 percent share of the on-the-ground troops. I don't think that's politically sustainable at home.'' Some participants in Tuesday's briefing _ noting that the Pentagon doubled its estimate of the cost so far of the troop deployment to at least $2.5 billion from $1.18 billion _ said money was a growing factor. ``As time goes on, there's going to be a strain,'' said Rep. Amo Houghton, R-N.Y., a member of the House Budget Committee. But Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said on CBS that ``the price tag of not doing what we're doing would have been even greater, both in lives as well as money.'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Congress and the president may have to scale back by as much as $15 billion the amount they hope to shave from the budget deficit next year. Some of that cost must be shouldered by U.S. allies who are even more dependent on Middle Eastern oil than the United States _ Japan and West Germany in particular, they said. Bush told the lawmakers he was working on just such a cost-sharing arrangement, participants reported. Another concern, voiced during the closed-door meeting by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, was that Bush has failed to articulate a national energy policy that can cope with the uncertainty the gulf crisis creates. Dingell said the country has no plan to encourage domestic oil production, no program to increase conservation and alternative energy sources and no standby rationing plan. ``I must say, the president's response on that wasn't the strongest,'' said Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash. Foley said Congress will expect to be kept informed of developments in the region, and it became clear that lawmakers will take a more active role in the crisis in the coming weeks. Two bipartisan delegations, one from the House and one from the Senate, are preparing to leave Friday for visits in Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other Middle Eastern countries to review the U.S. military deployment firsthand.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Calls for Peace Talks With Communist Rebels, Rebellious Troops
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino today reversed a long-held policy and said she was willing to negotiate cease-fires with Communist guerrillas and former soldiers who have staged coup attempts. Mrs. Aquino also invited the opposition to join the talks, including her most outspoken critic, Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile. Manila has been rocked by almost daily explosions. Although no one has claimed responsibility for the blasts, the government has blamed them on former soldiers who have repeatedly tried to toppled Mrs. Aquino in coup attempts. The Communist rebels have been waging a 21-year rebellion to establish a Marxist state. The last cease-fire with them collapsed in early 1987. Sen. Wigberto Tanada called for a truce between the government and the Communist rebels after a major earthquake in the Philippines on July 16, but Mrs. Aquino rejected the proposal. On Tuesday, a pro-Aquino senator, Orlando Mercado, urged Mrs. Aquino to put aside differences with her political foes and begin to discuss the nation's security problems and economic woes. Enrile said he was willing to reconcile with Mrs. Aquino, who fired him as defense minister after he was implicated in a coup attempt in November 1986. Mrs. Aquino said in a statement today that Mercado and Enrile are welcome to join discussions now being held by a committee of Cabinet members. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos has adamantly refused any cease-fire with the Communist guerrillas since November 1986 when the Aquino government negotiated with the rebels during a 60-day truce. Ramos, a member of the Cabinet committee, has been credited with crushing six coup attempts against Mrs. Aquino. Communists have accused him of whipping up threats of another coup attempt against Mrs. Aquino so that the civilian leadership would become indebted to him. Ramos has denied all allegations. The last cease-fire with the rebels collapsed in January 1987 after troops fired on farmers demonstrating outside Mrs. Aquino's office for land reform.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Import Ban over Dolphin Kill
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ordered a ban on imports of tuna caught by five nations until they can show that they are not killing more dolphins than U.S. law allows. U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson on Tuesday said the Bush administration had given foreign fleets too much time to comply with a 1988 federal law requiring an embargo of any nation whose dolphin-killing rate was more than twice the rate of the U.S. tuna fleet. The law provided for an embargo at the end of 1989 unless the Commerce Department had determined that a nation's dolphin kill rate was under the limit, Henderson said. The department contended it was entitled to evaluate figures submitted by each nation from 1989, an assessment that has not been completed. ``Under the agency's interpretation, it is the dolphins and domestic fishermen, not the foreign governments, who bear the burden of the foreign governments' late production of evidence,'' Henderson wrote. ``The continued slaughter and destruction of these innocent victims of the economics of fishing constitutes an irreparable injury to us all.'' August Felando, president of the American Tunaboat Association, the largest group of U.S.-flagged tuna boats, said the embargo could have serious consequences. ``What it can do is really disrupt the supply of tuna to the U.S. canners,'' Felando said. ``The U.S. fishermen cannot supply all the tuna that's required for the U.S. market.'' He said foreign boats caught 46 percent of the light-meat tuna canned by U.S. companies last year, and all of the foreign-canned tuna, which made up about a third of the U.S. market. The embargo affects the nations whose boats use nets to catch yellowfin tuna in the eastern Pacific _ Mexico, Panama, Venezuela, Ecuador and the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu. Some commercial fishing fleets deliberately drop their nets on dolphins, which swim above yellowfin tuna. To limit the deaths of dolphins caught in the nets, U.S. law requires posting of observers on tuna boats to monitor preservation efforts. U.S. law cannot directly regulate foreign fishing practices in international waters. The law, amended most recently in 1988, forbids imports of tuna caught by nations that do not meet prescribed limits for their dolphin kills: twice the U.S. rate by the end of 1989, and 1.25 times the U.S. rate by the end of 1990. A National Marine Fisheries Service official testified to Congress last month that foreign dolphin kills last year rose by over 40 percent to 84,000, while U.S. kills dropped to 12,643. The Commerce Department argued that the law required it only to compile information from foreign governments, which was submitted by a July 31 deadline, and decide whether each country met the legal standard. But an environmental group called the Earth Island Institute contended the law required an embargo of any nation that had not shown it met the limit by the end of last year, and Henderson agreed. Henderson said an embargo should have gone into effect at the end of 1989, to be lifted only as the Commerce Department determined, based on documentary evidence from each nation, that its dolphin kill rate was below the limit. The United States, the only country that regulates dolphin mortality in connection with fishing, allows a maximum of 20,500 deaths and stations observers on board all U.S.-flagged vessels to verify the number of deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Drunken Driving Arrest Upheld for Man Pushing Motorcycle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS to Lewistown sted Lewiston in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: The Montana Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld the drunken driving arrest of a man who was stopped while pushing his disabled motorcycle down a street. Although Ronald D. Turner was not driving the bike and its engine was not operating, he was in control of the vehicle and subject to the law requiring motorists to submit to a breath test, the court said in its unanimous ruling. Turner, 36, was on his way home from a bar in Lewistown last Sept. 19, and pushing a motorcycle with a broken clutch when he was arrested. He did not get on the bike or start the engine, but did turn on the headlight, the court said. A police officer said he refused to take a breath test by only blowing half-heartedly into the machine. His license was suspended for three months.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Gustav Moves Northward in Open Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Gustav continued losing strength over the open Atlantic this morning, with top winds down to 80 mph a day after boasting 105 mph gusts, the National Hurricane Center reported. ``It's getting weaker, we're looking at a little change, perhaps a slight weakening the next couple of days,'' said Ray Fagen, a hurricane specialist at the center in suburban Coral Gables. ``Right now, Gustav's heading generally towards Bermuda,'' he said. ``But that's four days away, and it's too soon to know what the effect, if any, there'll be on Bermuda.'' There was only ``a remote chance'' the hurricane would veer towards the U.S. East Coast during its trek northward, Fagen said. At 6 a.m. EDT, Gustav's center was located near 23.6 degrees north latitude and 57.6 west longitude, or about 750 miles southeast of Bermuda. It was moving northward at about 10 mph and was expected to hold that course and speed for the next 24 hours. Earlier in the week, Gustav skirted the Leeward Islands in the northeastern Caribbean, where hurricane warnings posted during the weekend were dropped Monday. Tropical storm Hortense, about 1,000 miles apart in the mid-Atlantic, also posed no threat to land. At 6 a.m., Hortense was moving northwest near 10 mph and had winds of 60 mph. The storm was centered near 24.5 degrees north latitude and 46.8 degrees west longitude, or about 1,450 miles west-northwest of the Cape Verde islands. The storm was expected to lose strength over the next two days, according to the hurricane center. Hortense, the eighth named storm of the Atlantic season, and Gustav were born as tropical depressions near the Cape Verde archipelago off West Africa. Tropical depressions become named storms when their sustained top winds reach 39 mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes at 74 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season runs through November.

DOC.HEAD: Animal-Rights Advocate Claims TV Chameleon Mistreated
DOC.TEXT: A chameleon that starred in a political commercial was worked to death, the director of an animal-rights group contends. Peter Hamilton, head of Lifeforce, said Tuesday the reptile was treated ``callously'' during an eight-hour shoot. The chameleon died after playing the feature role in a pre-election ad sponsored by the Socred party. In the ad, intended to show inconsistency in the New Democratic Party, the chameleon changes color with each conflicting NDP statement. The Socreds say the reptile's death probably was unrelated to the commercial. ``We were told that the animal had some sort of health problems,'' said Jess Ketchum, Socred director of operations. Ketchum estimates the animal spent only about 15 minutes under the lights.

DOC.HEAD: New Appeal for Bombing Convicts; Discrepancies in Police Records
DOC.TEXT: Citing new questions about police evidence, the government today ordered the Court of Appeal to review the convictions of six Irishmen serving life sentences for bombings that killed 21 people. It was a victory for the so-called Birmingham Six in a prolonged campaign to prove they were unjustly convicted of the 1974 Irish Republican Army bombings. The Home Office said apparent discrepancies were found in police notes of an interview with one of the convicts, Richard McIlkenny. Scientific tests indicated that some pages were written at different times, it said. Home Secretary David Waddington, the Cabinet minister responsible for law enforcement, ordered all six convictions referred to the Court of Appeal, according to a Home Office statement. ``This is very good news,'' Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said in Dublin. Relations between Britain and Ireland have been strained by the Birmingham Six and other British court cases involving IRA activities. Five of the six men were arrested Nov. 21, 1974, a few hours after the bombings, as they were about to board a ferry to Belfast, Northern Ireland for the funeral of an IRA man. McIlkenny, Johnny Walker, Patrick Hill, Hugh Callaghan, Gerry Hunter and Billy Power were convicted of murder for bombing two pubs in Birmingham, killing 21 people and injuring 162. All six were jailed for life in 1975. They were refused the right to appeal in 1976 and failed in a 1977 lawsuit against investigating officers for assault. A decade later the government acknowledged the doubts about their convictions by referring the case to the Court of Appeal, but the verdicts were in 1988. ``Let's hope this time it works for us,'' said McIlkenny's wife, Kate, who lives in Birmingham. ``I hope that the court will deal with the case speedily in order that this great scandal may be brought to an end as soon as possible,'' said Chris Mullin, a member of Parliament who wrote a book about the case. Mullin, of the opposition Labor party, claims he has met IRA members who admitted carrying out the Birmingham attack. The bombings were the deadliest ever by the IRA in England in its campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland. The Birmingham Six case is the last of three major trials of suspected IRA guerrillas from the 1970s to be returned to the appeal courts following vigorous public campaigns claiming their innocence. Three men and a woman convicted of killing six people in bombings in Guildford and Woolwich in 1975 were freed by the Court of Appeal in October. Six other people convicted in a related case of operating an IRA bomb factory are awaiting an appeal hearing, after Waddington announced in June that the convictions were ``unsafe.'' In March, Waddington asked the Devon and Cornwall Constabulary to investigate certain undisclosed points raised by defense attorneys. As part of that investigation, the police carried out electrostatic deposition tests on records of the West Midlands police force, whose detectives investigated the Birmingham bombings. A year ago, West Midlands Chief Constable Geoffrey Dear suspended two detectives and reassigned 53 members of the Serious Crime Squad after electrostatic deposition tests indicated that records had been falsified in cases going back to 1986. The appeal by the Guildford and Woolwich defendants also hinged on questions about police documentation. Prosecutors admitted that officers had lied about the timing of a statement by one of the defendants. Supporters of the Birmingham Six argue that their confessions contradict one another, that police tampered with logs to make statements appear consistent, that forensic evidence was flawed and that there was no witness who testified to seeing any of the men in the two pubs. Their cause had been taken up by Amnesty International, the Irish government and leading Irish and British political and clerical figures.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Refuses to Transport Troops, Weapons to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Kaifu speech, package details.

Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today that Japan will not transport soldiers or weapons to aid the international force in the Persian Gulf, but he pledged money, medical personnel and non-military supplies. Japan's assistance package, unveiled in a nationally televised speech, appeared to fall short of the aid level sought by the United States, which has deployed tens of thousands of troops to Saudi Arabia since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Although Japan quickly joined the trade embargo against Iraq, further response was slowed by debate over what action was permissible under Japan's post-World War II constitution, which bars the use of force in settling international disputes. Under the plan, Kaifu said Japan will use civilian airplanes and ships to transport food, water and medical supplies to the gulf. Japan also promised to send about 100 medical personnel. Turkey, Egypt and Jordan were singled out for ``substantial economic assistance,'' according to a copy of the package. Tens of thousands of foreigners fleeing Kuwait and Iraq have made their way to Jordan. The only specific amount mentioned was $10 million to aid refugees who have fled to Jordan. The package did not give a timetable for the aid. The package did not include increased funding for U.S. troops in Japan. There was no immediate reaction from the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo on the annoucement. But U.S. officials have indicated President Bush is hoping allies such as Japan will help share the cost of the military buildup in the gulf. In comments to Japanese reporters Tuesday night, U.S. Ambassador to Japan Michael H. Armacost urged Tokyo to help transport soldiers and weapons, said the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the country's leading economic newspaper. Earlier today, Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto said there was no link between the aid package and about 440 Japanese being detained in Iraq. He told a news conference that holding the captives was ``a sheer violation of international law.'' Iraq and Kuwait together supplied Japan with about 11 percent of its oil in the first quarter of 1990. Japan, which imports virtually all its oil, relies on the Middle East for about 70 percent of its needs.

DOC.HEAD: Rescue Workers Find Bodies Amid Rubble of Tornadoes
With PM-Illinois Tornadoes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers alternated between exhilaration at finding the living beneath beams and shattered glass and despair over holding dead children in their arms as they dug through the rubble left by tornadoes. ``It will be many nights before I have a good night's sleep again,'' said Will County Executive Charles Adelman, who helped comb a cornfield next to the Crest Hill Lake apartment complex. At least eight died at the complex Tuesday as tornadoes skipped through several northern Illinois towns, killing at least 24 people in Joliet, 40 miles southwest of Chicago, neighboring Crest Hill, and Plainfield to the Northwest. At least 293 people were treated at hospitals. Four of the dead, including a 4-month-old baby, were found flung into the cornfield next to the nine-building apartment complex. ``People were literally blown out of the building,'' said Crest Hill Mayor Don Randich. Two of the dead were found in cars nearby and two others were found in the building's rubble. Six of the apartment buildings were gutted and three had parts of their roofs blown away. Clothing, cars and appliances were strewn across the landscape. ``When the storm went through ... some of the buildings were disintegrated,'' said Lockport Fire Chief Dave Martis, who was in charge of the rescue effort at the site. At least 150 volunteer rescue workers rushed to the site, including officers from more than 30 area police and fire departments, said Plainfield Police Chief Don Bennett. Rescuers went from apartment to apartment, throwing rubble off of the three-story buildings with shovels _ or just their hands. Workers searched each building twice, sifting through debris until well after dark. Volunteers aided by dogs, floodlights, cranes and bulldozers looked for bodies. A National Guard helicopter shone a floodlight on the cornfield. Though some workers wanted to keep looking through the night, Martis called off the effort at 9:30 p.m. He said it was too dark and dangerous to continue. National Guardsmen and fire officials resumed the search today. In Joliet, four people died, including three in a subdivision where some houses were still under construction, said Joliet Police Chief Dennis Nowicki. ``I had a little baby die in my arms ... and a little girl,'' said a Joliet paramedic who did not identify himself. ``The last thing she said was she wanted her mommy, and her mommy was laying there next to her dead, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Sales of New Homes Fell 2.3 Percent in July
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes fell 2.3 percent in July, giving up half of their gain the previous month, the government said today in a report showing continuing weakness in the housing industry. The Commerce Department said new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 548,000 after advancing a revised 4.7 percent in June. The department originally reported June sales up 8 percent. The continuing weakness was further illustrated by the department's downward revision in the May sales figure as well _ last month's reported 2.3 percent gain was reduced to just 0.6 percent today. Until May, new home sales had declined for five straight months. For the first seven months of the year, they have fallen 12.4 percent below the pace of 1989. The department also said inventories of new homes showed a 7.8-month backlog at the July sales pace. It had been 7.7 months in June. Analysts have attributed the weakness in the industry to high interest rates, consumer caution because of adverse economic news and a glutted market. The National Association of Realtors reported on Monday that sales of existing homes, which represent about 80 percent of the housing market, rose 3.3 percent in July after advancing 0.9 percent in June. But the June advance had been the first in seven months and analysts predicted more declines because of rising mortgage rates resulting from the Mideast crisis. After peaking at 10.67 percent in March, fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages fell to 9.98 percent by the end of July, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. But by last Friday, rates had moved up to 10.29 percent. Commerce said the median price of a new home fell 4.7 percent in July to $121,000. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half less. The median price of an existing home that month was $98,400, according to the Realtors. Sales in the Northeast, which have been sluggish for more than a year, fell 10.1 percent to an annual rate of 80,000 units. The department also revised the June increase downward, from 36.9 percent to 25.3 percent. Sales also fell in the West, down 4.9 percent to 135,000 units while they were unchanged at 237,000 units in the South. Sales rose 2.1 percent to 96,000 units in the Midwest.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Suspended to Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Mail service to Iraq and Kuwait has been suspended, the U.S. Postal Service announced today. Mail service was halted because of transportation problems in reaching the two countries since the Iraqi invcaion of Kuwait, officials said. Until further notice all international mail destined for the two countries will be returned to the sender marked ``service temporarily suspended,'' postal officials said. People who receive returned mail can file applications for a refund of postage. Mail service to military personnel deployed in Saudi Arabia and mail to other areas of the Middle East continues as normal. To date, postal officials say, they have moved 110,000 pounds of cards and letters to service personnel in the region. That would amount to about 1.5 million cards and letters.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Proposed in Lawsuits Against Microwave Oven Maker
DOC.TEXT: Up to 50,000 people who bought microwave ovens thinking they were new when they weren't can get refunds from the Maytag Corp. U.S. District Judge Robert B. Propst gave initial approval to the Maytag offer, but set an Oct. 19 hearing to allow any objections from the buyers of the Magic Chef ovens. Since January 1987, Maytag's Anniston plant has repackaged or reconditioned ovens that customers had returned. The company then sold the ovens as new for $80 to $160. In the agreement, Maytag, parent company of Magic Chef, denied any liability but agreed to halt the practice and to offer refunds of $35 to people who bought the ovens, primarily through Wal-Mart stores. The refunds would be cash payments of $25 and a $10 certificate toward the purchase of a Magic Chef product. Maytag also agreed to pay $100,000 to the Alabama attorney general's office, which filed one of the three lawsuits, and up to $200,000 to the Birmingham law firm that filed two others.
