DOC.HEAD: Army Readies Tanks To Crush Mohawk Barriers; Violence at Blocked Bridge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with negotiations under way. Pickup 2nd pvs, `Canadian fighter...' Minor editing to CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk negotiators met with government officials today in an effort to end a standoff between troops and Indians after the army announced it was bringing in hundreds more soldiers to dismantle barricades. Quebec Native Affairs Minister John Ciaccia said the talks were under way at the request of the Mohawks and that he had briefed Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa Tuesday night. Ciaccia said he wasn't calling the talks to end the 7-week-old standoff ``formal negotiations'' and the army's intention to dismantle the barricades had not changed. Negotiators declined to comment as they entered a hotel room in Dorval. Canadian fighter jets on Tuesday swooped over the Oka area near Montreal where heavily armed Mohawks have dug in at a road barricade in a dispute over a planned golf course addition that they say would encroach on ancestral soil. About a dozen miles away just south of Montreal, Mohawks backing the Oka protest have barricaded a commuter bridge in sympathy. The Mercier Bridge blockade has angered many people who use the bridge to commute to Montreal, and about 500 people stoned Mohawk families leaving the adjacent Kahnawake reservation on Tuesday. Some injuries were reported. Brig. Gen. Armand Roy, tactical commander of the soldiers moving in on the two sets of barricades, told a news conference late Tuesday that ``military operations will cease only when the armed warriors lay down their weapons and surrender without conditions.'' Roy added that he has ordered his soldiers to move closer to Indian positions in preparation for a move to dismantle the Mohawk barricades at the Kahnawake and Oka reservations. Oka is 18 miles west of Montreal. The Kahawake reservation lies between the Mercier Bridge and suburban towns that depend on the bridge to cross the St. Lawrence River to get to Montreal. Early today, the army announced that 675 more men, 136 wheeled vehicles and 50 tracked vehicles would be deployed to the outskirts of the Kahnawake reservation. Before Tuesday, about 2,500 combat soldiers were positioned outside both reservations. The number of Indian fighters is believed to be in the hundreds. The army says Mohawks at the barricades have at least 170 automatic weapons and an intricate network of trenches, bunkers and strong points. Lt. Gen. Kent Foster said Tuesday that soldiers would use three unarmed, 42-ton Leopard tanks equipped with a bulldozer front to remove the barriers. He would not say when dismantling would begin. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney blamed Mohawk negotiators for the crisis. He went on national TV on Tuesday and challenged Mohawks to take down the barricades themselves before the army does. He said the federal and Quebec governments had dealt with the land dispute in good faith, but Mohawk bargainers advanced ``unrealistic conditions'' and then demanded acceptance. ``We cannot overlook the illegal activities of an extremist minority,'' Mulroney said, referring to the Mohawks' Warrior contingent. Mohawk negotiator Billy Two Rivers said one more day of talks should break the impasse and open Mercier Bridge and the roads leading to it. ``We are in a process of achieving through negotiation what the army was mandated to do by force,'' he said after Tuesday's session. ``We're positive that in the next 24 hours things can be resolved.'' But Mulroney said he consulted Quebec authorities and that a settlement ``doesn't appear to be within reach.'' Foster said there were plans to evacuate people from military zones if necessary and that those that live in surrounding areas will be told to stay in their basements. Many local residents have complained bitterly about the barricading of the Mercier Bridge, which has led to lengthy commuting detours and meant lost business. Hundreds of people hurled rocks and construction material at a convoy of 60 or more cars carrying Mohawk families out of Kahnawake reservation by the bridge on Tuesday. Police said there were some injuries but that no one appeared badly hurt. The armed confrontation in Oka began after a Quebec policeman was killed on July 11 when police tried to tear down a Mohawk barricade at the reservation and a gun battle erupted. Blame in the death has not been fixed. On Monday, Bourassa said he was through with talks and was asking the army to remove the barricades.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: be dismantled.
DOC.TEXT: Aug. 25 The Register-Guard, Eugene, Ore., on natural resources: New evidence that a substance extracted from yew trees can be used as an effective treatment for certain types of cancer transforms a low-grade natural resource into a potentially important one. It also teaches important lessons. Today's weed tree may be tomorrow's miracle, and what once was wasted may soon be developed as a valuable resource. The Pacific yew grows in small quantities over a broad range in the Northwest. Its uses are ancient but limited _ the longbows that defended England against Viking raids were made of yew, but it has never been a major commercial species. Today, yew wood is still used for bows as well as canoe paddles, fence posts and decorative veneers. The market is so limited, however, that loggers usually ignore yew in favor of Douglas fir, hemlock and other trees better suited as saw timber. That may change with the discovery that taxol, a compound found in the bark and other parts of trees of the yew, or taxus, genus, holds promise as a treatment for ovarian cancer. Ovarian cancer kills 12,400 women a year in the United States. Efforts to synthesize taxol have so far been unsuccessful. ... The potential emergence of what one dendrology book describes as a small, bushy, untidy tree as a treatment against a common type of cancer underscores the fact that there are no unimportant species. Judging a tree or a bird or a flower to be of no significance says more about the limits of human understanding than about the species in question. Every form of life has value of some kind _ but the true worth of many has yet to be discovered.

Aug. 26 The Oshkosh (Wis.) Northwestern on BGH: If bovine growth hormone (BGH) were eventually proven to be able to grow hair on a billiard ball, remove warts without surgery, and suppress the common cold, it would still have its detractors crying that that's not enough. The Food and Drug Administration has declared that BGH increases milk production in cows with no health risk to consumers. ``But we need more study,'' cry the critics. ``What about 10 years from now?'' Ten years from now, of course, the critics will still be asking for more study. That's the easy way of scuttling anything new. Studies by the FDA and by American Medical Association researchers have been reassuring that the hormone poses no risks. Some critics take a different tack, to be sure. Some cite the economic and sociologic aspects of introducing BGH into the dairy industry. But that is an absolute dead issue if the hormone is safe. It is just as logical to argue that the combine doomed the family farm concept as it is to blame BGH. Milk producers use every possible strategy to boost milk production with improved feeds and breeding programs. BGH is just another tool in that quest for more production for less cost. The evidence of science mounts that the hormone can benefit mankind, in much the same way, but more dramatically, than better bovine nutrition. Let it come.

Aug. 25 The Telegraph, Nashua, N.H., on the best place to live: Those people searching for heaven on Earth, or at least in the United States, should head out to Bremerton, Wash., the spot designated by a recent Money magazine survey as The Best Place To Live. ... One problem with such surveys is that they rely on a fairly predictable list of criteria to determine rankings. ... Below is a list of other categories that will have to be incorporated into these surveys for them to be taken seriously. Existence of a good car mechanic. Reliability, price and availability are the keys here. ... Traffic civility. ... An area recording a traffic related homicide involving firearms should be immediately discounted. Good Chinese food and pizza. ... Good reception. ... Being able to get clear pictures from all three commercial networks and one public television station.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Two Reported Dead in Hospital Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with quote from police chief.
DOC.TEXT: An 82-year-old man shot and killed his 80-year-old wife, then shot and killed himself today at the hospital where the wife was awaiting surgery. ``It appears at this point it's a mercy-killing type thing,'' Police Chief Frank Pomeroy said of the shooting at Community Memorial Hospital. Names of the victims were not immediately released and police said they did not know the reason for the shootings. The woman was shot in her bed, then the husband sat in a chair and killed himself, Pomeroy said. There were no other injuries reported. Police said they found the gun on the floor next to the man. Authorities did not immediately report the nature of the woman's illness. Shortly after the man entered his wife's room, nurses reported hearing two gunshots, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Forces Evacuation of 45-Story New York Hilton
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with fire out, power turned off, evacuation only partial.
DOC.TEXT: A smoky fire this morning in the basement of the New York Hilton forced the evacuation of 1,000 people from the 45-story hotel. No injuries were reported. Fire Chief Ellsworth Hughes said people were evacuated because the fire, which was contained in an electrical switching room, knocked out the 2,000-room hotel's power. Firefighters ushered people out of the lobby, warning them through bullhorns, ``Do not breathe the smoke.'' Thousands of conventiongoers were caught in the smoke, including Kathleen Booth of Norwalk, Conn., who said, ``The fumes were really intense.'' Hughes and Con Edison electric company spokeswoman Pat Richardi said the fire did not affect any transformers, so there was no danger from burned PCBs. Polychlorinated biphenyls, used as insulation in electrical equipment, cause toxic smoke when they burn. Con Ed shut off the power and the hotel resorted to emergency power. Full power was to remain off until sometime in the afternoon for repairs. The 1,000 people who were evacuated were not ordered out of the hotel _ they were simply advised to leave as a precaution, Fire Lt. Jim Powell said. It was not known how many people remained in the hotel. Twenty-three firefighting units were sent to the hotel. Side streets were closed and hundreds of people lined the sidewalks as acrid smoke filtered out of the hotel on Manhattan's Avenue of the Americas between 53rd and 54th streets. Booth's marketing convention was switched to another hotel, and other conventions were expected to do likewise.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: television station.
DOC.TEXT: Aug. 24 Het Parool, Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Saddam Hussein's televised meeting with Western hostages: Baffling images from Baghdad. With his revolting TV appearance ..., in which, as a well-meaning uncle, he let himself amiably be photographed with a powerless family of British hostages, Saddam Hussein has hopefully lost the credit he still had, especially in the Arab world. ... This Saddam Hussein is a dangerous lunatic, nothing more, but, most of all, nothing less, and he must be driven off stage as fast as possible. The threat emanating from his latest TV show _ I'm here and I do what I want _ is too big to allow him to carry on further. ... Precisely in this context it is promising that the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council agreed unexpectedly fast to a draft resolution which gives the military force that has already collected around Iraq the right to use force if necessary to stop the Iraqi dictator.

Aug. 25 Indian Express, New Delhi, on the Persian Gulf: The only hope of averting a major military collision in the present situation lies in President Saddam Hussein showing that his proclaimed desire for peace talks is not meant to trap the rest of the world into coming to terms with Iraqi seizure of Kuwait in any sense. If, however, he is only looking for a face-saving device to restore the status quo, there is no dearth of diplomatic skill to make this possible.

Aug. 26 The Sunday Correspondent, London, on the Persian Gulf: The release of Brian Keenan after his four-year incarceration in Beirut would, in normal times, be a cause for unfettered delight. ... Yet, in the context of the mass seizing of hostages by Saddam Hussein, the matter takes on another, and less happy, aspect. If our Western societies are so worried about the fate of a single citizen, how are they to cope with the fate of thousands? Will we become obsessed by Saddam's human shield? Will our human concern for the individuals involved paralyze our efforts to curb Saddam? If Jimmy Carter as president of the world's largest power could be brought down by his failure to rescue a handful of hostages in Iran, does not George Bush face certain humiliation as a result of the present, much larger problem? Much that is happening makes such an outcome more likely. ... (But) we have soberly to appreciate that some causes are important enough to be worth the sacrifice of human life. We have to recognize that, in this crisis, the side that blinks first is lost. We have to be aware that appeasement to save those individuals in peril, could easily threaten the lives of others whom Saddam might use as pawns in future.

Aug. 28 Business Times, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on the Persian Gulf: Whatever the outcome of the peace process and even if the status quo before Aug. 2 is restored _ that is the complete withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and the restoration of the al-Sabah family _ the scenario in the Gulf area will never be the same again. The crisis will be the watershed marking the beginning of the end of the old order in the area. Just as the winds of change have blown across the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, they have now moved down into the Persian Gulf. The writing is already on the wall for the absolute monarchies there. If they value their continuity, the monarchies will have to meet the new challenges by instituting fundamental changes to bring in democratic processes in their administrations by allowing greater citizen participation. The process for change has been simmering underground for some years and though President Saddam (Hussein) is nowhere near a role model for democratic participation, his actions will nevertheless act as a catalyst for the transformation of the old order in the Gulf. The mere presence of U.S. forces which include women and Jews in such a closed society as Saudi Arabia will definitely have repercussions on Saudi society and put further pressures for modernization. For the U.S. and the Western powers, they will also have to come to terms with legitimate Arab demands vis-a-vis the question of Arab interest which definitely also includes the interest for the Palestinians who are no less Arabs than the Saudis or the Kuwaitis.

Aug. 27 Western Straits Times, Singapore, on developments in Burma: Burma's rulers are still trying to reconcile the irreconcilable. They want the outside world's approval, expressed in aid and investments, but are unwilling to take the steps the world demands as a precondition for loosening its purse strings. Trade has been liberalized since 1985 and, in the past few years especially, foreign businessmen and potential investors have been actively courted. But the colonels and generals who rule Burma seem intent on ensuring that their version of glasnost and perestroika is confined strictly to a narrowly-defined economic sphere. ... Three months after holding free elections, the first in 30 years, the military is refusing to hand over power to the civilians who won 80 percent of the available seats. Worse, it is not even saying when it might do so. The population, having overwhelmingly rejected military rule, is not surprisingly resentful and there have been reports of scattered demonstrations in several cities. ... Like most of its factories and vehicles, which date to the 1950s, if not earlier, the economy is slowly but inexorably falling apart. The rulers have to make a choice: They either accept the verdict of the people and the need for real change or find themselves presiding over a ruin, not a country with a once-proud history.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Search Lifted for Men Missing After Boat Collision
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard has suspended its search for three fishermen who disappeared after their vessel and a Greek ship collided in fog off Nantucket. Two men aboard the New Bedford fishing boat, the New England, were rescued by the crew of a freighter, the Eurojoy. The fishing boat's captain, Manuel Vieria, said his 73-foot vessel rolled over and sank immediately after the crash Tuesday morning 42 miles east of Nantucket, the Coast Guard said. Vieria said he and the other rescued man were on deck when the collision occurred and the three missing crew members were below deck sleeping. The Coast Guard suspended its search late Tuesday. The 591-foot Greek ship was empty and on its way to Norfolk, Va. Fog reduced visibility to a half mile. ``The tanker never saw the fishing boat at all,'' said Coast Guard Lt. Richard Gill.

DOC.HEAD: Brewery Asked To Double Exports Nonalcoholic Beer For GIs in Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bavaria brewery said Wednesday that Saudi Arabia has asked it to double its exports of non-alcoholic beer to the Middle Eastern nation to help quench the thirst of American soldiers. ``The demand is much too large for us at the moment,'' said Rien Coolen, a spokesman for the Bavaria brewery. Before the request, Bavaria was finding it difficult to meet the demands for non-alcoholic beer in Saudi Arabia. A strictly Islamic nation, Saudi Arabia bans the sale of alcohol. To help meet the Saudi request, the brewery is increasing output and will ask employees to work overtime, Coolen said.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Killed in Mountain Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A bus plunged off a road in the Himalayan foothills and rolled down a gorge Wednesday, killing 30 people, news agencies said. Twenty-three other passengers were injured in the crash in Himachal Pradesh state near Rampur, 190 miles north of New Delhi, according to Press Trust of India and United News of India. The bus was carrying about 70 people when it toppled down the 650-foot deep gorge, Press Trust said.

DOC.HEAD: Bermuda Retains Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: Voters have elected to retain the death penalty in Bermuda, according to official results Wednesday. Nearly 11,000 people turned out Tuesday to vote in the island's first national referendum, which asked whether capital punishment should be abolished. Almost 79 percent voted to retain the death penalty for premeditated murder. The result is not binding on the Bermuda government. The ballot asked voters just one question: whether they were in favor or against retention of the penalty. Abolitionists opposed the referendum's style, saying voters should also have been asked if they support life imprisonment without parole for first-degree murder. The last time the North Atlantic island's gallows were used was on Dec. 2, 1977, when murderers Larry Tacklyn and Buck Burrows were put to death. The double hanging sparked civil unrest across the British colony. British troops were called in to restore order. Several people have been convicted of first-degree murder. In February and March, the governor, Sir Desmond Langley, commuted the death sentences of two people sentenced to death. There is no one on death row now. Britain abolished the death penalty in 1965. Bermuda, an island of 70,000 people, has been a British colony since the 1500s.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomat Dismissed For Failing to Evacuate Taiwanese from Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Foreign Ministry has fired a senior diplomat for failing to do his utmost to evacuate Taiwan nationals from Kuwait following that country's invasion by Iraqi troops, officials said Wednesday. The officials said the diplomat, Kenneth Keh, had been Taiwan's representative to Kuwait since 1986. Keh left Kuwait on Aug. 19 for Jordan with 11 other officials, leaving behind 136 Taiwanese. Most of them were employees of Taiwan's state-run BES Engineering Corp. and their family. Keh, whose position was equivalent to that of ambassador, said he left Kuwait first to seek outside help for the stranded Taiwanese, the officials said. The stranded Taiwanese later sought help from China and crossed into Jordan in a convoy of cars that Chinese authorities had arranged to evacuate hundreds of their nationals out of Kuwait. Keh and the Taiwan evacuees returned to Taiwan in a chartered plane on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Dallas Police Chief Charged with Perjury
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors filed seven perjury charges against Police Chief Mack Vines, reportedly for statements he made to a panel investigating a police officer's fatal shooting of an unarmed Mexican national. Dallas County District Attorney John Vance today announced the charges and said they will be reviewed by a grand jury next week. They are third-degree felonies, each carrying a maximum 10-year prison term and fines of up to $10,000. ``This office intends to seek indictments and prosecute any person who has committed crimes involving acts of official public corruption, regardless of who it may be,'' Vance said in a statement. Vance said details of Vines' statements will be made available ``upon the returning of indictments.'' Vines' attorney, Kim Wade, is ``not speaking with the media,'' a woman who answered the phone at Wade's office said this morning. The charges stem from Vines' testimony before a panel reviewing the 1989 dismissal of Officer Patrick LeMaire. The panel had confronted the chief with accusations that he tried to influence the testimony of an assistant chief regarding the speed of the internal investigation of LeMaire. Vines fired LeMaire 17 days after he killed Jose Hilario, an unarmed Mexican national, on June 27, 1989. The chief said LeMaire violated the department's policy by failing to take steps that would have avoided a confrontation. Vines first said, ``no'' when asked whether he had talked to anyone about the panel's investigation, but changed his answer upon further questioning, according to sources familiar with the transcript of the hearing, The Dallas Morning News reported. The chief then acknowledged that he talked to Assistant Chief Greg Holliday before Holliday testified. Vines has denied trying to influence him. Both Vines and Holliday have been on indefinite leave with pay for about three weeks. Saying she was speaking on behalf of her husband, the chief's wife said Tuesday night he had no comment when asked about stories in the News and the Dallas Times Herald that Vines' case would go to a grand jury. An administrative law judge ruled last month that LeMaire should be reinstated, saying the city failed to justify his dismissal. An internal affairs detective testified during the administrative hearing that his initial report on the shooting was later altered. Ms. Hart appointed a special panel to review the allegations. The panel found no wrongdoing in the LeMaire case by Vines and his staff, saying that the altered report was the result of poor procedures in the internal affairs division. But the panel brought up allegations of perjury and witness tampering that prompted Ms. Hart to place Vines and Holliday on indefinite paid leave. Sources say no charges will be filed against Holliday, the News reported.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Predict U.S. Would Strike Remote Iraqi Bases, Missile Sites
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military's first strike will be against remote air bases, missile sites and chemical weapons installations if the Persian Gulf standoff turns into a shooting war, experts on the Middle East and national security say. An attack on the presidential palace in crowded Baghdad is also seen as a possibility. American officials in Saudi Arabia say an all-out assault on Iraq is highly unlikely unless the Iraqis fire first. They have discussed contingency plans, but Pentagon ground rules forbids disclosure of specific targets. Experts here also were reluctant to pinpoint exact locations they thought might be targeted, but indicated the initial focus would be on Iraq's air force and missiles. ``To destroy the Iraqi air force on the ground will be the No. 1 priority, and to prevent them from firing missiles,'' said Barry Rubin, senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, a private research group. Other targets, Rubin predicted, would be supply depots and supply lines and places that produce chemical weapons. Asked to be specific, he said: ``I don't think it would be useful to go into that. But we know where the chemical installations are, and satellites take very nice pictures.'' William B. Quandt, a National Security Council official in the Nixon and Carter administrations who is a senior fellow with the Brookings Institution, listed much the same priorities. ``I think their first concern would be to neutralize surface-to-surface missile capability and then to establish air superiority without any question,'' Quandt said. He said military officials would be likely also to pinpoint ``anything they know about chemical depots _ not so much the plants but where they store the stuff.'' ``And then there is the kind of notion that we ought to sneak in and drop a bomb on the presidential palace on top of it all,'' Quandt said. ``I am sure somebody is thinking about hitting the so-called command and control centers.'' Such an attack would strike at the heart of Baghdad, a city of more than 3 million people. ``I am not sure you could take anything without taking out civilian populations; not around Baghdad, that's for sure,'' said Joyce R. Starr, a Washington consultant and expert on Middle East conflict who served in the Carter White House. ``I think if they really decide to go for broke there will be civilian casualties,'' Quandt said. Rubin said the military installations, unlike the presidential palace and other government buildings, are remote from population centers. ``They are not necessarily in the desert, but they are not in the middle of cities, either,'' he said. According to a forthcoming book by Leonard S. Spector and Jacqueline R. Smith of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Iraq has been conducting work on uranium enrichment, a key process in making fuel for nuclear weapons, at a plant near Baghdad. The book concludes that Iraq has apparently launched a nuclear weapons program, but will not be able to build such arms on its own until late in this decade. Rubin said the nuclear plant would not be an important target because, for the short run, Iraq has no nuclear capability. After the Air Force and the missile sites, he said, the principal aim ``would have to be at the war-making capacity, not at civilians or even at the industrial capacity.'' The State Department has said it had credible reports that Iraq was moving foreigners trapped within its borders to industrial sites that might be targets of attack. Quandt said he assumed the U.S. military would take that into account ``up to a point, but I think once they have decided something is really a high priority target, they will go after it with or without the presence of American civilians.''

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Reagan Has Cancerous Tumor Removed
DOC.TEXT: Former first lady Nancy Reagan today had a small cancerous tumor removed from just beneath her left nostril, a family spokesman said. The basal cell carcinoma was discovered during a routine dermatological examination at the Mayo Clinic and was removed by a plastic surgeon at St. Marys Hospital, said Mark Weinberg, spokesman for Mrs. Reagan and former President Reagan. In 1987, doctors at Bethesda Naval Hospital removed Mrs. Reagan's left breast and adjoining lymph glands after a cancerous tumor was found. The Reagans arrived at the Mayo clinic on Monday for what Weinberg said were routine physical examinations as part of their annual checkups. Physicians found the Reagans in otherwise excellent health and they planned to return home to Bel-Air, Calif., today, Weinberg said. Weinberg issued a statement on Mrs. Reagan's condition and did not return a phone call seeking further information. A Mayo Clinic spokeswoman said all information would have to come from Weinberg. The Reagans were scheduled to visit Germany, Poland and the Soviet Union on a trip beginning Sept. 10, Weinberg said Tuesday. It was not known if Mrs. Reagan's surgery would affect that schedule. Reagan, 79, was at the Mayo Clinic last September, when doctors performed neurosurgery to remove a pool of blood that formed on his brain after a fall from a horse.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Produce Sunlight That Outshines The Sun
DOC.TEXT: A solar collector has produced a tiny beam of sunlight that outshines the sun. It's 15 percent brighter than the glow at the sun's surface. In a brief note in Thursday's journal Nature, Dave Cooke and colleagues at the University of Chicago said they used a sapphire ``light funnel'' to produce sunlight 84,000 times as bright as the sunlight striking the Earth. The researchers, having beaten the sun at its own game, boasted that they had done more than set a world record. They produced the highest concentration of sunlight in the solar system. Two years ago, the group reported that it had produced sunlight 56,000 times as concentrated as sunlight at the Earth's surface. The concentrator uses a parabolic mirror like those used in reflecting telescopes, and a ``non-imaging concentrator'' made of sapphire. The mirror reflects light to the broad end of the cone-shaped concentrator, which acts like a funnel, the researchers said. Light is directed inside the concentrator to emerge in concentrated form at the tip of the cone, the researchers said. The bright beam of concentrated sunlight emerged from a 1-millimeter aperture at the tip of the concentrator. (One millimeter is about one-twenty-fourth of an inch.) Refinements of the technique could lead to the development of a laser fired by a0568 0443 12:40 08-29 ra AM-Ultrasound a0569 0262 12:42 08-29 ri AM-Pakistan

DOC.HEAD: Clapton's Show Goes On, After Death of Friend Vaughan
LaserPhoto KX1 of Aug. 28
DOC.TEXT: Apparently wishing to let his music speak for him, guitar master Eric Clapton performed without mention of blues comrade Stevie Ray Vaughan and other friends killed in a helicopter crash. He went through the show Tuesday night at Sandstone Amphitheatre seemingly like any other rock 'n' roll performance, although he had been on stage with Vaughan 48 hours earlier in Wisconsin. Gus Fasone, general manager at Sandstone, said Clapton refused all interviews and demanded that reporters and camera crews be barred from backstage. ``The people around him, it's like they are in shock,'' Fasone said. ``Backstage, it's like they aren't functioning, they're going through the motions.'' Little of that showed to the more than 16,000 fans at the outdoor theater, about 20 miles west of Kansas City, Mo. ``I think (the band) did an extremely brave thing,'' Fasone said. The helicopter crashed in dense fog early Monday, a few hours after a blues jam featuring Clapton, Vaughan and guitarist Robert Cray at Alpine Valley Music Theatre near East Troy, Wis. ``When I heard the radio I almost cried,'' said Mark Petitt, a 25-year-old Kansas City, Mo., man wearing a Stevie Ray Vaughan T-shirt. ``I said, `Man, why him?' Especially after he cleaned up his life. I don't understand it, but I think his music will live.'' Petitt said it was the tradition of rock to play on after the tragic deaths of stars. ``I think Stevie Ray Vaughan would have wanted him to go on,'' Petitt said. Clapton, 45, and Vaughan, 35, made their careers leading bands with guitar-driven rocking blues _ Clapton beginning in his native England and Vaughan in Texas. Both fell victim to drugs and alcohol, but each overcame problems to advance their careers. This year, Vaughan won a Grammy for the album ``In Step,'' referring to the ``12 Steps'' program used by recovering alcoholics. The others killed were agent Bobby Brooks of Los Angeles, bodyguard Nigel Browne and tour manager Colin Smythe, both of London, and pilot Jeffrey W. Brown, 42, of East Chicago, Ind.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Troops on `Front Line Against Aggression'
LaserPhoto WX15
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with White House comments on hostages, radio broadcast, dead hostage, Iraqi ambassador visiting State Department; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today called the Persian Gulf crisis ``one of the toughest military missions in modern memory,'' and the White House said Iraq had not yet made good on its promise to free foreign women and children. ``I have no evidence ... indicating that people have been allowed to leave.'' White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk told reporters. He said the government was ready to look into ``any means that will facilitate their departure,'' once Iraq's President Saddam Hussein fulfills his Tuesday pledge to allow departure from Iraq of foreign women and children. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, went to the State Department today to notify the United States of the decision to let women and children go. He said Americans will be allowed to leave through Jordan or Turkey, but gave no timetable for their departure. Popadiuk refused to confirm or deny a report that the administration had received a message from Saddam Hussein, offering to pull out his invading troops from Kuwait with conditions. The spokesman said that a Western physician would observe an autopsy of an American man who died while a hostage of Iraq. Iraqi officials said he had an apparent heart attack, and U.S. officials have said nothing to indicate they believe otherwise. ``In a situation wehre there's a war going on and people are being detained, there's all kinds of stress and who can say what might happen,'' Popadiuk said. The president this morning gave a radio pep talk broadcast over Armed Forces Radio to troops in Saudi Arabia, but most U.S. soldiers in the gulf did not hear it because the radio network does not have a transmitter in Saudi Arabia. In Dhahran, Navy Capt. Mike Sherman said trancripts and tape recordings of the speech will be distributed to each unit stationed in Saudi Arabia, a process which, including delivery time, would take a week. Popadiuk said the White House knew about the transmission problem ahead of time and anticipated the tape distribution. He said the only ones who heard it live were troops on ships and in Bahrain. Bush spoke by telephone this morning with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, whose government unveiled a package of money, medics and transportation for the multinational effort against Iraq. Bush also spoke Tuesday night to United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and wished him well in his Thursday negotiations with Iraqi officials, aimed at finding a solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. In his radio speech, Bush told the troops, ``You stand on the front line against aggression and international lawlessness.'' ``We have never sought conflict nor do we hope to chart a course for other nations, but at the hands of injustice in the face of aggression, ours is a once reluctant fist now clutched resolutely,'' he said. ``It is your presence, your skills, your talents, your judgment that bring America's principles to life and give them strength and meaning,'' Bush said. ``You're now in one of the toughest military missions in memory,'' Bush added. ``As tough as it is, know this: thanks to you, nobody's feeling the heat more than the government in Baghdad.'' The president's pep talk came a day after he received a strong vote of confidence from a large, bipartisan contingent of members of Congress. While they voiced overall support for his policy, some said they wanted to see other wealthy nations share the cost. The Bush administration is trying to allies to help pay for it, administration officials and lawmakers say. Members of Congress briefed by Bush on the Persian Gulf situation Tuesday said they received indications that the United States was pressuring the international community to provide money. ``The question of burden-sharing was brought up and discussed in a variety of ways,'' said Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``It's being carefully studied. Since it is an international effort, the burden falls on all countries. I would think that shortly here there would be clarification.'' While Bush got a message of strong support for his Persian Gulf strategy during the meeting with about 170 members of Congress, several voiced concerns about the cost and said other wealthy nations should shoulder some of the burden. ``Obviously people are concerned about the cost,'' said Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich. ``They want to know what the Japanese and the Germans and others are doing to share this burden.'' The Pentagon projected Tuesday the U.S. cost for the buildup will reach $2.5 billion by the end of September. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Bush sought to assure the lawmakers he did not intend to put the entire cost on the strapped U.S. Treasury, ``especially with precarious deficit-reduction talks in progress between the administration and Congress.'' The United States has about 80,000 troops either in Saudi Arabia or en route. Twenty-two countries, including the Soviet Union, Britain, France and Egypt, have either dispatched troops and equipment or have promised to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Flawed $11 Coin Sets Worth $1,400 Each
DOC.TEXT: Some 1990 U.S. coin proof sets that sell for $11 are worth more than 100 times that because of a missing mint mark on a penny, according to dealers. The penny in the 3,555 sets is missing the ``S'' all proof coins normally bear. That makes them unusual and valuable to collectors. The sets of highly polished coins were struck and issued before the error was discovered, U.S. Mint spokeswoman Hamilton Dix confirmed Tuesday. ``I stuck my neck out when these things showed up and predicted that by the end of the decade these things will be worth $10,000,'' said Alan Herbert, who broke news of the error in the Aug. 7 edition of Numismatic News newspaper of Iola, Wis. ``We have talked with a collector who had ordered five sets from the Mint and all five of those sets were missing the mint mark,'' said Beth Deischler, editor of Coin World newspaper in Sidney, Ohio. ``At that time, he wasn't considering selling at any price.'' ``The errors are a prize, because there are so few of them,'' Ms. Deischler said. Coin dealer Harry Forman of suburban Cheltenham paid $1,400 each last week for four sets and is now offering $1,700 per set. The proof coins are made by using polished blanks and dies. The flat surfaces are mirror-like and the relief portions look frosted. The $11 five-coin set contains a penny, nickel, dime, quarter and half dollar. A six-coin prestige set adds a proof dollar and sells for $46. Proof coins are struck at the San Francisco Mint and thus should bear an ``S'' under the date. Dies for striking the coins are made at the Philadelphia Mint. The Philadelphia Mint puts no mark on pennies it strikes, but they all go into general circulation. ``We're investigating to find out exactly what happened,'' Miss Dix said. ``We are taking steps to ensure this does not happen again.'' Similar errors were made on proof nickels in 1971 and proof dimes in 1968, 1970, 1975 and 1983, Herbert said.

DOC.HEAD: National Guard Targets Looters After Twisters Kill At Least 24
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Gov. James ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with governor's request to have area declared federal disaster area, quote from Thompson and state offer of low-interest loans; Picks up 7th graf pvs., `Elsewhere in ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CX1, CX2
DOC.TEXT: National Guardsmen and fire officials searched a muddy cornfield today for more victims of tornadoes that flattened scores of homes and killed at least 24 people. The dead included at least nine people found near a demolished apartment complex where six residents were missing, Lockport Fire Chief Dave Martis said today. At least 306 people were treated at hospitals after the cluster of tornadoes touched down in four spots Tuesday afternoon, cutting an eight-mile trail of destruction leading to the northern Illinois city of Joliet. At least 11 people were listed in critical condition today. In nearby Plainfield, residents began returning to the rubble of their homes. ``It was like an eggbeater went through the inside of the house,'' said 41-year-old Bruce Marshall as he tried to fashion a makeshift cover for his roofless home. Gov. James R. Thompson declared Will County a state disaster area, and requested that President Bush declare the area a federal disaster to provide additional relief. ``Nothing in my personal experience ... compares with this,'' Thompson said during a tour of Plainfield today. Illinois Treasurer Jerry Cosentino announced that the state will provide at least $25 million for low-interest loans to tornado victims. Elsewhere in the Midwest, thunderstorms Tuesday halted power to 70,000 customers in central and western Ohio. A tornado touched down south of Tecumseh in southern Michigan and storms that ripped through northern Indiana left at least one person dead. Pat Jones, 27, was killed when the house he was building in South Bend collapsed. At least two tornadoes were spotted in northwestern Pennsylvania, but no injuries were reported. Preliminary tallies made in the dark from the tornadoes in Illinois suggested more than 100 houses were destroyed, in addition to the apartment complex and a high school. The storms blacked out 17,000 homes and businesses, tossed trucks like toys and flattened crops. ``Cars were flying all over the place,'' said Tony Aloisio, who was driving by and stopped to help. ``It happened so fast that all I could do was sit there and watch. Then 15 minutes later the skies got blue like it had never even happened.'' About 30 Guardsmen took up positions in the three affected communities overnight and 150 were to arrive later in the day to search for victims and provide security, said Col. Phil Becker, a National Guard brigade commander. At least four people were arrested for looting, and five others were taken into custody for interfering with rescuers, authorities said. ``I saw everything out there,'' said Will County Executive Charles Adelman. ``Refrigerators, TV sets, washing machines, cars stacked three high.'' The twisters _ experts were unsure exactly how many _ hit Joliet, 40 miles southwest of Chicago, neighboring Crest Hill, and Plainfield to the northwest. Crest Hill Mayor Don Randich was among the first firefighters to arrive at the apartment complex. ``There were people wandering around, dazed,'' he said. ``Automobile horns were blowing, but there was no one in the cars. It was total confusion.'' Martis said the bodies of nine people were found near the apartment complex. Seven bodies, including that of a 4-month-old baby, were lying in a cornfield, some of them 400 feet from their apartments, and two were found in a car nearby, Martis said. Rescuers went from apartment to apartment, throwing rubble off of the three-story buildings with shovels or just their hands. The death toll was unclear. There were 24 confirmed fatalities as of 8:30 a.m. today, and there may be 30 dead, said John Plunk, acting director of the Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Agency. The Red Cross said about 600 people left homeless were given shelter. Michael Hejka, 28, was at a friend's house in Plainfield, a community of 4,500, when the tornado hit. ``I saw trees bending, and I said to my buddy, `It's a tornado!''' Hejka said. ``I said, `Jump into the bathtub.' He jumped in, and I jumped in right on top of him. The whole house lifted up, and then came down.'' Plainfield High School was demolished and some of the 175 students and teachers inside were hurt. Catastrophe was averted because coaches rushed dozens of athletes from a gym before the roof collapsed. ``We had some very short warnings,'' said teacher Steve Schernerhorn. ``We immediately took cover.'' Teacher Mike Salisburg said cars in the parking lot were thrown hundreds of yards. Will County is part of a frequently hit ``tornado alley.'' A tornado hit Plainfield Township in 1984, injuring six people and demolishing 14 homes. In 1976, a twister hit Lemont, 10 miles from Plainfield, killing three people and injuring as many as 40. That tornado damaged 375 houses and businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Health Board Drops Crack House Crackdown Rule
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to declare crack cocaine houses health hazards has been dropped and a regulation requiring health and safety plans for them has been repealed by the King County Health Board. After nine months of grappling with the issue, the panel voted 2-1 Tuesday to leave enforcement of cocaine and other drug laws to police. Board member Greg Nickels, who also serves on the County Council, said anti-crack regulations ``put the Health Department in this (law enforcement) role, I believe, inappropriately.'' He said health inspectors lack the training, experience and temperament to do police work. The regulation requiring crack house health plans was proposed in December. It was adopted Jan. 3, shortly before a change in board membership, and took effect July 1. But it never was enforced, largely because of concern that it gave the appearance of sanctioning illegal drug operations. Prosecutors drafted extensive amendments to establish a civil process for declaring premises where crack cocaine is made, sold or used to be health hazards. The declaration made owners and operators subject to heavy fines, closure and potential loss of the property. Assuming adequate police drug enforcement efforts, the health hazard plan would ``give us two stones at one bird,'' said deputy prosecutor John Cobb. ``I think the board felt at the time we should use whatever tools we have to fight crack houses,'' Hill said. The regulation drew fire from civil rights advocates and advocates for low-income renters and the homeless at a July 24 hearing. Opponents noted that health inspectors could enter a dwelling or apartment house without a search warrant and, if they found drugs, the landlord could evict everyone, including law-abiding occupants who might lack access to other housing. Authorities said they never expected to get health and safety plans but hefty fines for failure to file the plans would be a means to attack crack houses. Landlords, tenants and others found responsible could have faced fines as high as $1,000 for each day a crack house remained in operation. The proposals would not have affected Seattle, where police have relied on a state law allowing civil abatement proceedings to close and condemn crack houses after owners fail to end drug operations.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Officials Expect Iraqi Move Toward Kuwait Autonomy
With Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is expected to declare federated self-rule for Kuwait in a bid to ease the gulf crisis and the United States to withdraw in partial victory, senior Arab military officials said Wednesday. The idea, already floated to the Soviet Union and the United States, the sources said, may figure in talks Thursday between Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar in Amman. The officials, who spoke on the understanding that neither they nor their countries be identified, said Saddam was likely to announce the move before the end of September. Under a plan being considered, they said, Kuwait might have autonomy _ perhaps with a bloc of parliament seats and positions in the Iraqi national Cabinet. Saddam would accept a timetable and conditions to protect U.S. interests in the Persian Gulf, the sources said. Such a plan would have little appeal to the Kuwaiti government now in exile in Saudi Arabia. Saddam's centralized government is not likely to allow much political or economic leeway. According to the officials' analysis, neither Saddam nor President Bush can withdraw from the lines they have drawn in the desert sand. Both are buying time until some flexibility can be found. Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Six days later, Saddam annexed Kuwait despite universal condemnation and an American military buildup in Saudi Arabia. On Aug. 28, he declared Kuwait as Iraq's 19th province. The officials said Iraq was still working on the details of its federation plan which, presumably, would provide a different statute for Kuwait. The idea was passed to Soviet officials who, in turn, relayed it to Washington, the Arab sources said. Perez de Cuellar is expected to sound out Aziz and report to Washington. ``Iraq's move will take some time,'' one official said. ``But there should be a surprise from Baghdad in three to four weeks.'' Bush has repeatedly rejected out of hand any solution but the withdrawal of Iraqi forces and restoration of the Kuwaiti government. U.S. officials have made no public acknowledgement of flexibility. But the Arab sources said that privately the Americans are looking for some compromise which would make their point, assure stability in the gulf oilfields and allow an honorable disengagement. ``The Americans must bear in mind that Iraq will never let go of Kuwait,'' one official said. If no solution could be negotiated, the others agreed, Kuwait would have to be retaken by force. The officials considered the next three weeks to be crucial to Washington. U.S. forces can wait until late September when desert temperatures cool; when more units and heavy weapons, particularly tanks, arrive; and when troops are acclimatized to the terrain. But after that, Saddam's message of Arab unity, along with his linking of Kuwait to the Israeli-occupied territories, will bolster his support in the Arab world. Facing off a superpower would impress the undecided in the Arab world. Saddam's strategy appears to be that the longer he can be seen to be defying, single-handedly, the United States' military might, the more he will be viewed as the champion of the Arabs. Diplomatic sources and intelligence officials in Amman Wednesday reported that pro-Saddam demonstrations had even erupted in Syria, Iraq's long-time Arab rival. The senior military officials agreed that if Bush does not strike by the end of September, his administration will be seen to have failed in a dramatic attempt to rescue Kuwait. They felt that Bush is reluctant to test Iraq's ability to counter-attack. ``All diplomatic moves are pushing this way,'' one senior source said. ``All parties have the conviction that they should not escalate tension in the gulf while they explore for a peaceful solution.'' Iraq offered a form of autonomy to the Kurdish territory of northern Iraq in 1970. If the Kurdish experience is any model, federation within Iraq would require difficult bargaining, the officials acknowledged. Iraq's 3.5 million Kurds have bitterly resisted rule from Baghdad for decades. The Kurds accepted autonomy, with some parliament seats and positions in the national Cabinet. But two years later, the Kurds accused Baghdad of reneging and fighting broke out again. Saddam, then vice president and strongman of the regime, offered only limited autonomy. Full-scale guerrilla warfare broke out in 1974. It was crushed a year later when Iran withdrew its support of the Kurds in exchange for rights in the Shatt-al-Arab waterway on the border with Iraq. In 1980, the Kurds aided Iran in its with Iraq. After the August 1988 cease-fire, Saddam's army killed thousands of Kurds with poison gas.

DOC.HEAD: Champion for Disabled Fights for Own Life After Arson Fire
DOC.TEXT: A paraplegic who fought for years to protect the disabled was hospitalized after a fire that authorities said was started on the wheelchair ramp he needed to get to his door. James Lundvall, 46, was found unconscious in the front bedroom of his smoke-filled duplex early Tuesday after neighbors saw flames. He was in critical condition at Porter Memorial Hospital, suffering from smoke inhalation. Fire investigators believe Lundvall was a random victim of an arsonist who poured gasoline on the 40-foot wooden wheelchair ramp at the back of the duplex, then ignited it. Whoever set the fire ``kept pouring all the way down the ramp. They doused it,'' said Fire Capt. Gregory Taft. The back of Lundvall's home caught fire and smoke spread quickly because interior doors had been removed to allow Lundvall to move through the house in his electric wheelchair. ``It doesn't appear he ever woke up,'' said Taft. Taft said a car was set afire about six blocks away earlier in the morning, and investigators were checking for possible links. Lundvall was disabled by an auto accident when he was a teen-ager. He has only limited use of his arms, cannot speak and communicates with a word board. His girlfriend, Debbie Tracy, was killed several weeks ago when her wheelchair was struck by a car. Lundvall has been a champion for the rights of the disabled, participating in a lawsuit to win the right to live independently, and in demonstrations across the country to gain handicapped access to transportation and other services. ``He's been a fighter,'' said Wade Blank, a longtime friend and co-director of the Atlantis Community, an advocacy group for the disabled. Blank recalled that Lundvall pulled his wheelchair in front of a bus during a 1978 demonstration in Denver and crawled up the steps of the nation's capital earlier this year to support the rights of the disabled. Lundvall was bothered by youths who stole his television set about a year ago, but had no recent problems with crime, Blank said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Tells Legionnaires Iraqi Lawlessness Shows Need for U.S. Strength
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Quayle speech. Picks up 6th graf, `Willie M. McLaughlin...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait proves that the world remains a dangerous place despite the reduction of East-West tensions, Vice President Dan Quayle told veterans at the American Legion national convention today. ``As the Cold War comes to an end, the Free World may be less burdened with fighting communist aggression. But there's a new evil: lawlessness and terrorism,'' Quayle said. Quayle called Iraq ``an outrageous violator of decency and civilized international behavior.'' ``And it falls to America to play a critical role, an indispensible role in upholding global standards of civility and decency.'' Quayle urged congressional support for increased military spending ``because only a strong America can help bring peace to the world.'' Quayle, a former senator from Indiana whose National Guard service during the Vietnam War became a campaign liability, was greeted warmly by the Legionnaires. They interrupted his speech frequently with applause. On the opening day Tuesday of the weeklong 72nd American Legion convention, participants said the GIs sent to the Persian Gulf are better trained and equipped than ever and have greater public support than at any time since World War II. ``We've got the world on our side as well as the American public,'' said John Brieden, a 40-year-old Vietnam-era veteran from Brenham, Texas. Brieden said the issues surrounding the Persian Gulf crisis are better understood than those of Vietnam. ``As a result of that, they are supporting the current position,'' he said. ``During World War II everyone was behind the GI, more than in Korea or Vietnam,'' said Dick Carrignan, 72, of Fitchburg, Mass., a paratrooper in France and Germany during World War II. ``People can see why we're going there just the same as in World War II.'' Willie M. McLaughlin, a 63-year-old Korean War veteran from Greenwood, S.C., said troops today are professional soldiers with at least a high school education, while in Korea many draftees were in boot camp just a few weeks before seeing action. ``They are more mobile now. They can get into action much quicker,'' said George Cornish, a 61-year-old Korean War veteran from Canandaigua, N.Y. Several vets drew an analogy between the current deployment and World War II, arguing that in both cases an aggressive nation had to be held in check. ``In the beginning of World War II there were isolationists who didn't want for us to get into it,'' said former seaman Richard Ramage, 65, of Franklin, N.J. ``Now, I think probably a lesson was learned. We waited then and had to mobilize that much quicker to go and stop Hitler.'' The veterans expressed optimism that diplomacy would settle the conflict. ``I just hope they don't jump in too fast and pull the trigger too soon,'' said Cornish.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Stalled in July
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge stalled in July, indicating to analysts that the nation might have been limping toward recession even before the Middle East crisis. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators was unchanged after posting a barely perceptible 0.1 percent gain in June. The index is designed to forecast economic conditions six months to nine months in the future. ``Essentially, it's another indication of a slumping economy,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a new York securities company. ``In all likelihood, it'll be down sharply next month,'' reflecting the oil price shock and uncertainty caused by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said that while the July figures don't point to a recession, ``the sharp rise in world oil prices has made a downturn almost inevitable.'' Three successive declines in the index have often _ but not always _ signaled a recession in the past. However, some economists believe the economy already is in a recession. In a second report illustrating the weakness in the economy, the department said new home sales in July posted their fifth decline in seven months, down 2.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 548,000 units. New home sales so far this year are 12.4 percent below those of the first seven months of 1989. Only three of the 11 indicators in the leading index made positive contributions: an increase in orders for new plants and equipment, an increase in the price of raw materials and an index measuring consumer confidence. Analysts said the consumer confidence component, which is compiled by the University of Michigan, would plummet in the August index. ``Initial reports ... indicate that the consumer's first reaction to the Iraqi invasion was near panic,'' said economist Mark M. Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and economists worry that a major cutback could halt economic growth altogether and push the nation into recession. Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, noted that plant and equipment orders, one of the positive indicators, usually are a barometer of business investment plans. ``The question now is, how much of that will be held down now by not knowing what's going to happen and being unwilling to make decisions?'' he asked. Economist Richards suggested that ``because capital is energy-intensive, the oil price shock points to some scaling back of investment spending.'' Negative contributors were: faster business delivery times, a decline in the money supply, a drop in manufacturers' unfilled orders, a shorter average work week, a drop in building permits, an increase in weekly unemployment claims and a decline in the stock market. Daryl Delano of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said stock prices had continued to decline since the Iraqi invasion and, noting lackluster home sales, said building permits would remain a negative in the August report. One of the July components, orders for consumer goods, was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 146.1 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and up 1.4 percent from its level a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Sandy, Annie's Dog in Broadway Production, Dies at 16
DOC.TEXT: Sandy, the stray mutt that was rescued from the pound and went on to star in the Broadway smash ``Annie,'' died Wednesday in his sleep. He was 16, or 112 in dog years. Sandy, a mix of Airedale and Irish setter, originated the role of Annie's faithful dog in the Goodspeed Opera House's 1976 production in Connecticut. He then played the entire Broadway run, from 1977 to 1983, said William Berloni, Sandy's owner and trainer. It was Berloni, then an 18-year-old apprentice at the Goodspeed with no experience as an animal trainer, who rescued Sandy from the Connecticut Humane Society the day before the animal was to be put to sleep. Berloni had been told to find a dog for the production. After looking at 500 dogs he found Sandy and bought him for $8. ``He had been abused, he was frightened of people,'' Berloni said. ``So when we treated him with kindness and love and affection, he really responded. That made him easy to train.'' Sandy won the hearts of theatergoers as the dog that befriends Annie after she runs away from an orphanage. The two are separated and spend much of the musical looking for each other until they are reunited for a happy ending. ``It's interesting how one animal touched so many lives,'' Berloni said. ``People liked to believe in fun things and Annie and Sandy, wherever they went, really brought a lot of joy to people.'' Sandy had to perform more than 20 stunts during the show, including barking on a hand signal to protect Annie from the police and walking across the stage by himself, looking left and right in search of Annie. After the show closed, Sandy retired to Connecticut, but made occasional guest appearances. Sandy suffered in recent years from degenerative arthritis and bone spurs on his spine that brought on paralysis and general weakness. ``Working dogs ... when they can't do their jobs any more, they really give up and die,'' Berloni said. ``He decided his time was up.''

DOC.HEAD: AM-Arts Lawsuit,590
Lawsuit Charges NEA With Subsidizing Anti-Religious Art
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer sued the National Endowment for the Arts on Wednesday, alleging that its $15,000 grant for an artist's controversial exhibition displayed ``open and notorious hostility toward religion'' and violated the Constitution. The lawsuit was filed against the NEA and its chairman, John E. Frohnmayer, in U.S. District Court by the Rutherford Institute, a non-profit legal services organization, on behalf of David Fordyce. Fordyce, a lawyer, was described as a ``devout Christian'' from Los Angeles. The suit cited the NEA's grant last year for ``Tongues of Flame,'' an exhibit of works by David Wojnarowicz of New York that was organized by University Galleries at Illinois State University. The Fordyce suit alleged that the NEA-supported catalog for the Wojnarowicz show includes an image depicting Jesus Christ as an intravenous drug user. It said the catalogue also refers to Roman Catholic Cardinal John O'Connor of New York as a ``fat cannibal'' and ``the world's most active liar about condoms and safer sex.'' Fordyce said NEA support for the catalog conveys ``a message of hate and animosity toward institutionalized religion'' sponsored by the federal government in violation of the First Amendment's provision for separation of church and state. He asked the court for a permanent injunction prohibiting the arts endowment from ``funding, sponsoring and endorsing works which promote blasphemous and sacrilegious hate material.'' The endowment, an independent, $171 million federal agency that underwrites a wide variety of artists and arts organizations, had no immediate comment on the lawsuit. The NEA is embroiled in a controversy over art, obscenity and freedom of expression stemming from allegations by religious fundamentalists and conservative lawmakers led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that it has subsidized obscene and sacrilegious works. The endowment already is the target of two other federal lawsuits in New York and Los Angeles challenging Frohnmayer's requirement that grant recipients sign a pledge of compliance with a congressional ban on using federal funds for works that may be deemed obscene. Wojnarowicz could not be reached by telephone for comment. But Barry Blinderman, director of the Illinois gallery, accused the lawsuit's sponsors of ``hypocrisy'' and angrily defended the artist's work against charges of sacrilege. ``Before these people condemn the NEA, they should remember that it was the so-called holy men who didn't accept Christ and turned him in,'' Blinderman said. ``Jesus said `judge not,' and I recommend that these people follow the precepts of the God they are proclaiming.'' The ``Tongues of Flame'' exhibit opened at Blinderman's gallery earlier this year and is now appearing at the Santa Monica Museum of Art in California. John W. Whitehead, founder and president of the Rutherford Institute, told a news conference here that the NEA had ``unconstitutionally used taxpayers' funds to engage in actions which are hostile toward religion and religious persons.'' ``The government should not become the patron of hate art against some of its citizens,'' Whitehead said. ``Religious people must no longer be the personal targets of cannon fire from National Endowment projects.'' Wojnarowicz previously had filed a federal lawsuit in New York against the Rev. Donald Wildmon and his conservative American Family Association. In late June, a New York federal judge ruled that Wildmon's group probably had misrepresented Wojnarowicz's works by including fragments of them in a pamphlet titled ``Your Tax Dollars Helped Pay for These `Works of Art'.'' The judge said the pamphlets, which were mailed to members of Congress, religious leaders and media outlets, probably had damaged the artist's reputation and the value of his works. He issued an injunction forbidding further publication of the pamphlet.

DOC.HEAD: Those Who Have Homes Left After Fire Can Return Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with fire contained, new acreage, firefighter totals. Picks up 6th graf ``Power has...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HBX1
DOC.TEXT: Residents of an area swept by a man-caused blaze that killed two firefighters can return to their homes today, but they still will be without power. About 300 homes near this alpine community 30 miles east of Salt Lake City had to be evacuated because of the Wasatch Mountain fire, which destroyed 19 homes and burned through a 2,970-acre area. Andy Gray, Bureau of Land Management fire information officer, said 680 firefighters completed fire lines around the blaze this morning. The fire was expected to be declared officially under control by 8 p.m. ``We're looking real good,'' said John Shive, incident commander of the Interagency Fire Team coordinating firefighting efforts. ``You're still going to see smoke up there for a few days, but we're in good shape.'' Power has been off to the Swiss Oaks area since Sunday and will likely remain off for another week, although Utah Power & Light Co. has more than 250 workers in the area, Shive said. The fire, propelled by 60 mph winds, exploded in tinder-dry oak brush and pine trees Sunday afternoon. Shive said investigators believe an ember from a smaller blaze _ ignited by an apparently illegal campfire _ drifted over fire lines and started the deadly inferno. Officials have not determined who started the blaze. Sheriff's Deputy Blake Wright, 39, and county road crew worker Ralph Broadhead, 65, died Sunday night when apparently overcome by smoke as they were building a fire break on a ridge. Funerals for the two men will be Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: NASA to Get Outside Advice on Long-term Space Effort
DOC.TEXT: Some of the biggest names in the U.S. space program have been named as senior members of a group developing a strategy for long-term American involvement in space. Thomas P. Stafford, a retired Air Force lieutenant general and former astronaut who flew four missions in space, heads the Synthesis Group which is screening ideas from the general public, science and industry for new and more efficient ways to explore and use space. He was named to the job by NASA, which has come under pressure to seek outside advice for its long-range plans. Among the 22 senior members whose names Stafford announced Wednesday are retired Lt. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, former director of the Strategic Defense Initiative; Edward C. Aldridge Jr., former Secretary of the Air Force; Chris Kraft, a major NASA figure in the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programs and Eugene Covert, a member of the Challenger commission. The group was formed to explore alternative ways of meeting President Bush's goal of establishing a permanent manned base on the moon and sending missions to Mars. ``The president's Space Exploration Initiative is really a manifesto for this nation in the next century,'' Stafford told a news conference. ``Through an extensive SEI outreach program, creative ideas on how best to approach the space frontier have been gathered.'' The Bush proposal did not fare well in its first test in Congress. The House, in approving NASA's 1991 appropriations bill, eliminated the entire $309 million requested by the administration for its moon-Mars plans. The vote was 355 to 48. Stafford said the group, which will be broken up into teams, expects to make its recommendations next February to NASA administrator Richard Truly.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Of Saddam Supporters Reported Killed In Syria
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Syrian military forces killed dozens of demonstrators backing Saddam Hussein in protests near the Iraqi border, Arab diplomats and security sources reported Wednesday. As many as 50,000 troops were deployed along the Iraq-Syria border after the army quelled violent protests Sunday and Monday, according to officials who spoke on condition they not be named. Crowds of Syrians poured into the streets of eastern towns Sunday to protest President Hafez Assad's stand against Iraq, the sources said. A Syrian information ministry official, reached by telephone from Amman, denied there were any demonstrations and said he had no knowledge of troop movements. He declined to be named. The outbreaks of violence in Syria could become a threat to Assad, a former air force commander who seized power in November 1970. Assad and Saddam have waged an ideological feud for more than a decade. Syria and Iraq are ruled by rival wings of the Baath Socialist Party. During the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, Assad was Tehran's main Arab ally. Diplomats and Arab officials in Amman said their embassies in Damascus, the capital of neighboring Syria, reported scattered uprisings. ``Troops tried all day to stop the demonstrations and reports from our Damascus embassy said tens of people were killed,'' one Arab diplomat said. Others reported similar death tolls. Demonstrators surged into the streets, carrying huge portraits of Saddam, chanting slogans and waving Iraqi flags, the reports said. Some demanded separation from Syria to merge with Iraq. Eastern Syria is predominantly Sunni Moslem. Assad and most of his ruling faction are from the minority Alawite sect, centered in western Syria. The rioting is believed to be the worst violence in Syria since Assad crushed a Moslem Brotherhood uprising in Hama, north of Damascus, in 1982. Tanks ringed Hama and pounded it, razing much of the ancient city and killing thousands. During the Hama violence, Syrian officials flatly denied any disturbances until four days after riots began and the death toll was already in the hundreds. Following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2, Assad sent at least 1,100 troops to join an Arab force gathering in Saudi Arabia to protect the kingdom. Assad postponed a scheduled trip to Egypt on Sunday without explanation, but flew to Alexandria Tuesday for a day of talks with President Hosni Mubarak. Travelers from Syria reported tensions were high, but none who had visited the turbulent eastern part of the country would confirm reports of violence. ``I know nothing. I can't say anything,'' one trucker said, hurrying away, visibly frightened.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Turned Down Prize Honda Gets Third Chrysler
DOC.TEXT: Cars keep rolling in for a Chrysler Corp. employee whose loyalty to organized labor led her to refuse to accept a Honda she won on a televised lottery game. Pamela Richards, of Risingsun, Ohio, got the keys Tuesday to a white, 1990 Plymouth Acclaim from Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz. That's the third Chrysler product she's gotten as a result of her rejection. Ms. Richards, an employee of Chrysler subsidiary Toledo Precision Machining, won a $17,000 Honda Accord as part of a televised Ohio lottery game earlier this month. But she said: ``I don't want that Honda. I am union.'' Honda Accords are made in Marysville, Ohio, by workers unaffiliated with any labor union. Since then, the AFL-CIO has given her a Dodge Dakota pickup truck and a Chrysler-Plymouth dealership in Huntington, W.Va., loaned her a Chrysler Imperial to use for a year.

DOC.HEAD: Daughter of Timothy Leary Found Unfit For Trial
DOC.TEXT: The daughter of 1960s LSD guru Timothy Leary was again ruled incompetent to stand trial for attempted murder in the 1988 shooting of her sleeping boyfriend. Superior Court Judge Terry Smerling said Tuesday that Susan Martino, 42, was unable to understand the charges against her and committed her to a state psychiatric hospital until she could be found fit. In 1989, a judge found Martino unable to stand trial on the charges. She could be held for up to 14 years if she does not recover. Martino, also known as Susan Leary, was charged with shooting Joel Ruben Chavira in the back of the head as he took a nap on a couch in their apartment in Glendale, about 10 miles north of Los Angeles. She has pleaded innocent. Chavira has said that he awoke to a loud explosion in the back of his head on Dec. 18, 1988. He felt blood and the went into the kitchen and confronted Martino who was holding a gun. Deputy District Attorney Carol Rash said Wednesday that Chavira underwent skull reconstruction and was released from the hospital about a month after the attack. She said he was not left seriously disabled. At the time of the shooting, Timothy Leary issued a statement saying: ``I am extremely distressed about this tragic event. I am praying for the young man's continued recovery.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Johnny Depp, baby-faced star of TV's ``21 Jump Street,'' has signed a multipicture development deal with 20th Century Fox for projects in which he will star and produce. ``After starring in a hit series for Fox Television and in `Edward Scissorhands,' a film we're over the moon about, Johnny Depp is officially joining Fox's creative family,'' Roger Birnbaum of 20th Century Fox said Tuesday. Depp also starred in Universal's ``Cry Baby,'' director John Waters' spoof of juvenile delinquency. In the 20th Century Fox film ``Edward Scissorhands,'' directed by Tim Burton and scheduled for Christmas release, Depp plays a boy-creature who has sharp metal shears for hands. His past movie credits include ``A Nightmare on Elm Street,'' ``Platoon'' and ``Slow Burn.''

The Rap group Public Enemy released a video with actual footage of the violence at last year's Greekfest riots just in time for this year's Laborfest. And city officials aren't happy about it. The video version of the song ``Brothers Gonna' Work It Out'' shown on MTV last week ``has grossly misrepresented what Virginia Beach is trying to do relative to Laborfest,'' city spokeswoman Pam Lingle said Tuesday. ``In fact, it is a disservice to the many black people who are working so hard to make Laborfest 1990 an enjoyable experience,'' she said. The festival is planned for Labor Day weekend. The video showed staged scenes of actors portraying ``redneck'' state troopers and ``insensitive'' bureaucrats with footage of police kicking and clubbing blacks. It does not show the rioting and looting by young blacks that preceded the police action, city officials said.

Chet Atkins believes he may have influenced fellow guitarist Mark Knopfler, formerly with Dire Straits and now with the Notting Hillbillies. Atkins, 66, known as ``Mr. Guitar,'' said Tuesday he noticed it after listening to one of Knopfler's albums. ``I thought, `I believe he's heard me a time or two.' He phrased similar.'' After that, the two performed together in London and elsewhere and have just teamed up on an album, ``Neck and Neck,'' due for release next month.

A recent Beach Boys benefit concert not only fell far short of its expectations to raise money for the hurricane-stricken Isle of Palms Fire Department, but firefighters say it almost put them in debt. Fire Chief Larry Britton said Tuesday he initially had hoped the Sunday event would raise at least $50,000, now he's happy they didn't lose money. They'll probably make about $1,500, he said. If the group had been able to perform on the beach, things might have been better. Organizers blamed the poor turnout partly on Mayor Carmen Bunch, who refused to allow the Beach Boys to play in Isle of Palms, citing the traffic headaches the concert would cause. The concert was held about 20 miles inland, at Ladson. Ms. Bunch said Tuesday she wished she had never heard of The Beach Boys. She said the event was not worth all the turmoil, and believes islanders couldn't afford the tickets. ``It was risky business to begin with,'' she said.

Moviegoers know actress Kym Karath as one of the Von Trapp kids in ``The Sound of Music,'' but living room video buffs might not be acquainted with her. ``The girl at the edge was always cut off (in the video version), and I was always on the edge,'' said Miss Karath, who played Gretl Von Trapp a quarter-century ago. Five actors who played Von Trapp youngsters joined last week for ``The Sound of Music'' 25th anniversary celebration and a big screen redo. ``It's thrilling to think that my children are going to see the movie'' in theaters, said Heather Menzies, who played Louisa Von Trapp. ``There's a couple of generations of people who haven't seen it the way it should be seen.'' Participants in the movie family reunion included Duane Chase, Charmain Carr and Debbie Turner as well as Miss Karath and Miss Menzies. Angela Cartwright and Nicholas Hammond couldn't make the reunion.

DOC.HEAD: Arab-American Organization Petitions For Release Of Hostages In Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A major Arab-American organization began a nationwide petition campaign Wednesday urging Saddam Hussein to release all foreign nationals being held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait. James Abourezk, chairman of the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, said he hoped to personally present the petition to the Iraqi president in Baghdad. Abourezk, a former senator from South Dakota, said the Iraqi Embassy in Washington had not replied to the committee's request to send a delegation to Baghdad.
