He said he didn't know whether the petition would sway Saddam to release foreign hostages, ``but it would be remiss on our part not to try.'' The appeal says the release of those held against their will would lessen the ``extreme tension'' in the Middle East and could lead to a resolution of the crisis. ADC's Washington headquarters is sending the petition to all 25,000 of its members in 70 nationwide chapters. It hopes to obtain tens of thousands of signatures from Arab-Americans and other American citizens. There are about 2.5 million people of Arab origins in the United States. Iraq has detained thousands of foreigners, including about 3,000 Americans, since its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Some of the foreigners have been moved to key installations to act as human shields against an attack from the United States or other foreign forces. The petition campaign coincides with the group's efforts to combat what it calls a disturbing increase in anti-Arab discrimination in the United States since the gulf crisis began. The committee has chronicled several dozen cases of Arab-Americans being threatened or attacked in the United States. It also blamed the media, particularly radio talk shows, for stirring up anti-Arab sentiments through racist or discriminatory remarks. ``We are trying to do away with an incredible amount of stereotyping and racism,'' said Abdeen Jabara, outgoing committee president.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Fundamentalists Urge Iraqi Withdrawal from Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The main fundamentalist Moslem movement in the occupied territories on Wednesday urged Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, saying that Palestinians ``are aware more than others of the meaning of losing a homeland.'' It was the strongest anti-Iraq statement to date in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians have shown strong support for Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein since his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The appeal came in a leaflet issued by the Hamas, or ``zeal,'' movement. In a separate leaflet, the underground leadership of the Palestinian uprising repeated its opposition to the deployment of U.S. forces in the gulf. The underground leaders, backed by the Palestine Liberation Organization, urged Saddam ``not to respond to provocations or take measures that could be seen as reasons for (the U.S.) launching an aggression against Iraq.'' Both leaflets called for the withdrawal of foreign forces from the gulf and their replacement by Arab peacekeepers. The position taken by Hamas was a shift from its last leaflet, which focused on aggression by ``America and all its devilish allies'' but said nothing about Iraq's move against Kuwait. Moslem fundamentalists here, who want an Islamic state, are wary of Saddam because he has been an advocate of secularism. Hamas has been a leading force in the nearly 33-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. In its latest leaflet, Hamas said: ``We are aware more than others of the meaning of losing a homeland and the pains of exile. We are aware of the agony of the Moslem Kuwaiti people.'' The leaflet called for Kuwaiti self-determination along with negotiations to resolve Iraqi-Kuwaiti tensions. ``Any solution must include the withdrawal of foreign forces from the region and the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait,'' Hamas said. Meanwhile, Israel's Interior Ministry banned Palestinian professor Ghassan Khatib from traveling abroad. Khatib, an economist at the West Bank's Bir Zeit University, was the fourth Palestinian blocked from attending a convention in Switzerland on grounds it would endanger Israeli security. ``I think this is part of new restrictions they (Israel's government) are using right now, taking advantage of the gulf crisis to put more pressures on Palestinians,'' Khatib said. ``They know the world is focused on the gulf and will not pay any attention to their measures.'' Also Wednesday, the body of a Palestinian suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities was found near his home in the Tulkarem refugee camp in the West Bank. The victim was identified by Arab reporters as Faisal Mansuri, 35. The death raised to 254 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs in the uprising. At least 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 47 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Police Disperse Marches; Three More Die in Township Violence
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 7 grafs to update with report that ANC leader took part in talks, comments from Buthelezi. Pickup 5th pvs, `The violence...
DOC.TEXT: Police used birdshot, batons and tear gas Wednesday to disperse student marches against fighting in black townships. Three blacks died in new violence, raising the toll to 518 in less than three weeks. Also Wednesday, delegations linked to the African National Congress and the conservative Inkatha movement met in Natal Province to discuss the violence, according to news reports. The independent South Africa Press Association reported a member of the ANC's national executive committee, Jacob Zuma, took part. Inkatha, who are supported by the Zulus, have been at war with ANC-affiliated groups since the mid-1980s in Natal. Battles erupted in the townships around Johannesburg on Aug. 12. Low-level delegations from Inkatha and the ANC have met previously, but ANC leaders have refused to meet Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. They contend Inkatha spread the conflict to the Johannesburg area this month to broaden its constituency. Inkatha accuses the ANC of terrorizing other black opposition groups to try to consolidate power. Inkatha and the ANC both oppose apartheid, South Africa's system of racial separation, but they differ on ways to fight it. Buthelezi reiterated his call Wednesday for a meeting with ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela. He also said in a statement the ANC should end, instead of merely suspending, its armed struggle and stop calling for sanctions to push South Africa to end apartheid. The violence around Johannesburg has eased markedly since the initial days of fighting, when dozens of blacks were killed daily. But protests against the fighting and allegations of police bias toward Inkatha have continued. In Cape Town on Wednesday, police fired tear gas and birdshot at students from the University of the Western Cape, near Cape Town, who were protesting the recent violence, witnesses said. Police Maj. Gys Boonzaaier told the independent South Africa Press Association the students were throwing rocks at police and passing vehicles. Separate protests against the fighting also were held in Johannesburg and Pretoria. Police used batons and tear gas to disperse a march by students from the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, SAPA reported. Forty-six students were arrested and two police officers slightly injured, police said. Later, students from several organizations held a protest along a downtown street to protest the police action. Riot police in Pretoria halted a march by students of the Medical Univerity of South Africa, police and the university's rector said. The students said they had not sought permission for the march. In the township violence, two men were hacked to death and set alight at a migrant workers hostel in Tembisa, northeast of Johannesburg, while another died at a hostel in Katlehong, southeast of the city, police said. Some anti-apartheid leaders have blamed police for fueling the fighting in the townships. President F.W. de Klerk told Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu and other church leaders Tuesday he would investigate charges that police sided with Inkatha. De Klerk has previously said individual officers may have acted improperly but that the police force as a whole followed orders to be impartial.

DOC.HEAD: Zinc Research Could Help Develop AIDS Drugs
DOC.TEXT: A chemist says he has determined that zinc plays a key role in the spread of the AIDS virus, which could lead to a vaccine or drugs to combat the disease. Michael Summers, a chemistry professor at the University of Maryland Baltimore County, said Tuesday he had found that zinc is the glue that binds one protein critical to the virus' duplication to the genetic material that makes the virus infectious. Zinc is present in the body. If researchers can develop a drug that alters, eliminates or masks the zinc, the infectious material won't exist when new virus cells are formed, Summers told reporters. ``This research has important implications for the development of an AIDS vaccine,'' Summers said. He said healthy people could be injected with non-infectious virus to make them develop an immunity to the infectious form. He emphasized that a vaccine was still a long way off, but said the research provides another avenue for pharmaceutical companies developing drugs against AIDS. Summers' findings were published Tuesday in Biochemistry, a weekly journal of the American Chemical Society. He said the results are similar to those that led to the development of the AIDS-fighting drug AZT. AIDS attacks the body's immune system, rendering it helpless to fight disease. A biochemist at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine agreed that the findings are an important, albeit small, step. ``It really does present a new avenue of research which had been at least underappreciated if not completely unrecognized,'' said Jeremy Berg, who suggested zinc as a molecular glue in certain viruses four years ago. Wayne Koff, an AIDS vaccine researcher at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., called the findings interesting. ``In addition to potentially being an approach for development of vaccines, this research has provided potentially another target for drug development,'' said Koff. Summers said scientists at the National Cancer Institute in Frederick have begun work on a drug based on his research, but cautioned that there's no known way to alter the zinc. Berg said that even if Summers' research leads to a vaccine, it may not be effective in all cases. ``There are so many different forms of the virus and it changes so quickly, even if you were immune to one type of the virus, you probably wouldn't be immune to other types,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
State Department Says Iraqi Promise Step in Right Direction
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with State Department reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said today that Iraq's promise to allow all foreign women and children to leave the country is a ``significant step in the right direction'' if it is carried out. It said the Iraqi announcement could affect about 1,000 American women and children. ``This announcement of Saddam Hussein, if implemented, is a significant step in the right direction. We have heard statements like this before, and we hope Saddam Hussein will have the human decency to live up to his word,'' said department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. She said that about a third of the approximately 3,000 American citizens in Kuwait and Iraq are women and children. She said there are about 500 women in Kuwait, 25 of whom are pregnant; 350 children, ages 3 to 18; and 60 infants under 3 years of age. She did not have a precise breakdown for Iraq. Ms. Tutwiler said the United States would prefer that the Americans be evacuated via charter aircraft from Kuwait City and Baghdad. She spoke after the Iraq ambassador formally notified the State Department of Saddam's decision, announced Tuesday. Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat told reporters after meeting with department officials that the Americans will be allowed to leave through Jordan or Turkey but gave no timetable for their departure. ``It is not possible administratively that everybody go on the same day,'' Al-Mashat said. He said he did not know whether the Iraqi government would provide aircraft to facilitate the departures. Al-Mashat said once the United States gives assurances ``that they are not going to strike Iraq, and attack Iraq or aggress upon Iraq, then we are going to let even men out.'' In response, Ms. Tutwiler said the United States rejects the notion that ``there should be any conditions attached to the immediate safe departure of all foreign nationals, including Americans who wish to depart from Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Cult Leader Convicted, Wife Sentenced in Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Lundgren conviction; picks up 5th graf, ``I am ...'' ^By KRISTI UMBREIT
DOC.TEXT: A religious cult leader was convicted today of killing a family of five last year and burying them on a farm where his group lived. A Lake County Common Pleas Court jury deliberated three hours and 15 minutes before rendering the verdict against Jeffrey Lundgren. He showed no emotion when the verdict was read by Judge Martin O. Park. Lundgren could be sentenced to death. A sentencing date was not announced. Earlier today, Lundgren's wife was sentenced to five consecutive life prison terms for the murders that she blamed on her husband. Alice Lundgren, 39, appeared calm during her sentencing before Lake County Common Pleas Judge Paul H. Mitrovich. But outside the courtroom, with sheriff's deputies at her side, Mrs. Lundgren wept as she read a statement of remorse. ``I am not a cold-blooded murderer. He is,'' Mrs. Lundgren told reporters, referring to her husband. ``I, too, was numbered on the list (of intended victims),'' she said. ``I am not the `Angel of Death.' I am the mother of four.'' Mrs. Lundgren was convicted Aug. 1 on all counts against her _ five each of conspiracy and complicity to commit aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. Lundgren, 40, was charged with five counts each of aggravated murder and kidnapping in the deaths last year of Dennis Avery, his wife and three young daughters, whose bodies were found buried on the Lundgrens' rented farm in nearby Kirtland, 30 miles east of Cleveland. All five had been bound, gagged and shot to death, then dumped into a common grave. Their bodies, heaped with some personal belongings and debris, were found in early January. During her trial, Mrs. Lundgren testified that her husband sometimes hit her or threatened her by pointing a loaded gun to her head if she disputed him or balked at his orders. She also said Lundgren had spoken of killing the Averys, whom he criticized as being less zealous in cult beliefs, as a sacrifice so that cult members could see God. But she said she disregarded his talk ``because he'd come up with these wild-haired plans all the time and he didn't carry through.'' Three cult members who pleaded guilty in the case testified during her trial that Mrs. Lundgren got favors over the other cult women, by virtue of being the leader's wife, and that she urged the other women to obey him as a prophet. The prosecution said Mrs. Lundgren willfully helped her husband kill the Averys and should have warned authorities of his talk or told them after the fact. Lundgren had been a lay minister for the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, in Kirtland, but was defrocked in 1988 for inappropriate conduct and later formed his own sect, church officials said. The Lundgrens' 19-year-old son, Damon, also was among the 13 cult members arrested in January. He faces the same charges as his father and awaits trial.

DOC.HEAD: Preliminary Census Figures Released
DOC.TEXT: The United States has 245,837,683 residents, according to preliminary census figures released Wednesday. California was the most populous of the states. New York retained its grip on second place, with Texas a close third as the last four state population reports were made public. The new figures issued show both Illinois and Pennsylvania declining from 1980, to put Florida in fourth place. The reports for New York, Texas, Illinois and Pennsylvania completed the listing of all 50 states in the bureau's first round of population releases. New York was up slightly from 1980 to 17,626,586 while Texas jumped sharply to 16,824,665. Illinois dropped slightly to 11,325,247 and Pennsylvania also showed a decline over the decade, to 11,764,434. California's population was 29,279,015.

DOC.HEAD: FTC Says 'Consumers Beware'
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission warned consumers Wednesday to be leery of energy saving schemes, saying the public can be duped by get-rich proposals and devices claiming to save gasoline. ``Unscrupulous individuals often attempt to exploit situations like the present one by taking advantage of consumers,'' said FTC chairman Janet Steiger. The FTC was joined in the warning by the National Association of Attorneys General. Attorney General Mary Sue Terry of Virginia, president of the association, noted that with the Labor Day weekend ahead ``consumers should stay away from devices or fuel additives that claim to significantly increase fuel mileage.'' Rising energy prices and concern about future oil supplies is likely to unleash an array of fraudulent schemes ranging from the sale of phony gas-saving devices to oil and gas investment frauds, the FTC said. Among the things the FTC warned consumers about were: _ Phony investment schemes involving oil or gas partnerships, gold and silver mining or oil drilling that promise much higher rates of return than normally might be expected. ``When Wall Street is jittery, all kinds of investment scams appear,'' warned the FTC. _ Energy saving devices such as surge suppressors or furnace ``duty cyclers'' that may be costly without providing significant energy savings. _ Home improvement scams including the sale of improper solar energy systems, storm windows, siding or insulation. In some cases the promised energy savings may never be achieved, the agency said. ``If the savings claims appear unrealistic, they probably are,'' said the FTC. _ Gadgets or gasoline additives that are supposed to improve automobile mileage. ``None of these products has been found to significantly increase fuel economy,'' said the FTC. The agency suggested the best ways to save gasoline is to inflate tires to their proper pressure, remove excess weight from the car's trunk and make sure the car is properly tuned. It also advised against use of high octane gasoline unless it is recommended in the automobile manuel. Higher octane gasoline is more expensive and often does not improve car performance. The FTC also warned the public to be aware of telemarketing techniques that offer ``great bargains'' because of the oil crisis and reminded that calls to ``900'' numbers often cost from $2 to $45 a minute. ``Telemarketing techniques themselves are not deceptive, indeed, many reputable companies use them. But in the hands of unscrupulous individuals, they can hurt consumers,'' said the FTC.

DOC.HEAD: No Sign Yet of Women and Children Reportedly Freed by Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with State Department calling offer a step in the right direction. Pickup 2nd pvs, `Iraq's ambassador...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Jordan waited at the Iraqi border today to see if Saddam Hussein would make good on his promise to release Western women and children held in Iraq. The State Department called the Iraqi offer Tuesday a ``significant step in the right direction'' if it is carried out. It said the Iraqi announcement could affect about 1,000 American women and children. Iraq's ambassador to the United States today refused to give a timetable for their departure but said Iraq would also free the detained men after getting assurances from the United States that it would not attack. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk told reporters: ``I have no evidence ... indicating that people have been allowed to leave.'' The spokesman also refused to confirm or deny a report that the administration had received a message from the Iraqi president, offering to pull out his invading troops from Kuwait with conditions. In another development, OPEC voted to increase its oil production to make up for shortages caused by the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Japan promised to send money, medical personnel and non-military supplies to the Persian Gulf, but not soldiers, weapons or other military supplies. However, the aid package also will allow Japan to pay other countries chartering ships and planes to carry military cargo to the gulf. Thirteen people who were part of the U.S. mobilization died today when a giant C-5A cargo plane en route to the Persian Gulf region crashed on takeoff from Ramstein Air Base in West Germany. There were four survivors. President Bush today delivered a pep talk to U.S. troops broadcast over Armed Forces Radio. He said their assignment in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere in the gulf is ``one of the toughest military missions in modern memory.'' ``You stand on the front line against aggression and international lawlessness,'' Bush said. ``We have never sought conflict nor do we hope to chart a course for other nations, but at the hands of injustice in the face of aggression, ours is a once reluctant fist now clutched resolutely.'' Many in the region apparently did not immediately hear it because the radio network does not have a transmitter in Saudi Arabia. The only place it could be received there is at permanent U.S. barracks on Saudi military bases. Saddam announced Tuesday that the women and children among the thousands of foreigtn hostages in Iraq could leave today. However, no Western hostages had crossed the Jordanian border by mid-afternoon, and reports from Baghdad said their departure was stalled because they did not have the required exit visas. In Washington, Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat told reporters after meeting with State Department officials that the Americans will be allowed to leave through Jordan or Turkey but gave no timetable for their departure. Al-Mashat said once the United States gives assurances ``that they are not going to strike Iraq, and attack Iraq or aggress upon Iraq, then we are going to let even men out.'' A handful of Westerners today arrived from Baghdad on a Iraqi Airways flight to Amman, the Jordanian capital. But none appeared to belong to the hostage group of women and children who were told they are free to leave Iraq. Ambassador Roger Harrison traveled to the Jordanian border post of Ruweishid, 210 miles northeast of Amman, to supervise the reception of any American women and children arriving there, the embassy said. American diplomatic officials have manned the border round-the-clock for two weeks in case any U.S. hostages were freed. Harrison's presence suggested new arrivals were imminent. British officials told Iraq today they are ready to send aircraft to Baghdad to pick up Western women and children. But they also said they doubted the sincerity of Saddam's offer. ``It is a cat and mouse game _ now a little mercy, now some more ruthlessness,'' Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said in London. ``His purpose, as far as one can tell, is to keep the human shield policy but divert attention by little acts of mercy from the main and totally unacceptable policy.'' A senior Jordanian official at Ruweishid said by telephone that he expected a number of freed Westerners to pass through the border point today, but he was unsure when they might arrive. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today that Japan will not transport soldiers or weapons to the Persian Gulf, but he pledged money, medical personnel and non-military supplies. The assistance package, unveiled in a nationally televised speech, fell short of the aid sought by the United States. U.S. Ambassador to Japan Michael H. Armacost on Tuesday night had urged Tokyo to help transport soldiers and weapons. While Japanese craft would not be used to ferry military personnel or weapons, the package will allow payment to other nations chartering transportation carrying such cargo. The constitution Japan drew up with U.S. help after World War II bars Tokyo from sending troops overseas. In Vienna today, OPEC oil cartel ministers approved a deal permitting increased production by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and some other nations to help offset losses arising from the shortfall caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. The embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil removed about 4 millions barrels of oil a day from world markets, driving up the price of heating oil and gas. Meanwhile, the buildup of troops and hardware showed no sign of letup on either side of the Saudi-Kuwait border. The Pentagon said Iraqi troop strength in and around Kuwait has increased to 265,000, and dozens of heavy U.S. tanks arrived in Saudi Arabia on Tuesday and wheeled northward into the desert. On the diplomatic side, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar was to hold talks Thursday in Jordan with Iraq's foreign minister on the crisis that began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of oil-rich Kuwait. Saddam's promise to free all the foreign women and children came in a statement from Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council. The move came hours after Iraqi television showed Saddam meeting captive foreign families and hearing them express concern for their children. The official Iraqi News Agency said the decision was made ``to preserve the Arab humanitarian image.'' The Iraqi News Agency said the foreigners could leave starting today. It was not known how many women and children were among the hostages in Iraq or whether the decree also applies to foreigners in Kuwait. Saddam has detained 21,000 Westerners. About 3,000 Americans were in Kuwait and 500 in Iraq during the invasion, but an undetermined number have escaped. British and U.S. officials say Iraq has moved more than 150 Britons and more than 60 Americans from Kuwait to strategic locations for use as human shields against a possible attack. Iraq's troop strength in and near Kuwait has increased to 265,000 soldiers, supported by larger numbers of tanks and artillery, the Pentagon said Tuesday. ``There's been a general trend in the past several days of these numbers increasing,'' said Pete Williams, the Defense Department spokesman. Last week, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said 160,000 to 200,000 Iraqi troops were in Kuwait and southern Iraq together with an estimated 1,000 tanks. About 60,000 U.S. troops backed by dozens of planes and dozens of warships have assembled in the Persian Gulf region since the Iraqi invasion. It was unclear how many troops in the region heard Bush's message. Armed Forces Radio has some satellite receiver stations in the area, but they are not fully operational, Maj. Lon Oakley said from McDill Air Force Base in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Three Charged With Adultery in Connecticut
DOC.TEXT: Adultery charges have been filed against two women and a man in separate incidents in southeastern Connecticut. In New London, police arrested Bobbie Jo Johnson, 19, around dawn Tuesday, and charged her with adultery _ a misdemeanor punishable by up to one year in prison. Her husband, 32-year-old Clarence Johnson Jr., saw her ``involved with'' another man, according to the police report. Clarence Johnson was arrested earlier Tuesday morning on breach of peace charges in what police described as a domestic disturbance. Also Tuesday, Richard R. Wasik, 36, was charged in East Lyme. The woman with whom Wasik was allegedly involved, Debra J. Darling, 35, was arrested four hours later on the same charge, police said. Wasik's wife, Virginia B. Wasik, 32, filed the adultery complaints June 15, stating that her husband and Ms. Darling admitted to the affair. Ms. Wasik said the affair began in August 1989. She said she followed the couple to a house in Niantic, and then filed the complaint with East Lyme police. ``I just want to put our lives back together,'' she said. ``I feel bad I had to do this to him.'' The rarely enforced adultery law surfaced in June when Dawn Jakubowski, wife of Norwich Board of Education member James R. Jakubowski, was arrested on the charge. The case is pendin$2.5 billion through September. Japan pledged money, medical assistance and non-military supplies, but said it would not provide soldiers or weapons. _ The administration confirmed it had asked Congress to approve a $2.2 billion dollar arms sale to Saudi Arabia, including 24 F-15 warplanes, 150 M-60 A-3 tanks, 200 shoulder-fired Stinger missiles and 50 launchers and several thousand rounds of anti-tank ammunition. Other arms deals were being considered, the administration said. As for the proposed release of women and children, about 1,000 Americans could be affected. ``We hope Saddam Hussein will have the human decency to live up to his word,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. Popadiuk said, ``I have no evidence ... indicating that people have been allowed to leave.'' Yet, Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, went to the State Department to formally notify the United States of the decision to let women and children go. He said Americans will be allowed to leave through Jordan or Turkey, but gave no timetable for their departure. Al-Mashat said that once the United States gives assurances ``that they are not going to strike Iraq, and attack Iraq or aggress upon Iraq, then we are going to let even men out.'' From the Oval Office, Bush offered words of appreciation for the U.S. forces in the gulf. ``Our troops around the world are providing the kind of strength and security that makes this mission possible,'' Bush said. ``And with the support of friends and family and the admiration of this great nation, you're proving that you'll do what it takes at any hour, anywhere, to contain aggression and keep freedom's light alive.'' The message was beamed live over Armed Forces Radio but was not heard by most U.S. soldiers because the radio network does not have a transmitter in Saudi Arabia. The White House said it was heard on ships in the area. In Dhahran, Navy Capt. Mike Sherman said transcripts and tape recordings of the speech will be distributed to each unit stationed in Saudi Arabia, a process which, including delivery time, would take a week. Bush encouraged the troops to ``stand strong'' despite many hardships. He told them, ``You stand on the front line against aggression and international lawlessness.'' ``We have never sought conflict nor do we hope to chart a course for other nations, but at the hands of injustice in the face of aggression, ours is a once reluctant fist now clutched resolutely,'' he said. ``It is your presence, your skills, your talents, your judgment that bring America's principles to life and give them strength and meaning,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Filed in Plane's Crash into Car
DOC.TEXT: A novice pilot with a ``Top Gun'' fixation buzzed a swimming pool and performed acrobatic stunts before crashing a plane into a car, killing himself and the car's driver, according to a lawsuit. Brian Knox, 18, of Auburn, N.H., had made his first solo flight the day before the fiery crash Aug. 3 in Northampton County, says the lawsuit. The lawsuit was filed Tuesday in Northampton County Court by Rella and Anthony Sisonick, parents of Jonelle Sisonick, 23, whose car was struck as she backed out of a driveway. The defendants included Knox's estate and the American Flight Academy of Allentown, which owned the Cessna 150L airplane and taught Knox to fly. The suit contends the academy gave substandard instruction and failed to recognize and correct Knox's hazardous attitude. It seeks compensatory and punitive damages for the loss of Miss Sisonick's potential lifetime income and the pain that preceded her death. Knox, who was scheduled to enter aviation engineering studies at the University of New Hampshire, had seen the Tom Cruise hit movie ``Top Gun'' about Navy pilots 50 times, according to the lawsuit. Knox took off from Allentown-Bethlehem-Easton Airport and performed acrobatic maneuvers for an hour over the Palmer Lions Pool and his grandparents' house, according to the suit. The academy's operations manager, Eric Zupolski, said he could not comment on pending litigation.

DOC.HEAD: Derailment Forces Amtrak Detours
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen cars of a 103-car Conrail freight train derailed early Wednesday, tearing up tracks in both directions and forcing Amtrak to reroute two passenger trains. The Conrail cars, carrying lumber and retail goods, left the tracks midway between Latrobe and Greensburg about 6 a.m., said Conrail spokeswoman Pat Linskey. The train was en route from Pittsburgh to Baltimore. Conrail said the wreckage was expected to be cleared and the tracks repaired by Wednesday night. Amtrak rerouted its eastbound Chicago-to-New York Broadway Limited, which stops in Pittsburgh, and its Pennsylvanian, which originates in Harrisburg and Philadelphia en route to New York. The rerouting forced the Broadway Limited to miss its usual Greensburg stop and an overall two-hour delay in its run to New York was expected, said Cliff Black, an Amtrak spokesman. The eastbound Pennsylvanian missed stops in Latrobe and Greensburg and its trip was expected to take 1{ hours longer than usual, he said. The cause of the derailment, which occurred in a wooded valley three miles west of Latrobe in Unity Township, was under investigation, Ms. Linskey said.

DOC.HEAD: Armenia Declares State of Emergency, Bans Nationalist Vigilantes
DOC.TEXT: Armenia's parliament put the republic under emergency rule, banned a nationalist paramilitary group and blocked roads around the capital Wednesday after a string of attacks left an Armenian legislator dead. The central Soviet government was not involved in the decision. A curfew from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. was imposed throughout the republic, and an Interior Ministry officer said troops with armored vehicles were guarding all roads to Yerevan, the capital, allowing passage only by special permit. Armenian President Levon Ter-Petrosyan appealed in a radio broadcast for calm. ``I assure you that we, the Armenian authorities, are in a position to eliminate the danger posed by this armed organization,'' Ter-Petrosyan said. ``There should be no panicking.'' Alexander Arzumanyan, a spokesman for the Armenian National Movement, and Raffi Hovannisian, a Yerevan representative of the Armenian Assembly of America, said in telephone interviews that the attacks began early Wednesday. According to their description of events, members of the renegade Armenian National Army attacked a gas station and shot and wounded three people. An Armenian legislator, Viktor Aivazian, was then shot to death as he approached the headquarters of the Armenian National Army to investigate the gas station incident. Also killed in the shooting was Gehavnik Manukyan, an officer of armed Armenian National Movement troops loyal to the republic's government. Later Wednesday, members of the Armenian National Army attacked the headquarters of the Armenian Nationalist Movement with automatic weapons, according to the official Tass news agency. Tass said the attack lasted about an hour. No casualties were reported. Also Wednesday, another member of Armenia's parliament, Rafael Ishkhanian, was run over by a vehicle without plates and was in critical condition, Hovannisian said. It was unclear if Ishkhanian was hit deliberately. But Hovannisian said the parliament stood for a moment of silence for both Aivazian and Ishkhanian before unanimously adopting the state of emergency. Parliament also banned the Armenian National Army, which was formed in January and claims to protect Armenians from attacks by armed groups from the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. However, ANA members have attacked police stations and gasoline depots in Armenia to seize the weapons and fuel they need to fight Azerbaijanis. Armenia, which is mostly Christian, and Azerbaijan, which is mostly Moslem, have been engaged for more than two years in a bloody dispute for jurisdiction over Nagorno-Karabakh, a largely Armenian enclave that lies within Azerbaijan. At least 300 people have been killed in the fighting. At times, Armenian officials have appeared to tolerate the Armenian National Army, which is believed to have several hundred hard-core fighters and many more sympathizers. But on Wednesday, the republic's leaders formally outlawed the vigilante group. ``The people's patience has run out,'' Ter-Petrosyan said in his radio address. ``They can no longer bear the adventurism of these armed detachments which endanger both the security of our citizens and the formation of our statehood.'' Parliament demanded that members of the Armenian National Army turn in their weapons by Wednesday night and hand over the buildings and vehicles they have seized. It said members of the group who comply would receive an amnesty and that those who resisted would be detained and punished ``with the strict severity of the law.'' The Armenian legislators _ themselves ardent nationalists who have declared independence from the Soviet Union _ said the state of emergency would be imposed solely by police and troops under their control, not by Soviet forces. An Interior Ministry duty officer in Yerevan, who declined to be identified by name, said all vehicles trying to enter the city would be turned away unless they had permits from local authorities. He said this was to prevent more Armenian National Army units from reaching the city. He also said Azerbaijanis had shut off the only natural gas pipeline to Yerevan, leaving most of the city's 1.2 million residents without cooking fuel. The state of emergency in Armenia is different in key respects from one declared in Azerbaijan on Jan. 15. In Azerbaijan, Soviet authorities imposed the emergency after gangs in the capital, Baku, attacked Armenians and 25 people were reported killed. It has been lifted throughout the republic except in Baku and along the Armenian border. Armenia's parliament passed a declaration of independence last week, becoming the fifth Soviet republic to vote to sever from the central Soviet state. Armenia, which borders Turkey and Iran, has 3.3 million people. The independence declaration calls for creation of Armenia's own armed forces to safeguard the border, which last week was the scene of violent conflict with Azerbaijanis. The declaration also calls for Nagorno-Karabakh to become part of Armenia. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued a decree last month ordering illegal paramilitary groups to disarm and disband. The decree was his latest attempt to end the violence along the Armenia-Azerbaijan border. It was largely ignored.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says Republican Military Buildup Vindicated
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said Wednesday that the threat to peace posed by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein vindicates the Republican-led U.S. military buildup of the past decade. And he said it proves more than ever the need for the Strategic Defense Initiative. Addressing the 72nd annual meeting of the American Legion, Quayle said the lessening of East-West tension has not diminished the need for a strong national defense, including the SDI space shield against nuclear weapons. ``As the Cold War comes to an end, the free world may be less burdened with fighting communist aggression. But there's a new evil: lawlessness and terrorism,'' Quayle told the veterans. ``There are still brutal dictators who prefer the rule of the jungle instead of the rule of law,'' he said. Saddam Hussein has used chemical weapons on his own people, supports terrorism, and uses Americans and others as human shields, Quayle said. Quayle said President Bush will not be satisfied until Iraq withdraws all of its forces from Kuwait and ensures the security of Saudi Arabia and the rest of the oil-rich gulf region. ``Make no mistake about it. What is at stake in the Persian Gulf is nothing less than the shape of tomorrow,'' Quayle said. ``This is the first international crisis in the post-Cold War era. If Saddam Hussein's aggression remains unchecked, new and more terrible aggression will surely follow,'' the vice president said. Quayle criticized Congress for recent cuts in defense programs that would leave U.S. military forces with fewer options and less preparation to deal with sudden crises such as the current one in the gulf. He said he was grateful for the general military buildup that has occurred under Bush and former President Reagan, and he called for new investment in research and development and in the SDI system, sometimes referred to as Star Wars. Iraq and other regional powers are gaining ballistic missile capability, he said. ``That's why the president thinks strategic defense makes more sense in the 1990s than ever before,'' Quayle said. ``That is why we will continue our work to slow and stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and the means to deliver them.'' Quayle, a former Indiana senator whose own National Guard rather than regular military service became a campaign liability two years ago, was interrupted frequently with applause and by two standing ovations. That contrasted with the cool reception he received during a 1989 speech to a Veterans of Foreign Wars meeting. Quayle drew chuckles when he refered to President Bush's celebrated campaign gaffe before the Legion two years ago, when he said Pearl Harbor Day was Sept. 7, 1941, instead of Dec. 7. ``I was with the president this morning to ask him for a few tips of what I ought to say today. He told me the exciting time he had talking to you two years ago, but that I should be especially careful if I start talking about Pearl Harbor.''

DOC.HEAD: Football and Volleyball; Sleep During Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To comply with Pentagon ground rules, exact locations of U.S. military installations are not disclosed
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: This volleyball game, like those on California beaches, is played in the sand. But there's no ocean in the Saudi desert, and the troops at play are wearing boots and bulky uniform pants. Several miles away, at another camp for American troops, the helicopter mechanics are just getting up as the sun goes down _ if they were lucky enough to catch some sleep during the scorching hot day. Further down the road, some Marines are adopting an Arab custom, covering their heads and necks, mostly with T-shirts, to block the sun. To beat the heat and the boredom, American troops are sleeping during the day, working at night and trying to organize recreational activities to make a far-away place a bit more bearable. The helicopter mechanics are among a growing number of troops who do their work at night to escape the heat of day, which often reaches 120 degrees. One maintenance worker, 35-year-old Gary Stutz from MacGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey, says he and his co-workers slowly are adjusting. He says the Air Force is helping by getting the men desert uniforms and lighter boots, with a cloth upper body instead of leather. Air Force Sgt. David Klunker's solution to the heat is to take off his shirt, but he's been told it's against the rules. Three weeks into the deployment of U.S. troops here, some say they're geting used to the heat. Others say they never will. Air Force Sgt. Alan Wagner of Davenport, Iowa, is among those who say they are beginning to get used to it. ``It was unbearable at first,'' he said. After arriving, Wagner said he worked 40 hours and nearly passed out. ``I don't normally sweat, but I was getting dizzy,'' he said. Military hospitals and medics are treating dozens of people a day for heat-related ailments, mostly minor cases of dehydration. Some troops are out in the desert during the day, training under the hottest sun to get acclimated. Others are taking some steps to ease the load on the weary troops. At the 82nd Airborne camp, physical exercises _ primarily walks and jogging _ are done in the early morning and late afternoon. ``We found that water consumption went way down when we started doing it that way,'' said Maj. Baxter Ennis, the division's public affairs officer. ``We've learned to adjust, to get the guys used to the climate but then to try to do most of the other work at times other than the middle of the day.' They may be split over their tolerance to the heat, but troops visited this past week were unanimous in saying there was a need for more recreational activities. ``We train and sit, train and sit,'' said one Army lieutenant on condition of anonymity. ``How can you not be bored?'' At the 82nd Airborne Division's camp, the volleyball game is a big hit _ some of these paratroopers have been here for three weeks, with little or no contact from home and instructions not to venture into Saudi cities The 82nd, among the first units into Saudi Arabia, is also leading the effort to improve recreation activities for the troops. In addition to volleyball, touch football games are now a staple at the 82nd's camp. Some of the later arrivals even have shorts and running shoes. ``The guys who packed up on a minute's notice have to tough it out in boots,'' said Ennis. He commandeered a box of books for the unit and was in town Wednesday seeking to bargain with the U.S. consulate for a major prize _ a movie projector. ``We've got one on the way from Fort Bragg,'' Ennis said. ``But the guys could use one now.''

DOC.HEAD: Multinational Forces Working Chain of Command
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Multinational forces in Saudi Arabia have ironed out a relationship allowing troops to stay under their national command while conducting joint training exercises. The system seems to be working, but Saudis and Americans are deliberately vague about who would take charge if hostilities break out with Iraqi forces. Lt. Gen. Khalid Bin Sultan, head of the joint Arab Islamic Task Force, refused to answer questions about plans for combat, saying he didn't want to tip his hand to the enemy. ``The standard answer is that all command relationships are still being worked out,'' said Lt. Col. John Olsen, a spokesman at the U.S. Central Command headquarters in Saudi Arabia. The consensus is the United States, with the largest military force in the country and its array of weaponry, would call many of the shots in a combat situation, consulting with the Saudis because of their sovereignty. The Saudis' total military force, with a predominance in the Air Force, numbers about 65,000. ``We are not going to do anything unilaterally,'' said one American official on condition of anonymity. ``If we do anything in that area it will be by agreement with the Saudis.'' Any decision to attack Kuwait or Iraq would need approval at the highest levels, meaning King Fahd and President Bush, officials from both nations said. Meanwhile, officials are trying to coodinate the air, land and naval operations in which at least 22 nations say they are involved or will join. The difficulty in bridging language, cultural and political gaps has caused some frustration among the military officials, said Air Force Lt. Gen. Charles Horner, the first on-site American commander and now the No. 2 man. Learning to be patient and adapt to the Saudi style of doing business was difficult when ``you're charging and trying to get the job done,'' he said. The air defense system, based at a huge air base here, is running smoothly after some initial kinks, officials said. ``Communications were under some pressure'' at first, said British Defense Secretary Tom King. The Saudis, the Americans and the British keep their planes near each other, but separate. Saudi pilots fly both American-built F-15s and British-built Tornados. The British have dispatched their own squadron while the Americans have a tactical wing here. ``Everything is done jointly,'' said Prince Turki Bin Nasser, head of the air base. The operations are meshed on a day-to-day basis, with each service responsible for a geographic area, officials said. The coordination is easy because the Saudi pilots have either trained in the United States or in Britain. American military officials have said the U.S. forces are under strict orders to avoid initiating combat in response to actions by Iraq that fall short of actual combat or a clear-cut invasion of Saudi Arabia. On the ground, the Saudis have put about 2,000 men in front-line positions a short distance from its borders with Iraq and Kuwait, so that they _ not Americans _ would take the first hits if a ground war erupted. ``The Saudis felt they had to be at the front,'' one American said. The Saudis are directing a combined Gulf Cooperation Council force in the northeastern part of the country near the Kuwait-Saudi border. The gulf nations' force _ from Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates and Qatar _ numbered 10,000 before Iraq's Aug. 2 of Kuwait, and will be increased, officials said. Some 2,000 Egyptians, 1,200 Moroccans and 1,000 Syrians also are on the ground. But they are removed from the front line and do not intermingle. In the Persian Gulf, warships remain independent and under their own flag. They try to avoid conflicts with each other by notifying one another about actions.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Ferrying Supplies For U.S. Gulf Troops Crashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8 pvs, `Cathy Cox...' to UPDATE with list of victims. Pickup 9th pvs, `No civilian...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhotos FRA2,4
DOC.TEXT: A giant Air Force cargo jet loaded with supplies for U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf crashed and burned shortly after takeoff today. Officials said 13 people on board were killed. Air Force spokesman Doug Moore said the Lockheed C-5A had 17 military personnel aboard, most of them reservists who had volunteered for the round-the-clock deployment aimed at discouraging further Iraqi aggression. The plane, which can lift about a quarter million pounds, crashed in a field a quarter mile from the Ramstein Air Base runway at 12:30 a.m., said Capt. Ed Worley, another Air Force spokesman. He said the jet was headed for Frankfurt's Rhein-Main base, about 90 miles to the northeast, and then on to the Persian Gulf. The aircraft cut a deep swath for about half a mile, broke apart and burned. Twisted chunks of wings, landing gear, fuselage and other debris were scattered over a wide area. Firefighters were still dousing the smoldering sections of wreckage 12 hours after the crash. Late today, the Air Force released the names of those who were aboard the plane. No hometowns were listed. Nine of the 13 dead were from the 433rd Military Aircraft Wing at Kelly Air Force Base in Texas. The four others were stationed at Ramstein or at nearby Hahn Air Base. Listed as dead from the 433rd were Maj. John M. Gordon, pilot; Maj. Richard W. Chase, pilot; Sgt. Rosendo Herrera, flight engineer; Sgt. Carpio Villarreal, flight engineer; Sgt. Daniel G. Perez, loadmaster; Sgt. Edward E. Sheffield, loadmaster; Maj. Richard M. Price, first pilot; Sgt. Lonty A. Knutson, crew chief; and Sgt. Daniel Garza, crew chief. Also killed were Capt. Bradley Schuldt and Sgt. Rande Hulec of Ramstein and Sgts. Samuel Gardner and Marc Cleyman of Hahn. Listed as injured were Lt. Col. Frederick Arzt and Sgt. Dwight Pettit, both of McChord Air Base in Washington state; Capt. Cynthia Borecky of England Air Base, Louisiana, and Sgt. Lorenzo Galvan Jr. of the 433rd. Cathy Cox, an Air Force spokeswoman, said the injured were in stable condition at the U.S. Army's nearby Landstuhl hospital. No civilian casualties were reported. Col. Brian R. Fullerton, an Air Force spokesman, said the plane was carrying no hazardous cargo. The plane's cargo included food, medical supplies and aircraft maintenance equipment, according to Moore. The cause of the crash was under investigation. Ramstein, the largest U.S. Air Force base in Europe, has been a stopover point for the steady stream of U.S. planes headed to and from the Middle East. Worley said the C-5A belonged to the 60th Airlift Wing at Travis Air Force Base in California. He said it was flown by a crew from Kelly Air Force Base in Texas. The 433rd had not been called to active duty, but some reservists with the wing were voluntarily participating in Operation Desert Shield after arranging time off from their civilian jobs. The C-5A and C-5B are the largest transport planes in the Air Force fleet and each costs about $148 million. Under Desert Shield, begun after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the United States and other Western and Arab countries have sent troops, equipment and warships to the gulf region to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraq and to pressure Baghdad into withdrawing from Kuwait. The crash today occurred a day after the second anniversary of a collision during an air show at Ramstein that killed 70 people. On Aug. 28, 1988, three Italian planes crashed during maneuvers and flaming wreckage flew into the crowd of spectators. The crash of a C-5A on April 4, 1975 in Saigon killed more than 200 people, including more than 100 orphan children being flown to the United States in the evacuation from South Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Condemned Marine Challenges Military Justice System
DOC.TEXT: Defense lawyers in the racially tinged case of a Marine facing the first military execution in 29 years argued Wednesday that sections of the military death penalty are unconstitutional. Murder defendants in military trials don't have the same protections as civilians in state courts, attorneys for Lance Cpl. Ronnie Curtis told the U.S. Court of Military Appeals. The court appointed lawyers, Lt. Cmdr. John B. Holt and civilian Robert Morin, also argued that President Reagan abused his executive privilege in 1984 by signing an order outlining whom the military may sentence to death. ``Congress has not decided. Congress has not delegated this power to the president,'' Holt told three civilian judges of the military appeals court. Curtis, who is black, contends racial taunts drove him to kill Lt. James Lotz and Lotz's wife, Joan, at Camp Lejeune, N.C., on April 13, 1987. Curtis, who confessed to a state trooper and to investigators, was sentenced to death after being convicted in a military trial. He is being held at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. The appeals court allowed television cameras to broadcast the proceedings live for the first time on the C-Span cable network. Curtis did not attend the hearing. The case is seen by attorneys on both sides as a test of the military death penalty in murder cases. Among the many intervenors is the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, which said Curtis' court-martial was tainted by racial bias. ``In civilian courts, a lot of issues relating to capital punishment have been considered for years,'' Ronald Wright of the Wake Forest University law school said in an interview. ``This is a chance for the military to ask if its system measures up.'' Wright filed a friend of the court brief in the case. The court is considering the appeal in two stages. A ruling is expected by late September on the constitutional challenge. If Curtis loses that, he will be permitted a second appeal that could consider the composition of the military jury and other racial issues, lawyers said. Curtis, the adopted son of a working-class couple from Wichita, Kan., could take his case to the U.S. Supreme Court if he loses his appeals. A key element of the appeal is that Curtis was sentenced by a nine-member court-martial panel, even though all states with death penalties require 12-member sentencing juries in capital cases. Military law requires only five panelists, a provision Morin said could deprive defendants of ``substantial input and consideration.'' The government says the Constitution does not require a 12-person panel, and that defendants can get fair sentences with fewer members. Curtis, then 21, was convicted of fatally stabbing Lotz, a Scranton, Pa., native who was his section officer, then stabbing Lotz's wife and sexually abusing her as she lay dying in her home. Curtis' lawyers said in appeal papers that Lotz, who was white, antagonized Curtis by imitating what he believed were black mannerisms and by calling Curtis ``Bebop'' and ``Shoo-be-do.'' ``You wanted a dog, you snapped (your) fingers, you called me names, you wanted a dog, here's your dog right here,'' Curtis said at the court-martial. The military said Lotz did call men by nicknames, but that the trial record showed that the use of the names was ``not racial and that the lieutenant was not racist.'' The court-martial panel of nine enlisted men and officers included three blacks. The NAACP said the military judge allowed prosecutors to ``evoke racial bias'' by permitting such evidence as Mrs. Lotz's blood-soaked underwear, which prosecutors said was relevant to their case. Curtis' lawyers argued Wednesday that Congress never granted authority for Reagan's 1984 executive order defining who is subject to capital punishment in the military. But the government said Congress gave the president power for the order by creating a military conduct code in 1950. The last military execution was in 1961 when a soldier was hanged for rape and attempted murder. The military has built a chamber at Fort Leavenworth designed for lethal injections.

DOC.HEAD: List of Victims of U.S. Military Plane Crash in West Germany
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list released by the U.S. Air Force late Wednesday of the the names of those Americans aboard a C-5 transport plane that crashed near Ramstein Air Base. Nine of the 13 dead were from the 433rd Military Aircraft Wing at Kelly Air Force Base in Texas. The four others were stationed at Ramstein or at nearby Hahn Air Base. No hometowns were listed. Listed as dead from the 433rd were Maj. John M. Gordon, pilot; Maj. Richard W. Chase, pilot; Sgt. Rosendo Herrera, flight engineer; Sgt. Carpio Villarreal, flight engineer; Sgt. Daniel G. Perez, loadmaster; Sgt. Edward E. Sheffield, loadmaster; Maj. Richard M. Price, first pilot; Sgt. Lonty A. Knutson, crew chief; and Sgt. Daniel Garza, crew chief. Also killed were Capt. Bradley Schuldt and Sgt. Rande Hulec of Ramstein and Sgts. Samuel Gardner and Marc Cleyman of Hahn. Listed as injured were Lt. Col. Frederick Arzt and Sgt. Dwight Pettit, both of McChord Air Base in Washington state; Capt. Cynthia Borecky of England Air Base, Louisiana, and Sgt. Lorenzo Galvan Jr. of the 433rd.

DOC.HEAD: Police Disperse Protests Before Arrival of U.S. Delegation
DOC.TEXT: Riot police wielded batons and fired tear gas Wednesday to disperse thousands of ethnic Albanians awaiting a U.S. Congressional delegation to complain about alleged human rights abuses. But a statement by Yugoslavian President Borisav Jovic, issued after earlier talks with the seven Republican senators, said the ethnic Albanians in the southern Kosovo province have ``far greater rights'' than minorities in other European countries. In Pristina, riot police dispersed an estimated 10,000 people who chanted ``Freedom! Freedom!'' and ``U.S.A.! U.S.A.!'' A Belgrade television station reported 46 people were arrested and more than 20 were injured, including seven police officers. Two squad cars and several passenger vehicles were demolished. The delegation, headed by U.S. Sen. Robert Dole of Kansas, arrived under heavy police escort about three hours after the clash with protesters, some of whom pelted police with rocks and bottles. ``The senators will see for themselves what kind of police repression we live under,'' said Ibrahim Rugova, head of the 500,300-member Democratic Union, the largest ethnic Albanian political party in the region. Rugova and other ethnic Albanian leaders spent nearly seven hours with the senators, who were accompanied by U.S. Ambassador Warren Zimmermann. Later, the group met with representatives of the rival Serbian community and the Serbian Orthodox church. Earlier Wednesday, the senators met in Belgrade with Jovic and other senior officials. The national news agency Tanjug quoted Jovic, an ethnic Serb, as rejecting claims of human rights abuses in Kosovo. Ethnic Albanians have ``far greater rights than are generally accorded to national minorities'' in other European states, he was quoted as saying. ``The crux of the problem in Kosovo lies in the attempt to secede from both Serbia and Yugoslavia.'' Ethnic Albanians comprise about 90 percent of the 1.9 million people in Kosovo province, an administrative district of Serbia. Kosovo has been the scene of tension since Serbian officials began to restrict the province's self-government last year. Several Yugoslav and international human rights organizations, including Amnesty International and the Vienna-based Helsinki Watch, this year criticized Serbia for its treatment of Kosovo's ethnic Albanians. The region's sole Albanian-language daily was banned in July, and several Kosovo independent trade union activists have been jailed for calling for a general strike for Sept. 3. Serbian authorities in Kosovo have said they will keep ethnic Albanian political parties from taking part in the province's multiparty elections, expected to be held by the end of the year. Accompanying Dole on the trip are Sens. John Warner of Virginia, Jake Garn of Utah, Don Nickels of Oklahoma, Alfonse D'Amato of New York, Steven Symms of Idaho and Connie Mack of Florida. The senators left late Wednesday for Zagreb. They are scheduled to visit Bulgaria and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Army, Florida Sign `Bellwether' Agreement to Find Civilian Jobs For Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: The state of Florida and the Army have agreed to work together to find civilian jobs for soldiers put out of work by the end of the Cold War. Despite the current deployment of thousands of U.S. soldiers in the Mideast, the 764,000 active duty forces will be pared down during the next few years, and could see annual cuts of 35,000, according to Michael Stone, secretary of the Army. ``It is what becomes of those 35,000 soldiers per year that we're talking about today,'' Stone told Gov. Bob Martinez and the Cabinet on Tuesday. The project involves finding soldiers jobs as teachers, truckers, health care workers and law enforcement officers. The state plans to send out brochures and offer a hotline number promoting job counseling services for out-of-work soldiers. ``Florida will become the first state in our country to implement programs that will help ... military personnel with education, training and job placement services,'' Education Commissioner Betty Castor said. Although Stone said it was not inappropriate to make plans for the future of the Army with the unfolding Persian Gulf crisis, he said personnel cutbacks would be put on hold until the confrontation is resolved. But he thanked the state for its ``willingness to be out front in such an important project.'' The Army has not yet worked out similar agreements with other states because it had concentrated on negotiating a ``bellwether'' agreement with Florida, Stone said. ``Florida stood up and said `Yes, we'll work with you in the Army,''' he said. Tom Heath, vice president for ComCar Services, an Auburndale-based trucking company, has recruited veterans on his own and will also participate in the project. ``The more of these people we get, the better off we're all going to be,'' he said. Stone said soldiers have many appealing qualities for prospective employers. Ninety-five percent of the Army's soldiers have high school diplomas and many have college education going up through graduate work, according to Stone. Teaching was the first field Stone said would be a good match, particularly taking into account the need for minority educators. More than 28 percent of the Army is black, including 11 percent of the officers, according to Stone. Stone also cited law enforcement and industrial fields that require expertise in maintenance, electronics and transportation as areas that will find good employees in the pool of former soldiers. Although the agreement was officially signed Tuesday, publicity the project has received during the past several weeks has generated about 200 phone calls and letters from service personnel. Two recently retired captains, one from the Army and one from the Navy, have been hired as teachers by school districts.

DOC.HEAD: Victims were Bright, Dedicated Students
With AM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The five young people who were slain here this week were remembered by peers and professors alike as bright, dedicated students who excelled in school. The four women were attractive, brunette, and petite. The lone man was a strapping, 6-foot athlete. But aside from the women's physical similarities, which may have been a factor if authorities' theory of a single killer is correct, little else linked the victims, who were slain in three different apartments. Tracey Inez Paules, 23, was a prelaw student. Roommate Manuel Ricardo Taboada, 23, was a natural athlete and aspiring architect. Christa Hoyt was a biochemistry major by day and a sheriff's records clerk by night. Christina Powell studied architecture, and her roommate Sonja Larson was a church volunteer who wanted to teach. The latest victims, found Tuesday, were Miami high school pals Paules, a University of Florida senior, and Taboada, a Santa Fe Community College student who planned to transfer to a university. Paules was a class president, homecoming queen and cheerleader in high school and a prelaw senior at the University of Florida. She was a National Honor Society member and had played soccer and softball in high school. ``They were dream kids,'' said Fred Bertani, principal of their alma mater, American Senior High School. ``The kind every parent wanted their kids to be.'' Taboada, a varsity football player all through high school, ``was a nice boy who helped his family and put himself through college,'' said American night-school principal Art Stevens. Taboada and Paules were not romantically involved, friends said. ``They're both great kids,'' Stevens said. ``You talk about a loss, I mean this truly is a loss for anyone who knew them.'' Hoyt, an 18-year-old sophomore, was an honor student on a full scholarship at Santa Fe. She had been a student council member and band member in high school. She was described as security conscious because of her work at the sheriff's department and membership in a sheriff's youth group. By chance, she was briefly living alone. Ex-roommate Bridgette Toombs had moved out last week, and Hoyt's cousin had not moved in yet, Toombs said. Stepmother Diana Hoyt described the girl as a warm, loving person, but ``very timid and afraid to be on her own.'' Harry Conner, her high school principal in nearby Newberry, said, ``She was well-liked by everyone. She always wore a smile.'' Powell, 17, and Larson, 18, came from strong religious backgrounds. Powell attended an Episcopal high school in Jacksonville; Larson sang in her Baptist church choir in Deerfield Beach. Both were attending the university's summer school to enter fall classes as second-semester freshmen. Powell, the youngest of eight children, ``was going to build housing for low-income people,'' said Ted Pina, a high school coach for the softball and volleyball player. ``She was excited about life. She wanted to improve the world.'' Sunday-school teacher Larson had worked in her church day-care center for the past three summers and planned to major in elementary education. She had sought a dormitory room on the campus, but the University of Florida and its fraternities can only house about a fourth of the 34,000 students. She had been put on a waiting list and was living in the apartment with Powell. Their bodies were found there Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Irish Hostage Reunited With Ailing Mother
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Brian Keenan had an emotional reunion Wednesday with his 69-year-old mother, who had her first drink in 11 years to toast his release. Minnie Keenan was driven to Dublin from her home in Belfast to see her only son, who is resting and undergoing medical tests at Mater Private Hospital. The 39-year-old university lecturer was freed Friday after 4{ years as a hostage in Lebanon. Mrs. Keenan laughed and joked with her son, who looked healthier than in recent days as he sat on his hospital bed surrounded by cards and flowers from well-wishers. After the two-hour reunion, during which she sipped from a glass of Guinness, Mrs. Keenan was too emotional to speak to reporters. ``She enjoyed meeting Brian so much and even had a glass of alcohol, her first one in 11 years,'' said family friend, Frank McCallam. ``She has had a ball.'' Keenan was presented with a cake depicting a bearded man lying in a hospital bed with two nurses. He appeared on Irish state television reading the book ``Friendship,'' sales of which will boost the Friends of John McCarthy fund. McCarthy, a British journalist, was kidnapped in Beirut on April 17, 1986 and is still a hostage. Keenan told doctors he and McCarthy were held in a small, hot, mosquito-infested room. He also said he was beaten and poorly fed. He said he didn't want to leave without McCarthy but was forced to go by his captors. There are 13 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Home Base Mourns Deaths ^Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `One of...,' and ADDS 2 grafs at end to update with names of dead from the 433rd Military Airlift Wing. ^With AM-Ramstein Crash
DOC.TEXT: Friends and relatives were in mourning Wednesday because of the deaths of nine Kelly Air Force Base reservists in a military plane crash in Germany. ``The mood is very solemn, and many people are sad because of the incident. It really was a shock to a lot of people,'' said Lt. Mike Franco, spokesman for the 433rd Military Airlift Wing based at Kelly. The nine members of the 433rd were among 13 killed when a C-5 cargo plane crashed Tuesday at Ramstein Air Base in West Germany. The huge plane was carrying food, medical and aircraft supplies for the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East. One of the four survivors of the crash also was from the 433rd. It wasn't immediately known when their bodies would be returned, officials said. ``Everybody's in shock at the wing. It's been quite a blow to everybody here,'' said Maj. Meade C. Warthen, public affairs chief for the reserve unit. The plane was from the 60th Military Airlift Squadron from Travis Air Force Base in California and was en route to Rhein-Mein Air Base in West Germany, authorities said. The reservists were volunteers who had arranged time off from their civilian jobs to help in Operation Desert Shield. The airlift wing, which includes 3,700 members stationed in Texas and Oklahoma, has not been called to active duty. Wing officials invited reporters to Kelly on Tuesday to tour a C-5 and interview reservists just back from missions to Saudi Arabia. The reservists described their trips as tiring and sometimes frightening, but said they were committed to carrying out the job. Several 433rd reservists said they made quick turnarounds in Saudi Arabia, sometimes only stopping for six hours to unload. The 433rd operates a fleet of C-5 aircraft, described by the Air Force as the free world's largest plane. The cause of the crash was under investigation. Members of the 433rd among the dead were Maj. John M. Gordon, pilot; Maj. Richard W. Chase, pilot; Sgt. Rosendo Herrera, flight engineer; Sgt. Carpio Villarreal, flight engineer; Sgt. Daniel G. Perez, loadmaster; Sgt. Edward E. Sheffield, loadmaster; Maj. Richard M. Price, first pilot; Sgt. Lonty A. Knutson, crew chief; and Sgt. Daniel Garza, crew chief. Among the injured was Sgt. Lorenzo Galvan Jr. of the 433rd.

DOC.HEAD: French Farmers Protesting Drop in Meat Prices Battle Police
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of angry farmers battled police, blocked roads and railways and let imported livestock run free Wednesday in a nationwide display of frustration at falling meat prices. Tear gas and water cannons were used to break up demonstrations. Farmers want government protection against foreign competition, but officials say they cannot afford to subsidize French livestock to bolster sagging prices, or block imports. The protests signaled a worsening in the 2-month-old movement to keep out foreign animals, which livestock herders say undercut domestic prices. Clashes between riot police and farmers broke out in Evreux, Normandy where bout 1,000 farmers hurling stones tried to break into government buildings, police said. Six officers were injured, along with three firefighters hurt while trying to douse bonfires set under effigies of public figures. Riot police fired tear gas to break up a crowd of about 400 violent demonstrators in front of government buildings in Rouen, Normandy. There were no reported injuries. Farmers in Normandy earlier intercepted two trucks carrying Irish sheep and British calves and turned the animals loose in the streets of Saint-Lo. Police used a water cannon to disperse 1,000 farmers demonstrating at government buildings in Angers, western France. Police filled the streets with tear gas later when a crowd of 2,000 assembled. Farmers threw rocks and police answered with tear gas at Lons-le-Saunier near Switerland. The farmers had driven tractors and herded about 400 sheep to the city hall before trying to break into the building, police said. ``Farmers are fed up and have no more patience,'' said Joseph Daul, president of the national beef-raisers union. ``I fear yet more violent actions.'' Daul, speaking at a roadblock on the Bridge of Europe in Strasbourg, along France's border with Germany, claimed that cheap meat imports from Eastern Europe will flood the 12-nation European Community through East Germany once the Germanys unite. At Macon in the Burgundy region, farmers threw hay bales on tracks carrying high-speed trains from Paris. Barriers held up one train for 30 minutes, rail officials said. Farmers parked tractors or built barricades of burning tires and trash at 55 spots on main roads in the Vendee region of western France, police reported. About 200 farmers blocked the main north-south highway near Dijon, causing traffic jams more than six miles long in both directions. Other barricades were set up around Ille-et-Villaine, Meurthe-et-Moselle and Metz-Nancy regions. In some places, motorists who tried to break through had their tires slashed. At La Rochelle, western France, about 200 farmers broke into the main regional government buildings early Wednesday and occupied them throughout the morning. In the popular Dordogne vacation region, about 30 farmers intercepted a truck carrying carrying gooseflesh from Bulgaria ready for processing into pate. They threw the meat products into the road and burned them.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Racketeering Suit Against Hotel Queen Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: A judge Wednesday threw out a civil racketeering lawsuit that claimed Leona Helmsley illegally took millions of dollars from her ailing real estate tycoon husband. The complaint in Manhattan's federal court was filed last September by a former Helmsley company executive who said Mrs. Helmsley's actions had reduced the size of his commissions. The suit had contended that Mrs. Helmsley, with the help of a former personal aide, fraudulently transferred to her possession things like a $16 million apartment building, a corporate jet and more than $90 million of bearer bonds. The scheme was part of an effort to circumvent a prenuptial agreement between the Helmsleys, the suit claimed. It said the transfers were accomplished ``by taking advantage of Mr. Helmsley's declining mental facilities.'' U.S. District Judge Kenneth Conboy ruled that the lawsuit had no standing under the civil racketeering law because the plaintiff, William R. Miller, was an ``indirect secondary victim of these alleged frauds.'' Miller was president of a Helmsley real estate subsidiary, Brown Harris Stevens, until April. The suit claimed that Miller lost out on commissions and bonuses from Brown Harris Stevens because the alleged scheme deprived the company of profits. Miller also said Mrs. Helmsley had charged him with theft and forced his resignation from the company. Calls to attorneys for Mrs. Helmsley and Miller were not immediately returned. Mrs. Helmsley, 70, who is president of Helmsley Hotels, was convicted in August 1989 of federal tax fraud charges and was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million. She is free pending her appeal. Her 81-year-old husband, Harry, also was charged in the criminal case but was found mentally incompetent to stand trial. The civil lawsuit had named Mrs. Helmsley, several top Helmsley executives and Helmsley Enterprises and 11 subsidiaries.

DOC.HEAD: Military Cargo Plane Crash Site Yields Few Clues
LaserPhotos FRA2-4, KAI2,5,101 ^With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nine reservists helping in the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf were among the 13 people killed in the crash of U.S. military cargo plane in West Germany, military authorities said Wednesday. The crash early Wednesday of the huge C-5A transport was the first major accident in the nearly 3-week-old, round-the-clock deployment of U.S. personnel and equipment to the gulf. ``I don't want to speculate on the cause of this mishap,'' said Brig. Gen. Richard Swope of the 316th Air Division. ``We don't have any indication as to what the cause of the accident was.'' Four of the 17 people aboard the cargo plane were injured when the massive aircraft tumbled into a field early Wednesday after taking off from Ramstein Air Base, a stopover for many U.S. military flights bound for the gulf region. The plane was bound for Frankfurt carrying medical supplies, food and aircraft maintenance equipment for U.S. troops sent to Saudi Arabia following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, U.S. Air Force officials said. Late Wednesday, the Air Force released the names of the victims. No hometowns were listed. Nine of those killed and one of those injured were reservists with the 433rd Military Airlift Wing from Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio. The four others were stationed at Ramstein or at nearby Hahn Air Base. Listed as dead from the 433rd were Maj. John M. Gordon, pilot; Maj. Richard W. Chase, pilot; Sgt. Rosendo Herrera, flight engineer; Sgt. Carpio Villarreal, flight engineer; Sgt. Daniel G. Perez, loadmaster; Sgt. Edward E. Sheffield, loadmaster; Maj. Richard M. Price, first pilot; Sgt. Lonty A. Knutson, crew chief; and Sgt. Daniel Garza, crew chief. Also killed were Capt. Bradley Schuldt and Sgt. Rande Hulec of Ramstein and sergeants Samuel Gardner and Marc Cleyman of Hahn. Listed as injured were Lt. Col. Frederick Arzt and Sgt. Dwight Pettit, both of McChord Air Base in Washington state; Capt. Cynthia Borecky of England Air Base, Louisiana, and Sgt. Lorenzo Galvan Jr. of the 433rd. The four were hospitalized and reported in satisfactory condition, said Sgt. Rourk Sheehan, spokesman for the Landstuhl Army hospital nearby. The 433rd had not been called to active duty, but some reservists with the wing were voluntarily participating in Operation Desert Shield after arranging time off from their civilian jobs. The plane was from the 60th Military Airlift Squadron from Travis Air Force Base in California and was en route to Rhein-Mein Air Base near Frankfurt, authorities said. It left the Ramstein air base at about 12:30 a.m. and clipped the tops of trees before crashing and breaking apart. Twisted chunks of wings, landing gear, fuselage and other debris were scattered over a wide area. Firefighters were still dousing smoldering sections of wreckage 12 hours after the crash. The weather was hazy but visibility was about one mile, said Swope. He said the aircraft was just over 20 years old, which he said is not uncommon for the C-5.
