The accident occurred about six miles from Miesau, where U.S. military authorities have been removing a cache of chemical weapons under an agreement with the West German government. The West German Defense Ministry said in a statement Wednesday the crash posed no danger to the operation. Ramstein, the largest U.S. Air Force base in Europe, is 90 miles west of Frankfurt. The C-5 is the largest transport plane in the Air Force fleet and costs about $148 million. It was the first crash of a C-5 in 15 years. On April 4, 1975, a C-5B carrying Vietnamese orphans crashed shortly after takeoff near Saigon, killing 172 people. The crash Wednesday occurred a day after the second anniversary of a collision during an air show at Ramstein which killed 70 people.

DOC.HEAD: Students, Parents Not Aware of College Costs
DOC.TEXT: Parents and students may be ``prematurely slamming the door on college'' by inaccurately estimating costs and failing to tap all available sources of financial aid, Sen. Edward M. Kennedy said Wednesday. Kennedy, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, commented on a General Accounting Office report that said a review of nine studies and a GAO analysis found students in grades 10 through 12 knew little about federal financial aid. Generally, the studies showed parents had little idea of about college costs. Most parents greatly overestimated costs or offered unrealistically low estimates, ranging from a low of $2,000 to a high of $60,000 a year. The College Board said total available student aid in 1989-90 amounted to $27.9 billion. After adjusting for inflation, total aid increased 10 percent over the 1980-81 level. In 1980, only 12 percent of all high school sophomores thought the Pell Grant program was available in their schools and only 8 percent believed Stafford Loans, a government-backed program, were available. Pell grants, the largest aid program, are available to all who qualify. But a 1988 study by the Council for Advancement and Support of Education found 49 percent of the high school students polled incorrectly thought they were ineligible for aid to attend an expensive private school if their parents could afford a state school. One-third of those polled also incorrectly believed financial aid is set aside solely for minority students, and almost a quarter incorrectly believed that students with average grades don't qualify for financial aid. The study found that more than half the high school graduates who didn't enroll in college cited affordability, finances and the need to work as reasons. A 1983 study by the Pennsylvania Association of Colleges and Universities, found that 59 percent of ninth graders reported receiving no information about financial aid from their schools. The GAO report also found that high school students knowledgeable about financial aid were more likely to enroll in college than students less familiar with such aid. ``It seems likely that lack of knowledge and misconceptions limit students' and parents' understanding of postsecondary options: At worst, such ignorance may lead to specific decisions about high school courses that close the doors on some future job and school possibilities,'' the GAO said.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge And Guerrilla Allies Accept U.N. Proposal For Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The Khmer Rouge and its two non-communist guerrilla allies said Wednesday they support a United Nations plan to place Cambodia under U.N. control until a new government can be elected. Vietnam and the government it installed in Cambodia have not responded to the proposal made Tuesday by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. Talks on Cambodia resume Friday in New York between U.S. and Vietnamese diplomats. Analysts in Bangkok, Thailand, say the Cambodian government wants to retain interim power and limit the U.N. role to organizing elections. On Tuesday, the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France _ announced a proposal calling for a cease-fire in Cambodia and for the United Nations then to ``supervise and control ... if necessary'' five key Cambodian ministries: defense, foreign affairs, finance, public security and information. It would be an unprecedented U.N. operation to solve a regional conflict, costing the United Nations up to $5 billion over one or two years and involving as many as 10,000 peacekeeping troops and 10,000 civilian personnel, a U.S. diplomat said. ``We have gone as far as we can as the five permanent members,'' said a U.S. diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The question is, can the four Cambodian factions agree?'' He referred to the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge, its two U.S.-supported non-communist guerrilla allies, and the government in Cambodia that gets funding from Moscow. ``It really comes down to how much influence the (Security Council) members can have on the factions,'' Suvit Yodmani, a spokesman for Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan, said in Bangkok Wednesday. The Thai leader has been active in recent mediation efforts. The Cambodian factions are to meet in Jakarta, Indonesia next month. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said that he hopes ``the Cambodian parties will accept this framework so that we can move forward to a restoration of peace in Cambodia.'' The Cambodian resistance groups announced their acceptance of the proposal in a statement released at the United Nations. ``All the parties of the Cambodian National Resistance, including the Democratic Kampuchea Party (Khmer Rouge), have repeatedly expressed their full support for the works of the Five Permanent Members of the United Nations Security Council and viewed that the documents successively adopted by them should constitute the framework of a comprehensive political settlement of the Cambodian conflict,'' it said. ``The fundamental stumbling block which has undermined a political settlement of the Cambodian problem is ... Vietnam's duplicity on the role of the United Nations,'' said the statement. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in December 1978 to oust the Khmer Rouge, blamed for the deaths of up to 1 million Cambodians by executions and starvation after they took power in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota, Baltimore Companies Develop New Fast Drug Test
DOC.TEXT: The FBI soon will field-test kits that enable police officers to wipe your palm and determine within minutes whether you've been handling drugs or explosives recently. ``It's a much less intrusive method of testing for drug use than the traditional urine test,'' and does not require hours or days of work by laboratory technicians, said Dr. Dean Fetterolf of the FBI's forensic science research unit in Quantico, Va. Fetterolf described the new test gear for drugs and explosives for a news conference at a meeting of the American Chemical Society. The new test uses antibodies, produced in laboratory animals, to detect the presence of micrograms _ millionths of a gram _ of the target substance on skin, desk tops or other surfaces. The antibodies trigger a color change in an indicator chemical if the target is present. The tests are calibrated so that they will not pick up the tiny but detectible amounts of cocaine on virtually all the $20 and $50 bills in circulation, Fetterolf said. Antibodies are specific to the triggering substance and the test should not be triggered by other chemicals, he said. Such ``false positives'' are a bane of many current tests. Some urine tests, for example, indicate drug use if the subject has eaten a lot of sesame seeds. The first drug test kits, 200 for cocaine and 200 for heroin, should be delivered next month for FBI field tests, and future kits might also be used for amphetamines and phenylcylidine, PCP, he said. The drug kits are being developed under a $50,000 contract by Bio-Metric Systems, Inc. of Eden Prairie, Minn. A similar kit for certain explosives is being developed for $35,000 by Westinghouse Corp. of Baltimore. ``Taking laboratory technology from a three-hour analysis with a trained technician down to a 30-second analysis that can be done by someone who's not trained as an expert in chemistry or science is not a trivial task,'' Fetterolf said. A sample test kit displayed by Fetterolf and other FBI agents consisted of three tiny tubes of liquids and a smaller-than-a-matchbook plastic container. Dr. Patrick Guire, Bio-Metric's vice president for research and development, said the company is ahead of schedule and may even ship the kits early. Guire said the kits will be mass produced and sold either by Hycor Biomedical of Garden Grove, Calif., with which his company has a licensing agreement for other antibody tests, or by Bio-Metric itself. Fetterolf predicted each one would cost $7 to $8, but Guire said he expected the cost to be about $5 once mass production begins. The FBI soon will receive a prototype of the antibody test kit for explosives, Fetterolf said. ``It's very well documented in the scientific literature that ... someone (who) handles explosives and then picks up a briefcase, will transfer the explosives from the outside of their hand to the briefcase,'' he said. The kits can detect TNT in traces as small as one part per billion, and in the last few weeks, an antibody has been developed for PETN, a major component of plastic explosives, for as little as 30 parts per trillion, he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Shocking' Lead Exposure in California Workers Reflects `National Scandal'
DOC.TEXT: On-the-job lead poisoning is rampant in California, two state-run studies reveal. A medical journal editorial called the findings shocking and said they reflect a national scandal. A third study, yet unpublished, estimated at least 2,500 California children under age 17 have potentially toxic levels of lead in their blood because they live near factories that use lead or in homes with lead-based paint. The research by California's Department of Health Services shows that ``you literally have thousands of people exposed to an agent that's been known to be toxic for centuries,'' said Dr. Kenneth Kizer, the department's director and co-author of two of the studies. ``We can now verify there are substantial numbers of people who are being poisoned,'' Kizer said during a phone interview from Sacramento. Lead, a toxic metal, is widely used in battery manufacturing plants, brass foundries, construction, radiator repair shops, gun firing ranges and pottery and ceramics plants. Lead poisoning can cause anemia, high blood pressure, stomach upset, constipation, headaches, infertility, miscarriages, possible nervous system and brain damage, joint pain, kidney damage, convulsions and coma. The two studies of adult workers were published in the August issue of the American Journal of Public Health. They demonstrate ``there's an epidemic of occupational lead poisoning in California,'' said Neil Maizlish, chief author of one of the studies and a state epidemiologist in Berkeley. ``These data, combined with (earlier research) data from Texas, New York and New Jersey collectively show there is an epidemic of occupational lead poisoning in the United States.'' The editorial accompaning the studies said: ``The continuing overexposure of American workers to lead and the persistent occurrence of occupational lead poisoning is a national scandal.'' The editorial's author, Dr. Philip Landrigan of New York's Mount Sinai Medical Center, described the studies' results as shocking and said on-the-job lead poisoning ``is entirely preventable.'' Jerome Smith, executive director of the Lead Industries Association in New York, said he hadn't seen the studies and couldn't comment. But he suggested California officials overstated the problem by considering lead a health threat at levels lower than the government standard. Landrigan called the standard too weak. The studies blamed California's on-the-job lead-poisoning problem on employers' ignorance of lead exposure laws, company doctors' ignorance of how to recognize and treat lead poisoning, and weak enforcement by overburdened state and federal occupational health agencies. The first study found that, as of 1987, only 2.6 percent of California's lead-using industries conducted legally required tests of airborne lead in the workplace, while only 1.4 percent regularly tested lead levels in workers' blood. The second study and more recent state-collected data revealed that by the end of July, even the relatively small number of tests that were conducted showed at least 5,000 California workers have elevated, potentially toxic blood lead levels. One-sixth of those workers had levels that can produce lead-poisoning symptoms, Maizlish said. The two studies show ``there is a significant lead poisoning problem out there, and that many if not most of the cases are going undetected,'' said industrial hygienist Jeffrey Jones, a study co-author. Based on the studies, Maizlish said his department estimates 205,000 of the 230,000 Californians exposed to lead at work are employed by companies where airborne lead levels aren't tested. ``The bulk of the problem is in the mom-and-pop operations,'' Kizer said. The studies of on-the-job lead exposure stemmed from a state law officials hoped would detect lead poisoning in children. It took effect in 1987, and required medical laboratories to report to Kizer's agency the results of blood tests that found elevated lead levels in anyone tested. Ninety-five percent of the early reports covered adult workers, indicating doctors tested few children for lead exposure. So the department conducted the third study by testing blood lead levels in children in Oakland, Sacramento, Wilmington and Compton neighborhoods that had homes with lead paint or were located near lead-using industries. Based on the findings, the researchers estimated at least 2,500 California children have potentially toxic blood lead levels. The other studies found 81 percent of the employees with elevated blood lead levels worked in Los Angeles County _ the state's manufacturing center _ and 44 percent were Hispanic, even though Hispanics make up only 24 percent of California's population. ``Whoever is at the bottom at the socioeconomic ladder tends to do this kind of work,'' Jones explained.

DOC.HEAD: Blood, Broken Bones _ Inmates' Version of Jail Fight
LaserPhoto NY32
DOC.TEXT: Rikers Island inmates on Wednesday detailed a night of horror in which they said guards lined them up in a prison corridor and battered them with nightsticks, splashing blood all over the hallway. ``I got hit with a nightstick so hard they nearly tore my finger off,'' said Ronald King, 30, showing his bandaged right hand to reporters touring the jail for the first time since the Aug. 14 riot. A state watchdog panel in Albany backed up the prisoners Wednesday, ruling the officers used excessive force in the uprising. ``Correction officers used force that was far in excess of what was reasonable and necessary to establish control of inmates and defend themselves,'' said William McMahon, chairman of the state Commission on Correction, which oversees all local jails in the state. ``The numbers of officers and inmates injured, and the nature of their injuries, are grossly disproportionate,'' he said. McMahon said 144 inmates were injured, including two or three requiring neurosurgery and others with defensive injuries like broken arms and rear skull damage. Eighteen guards also were injured. Correction officials also said Wednesday that a shakeup in command followed the episode. A new warden and deputy warden were brought in last week at Rikers Island's Otis Bantum Correctional Center, where the confrontation occurred. Correction officers claimed they struck the inmates in self-defense after the riot, but the inmates _ shouting through glass partitions to reporters _ told a different story. Charges that inmates destroyed property were trumped up to explain the injuries the prisoners suffered, members of the inmate council said. Inmates handed reporters copies of their infraction notices from that night _ forms filled out by officers detailing alleged inmate wrongdoing. An inmate charged with smashing windows was subdued with ``batons, body holds, punches ... all parts of body,'' one form said. King said on the night of Aug. 14, he was standing with his hands on his head when a guard smashed him with the stick. The inmates had been forced from their beds on an upper floor that night by tear gas and the officers, he said. ``I saw the aftermath _ the stitches, the black eyes. There was blood everywhere, through the whole bottom corridor,'' said William Whitaker, a member of the inmates council. The council chairman, Victor Lantey, said there was ``a massive amount of blood in the corridors.'' Four members of the council met the reporters in the jail chapel. ``It was horrible, horrific, brutal,'' said Lantey, 50, who has been at Rikers for 11 months. ``I saw heads busted, eyes swollen up, ribs broken. It was excessive.'' The hallway was clean Wednesday and freshly painted. Whitaker, 35, said the first indication the inmates had of an impending assault was when guards began moving through the cells taking blankets and coats from them _ things they could use to absorb any blows. The incident followed a settlement between the officers' union and the city that ended a two-day blockade of the bridge leading to the jail. A report of a riot came in as the deal was made public, and guards quickly poured across the bridge and onto the island. Inmates, however, said they were only barricading themselves in because they anticipated violence after correction officers union head Phil Seelig announced a rule had been eliminated that restricted the circumstances under which a guard could use force. City officials later said the rule was simplified, not eliminated. Corrections Commissioner Allyn Sielaff, who took over the troubled city jail system in March, said in Albany that he could not comment on the allegations of brutality because the riot is under investigation by the city Department of Investigation. ``There's an independent, objective investigation going on, which I'm thankful for,'' said Sielaff. ``I'm not privy to the details of that investigation.'' McMahon said Sielaff's ignorance about the incident disturbed him. ``I'm very surprised,'' McMahon said after talking with Sielaff. ``I can see where he's coming from ... but he's facing some serious problems that he should be looking at. He can't just sit back.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Charges NEA With Subsidizing Anti-Religious Art
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Wojnarowicz could ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with artist's comments. Picks up 12th graf pvs `Before these ...'
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer sued the National Endowment for the Arts on Wednesday, alleging that its $15,000 grant for an artist's controversial exhibition displayed ``open and notorious hostility toward religion'' and violated the Constitution. The lawsuit was filed against the NEA and its chairman, John E. Frohnmayer, in U.S. District Court by the Rutherford Institute, a non-profit legal services organization, on behalf of David Fordyce. Fordyce, a lawyer, was described as a ``devout Christian'' from Los Angeles. The suit cited the NEA's grant last year for ``Tongues of Flame,'' an exhibit of works by David Wojnarowicz of New York that was organized by University Galleries at Illinois State University. The Fordyce suit alleged that the NEA-supported catalog for the Wojnarowicz show includes an image depicting Jesus Christ as an intravenous drug user. It said the catalogue also refers to Roman Catholic Cardinal John O'Connor of New York as a ``fat cannibal'' and ``the world's most active liar about condoms and safer sex.'' Fordyce said NEA support for the catalog conveys ``a message of hate and animosity toward institutionalized religion'' sponsored by the federal government in violation of the First Amendment's provision for separation of church and state. He asked the court for a permanent injunction prohibiting the arts endowment from ``funding, sponsoring and endorsing works which promote blasphemous and sacrilegious hate material.'' The endowment, an independent, $171 million federal agency that underwrites a wide variety of artists and arts organizations, had no immediate comment on the lawsuit. The NEA is embroiled in a controversy over art, obscenity and freedom of expression stemming from allegations by religious fundamentalists and conservative lawmakers led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that it has subsidized obscene and sacrilegious works. The endowment already is the target of two other federal lawsuits in New York and Los Angeles challenging Frohnmayer's requirement that grant recipients sign a pledge of compliance with a congressional ban on using federal funds for works that may be deemed obscene. In a telephone interview from New York, Wojnarowicz lamented the NEA's ``awful track record'' in supporting works by minority artists, including homosexuals and lesbians. ``If this kind of heat comes from cult or extreme conservative religious groups over the few coins that finance minority expression, then this country is in pretty bad shape,'' he said. Barry Blinderman, the Illinois gallery director, accused the lawsuit's sponsors of ``hypocrisy'' and angrily defended Wojnarowicz's work against charges of sacrilege. ``Before these people condemn the NEA, they should remember that it was the so-called holy men who didn't accept Christ and turned him in,'' Blinderman said. ``Jesus said `judge not,' and I recommend that these people follow the precepts of the God they are proclaiming.'' The ``Tongues of Flame'' exhibit opened at Blinderman's gallery earlier this year and is now appearing at the Santa Monica Museum of Art in California. John W. Whitehead, founder and president of the Rutherford Institute, told a news conference here that the NEA had ``unconstitutionally used taxpayers' funds to engage in actions which are hostile toward religion and religious persons.'' ``The government should not become the patron of hate art against some of its citizens,'' Whitehead said. ``Religious people must no longer be the personal targets of cannon fire from National Endowment projects.'' Wojnarowicz previously had filed a federal lawsuit in New York against the Rev. Donald Wildmon and his conservative American Family Association. In late June, a New York federal judge ruled that Wildmon's group probably had misrepresented Wojnarowicz's works by including fragments of them in a pamphlet titled ``Your Tax Dollars Helped Pay for These `Works of Art'.'' The judge said the pamphlets, which were mailed to members of Congress, religious leaders and media outlets, probably had damaged the artist's reputation and the value of his works. He issued an injunction forbidding further publication of the pamphlet.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Gambling Defeated in Alaska; Boren, Stevens Roll to Victory.
DOC.TEXT: The former mayor of Anchorage and a Republican state senator turned their attention to their general election battle for governor Wednesday after a primary election in which voters folded an effort to legalize casino gambling. In Oklahoma's gubernatorial primary, voters Tuesday narrowed crowded fields in both parties but failed to give any candidate a majority, setting up two Sept. 18 runoffs. And in Cripple Creek, Colo., voters threw three City Council members out of office in a dispute over a state ballot initiative to bring low-stakes gambling to three depressed former mining towns on the slopes of Pike's Peak. The recalled council members, Mike Altman, Roy Carico and June Sylvain, said voters were angry because they oppose the proposal to allow slot machines, poker and blackjack. Alaska state Sen. Arliss Sturgulewski, who almost became the state's first woman governor four years ago, brimmed with post-primary enthusiasm after winning the GOP nomination. ``I feel very, very strong about victory in November,'' said Sturgulewski, who has represented Anchorage in the state senate for 12 years. ``We have a plan and we're ready to start.'' Tony Knowles, claiming victory in the Democratic primary, said: ``This is just the first step. I'm going to change my watch from primary time to general time.'' In other races, Republican Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska won his party's nomination for his fourth full term. With 98 percent of the vote in, he had 70 percent to 30 percent for Bob Bird, a high school teacher and anti-abortion activist. Stevens faces businessman Michael Beasley, the Democratic nominee with 57 percent of his party's vote. In Oklahoma's Democratic primary, Sen. David Boren steamrolled to victory in his bid for a third term with 428,921 votes to 55,561 for his nearest opponent. Boren will face Republican Stephen Jones, a lawyer who ran unopposed. Alaska's casino measure, which would have allowed blackjack and other forms of gambling, lost 65 percent to 35 percent. Supporters had said gambling would generate revenue. Opponents, including retiring Gov. Steve Cowper, argued gambling would increase crime, create few jobs, cost too much to regulate and undermine the state's image as a wholesome wilderness paradise. In the Oklahoma governor's race, restaurateur Vince Orza, a political newcomer, will face former U.S. Attorney Bill Price in the Sept. 18 runoff for the Republican nomination. With all votes counted, Orza finished first with 76,046 votes or 40 percent, and Price was second with 51,421 votes or 27 percent. Three other candidates divided the rest. Incumbent Republican Gov. Henry Bellmon decided not to run for another term. ``I feel great,'' said Orza. ``My expectations were that we had a chance to win if we played hard and we played fair.'' In the five-way Democratic race for governor, Wes Watkins, a seven-term congressman, and businessman David Walters finished on top. Watkins had 174,575 votes or 32 percent, Walters had 171,675 votes or 32 percent and House Speaker Steve Lewis finished third with 159,995 votes or 30 percent. In Alaska, with 98 percent of precincts reporting, Knowles had 32,157 votes or 56 percent and Lt. Gov. Stephen McAlpine had 24,943 votes or 43 percent after what pollsters had predicted would be a tight race turned into a landslide. In the GOP race, Sturgulewski had 24,317 votes or 36 percent, businessman Jim Campbell had 21,387 votes or 32 percent of the vote and state Sen. Rick Halford had 20,561 votes or 31 percent. Complete returns for Alaska weren't expected Wednesday because vote-counters in some bush precincts were still traveling to communities with telephones so they could report.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Strained, But Moving ``Enormous Amounts''
With AM-Gulf Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The massive deployment of U.S. Navy warships and support vessels to Saudi Arabia has been ``putting a strain'' on the service, a senior Navy official said on Wednesday. ``We're strained at the level (where) we are. We'll just have to operate that way for a while,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official said that the deployments of some major warships _ such as the aircraft carrier USS Eisenhower and its battle group _ have had to be extended for a time because of the crisis, but the Navy leadership is committed to getting its long-absent sailors back home as soon as possible. The Eisenhower and its guardian ships have been at sea since March, and six-month deployments are about ``what people can endure'' away from home and family, said the official. Four U.S. carriers, each bristling with dozens of warplanes, have been deployed to Middle East waters in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The Navy also has been moving some 45,000 Marines onto Saudi soil and aboard amphibious assault ships near the Arabian peninsula. Tens of thousands of soldiers have been flown into Saudi Arabia and the military's fast sea lift ships have gotten the Army's first heavy tanks in place in recent days to defend the Saudi oil fields. But some problems have arisen with meeting deadlines for transporting cargo with the Ready Reserve Fleet, the official acknowledged. Those ships are mothballed and only put into service in times of emergency, so some snags and delays were expected to occur, the official said. The Navy's Military Sealift Command provides ships to the other services for transport purposes. There are 96 ships in the Ready Reserve fleet. Of the 41 ships requested for service, about 27 weren't ready for loading on time, with delays ranging from one to 20 days, Pentagon officials said. Even so, the military has been able to move ``an enormous amount of cargo'' in a very short time with little warning, the Navy official said. ``We've moved more stuff in three weeks than we did in the first three months of the Korean War,'' the official said. ``You're always going to have problems with sealift, because ... when you have a conflict like this, you have to use ships that have been tied up for some time,'' the official said. The massive transportation effort has ``played out about like I expected it to _ it wouldn't all be perfect, but we'd get the cargo moving _ and it is moving,'' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iraq Makes Secret Offer to U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after 7th graf, ``He said xxx out of Kuwait,'' to update with Iraq denial that proposal was made.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has told the White House it would withdraw from Kuwait and allow foreigners to leave if certain demands were met, Newsday reported Wednesday. In its secret offer, Iraq said it wants United Nations sanctions lifted, guaranteed access to the Persian Gulf and sole control of an oil field that dips into Kuwait, Newsday's Washington bureau reported. The newspaper said an unidentified, former high-ranking U.S. official confirmed that he had delivered Iraq's message to National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft last Thursday. In Washington, a White House official confirmed Wednesday that the message was delivered to Scowcroft but said it was ``basically a nonstarter.'' ``Our position has always been that Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait. Anything that seeks to circumvent the U.N. resolve does not provide great optimism for movement,'' he said, commenting only on condition of anonymity. White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk refused to confirm or deny the existence of the message but said ``we're aware of many initiatives that are being undertaken by various bodies.'' He said it would be ``self-defeating to start singling out one proposal or one putative proposal or initiative at the expense of others.'' He said the main point is that the United Nations has ``spoken as one voice'' in demanding that Iraq pull its troops out of Kuwait. In Baghdad, Iraq's official news agencey said no such proposal was made. Newsday said that the former official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he was unsure whether the proposal was a serious offer or ``floating something to see whether you're going to bite or not.'' However, Newsday quoted an unidentified administration official who specializes in Mideast affairs as saying that the proposal was serious and that the package was ``negotiable.'' That official said it was significant that Iraq made no mention in its proposal of a precondition that the United States pull its troops out of Saudi Arabia. The official said earlier Iraqi proposals had contained what he described as ``impossible demands,'' such as linking a pullout from Kuwait with an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Newsday said an unidentified White House spokesman, when asked to comment, reaffirmed President George Bush's stated precondition that Iraq pull out of Kuwait, allow the restoration of its government and release all hostages before any negotiations begin.

DOC.HEAD: Attacks on Academic Freedom Rise, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Censorship attempts ranging from book bannings to protests of AIDS education made 1989-90 the worst year on record for academic freedom in the public schools, an advocacy group said Wednesday. People for the American Way, a liberal organization that focuses on constitutional liberty issues, said it documented 244 attacks on freedom to learn _ up from 172 incidents it cited in 1988-89. This year's total was the highest since the group began its annual survey in 1982, but it probably represents only a fraction of all the incidents that occurred, the report said. ``The censorship movement in America is flourishing,'' said Arthur J. Kropp, president of People for the American Way. ``From novels to television programs to fine art to music to movies to textbooks, we are witnessing an explosion of censorship, an explosion sparked by the match of far right and religious right intolerance,'' Kropp said. But the report also said only about one-third of the censorship attempts succeeded this year, while the others were rejected by principals, school boards or other officials. In 1988-89, about 50 percent of the attempts succeeded. Thirty-nine states had at least one documented incident, but 114 of the incidents _ 46 percent _ occurred in the West. California led with 70. Oregon was second with 16, followed by Washington and New York with 14 each, Michigan with 13 and Florida and Texas with 12 each. The report attributed California's total to activities by right-wing religious groups waging a campaign to change state-approved curricula and reading lists. Those groups have focused on Impressions, a reading series for kindergarten through sixth grade published by a subsidiary of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. The series features stories, poems and literary excerpts, including writings by Martin Luther King Jr., C.S. Lewis and Laura Ingalls Wilder. There also are fantasy stories, some dealing with witches and goblins. Educators have praised Impressions, but critics say the books promote Satanism, witchcraft and rebellion against parents and other authority figures, Kropp said. Others describe the material as violent and depressing. Many of the California incidents in the People for the American Way report involve Impressions. The series was removed from classrooms in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. An attempt to ban the books in Redondo Beach, Calif., failed. A court battle is under way in Dixon, Calif. The Rev. Louis P. Sheldon, chairman of Traditional Values Coalition of Anaheim, Calif., which opposes the series, said it contains some good literature. But some of the writings promote a ``New Age'' religion, he said. ``It has stories and characters that demean and denigrate traditional values and beliefs,'' Sheldon said. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich said in a statement: ``We are not going to be intimidated by self-appointed guardians of local reading standards.'' The Impressions series provides ``instructional experiences that build and strengthen reading ability while allowing students to experience overall enjoyment and excitement in reading,'' the company said. Meanwhile, efforts continued from Florida to Colorado to require that textbooks give the biblical account of creation and downplay evolution, People for the American Way said. Book bannings were sought across the nation for use of offensive words, the report said. Among works critics sought to be removed from school libraries and classroom reading lists were Mark Twain's ``The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' Maya Angelou's ``I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,'' and Shakespeare's ``Romeo and Juliet.'' Sex education and AIDS instruction were attacked in Alabama, New York and South Carolina, the report said. In several Texas communities, students were prohibited from wearing jewelry, clothing or symbols thought to be associated with Satanism.

DOC.HEAD: 27 States To Conduct Sobriety Checks, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: Motorists in 27 states will face sobriety checkpoints during the Labor Day weekend, a private group said Wednesday after it surveyed authorities nationwide. The setting up of roadside checkpoints follows a Supreme Court ruling in February that allowed random checks for drunken drivers. The American Alliance for Rights and Responsibilities, a new group that supports the idea of checkpoints, said it contacted public safety officials in every state by telephone. The organization had written all governors urging a start of the program this weekend. The 20 states without plans for sobriety checks said they would step up patrols to catch drunken drivers during the weekend, said Roger Conner, alliance president. Three states _ Hawaii, Iowa and Nebraska _ failed to respond to the survey, he said. Four states _ Louisiana, Michigan, Oregon and Vermont _ have ongoing litigation or court rulings based on state constitutions that prohibit checkpoints, Conner said. Police checking motorists for drunkenness generally have to delay a driver for only about 90 seconds, he said. The court ruled that the minimal intrusion for law-abiding motorists is outweighed by the benefit of preventing drunken driving. Alcohol figured in about half of the 46,000 traffic fatalities last year. Of the 27 states which said they would set up the checkpoints, 24 said the programs are the result of both state and local law enforcement efforts, the survey said. In three states _ Connecticut, Georgia and North Carolina _ the programs reportedly were set up only by some local police agencies. States planning the checkpoints statewide, according to the survey, include Arizona, California, Colorado, Delaware, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Maryland, Maine, Missouri, Mississippi, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico, Nevada, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, South Dakota, Virginia and West Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Record Crop in California This Year
DOC.TEXT: California, the main source of U.S. pistachios, is producing a record crop of the nuts this year, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Production was estimated at 115 million pounds, an in-shell weight, almost triple last year's harvest and 22 percent more than the previous record of 94 million pounds in 1988. ``The large increase is primarily due to the alternate bearing cycle of the pistachio crop,'' the report said. ``Bearing acreage also increased 6 percent from 1989 to 51,500 acres.'' An alternate bearing cycle means large production one year and a smaller harvest the next.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Hotel Burns Two Days After Closed By Bankruptcy Trustee
DOC.TEXT: The historic Hotel Barre was destroyed by a suspicious fire Wednesday two days after the 101-year-old inn, recently restored to its Victorian elegance, was ordered closed by a bankruptcy court. ``A business tragedy has become a human tragedy,'' said David M. Nickless, a Fitchburg lawyer who was appointed trustee for the property Monday. ``The town has lost something that it had put its whole heart and soul into. The restoration of the hotel had become the rebirth of the town.'' The state fire marshal's office was investigating the blaze and Nickless said he would ask federal officials to join the inquiry. Fire Chief Raymond Howard termed the fire suspicious, and said the building was supposed to have been empty. The stately three-story hotel on the town common was engulfed in flames when firefighters arrived, said Howard. More than 100 firefighters from 10 towns battled the blaze, which lit the night sky for miles in central Massachusetts, northwest of Worcester. By 7 a.m. scores of stunned residents began gathering on the common to watch as firefighters worked on the smoldering ruin. ``This is a horrible loss to Barre,'' said state Rep. Steven Brewer, a Barre resident. ``The town will never be the same.'' ``The hotel brought people from all over the world to Barre,'' said Selectman Duk Demetroupoulos. Built in 1899 in a style that suggested a Mississippi River steamboat, the inn had 36 guest rooms, 11 fireplaces and an elegant dining room decorated with murals. Guests had included presidents Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson and Calvin Coolidge. It was purchased in 1985 for $265,000 by the Kenneth and Nancy Lee Wright and Douglas Merrifield, who recreated its lavish Victorian atmosphere. Before its shutdown, the hotel had 68 full and part-time workers. Wright, who had managed the hotel, declined to comment on the fire. The owners sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy law protection in February 1989 citing assets of $2 million and liabilities of $1.8 million. On Monday, a federal bankruptcy court judge ordered the liquidation of the hotel at the request of its largest creditor, the Worcester County Institution for Savings. Nickless said the hotel was covered by an $800,000 insurance policy. It had been listed for sale in 1987 with an asking price of $2.6 million unfurnished, or $3.6 million furnished.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Cash Income Up
DOC.TEXT: Farm income prospects have brightened significantly despite rising energy costs prompted by the Mideast crisis, an Agriculture Department report showed Wednesday. ``The Iraq situation pushed the price of crude oil up sharply,'' the report said. ``If a price increase of $10 a barrel is maintained for the remainder of the year, agricultural fuel expenses in 1990 will be 10 percent higher than in 1989.'' Earlier, the department's Economic Research Service had forecast a 5 percent increase in 1990 fuel costs. But the report also showed that ``net cash income'' of farmers this year is expected to be record high, in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about one-tenth from 1989. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988. The forecast for net cash income had been in the range of $55 billion to $59 billion in recent months. As used by the agency, net cash income ``measures the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less out-of-pocket costs.'' Some commodities sold actually may have been produced in earlier years and stored until marketed. In another method of accounting, the report said ``net farm income'' may be in the range of $47 billion to $52 billion, compared with the previous forecast of $47 billion to $51 billion. Last year's was about $47 billion, a downward revision of $2 billion from previous 1989 estimates. Net farm income is used to measure the value of agricultural production, whether sold or stored, in a calendar year plus government payments, minus all costs, including depreciation and other allowances. The report said 1990 cash receipts for crops and livestock are expected to climb 6 percent to 8 percent from last year. Direct government payments are down somewhat from 1989, however. Cash expenses were forecast to be up 1 percent to 3 percent from 1989. Those include higher costs of fuels, marketing, storage, transportation and farm rents. Overall, the report said, the 1990 balance sheet ``reflects a strong position for U.S. agriculture'' with rising asset values _ mostly land _ and steady debt. The rise in energy prices will have negligible effect this year on the farm cost of fertilizer and other chemicals ``but will probably be more pronounced in 1991 because most application is in the spring.'' Analysts said the performance of the general economy will be strongly influenced by how long the Middle East crisis continues and how high oil prices climb. ``Current conditions point to dampening demand, slower growth and higher inflation, a situation that would be aggravated by extended oil price hikes,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Arrives in Baghdad to Interview Saddam
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived in Baghdad Wednesday to interview Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for a syndicated U.S. television show. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Jackson was met at Baghdad's airport by officials from the foreign ministry. The agency did not give their names. On Tuesday, in Amman, Jordan, the civil rights leader and former Democratic presidential candidate told reporters that he hoped to help keep adversaries talking in order to avoid war in the Middle East. ``If (leaders) keep talking and keep acting the worst scenario can be avoided,'' he said. ``It is better when people talk, talk, talk rather than fight, fight, fight.'' Jackson has stressed that he would be making the trip as a journalist to interview Saddam, senior Iraqi officials and American hostages in Baghdad, and would not be engaged in any diplomatic negotiations. Jackson is scheduled to interview Saddam for the syndicated television show ``Inside Edition,'' said Allyson Kossow, a spokeswoman for the show. She said on Monday that no date had been set yet for the broadcast of Jackson's interview with Saddam, whose Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait touched off the Persian Gulf crisis, which has brought thousands of U.S. soldiers to Saudi Arabia. Ms. Kossow said Jackson isn't being paid for the interview, nor will the interview appear on Jackson's own show, which is syndicated by Warner Bros. in Los Angeles. ``The Jesse Jackson Show'' is scheduled to premiere next month. ``Inside Edition,'' which is syndicated by competing King World Productions, is paying for the travel and production expenses of Jackson's group, and ``we retain complete editorial control'' of interviews, Ms. Kossow said. Jackson, an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1984 and 1988, traveled to Syria in 1984 to arrange the release of a U.S. Navy pilot held there.

DOC.HEAD: Training Carrier Retires
DOC.TEXT: The aircraft carrier used to train the Navy's sailors and pilots _ the USS Lexington _ will be decomissioned in mid-1991, the Navy announced Wednesday. The USS Forrestal, which is homeported in Mayport, Fla., has been named to replace the Lexington as the service's training carrier. The Lexington was the site of a major accident last fall, when a jet pilot making his first landing crashed into the deck, killing himself and four others. In a statement issued at the Pentagon, the Navy said it had opted to retire the 47-year-old carrier rather than perform an overhaul to extend its service life. Since 1962, the Lexington has been used to qualify thousands of naval aviators, and it has recorded more than 490,000 aircraft landings on its flight deck. The Lexington was launched in 1942. During World War II, its crew destroyed more than 1,000 enemy planes and sank 300,000 tons of shipping, earning it the nickname ``The Blue Ghost'' and the reputation that it couldn't be sunk.

DOC.HEAD: Slayings Spotlight Wave of Violence Against Women, Senator Says
DOC.TEXT: A series of murders near the campus of a Florida university shows Americans have been too slow to recognize a plague of violence against women, Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Wednesday. ``It should not take such a grizzly and horrifying incident for us to act,'' said Biden, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. ``We already know that young women are disproportionately victimized by violent crime.'' He said the five slayings discovered in recent days near the University of Florida in Gainesville ``dramatize just how vulnerable America's young women are as they return to campus.'' Four of the Florida victims were women. The comments came at the start of a Judiciary Committee hearing at which two women pleaded for congressional action to combat what they said was a spreading problem of ``acquaintance rape.'' Philadelphia paralegal Christine Shunk, 25, told the committee that she was raped twice, the first time when she was a college freshman and being escorted home from a fraternity party by a man she believed to be a friend. Two years later she was raped at knifepoint by a stranger. ``I have already been raped twice and I have survived,'' she said. ``I do not know how I would survive a third assault mentally. You see, being raped is like having your whole world turned upside down.'' The committee released results of a study done on behalf of the American Psychological Association that said the chances of any woman being raped in her lifetime were one in five. It said the odds of being raped by an acquaintance were one in six. ``We are here to debunk the myth that real rape only happens when a man jumps out of the bushes and attacks an unsuspecting victim,'' said Biden, D-Del. ``In fact, rape by someone the victim knows _ usually referred to as acquaintance rape _ is real rape and it is far more common and may be even more devastating to its survivors.'' Biden said support is growing for legislation that would direct more federal resources to combatting violence against women. Ms. Shunk, of Coatesville, Pa., said she was plagued by guilt after the first attack because she had agreed to accompany the young man to his dorm room to pick up his jacket before he took her home. In the first case, Ms. Shunk said, she didn't realize at first that she'd been raped. A counselor she consulted didn't ask the name of her assailant but merely advised her to keep her grades up so that she could transfer to another school. Nicole Snow, 21, of New Canaan, Conn., told the committee that the summer before her junior year in high school she was raped by a boyfriend she at first ``thought was my dream.'' ``I thought he was a popular, caring, wonderful football player and he seemed crazy about me,'' she said. ``My dream was quickly shattered. A month after our first date ... he changed my life forever by brutally raping me.'' She said that afterward she pretended it hadn't happened. ``I continued my life robotically, striving socially, academically and athletically _ but inside there was a crying young girl,'' she said. ``It took three and a half years until I got the courage to seek therapy.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Ordered to Review IRA Bombing Convictions; Evidence in Doubt
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday ordered an appeals court to reopen the cases of six Irishmen convicted of murdering 21 people in a pair of IRA pub bombings in 1974, saying police may have tampered with evidence. Though doubts were raised only about evidence against one defendant, Home Secretary David Waddington ordered the Court of Appeal to review all six cases. ``It is good news, but I'm keeping my feet firmly on the ground,'' said Hugh Callaghan, one of the so-called Birmingham Six, who have maintained their innocence for 16 years. Their convictions were affirmed by the Court of Appeal in 1988. The explosions in two pubs in Birmingham on Nov. 21, 1974, were the deadliest attack ever mounted in England by the outlawed Irish Republican Army in its campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland. The explosions killed 21 people and injured 162. Scientific tests of police notes of an interview with convict Richard McIlkenny indicated that some pages were written at different times, the Home Office said. Waddington said the interview with McIlkenny implicated one other defendant, but fairness required a review of all six cases. ``It's very, very difficult to disentangle the significance of evidence like this for the case of one defendant as compared with its significance for the case of the other defendants,'' Waddington said in an interview with BBC radio. Chris Mullin, a member of Parliament who wrote a book arguing the innocence of the six, said it was likely that much additional new evidence would be presented to the court. ``For the first time, I detect that there is a will on the part of many of those in authority to bring this great scandal to an end once and for all,'' said Mullin, a member of the opposition Labor Party. ``It's casting a blight upon our whole legal system not only at home but around the world.'' Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said the new appeal was ``very good news.'' Relations between Britain and Ireland have been strained by the Birmingham Six case and others in Britain involving IRA suspects. Five of the six men were arrested a few hours after the bombings, as they were about to board a ferry to Belfast, Northern Ireland, for the funeral of an IRA member. McIlkenny, Callaghan, Johnny Walker, Patrick Hill, Gerry Hunter and Billy Power were convicted of murder in 1975 and sentenced to life in prison. They were refused the right to appeal in 1976 and failed in a 1977 lawsuit alleging that they were assaulted by investigating officers. A decade later the government acknowledged doubts about their convictions by referring the case to the Court of Appeal, which affirmed the convictions. The Birmingham Six case is the last of three major trials of suspected IRA guerrillas from the 1970s to be returned to the appellate courts following vigorous public campaigns proclaiming the defendants' innocence. Three men and a woman convicted of killing six people in bombings in Guildford and Woolwich in 1975 were freed by the Court of Appeal in October. Six other people convicted in a related case of operating an IRA bomb factory are awaiting an appeal hearing, after Waddington announced in June that the convictions were ``unsafe.'' In March, Waddington asked the Devon and Cornwall Constabulary to investigate certain undisclosed points raised by attorneys for the Birmingham Six. Devon and Cornwall police conducted electrostatic deposition tests on records of the West Midlands police force, whose detectives investigated the Birmingham bombings. The test can determine when a document was written and whether any alterations have been made to it. A year ago, West Midlands Chief Constable Geoffrey Dear suspended two detectives and reassigned 53 members of the Serious Crime Squad after the tests indicated that records had been falsified in cases going back to 1986. Supporters of the Birmingham Six argue that their confessions were contradictory, that police tampered with logs to make statements appear consistent, that forensic evidence was flawed and that no witness testified to seeing any of the men in the two pubs.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are Wednesday's developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

U.S. officials rushed to Jordan's border with Iraq to greet Americans fleeing from Iraq, but there was no sign that Saddam Hussein had carried out his pledge to free Western women and children. No members of that hostage group were aboard the two Iraqi Airways flights that arrived in Amman, Jordan, from Baghdad. Cable News Network quoted unidentified Iraqi officials as saying an Iraqi Airways plane filled with Westerners will leave Baghdad for Amman on Thursday.

Nine reservists helping in the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf were among the 13 people killed in the crash of U.S. military cargo plane in West Germany early Wednesday, military authorities said.

President Bush called the Persian Gulf crisis ``one of the toughest military missions in modern memory,'' and told U.S. troops they are bringing America's principles to life. Bush's pep talk to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia was broadcast over Armed Forces Radio, but many troops apparently did not hear it because the radio network does not have a transmitter in Saudi Arabia.

Iraq has told the White House it would withdraw from Kuwait and allow foreigners to leave if certain demands were met, Newsday reported. In its secret offer, Iraq said it wants United Nations sanctions lifted, guaranteed access to the Persian Gulf and sole control of an oil field that dips into Kuwait. A White House official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the offer was received but rejected. Iraq's official news agency said no such proposal was made.

OPEC oil ministers approved a plan allowing Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other member countries to pump more oil and help hold down crude prices. One OPEC minister predicted the agreement could replace 3 million of the 4 million barrels of oil the day that disappeared from the world market because of the embargos on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. That shortfall caused oil prices to skyrocket.

After days of discussion, Japan announced it will supply money, medics and transportation to the multinational forces being deployed to prevent an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia. However, Tokyo ruled out a role for Japan's military.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Extradite Chinese Pilot Who Wanted to Defect to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet authorities sent home a Chinese pilot and his MiG-19 fighter Wednesday, four days after he flew to Vladivostok and announced he wanted to go to the United States. Senior Lt. Van Baoshi was put on a passenger plane that the Chinese government sent from Beijing to pick him up, the Soviet government newspaper Izvestia reported. His fate in China was uncertain, but he could be tried for desertion, theft of state property or even treason, which carries a possible death penalty. The Tu-154 plane carrying Baoshi took off just behind his MiG-19 fighter, flown by another Chinese pilot, Izvestia said. Both Izvestia and the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said Baoshi had nearly collided with a passenger plane taking off from Vladivostok Airport when he landed. They said he arrived at the eastern Soviet city near the Chinese border on Saturday. Baoshi, 28, told Soviet investigators he had wanted to fly to the United States but didn't have enough fuel, Izvestia reported.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Official: TV Stations May Have to Give Jackson Opponents Equal TIme
DOC.TEXT: Washington-area TV stations may have to offer equal time to political opponents of Jesse Jackson if the stations show him conducting interviews in the Middle East, a federal official said Wednesday. Jackson hopes to interview Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, along with American hostages, this week for the syndicated TV series, ``Inside Edition,'' which is broadcast on the local NBC-owned TV station. Jackson is running in the District of Columbia for a ``shadow'' seat in the U.S. Senate, an unpaid lobbyist post for D.C. statehood. He reportedly is being paid about $125,000 to work as a journalist, although officials at King World Productions, which syndicates ``Inside Edition,'' have said they're only picking up Jackson's expenses. News programs can claim exemption from federal equal opportunity _ commonly known as equal time _ rules if candidates are the subjects of bona fide newscasts, documentaries or other types of legitimate news events. But because Jackson will be an interviewer and not an interviewee, a station probably could not claim such an exemption, said Milton Gross, chief of the Federal Communications Commission's fairness-political programming branch. Gross said he gave such an opinion informally to someone who called him on behalf of the NBC-owned station in Washington, WRC-TV, which broadcasts ``Inside Edition.'' He would not identify the caller. ``The subject of the news would be exempt, but not the interviewer,'' Gross said. He added that ``Inside Edition'' had not sought an equal time exemption as a news program, as have some other shows such as ``Hard Copy'' and ``Entertainment Tonight.'' Gross based his opinion on a Supreme Court ruling involving a California newscaster who also was a political candidate. The newscaster had argued that the equal time rules were depriving him of his livelihood. But the court said station employees could not claim the exemption, Gross said. Jackson's appearance on ``Inside Edition'' would not be exempt if the Supreme Court's decision were applicable, Gross said. The FCC official said he did not know if the equal time rules would apply to a Washington station that used portions of Jackson's ``Inside Edition'' appearance on its regularly scheduled news programs. He said he could give a definitive ruling only if a Jackson opponent demanded equal time and a station refused. WRC-TV vice president-general manager Allan Horlick said he felt his station could broadcast Jackson's interview without being subject to any equal time claim. ``We anticipate certainly broadcasting the show and we will be in full compliance with anything coincidental to the fact he is running for a shadow Senate position,'' Horlick said. Jackson also has a new syndicated program, ``The Jesse Jackson Show,'' due to debut next month nationwide, but it will be blacked out in the Washington area until after the November election.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Man Kills Wife, Self, in Hospital Room
DOC.TEXT: After leaving a note saying ``we decided we don't want anymore,'' an 82-year-old man shot and killed his 80-year-old, cancer-stricken wife in her hospital room Wednesday, then killed himself, police said. ``It appears to be a homicide-suicide, mercy-type killing,'' Police Chief Frank Pomeroy said. Jane Harbrecht had been at Community Memorial Hospital for about two weeks awaiting surgery and was told Tuesday she had colon cancer that had spread to the lymph nodes, Pomeroy said. Her husband, Raymond Harbrecht, had previously been married to another woman who died of cancer. ``A lot of financial and emotional concerns came from that,'' Pomeroy said. Harbrecht entered the hospital around 6:20 a.m., spoke to a receptionist and then went to his wife's second-floor room. He shot her once in the head with a .38-caliber revolver, then sat in a chair and shot himself, Pomeroy said. Both died immediately. Harbrecht left a note to his son-in-law that read, in part: ``Dave, sorry to do this, but we decided that we don't want anymore. You are free to do anything you wish because we know it will be right. Mom and Dad. P.S. Give car to Nick. Pop.'' The note was dated Wednesday, Pomeroy said. It was found at the couple's home about a mile south of Winona, a city in southeast Minnesota. Pomeroy didn' disclose the son-in-law's full name and said he didn't know Nick's relationship to the family. Hospital officials had no indication of what was going to happen, Pomeroy said, adding he didn't know what Harbrecht said to the receptionist before entering his wife's room. Harbrecht apparently hid the gun in his pants when he entered the hospital, Pomeroy said. Police found the weapon on the floor next to Harbrecht.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Telescope Spots Galaxy That May Have Black Hole
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tod in 6th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A photo taken by the Hubble Space Telescope shows a galaxy seen only as fuzzy ball by telescopes on Earth is actually so tightly packed with stars that it may harbor a black hole at its center, NASA said Wednesday. The picture, which an official said was taken ``to prove to the public that the Hubble is not broken,'' shows a galaxy 400 times more tightly packed with stars than the sun's own Milky Way galaxy. Scientists said the Hubble photo captured more detail of the galaxy than is possible by Earthbound telescopes and was thus able to determine that the stellar group had many more stars than expected. The picture was taken by the wide field-planetary camera on Hubble, one of the instruments officials said was seriously affected by a focusing flaw manufactured into the telescope but not discovered until after it was launched. Officials also released a photo taken with another Hubble camera that shows a ring of matter encircling a supernova, a star that exploded in the southern sky in 1987. The ring of material had not been spotted before by telescopes on Earth. Tod R. Lauer, an astronomer with the National Optical Astronomy Observatories, said the compact galaxy of stars discovered by the Hubble ``is vastly denser than we expected this galaxy to be.'' He said ground-based photos of the galaxy showed a smooth blob of light and gave no suggestion that it contained so many stars. ``We've never been able to study any galaxy outside of our local group (two dozen galaxies near the Milky Way) at this resolution before,'' Lauer said. The galaxy, called NGC7457, is 40 million light years away and contains about 30,000 stars within an area of only about nine light years. Hubble chief scientist Ed Weiler said that one explanation for such a dense galaxy would be the presence of a black hole. ``We're not claiming that this is a black hole,'' he said at a news conference. ``It is not inconsistent with a black hole, however.'' Astronomy theory holds that a black hole can be formed when stellar matter collects in such a mass of such density and of such a high gravitational force that even light cannot escape. There have been no confirmed black holes found in the universe, but Weiler said that if one existed it might take on the appearance of the galaxy photographed by the Hubble. Weiler said the galaxy will be further studied by Hubble instruments to determine if it does contain a black hole. The other photo released showed a glowing ring encircling supernova 1987A, an exploded star 160,000 light years from Earth. The picture was taken by Hubble's faint object camera, an instrument made the European Space Agency for the space telescope. Nino Panagia, a ESA scientist, said the photo shows that matter ejected from the star years before its explosion was compacted and then set aglow by the burst of light when the star blew up. He said the ring will be blow apart within a few years when the blast wave from the exploding collides with the material in the ring. NASA took the pictures as part of a campaign to demonstrate that the Hubble is a valuable telescope even though it has flawed optics. Eric Chaisson, educational director of the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, said he wrote memos in recent weeks calling for a campaign to change the perception of the public and of the science community about the problems with Hubble. In a memo obtained by the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News, Chaisson said action should be taken to change the public image of the $1.6 billion observatory. ``Unless a dramatic campaign is mounted to share with the American public the technical truth with a positive spin,'' Chaisson wrote, ``then we should prepare ourselves for an endless stream of newspaper cartoons, late-night TV talk-show jokes and blistering post-mortems by columnists the world over.'' He added: ``We shall continue to see an erosion of public support for NASA's ambitious space program.'' Reached by telephone, Chaisson confirmed that he had written such a memo, noting that the pictures of the galaxy and supernova were taken in part because of his efforts. ``We needed some science to prove to the public that Hubble is not broken,'' he said. ``I don't apologize for it. What I was trying to do (with the memo) was to jerk the system around so it would do a little science.'' Since Hubble has been launched, it has been in a shakedown operation designed to test it capabilities. Since the focusing flaw was found, engineers have been operating the Hubble to find out the precise nature of the malfunction. Chaisson said his memo helped persuade NASA to interrupt the engineering checkout and take some pictures of scientific value.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Lambasts Officials for Shortage of Soviet Smokes
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev chewed out five top officials on Wednesday for the cigarette shortage that has led to street protests across the nation and rationing in Moscow. ``The discussion showed that managing officials acted irresponsibly, neglected their duties and have not taken necessary measures to resolve the problem concerning millions of people,'' Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said Gorbachev demanded an explanation of the tobacco shortage from the officials and found their responses ``unconvincing and unsound.'' The meeting came one day after the Moscow City Council voted to begin cigarette rationing, at just five packs a month per person, starting Saturday. Authorities have also announced price increases that will triple the official cost of most cigarette brands starting next month. The tobacco shortage, which has lasted all summer, has forced Soviet smokers to spend hours waiting in lines at kiosks to buy cigarettes. Hundreds of irate nicotine addicts have rallied in Moscow, Leningrad, Gorky and other cities, and young people demanding more cigarettes, alcohol and food rioted in the Siberian city of Chelyabinsk. The officials summoned by Gorbachev to provide explanations for the shortage were Soviet first deputy prime ministers Vladilen Nikitin and Lev Voronin, Russian Republic prime minister Ivan Silayev, Russian Republic first deputy prime minister Gennady Kulik and deputy minister of trade Suren Sarukhanov. Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov also attended the session, Tass said, but he apparently did not suffer Gorbachev's wrath. Official spokesmen have blamed the shortage on factory breakdowns, hoarding by black marketeers and the near-depletion of the nation's reserves of foreign currency, which has led to reduced cigarette imports from Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Population Gains to Give Sunbelt States More Seats in Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 6th graf with 1980 population
DOC.TEXT: The flow of Americans to California has pushed the Golden State far ahead of all rivals in population and will give it a record 52 seats in the 1992 House of Representatives, new census figures indicate. Preliminary 1990 population figures show California picking up seven House seats, followed by Florida with four, Texas three and a handful of other warm-weather states with one each. New York hung on to its No. 2 ranking in population behind California in the new figures _ with Texas and Florida closing fast in third and fourth places _ but will lose three seats in Congress because its population rose only slightly in the 1980s. Four Northern industrial states _ Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania _ lost population during the decade and will have two fewer seats each. The Census Bureau estimated a national count of just under 246 million, including 29.3 million in California, 17.6 million in New York, 16.8 million in Texas and 12.8 million in Florida. Wyoming was last, at just under 450,000, passed by Alaska, which had the smallest population in 1980 but grew to almost 546,000 in 1990. The total population count in 1980 was 226,545,805. House seats are redistributed among the states after each Census. Because the number is limited to 435 seats, when a growing state gains a seat some other state must lose one. New York's slight population gain was quickly disputed by state officials, who had predicted repeatedly that the state would be undercounted. ``I don't believe it,'' Gov. Mario Cuomo said in Albany. ``Do you really, honestly believe that everybody who should be counted has been counted? The answer is of course not. My mother had trouble; she didn't want to answer.'' New York Mayor David N. Dinkins called the city's estimated slight decline ``unadulterated nonsense'' and promised to pinpoint where he said the government had made errors. Overall 19 House seats will change states according to the figures, which could change significantly before the final report is issued Dec. 31. The widely noted movement of Americans to the Sun Belt was documented anew in the Census Bureau figures. Besides California, Florida and Texas, states gaining a House seat each were Arizona, Georgia, North Carolina, Virginia and Washington. Besides the two-seat losers _ Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania _ there will be one less seat each for Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Montana, New Jersey and West Virginia. Overall, the preliminary Census figures show the United States with a population of 245,837,683 residents. That's somewhat below the 250 million that the bureau had estimated earlier this year. However, 4 million or more may be added as the Census Bureau conducts follow up counts and completes tabulations before the final reports are made public. If those are added in only a few states, some of the seats allocated in the preliminary tally could shift again. For example, a study by the private firm Election Data Services showed Kentucky and Mississippi neck and neck for the last seat allocated. Mississippi got the seat, but a shift of 3,000 people could shift it to Kentucky. Kimball Brace, head of EDS, stressed that the figures are subject to change. In addition to changes made after local officials assess the preliminary figures, there is a chance that the final report could be adjusted next summer. The bureau has been criticized for undercounting minorities in the past and is conducting a post-census check on its count this time. If officials determine that some group has been missed a decision could be made to statistically adjust the final numbers. That ruling will be made by the Department of Commerce in mid-July 1991. The national total was completed Wednesday with the reports for the final four states _ New York, Texas, Illinois and Pennsylvania. Census officials emphasize that the figures are provided to allow local governments to question the results in the event people were missed or overcounted.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Meets With Yeltsin in Kremlin
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with his chief rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, for several hours on Wednesday and they discussed their nation's crumbling economy and relations with Japan, a spokesman said. The meeting was the first between the two since they clashed earlier this month over the attempt by Russia, the Soviet Union's largest republic, to seize control over its vast natural resources from the central Soviet government. Yeltsin is president of the Russian republic. Gorbachev issued a presidential decree last week nullifying the Russian move. ``This was a very good and a very constructive discussion,'' said Gorbachev's new spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko. Ignatenko said the two talked about matters relating to Russia, the entire Soviet Union and international topics including Europe and relations with Japan. He provided few details on the discussion, but he said the Soviet economy was a central theme. ``The situation in the country is such that we are on the threshold of major decisions,'' Ignatenko said. ``We have approached such a decisive stage when we are speaking about a real change in economic structures and new relationships within the union itself. ``Old structures are becoming a thing of the past, but the new structures are still emerging. This gives rise to a certain instability, to heated discussions and this situation cannot easily be kept under control.'' Gorbachev and Yeltsin have jointly appointed a commission to study making the transition to a market economy. Another commission, led by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, is also drafting plans for the economic switch. Gorbachev favors a gradual approach to avoid the shock of sudden price increases. Yeltsin wants to make the transition quickly, arguing that the ailing economy needs urgent measures. Yeltsin has accused Ryzhkov of duplicating his work, and said if more than one plan were presented to the national parliament, the Russian republic would go its own way. Ignatenko said Gorbachev would convene a joint meeting of his Presidential Council and the Council of the Federation on Thursday. Gorbachev has invited Yeltsin and other leaders of the Soviet republics and autonomous regions to attend. This meeting also will focus on the economy and the unrest in the republics, Ignatenko said. ``Today our leadership is expressing only one wish: to stabilize the situation, to protect the new economic policy by exercising its powers to defend perestroika,'' he said. ``The coming few months should be decisive in many ways. ``I hope that this political line will be protected.'' Ignatenko, whose appointment was announced Tuesday, told a room crowded with journalists that he planned to hold weekly news conferences.

DOC.HEAD: Way of Life Disappears In Minutes for Tornado Victims
With AM-Illinois Tornadoes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Classes were supposed to start here Wednesday, but after a few howling minutes of chaos there was no class, no school, and for many residents, no home. The twisters that tore into this northern Illinois community and several neighboring towns Tuesday killed at least 24 people and injured more than 300. As they flipped cars and tore roofs off houses, the tornadoes also threatened to bury hundreds of lives. ``Life in Plainfield, Crest Hill, Joliet and surrounding towns will never be the same,'' said an editorial in Wednesday's Joliet Herald-News. ``It has only been a few hours since the tragedy struck. It will take days, weeks and years to recover.'' Scores of residents were left homeless. Some residents who had been planning a new beginning were suddenly faced with nothing. Jerry O'Shea, a new teacher, was getting ready for the start of classes and left Plainfield High School minutes before the twisters hit. He returned Wednesday to a school in ruin. ``This was going to be my first day teaching,'' O'Shea said. ``Welcome to Plainfield.'' In the Warwick subdivision of Joliet, about 35 miles southwest of Chicago, new homes finished in the last six months were reduced to their foundations in minutes. Joliet officials had to explain to a touring Gov. James R. Thompson that it wasn't a construction zone. ``All these homes were occupied,'' said Joliet Alderman Warren Dorris. ``We lost 31 (homes) and we had three fatalities here. It's just a shock.'' There were even more homeless at a seven-building apartment complex in Crest Hill, near Plainfield. Parts of the complex were destroyed, and authorities were only allowing people into relatively undamaged buildings to retrieve personal belongings. Norm Treonis, chairman of the company that owns the apartment complex, said he was working to put displaced residents into some of the company's other vacant apartments, rent-free, for up to two months. Workers also were issuing checks on the spot to reimburse residents for security deposits and rent. By late morning Treonis had issued checks to more than 100 people for amounts ranging from $200 to $600. Most storefronts along Plainfield's main thoroughfare, Lockport Street, were shuttered Wednesday. But two insurance agencies were doing a brisk business. ``We've had three dozen calls since eight o'clock this morning,'' said Mike Hull of Plainfield Insurance Agency Inc. In Plainfield Township people also hurried to clean yards and what was left of their homes. ``We're just waiting for the insurance guy to come out,'' said Jim Schmidt, owner of a frame house that suffered extensive damage in the storm. ``Obviously it's going to be a while.'' The American Red Cross had three shelters for the homeless. While providing for immediate needs such as food and clothing, the organization was also concerned about the long-term mental impact of the disaster. The Red Cross will provide ``someone to talk to and some stress counseling,'' said spokeswoman Michele McCrillis. ``A lot of people _ it hasn't hit them yet,'' she said. ``The full shock isn't going to hit them probably for a little while.'' The flat area southwest of Chicago is sometimes referred to as ``Tornado Alley.'' On June 23, 1976, three people were killed when a twister passed through nearby Lemont. A 1969 tornado killed 33 people in Oak Lawn, a southwest Chicago suburb.

DOC.HEAD: Opposing Forces in the Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the breakdown of the opposing forces in the Persian Gulf:
DOC.HEAD: IRAQI FORCES: Army: regular 555,000, reserves 480,000. Claims
DOC.TEXT: militia called Popular Army, originally formed in gulf war and partially demobilized after cease-fire, of 5 million. Tanks: 5,500, including some 500 T-72s. Heavy artillery: 3,500 Multiple Rocket Launchers: 200 Surface-to-Surface Missiles: estimated 500 Surface-to-Air Missiles: 330 launchers Combat Aircraft: 500-plus, reportedly including Soviet-supplied Su-24 long-range fighter-bombers. Navy: 1 training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, estimated eight missile attack craft, six torpedo boats.
DOC.HEAD: MULTINATIONAL FORCES OPPOSING IRAQ:
