UNITED STATES: Officials say more than 100,000 troops,
DOC.TEXT: including those aboard ships, are in the gulf region or on the way. Deployments could go as high as 250,000. The troops include elements of the 82nd and 101st Airborne Divisions, the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment, and other units. They also include a contingent of 45,000 Marines. The American fleet in the gulf and Arabian Sea waters immediately outside it totals about 30 ships, including three aircraft carriers, a battleship armed with Tomahawk cruise missiles, more than a dozen missile cruisers, destroyers, supply ships and an undisclosed number of submarines. Two hospital ships are sailing for the gulf. Another seven ships are expected in the Mediterranean. The Pentagon has also sent 22 Stealth fighter-bombers and dozens of other aircraft.
DOC.HEAD: BRITAIN: Has a flotilla permanently in the gulf and has
DOC.TEXT: contributed three warships: a destroyer armed with Sea Dart missiles and two Frigates armed with Exocet and Seawolf missiles. They are accompanied in the gulf by a Royal Fleet auxilliary vessel. Soon to join them will be three Royal Fleet auxiliary ships: one supply vessel, one fleet tanker and one forward supply vessel. Three minesweepers and one support vessel are en route, but the minesweepers are expected to stay in the eastern Mediterranean. Also dispatched were two squadrons of Tornadoes and one squadron of Jaguar fighter-bombers. A squadron totals 12-16 planes. The F3 class Tornado fighter-interceptors is based in Saudi Arabia. The Jaguars are at Thumrait airbase in neighboring Oman. The second squadron of Tornadoes, which are IDS-type interdictor strike planes, are expected to arrive within the week from a base in West Germany. There are also three Nimrod maritime reconnaisance aircraft stationed in Oman.
DOC.HEAD: FRANCE: Nine ships are either in the gulf or en route,
DOC.TEXT: including the aircraft carrier Clemenceau with anti-tank helicopters, a guided-missile cruiser and two destroyers equipped with anti-ship Exocet missiles, two frigates and one corvette. The helicopters will be sent to Saudi Arabia. One company of 180 paratroopers has been sent to the United Arab Emirates. They are equipped for chemical warfare.
DOC.HEAD: GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United
DOC.TEXT: Arab Emirates, Qatar and until Aug. 2, Kuwait): A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops based in northeast Saudi Arabia. They would be supported by Saudi Arabian forces.
DOC.HEAD: GREECE: Greece has pledged to send its top frigate, the Limnos,
DOC.TEXT: to join multinational operations in the gulf. The ship was expected to depart soon, although no date was announced. The frigate has a 180-member crew and is equipped with a Phalanx anti-missile system, ground-to-air missiles and ground-to-ground missiles. It can also carry two anti-submarine helicopters.
DOC.HEAD: ITALY: Two frigates and a support ship are on the way to the
DOC.TEXT: gulf, having sailed through the Suez Canal. Two corvettes are in the eastern Mediterranean off the coast of Turkey.
DOC.HEAD: NETHERLANDS: Has sent one air defense frigate and one standard
DOC.TEXT: frigate are expected to arrive in the Gulf of Oman or Gulf of Aqaba next week. The Dutch navy has sent six Stinger short-range missiles.
DOC.HEAD: SPAIN: Sending one frigate and two corvettes. The frigate will
DOC.TEXT: be based in the Gulf of Oman. The corvettes are en route to Bab El Mandeb Strait at the entrance to the Red Sea.
Also:
DOC.HEAD: EGYPT: 4,000 ground troops sent.
MOROCCO: 1,200 ground troops sent.
SYRIA: 2,000 ground troops sent.
AUSTRALIA: Two-guided missile frigates and a supply ship are en
DOC.TEXT: route.
DOC.HEAD: BELGIUM: Two minehunters and a supply ship are en route to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: of Oman.
DOC.HEAD: CANADA: Two destroyers and a supply ship are heading for the
DOC.TEXT: gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Record Heat Continues From Plains to South Atlantic Coast
DOC.TEXT: Wednesday was another scorcher from the lower half of the Plains to the southern Atlantic coast, and rain spread through the Ohio Valley. Record high temperatures were recorded in Jonesboro, Ark., at 102; Macon, Ga., 102; and Tupelo, Miss., 102, and tied in Augusta, Ga., 100; Cape Hatteras, N.C., 91, and Jacksonville, Fla., 99. Humidity with the 99 degrees at Jacksonville brought the heat index to near 110 degrees. In Alabama, state health officials issued a heat alert, warning people to stay indoors as much as possible. Alabama farmers fear continued hot, dry weather that has parched pastures and fields will severely reduce harvests of cotton and peanuts. In Washington County, Arkansas, record heat killed thousands of chickens. Bob Justice, a spokesman for Tyson Foods Inc. in Springdale, said the company's growers have lost 25,000 birds in the last few days. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms extended over Kentucky, Tennessee, western North Carolina, parts of West Virginia, northern Ohio, southern Indiana and southern Illinois. Showers and storms also were scattered along the Gulf Coast, the coast of the Pacific Northwest, northeastern California, north-central Iowa and northern Maine. A record low temperature for the day was recorded in Hollywood, Fla., at 69. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 31 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 58 at Bremerton and Oak Harbor, Wash., and San Luis Obispo, Calif., to 107 at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares Disaster
With AM-Illinois Tornadoes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday declared the tornado-devastated area of Illinois a disaster area. The declaration makes residents of Will County eligible for special federal aid assistance such as loans and grants to individuals, businesses and public utilities. The White House said Bush spoke with Gov. Jim Thompson before issuing the declaration.

DOC.HEAD: Second Prototype of Advanced Tactical Fighter Rolls Out
LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp.'s contender in the competition to see which defense contractor will build the nation's 21st century fighter jet was unveiled Wednesday, a fierce-looking, twin-tailed, stubby-winged craft. Air Force generals at the ceremony said the Middle East crisis demonstrates the need for such a plane. Lockheed's YF-22 prototype of the Advanced Tactical Fighter was rolled out at its Palmdale manufacturing plant to the strains of Wagner's ``The Ride of the Valkyries'' in the background. ``This is a great day for the evolution of tactical aircraft,'' said Lockheed chairman Daniel M. Tellep. Lockheed's plane will compete against a Northrop model YF-23, which was rolled out and taken for a test flight Monday. Lockheed teamed with the Boeing Corp. and General Dynamics to build the YF-22. Northrop teamed with McDonnell Douglas to build its prototype. Both planes have smooth contours to reduce their radar reflections and are built of advanced composite materials. The Pentagon wants a fighter plane that can fly twice the speed of sound without using fuel-guzzling afterburners. But it must also be highly maneuverable for dogfights with other planes and use radar-evading stealth technology. The Lockheed plane resembles the Navy's FA-18 Hornet fighter-attack aircraft, with stubby wings. The Northrop plane is longer, with a cigar-like fuselage and a wingspan that, from overhead, looks like a kite. The Lockheed YF-22 stayed on the ground after its rollout ceremony and officials refused to say when it would be flown. Tellep said it doesn't matter that Northrop got its aircraft up first. ``It is not he who flies first, it is he who flies best,'' he said. The ATF program faced fading prospects for approval in Congress before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, but the crisis has enhanced prospects for approval of major defense projects. The contract calls for 750 fighter planes for the Air Force and approximately 500 for the Navy at a cost of $51 million apiece. The price tag is about twice the cost of the F-15 Eagle, the current front-line fighter deployed in the Middle East. The F-15 will have been in service nearly 30 years when the first ATFs enter military service in the year 2002. Air Force Gen. Ronald W. Yates Jr. recalled the Munich crisis of 1938, in which Adolf Hitler's military might forced appeasement by Britain's Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain. He compared it to today's standoff with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. The difference is the support of a strong military armed with the most advanced weaponry, said Yates, commander of the Air Force Systems Command at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio. Air Force Maj. Gen. Joseph W. Ralston said he is optimistic about congressional funding for the ATF program in spite of recent defense spending cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Perjury Charges Filed Against Police Chief; Interim Chief Appointed
DOC.TEXT: Seven perjury charges were filed Wednesday against suspended Police Chief Mack Vines as a result of an investigation into his testimony to a special panel that looked into the shooting of a civilian by an officer. ``It's sufficient to note that we found in that investigation ... seven separate counts of aggravated perjury,'' said District Attorney John Vance. ``I think the chief made two appearances (before the panel), but we can't go into what is alleged in each of those because that is still pending before the grand jury.'' Vance said the charges would be presented to the grand jury on Sept. 10. A third-degree felony carries a maximum 10-year prison term and fines of up to $10,000. City Manager Jan Hart, said Vines, 51, would remain on indefinite suspension and named a new acting chief. Vines' attorney, Kim Wade, was ``not speaking with the media,'' a woman who answered the phone at Wade's office said Wednesday. Vines in the past has denied wrongdoing and has refused to resign. Some city council members said the charges alone are enough to cost Vines the job he has held since July 1988. During his tenure, Vines has angered some veteran officers while winning the support of some leaders of minority groups. ``I think it would be nearly impossible for Chief Vines to lead this police department with the confidence of the city into the future. Humpty Dumpty is broken and I don't think there's any reasonable way of putting that all together again,'' said Councilman Jerry Bartos. Dallas Police Association President Monica Smith, who has been critical of Vines in the past, said she believed Vines ``is entitled to and will receive a fair review of the facts presented to the grand jury by the district attorney's office.'' The developments stem from the fatal shooting last year of an unarmed Mexican national by officer Patrick LeMaire. Vines fired LeMaire 17 days after the killing. LeMaire was reinstated last month by an administrative law judge who said Vines failed to justify the firing. During the administrative hearing, an internal affairs detective testified that his initial report on the shooting was altered. That led the city manager to appoint a three-member panel to look into the internal affairs officer's allegations, and the speed with which LeMaire was fired. Ms. Hart suspended Vines and Assistant Chief Greg Holliday with pay on Aug. 3 after Holliday told her Vines had called him at home and tried to persuade him to de-emphasize in his testimony the speed of Vines' firing of LeMaire. Ms. Hart asked Vance to investigate the charges. The panel decided the haste ``created a frenzied atmosphere conducive to mistakes'' and said that cast suspicion on LeMaire's suspension. Vance said Holliday was helpful in the investigation, and Ms. Hart said, ``there is no indication that Chief Holliday was not truthful to the panel.'' She lifted his suspension Wednesday and said he would return to work immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Begin Lifting 150 Bodies in Yugoslavian Mine
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers on Wednesday started hauling to the surface the bodies of 150 miners killed in the country's worst mining accident. Officials said the death toll could eventually reach 180. Mining inspectors said too many miners were allowed in the Kreka coal mine shaft at the time of Sunday's blast, although they did not say how many miners should have been allowed. Inspectors also said mine officials broke regulations by allowing relatives of the miners to work in the mine without being officially assigned there. The mine is located 90 miles west of Belgrade. Rescuers in recent days found the bodies of 150 miners and started bringing them up early Wednesday with a conveyor system repaired after the blast, according to Bosko Zelic, a member of the mine's managing board. Rescue teams working in round-the-clock shifts were still trying to clear away rubble blocking access to remote parts of the nine-mile maze of underground corridors, officials said. They also were striving to ventilate all corridors to eliminate the possibility of a new explosion. The management issued an updated casualty list with the names of 180 miners instead of the 170 previously thought to have been working underground at the time of the explosion. The blast is thought to have been caused by a buildup of coal dust or methane gas. An investigation is under way. Officials said a funeral ceremony will be held on the main square of the nearby town of Tuzla once the bodies of all victims are recovered. Yugoslavia's worst previous mining disaster occurred in 1965, when 128 miners were killed in a mine explosion in Bosnia. Ninety miners were killed in an explosion at a coal mine south of Belgrade in November.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Say Manager of Failed Credit Union Has Recovered
DOC.TEXT: The former manager of a failed credit union has recovered from a mental illness enough to understand fraud and tax charges against him and help in his defense, federal medical authorities said. Lawrence E. King Jr., former manager of the Franklin Community Federal Credit Union, will be allowed to return to Omaha from the U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisoners at Rochester, Minn., U.S. Magistrate Richard Kopf said in an order filed Tuesday. King is ordered to report Friday to a pretrial services officer in the U.S. Probation Office in Omaha, Kopf said. Kopf ordered the report sealed but said in his order: ``In pertinent part, the certificate provides that Mr. King has recovered from his mental disease or defect to such an extent that he is able to understand the nature and consequences of the proceedings against him and to assist properly in his defense.'' The judge gave defense attorneys 10 days to study the psychiatric report. A federal court hearing will be held later to determine whether King is now competent to stand trial on charges facing him, Kopf said. King, a prominent businessman who sang the national anthem at the 1984 Republican National Convention, is awaiting trial in U.S. District Court on 40 counts charging conspiracy, fraud and filing false tax returns stemming from the November 1988 failure of Franklin. King's wife, Alice, is charged with 12 counts of conspiracy and fraud. Federal authorities said $39 million was missing from the credit union, which had been established to help north Omaha's poor, when it was closed on Nov. 4, 1988. King was sent to the Rochester center April 5 for four months of examination and evaluation after being found incompetent to stand trial. He had been diagnosed as suffering from ``delusional paranoid disorder, grandiose type'' by the chief psychiatrist at the U.S. Medical Facility at Springfield, Mo. King's court-appointed attorneys, Steven Achelpohl and Marilyn Abbott, did not challenge the competency finding in March. A third attorney appointed to represent King's personal interests in the case, Alan Stoler, said King thought he was competent and resisted the evaluation and treatment. King and his wife were indicted by a federal grand jury in May 1989.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Expects to Sign Unification Treaty Soon
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with new disagreement over abortion developing Wednesday night. No pickup. ^By TERRENCE PETTY
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government said Wednesday the two Germanys will likely sign within two days a treaty providing the formal basis for unification, although differences remain over abortion. In East Germany, an estimated 90,000 public employees in at least 20 cities held a second day of warning strikes over fears their jobs will be endangered by unification with West Germany. About 10,000 nurses, garbagemen, bus drivers and others stopped working for two hours in East Berlin. Strikes of up to two hours were also reported in Erfurt, Potsdam, Leipzig, Gera and several other cities. Fire trucks and garbage trucks blocked several streets, and the airport in Leipzig was temporarily closed. In Bonn, West Germany's capital, Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said a treaty to serve as the document formally merging the nations on Oct. 3 and meshing their laws is near approval. Closed-door talks among government and opposition officials continued into the night in an effort to clear up the remaining difficulties. But Schaeuble said no difficulties were expected in getting the approval of all sides. Parties within Kohl's coalition had already signaled they would yield to the opposition Social Democrats' insistence no West German women be prosecuted for seeking abortions in East Germany after unity. The left-of-center Social Democrats had threatened to veto the treaty over that issue. But late Wednesday another disagreement arose in the abortion dispute _ how long after unity the two Germanys would keep their widely differing abortion laws. East Germany's abortion law is far more permissive than West Germany's. The major political parties had already agreed the two Germanys should keep their respective abortion laws for an interim two-year period until an all-German parliament can choose abortion statutes for a united Germany. But the Social Democrats insisted Wednesday night that there should be a three-year extension if the all-German parliament fails to agree on a new abortion law. Lawmakers from Kohl's coalition said the more restrictive West German abortion regulations should automatically extend to what is now East Germany at the end of two years. Earlier Wednesday, Schaeuble expressed confidence that all major obstacles to the treaty would be worked out. Schaeuble also said Kohl's government and West Germany's 11 states agreed that Oct. 3, the chosen date of unity, will be written into the treaty as an all-German national holiday. The interior minister told reporters the treaty will likely be signed Friday in West Berlin at a ceremony in the Reichstag, the former Parliament and one of Germany's most important landmarks, ``if everything goes according to my own desires.'' He said the two German governments will hold one final round of negotiations on the treaty Thursday. Schaeuble made the remarks after Kohl met with governors of the 11 West German states, most of whom belong to the opposition Social Democrat Party. The conservative chancellor needs a two-thirds parliamentary majority to ratify the treaty and thus the support of the Social Democrats, the second-largest party in West Germany. The Social Democrats had given Kohl until Wednesday to reverse his earlier decision on abortion. During the past two days, he had given strong signals he would do so rather than jeopardize the treaty. Approval of the treaty was not essential for unification. But leaders of both nations considered it imperative that they negotiate such a document rather than allow West German law to simply take effect automatically in East Germany. But there were intense differences _ even within Kohl's coalition _ over his earlier decision that West German women be legally barred from seeking abortions in East Germany. In another issue threatening to block the treaty, West Germany's states were afraid they might get unfair treatment when it comes to divvying up sales tax revenues with the five soon-to-be-resurrected East German states. Under the draft treaty, East German states will get a smaller proportion of the revenues than West German states because of their smaller economies. Nonetheless, the treaty will pave the way for more assistance than the East German states now receive from West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Freed in Mexico As Satanic Cult Case Collapses
DOC.TEXT:
A district judge has released eight Indians accused of participating in a drug cult that allegedly killed about 30 people, a lawyer for a government advocacy group said Wednesday. The action by Judge Jose Cuevas Zavala in Tepic, 400 miles northwest of Mexico City, represents another blow to the spectacular case launched by federal police in July. In comments to reporters last month, the judge ridiculed police allegations that the Indians had killed about 30 people in satanic rituals. Prosecutors in neighboring Durango state, where the killings allegedly occurred, refused to press charges in connection with the alleged deaths. No human remains were found, and senior church officials in the area denied the existence of a satanic cult. The National Indian Institute, a government organization to protect Indians, joined the case to help Tepehuano Indian defendants it said were being mistreated by police. The Institute attorney, Carlos Puga Quiroga, said the judge on Tuesday ordered the eight released on their own recognizance. They still face the only charges filed against them _ cultivating marijuana in their remote villages. In addition, Puga said five minors held in the case have been cleared of any charges and will be released to their parents. Only one man, Olayo Soto Soto, remains imprisoned in the case. Puga said Soto is accused of owning the land on which police found a small marijuana patch, while the others were accused only of helping cultivate the crop. In July, federal police in Tepic claimed Soto was the chief sorcerer of a cult that worshipped an idol called ``El Amigo,'' or ``The Friend,'' that had sacrificed 30 or more people to gain protection for their drug activities. Members of the group initially confessed to the allegations during police questioning. But they recanted before the judge, saying the confessions had been beaten out of them. Soto told reporters he is a traditional Indian healer, but he denied practicing any sorcery. The Institute also has appealed for his release. In an earlier drug-cult case, police in April 1989 found 15 bodies buried on a ranch near the northern city of Matamoros across the U.S.-Mexico border from Brownsville, Texas. Among those slain 21-year-old University of Texas student Mark Kilroy.
Police claimed those victims were slain by drug smugglers who believed human sacrifices would protect them from police. Group leader Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo and his bodyguard died of gunshot wounds as police closed in on them in a Mexico City apartment in May 1989. Ten people still face charges in connection with the case.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Announces New Austerity Measures
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf: ``The measures,'' to note news agency with similar account
DOC.TEXT: Cuba on Wednesday announced sweeping energy-saving measures to compensate for a 2-million-ton deficit in oil deliveries from the Soviet Union. The supply of gasoline by private vehicles was cut by 30 percent and unspecified cuts were instituted in the delivery of diesel fuel to state enterprises. The measures were announced on state television; a text was made available through a U.S. government monitoring service. The Cuban news agency, Prensa Latina, later carried the announcement, according to monitoring in Mexico City. The account said the Soviet Union had not been able to make deliveries of supplies, including fuels, for some time. ``So far, almost 2 million tons of oil and derivatives have not been delivered,'' the broadcast said. ``It is impossible that such a high deficit, a fifth of the fuel that should be received, does not have serious effects in the functioning of the economy and the life of the country.'' According to the broadcast, the Soviets are making every effort to fulfill their commitments and Cuba will continue will its export delivery schedule to the Soviets. It said the gasoline delivered through a voucher system would be cut by 50 percent, but did not say what percentage of consumption is accounted for by that system. Production at a nickel plant is being halted because of that industry's high energy consumption, the report said. Families were encouraged to reduce the average monthly consumption of electric power by 10 percent. If there is no such reduction, households in areas of maximum demand would be forced to do without electricity one day a week, the broadcast said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Drafts Law To Open First Postwar Stock Exchange
DOC.TEXT: A law has been drafted to open the first stock exchange in postwar Poland, a government spokesman said Wednesday. The law on securities and the stock market represents the next step in Poland's legislative drive toward introducing capitalism. Last month, the Parliament passed a statute on selling state-owned industries to private owners. Jan Buchacz, a spokesman for the government committee established to reform Poland's laws on ownership, said the draft law on the stock exchange is ready for public discussion. ``We want everyone to add his opinion and see if there is no essential discrepancy in it,'' he said. He said the law could be passed by Parliament within the next few weeks. Creation of the stock exchange is fundamental to Poland's economic reform program, which is aimed at transforming the centralized economy to a market-driven system. Under the privatization law, all citizens are to be given bonds which can be exchanged for stock in the previously state-owned companies. The draft law provides a legal framework for the functioning of the stock market, establishing a state-controlled stock exchange and a committee to grant licenses for issuing and selling shares, the government daily Rzeczpospolita reported Wednesday. ``I treat it as a continuation of the privatization law _ another push, another expression of that law,'' Buchacz told The Associated Press. The government committee studied international stock markets and followed ``various solutions and experiences, especially of the British and American systems,'' Buchacz said. ``But we also watched closely what was happening in Hungary,'' he said, referring to the first stock exchange in the East bloc, which opened in Budapest on June 21. Rzeczpospolita observed that implementation of the stock exchange law will mean creation of a new professional group _ brokers _ who will receive licenses from the stock committee and will be expected to form an association. Buchacz said his committee is preparing training programs and examinations for brokers, a profession virtually unknown in Poland, and hopes that the first brokers will receive licenses in October or November. ``After this law is passed, we will need only a lot of wise heads,'' he added. Poland had a stock exchange until 1939, when Nazi Germany invaded. The Soviet-backed Communists who consolidated power after World War II did not reopen it.

DOC.BYLINE: Army Depots Work Overtime To Meet Crisis Needs ^By RICH KIRKPATRICK
DOC.TEXT: Officials at two key Army supply depots said Wednesday their staffs were working around the clock to outfit troops sent to Saudi Arabia, despite layoff announcements that some say have affected morale. The officers at the New Cumberland Army Depot and the Letterkenny Army Depot in Chambersburg, Pa., took reporters and photographers on a tour of their bases. Col. John K. Joseph, commander of the New Cumberland depot, said his employees' dedication to the Desert Shield mission had overcome dismay over a layoff announcement that came Aug. 8, just as the buildup was getting underway. ``My impression is the troops are OK,'' he said at a briefing. ``They are pretty patriotic folks and they're dedicated. They're down there supporting the soldiers that are over there and they're proud to do it.'' The depot has been working two shifts, seven days a week in the wake of the American response to the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Joseph said. In some areas, three shifts are going, he said. Most of the employees are civilians. At Letterkenny, Col. David Gordon, director of supply, said the supply and ammunition depots have gone to either 12-hour shifts or three eight-hour shifts. People have been generally willing to work overtime, he said. ``The attitude's been real good,'' Gordon said. Faced with budget cuts, the Army Materiel Command announced three weeks ago that 365 of the 2,500 employees at New Cumberland and 450 of 3,400 at Letterkenny would be laid off Oct. 12. Steve Lightfoot, a 12-year employee who works in the shipping section at New Cumberland, said the layoffs are ``a sore subject everywhere.'' With the Middle East crisis, the work load is increasing, ``but morale is so far down because they know they're losing their jobs and it's hard to do the job,'' said Lightfoot, not among those who have received pink slips. Some employees facing layoffs are working hard but others aren't, he said. Joseph said the reductions were based on assumptions and budget decisions before the Iraqi invasion. ``This action in the desert changed all that,'' he said. ``The Department of the Army is looking at how to fix that ... I personally hope they do change it.'' New Cumberland, an 850-acre base across the Susquehanna River from the state capital, supplies 88 percent of the goods the Army ships to overseas posts. Its $3.5 billion inventory includes 307,569 items ranging from clothing to spare parts and tools. The items are loaded onto trucks for shipment to ports in Baltimore or Bayonne, N.J., or to Air Force bases at Dover, Del. and other East Coast locations. At the 19,000-acre Letterkenny depot, four shipping crews of four to five people work shifts of about 12 hours moving ammunition to Desert Shield and other units. About 15 truckloads a day have been going out since early August, said Frank Van Hatten, director of ammunition operations. The depot stores ammunition ranging from small arms bullets to 2,000-pound bombs and some conventionally armed missiles in 902 earth-covered igloos and 10 warehouses. Workers were loading boxes of .50-caliber bullets and smoke grenades from one igloo as reporters watched. Van Hatten said about 1 percent of the depot's ammunition stock has been drawn down since the American force was deployed to Saudi Arabia. At a truck painting and rehabilitation building, workers were putting tan paint on military vehicles. Gordon said they've run out of desert sand color and are getting low on tan as well.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Must Die, Former Israeli Intelligence Chief Says
DOC.TEXT: Israel's former spy chief said Wednesday that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein must die, for the sake of Arabs as well as Jews. ``For the survival of all the Arab states, Saddam Hussein has to be destroyed ... Someone has to find him in his bunker and kill him,'' Maj. Gen. Shlomo Gazit told delegates at the biennial convention of B'Nai B'rith International in Dallas. ``If Saddam Hussein is not destroyed, he definitely will continue with his nuclear armament goal,'' he said. ``It has to be done only by the Iraqis themselves, and I'm not sure they are ripe enough, mature enough to do it.'' Gazit, who headed Israeli military intelligence in the 1970s, voiced the concerns of many Israelis that Saddam could turn the Arab-Iraq conflict into an Arab-Israeli conflict. Another worry is the survival of Jordan's King Hussein, a moderate in terms of Israeli-Arab politics. ``If this conflict is not resolved quickly, this could mean the end of King Hussein's reign in Jordan,'' Gazit said. He spoke during a panel discussion during the convention of the world's largest Jewish organizaiton. Seymour Reich, president of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish-American Organizations, said Jewish leaders in the United States are solidly behind President Bush's deployment of U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf, even though it means U.S. forces are protecting an Arab country. ``We believe it is essential that the governments of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait be maintained, and we told President Bush we fully support the actions he has taken,'' Reich said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Search for Missing in Tornado-Shattered Towns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with aid offer from Soviets; SUBS grafs 11-13, bgng `He declared ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with federal disaster relief promised, add detail on offer, report of death; picks up 14th graf, `More than...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CX8,9
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers on Wednesday searched a tornado-devastated swath of northern Illinois for the missing and the dead, while folks began salvaging belongings from homes the twisters shredded ``like an eggbeater.'' At least 24 people died and more than 300 were injured Tuesday by the tornadoes, which steamrolled across a region known as ``Tornado Alley,'' about 35 miles southwest of Chicago. Scores of people were left homeless. Others spent the day cleaning their yards, hammering on temporary roofs, sifting through rubble, piling up belongings in pickup trucks lining the streets in neighboring Plainfield. Offers of aid have poured in, including one from the Soviet embassy in Washington. Theresa Rabaduex, a 23-year-old school bus driver who lived in a complex ripped apart by the storm in Crest Hill, said tenants in her building were being moved to free lodging ``but that doesn't do you any good if you don't have any of your things. I don't even have a bed.'' She walked through the debris, trying to find her three black cats. ``That's all that really matters to me,'' she said. ``It was like an eggbeater went through the inside of the house,'' Bruce Marshall said as he tried to fashion a makeshift cover for his roofless home in neighboring Plainfield. The storms struck virtually without warning Tuesday afternoon along an eight-mile path. Hit hardest were the small towns of Crest Hill and Plainfield. Portions of Joliet also were damaged, including a new subdivision of houses torn down to their foundations just a few months after they were built. Gov. James R. Thompson said he's seen a lot of disasters during 14 years in office, but ``nothing in my personal experience ... compares with this.'' ``Anything that is still standing is pure luck,'' he said after touring the stricken area Wednesday. ``All I can say is thank God the death toll is not in the hundreds. We are very, very lucky.'' President Bush declared the region a disaster area. The Soviet officials called the governor's office seeking information on how to help, Thompson said. Illinois will provide at least $25 million in state deposits for low-interest loans to tornado victims, said state Treasurer Jerry Cosentino. There were 24 fatalities confirmed Wednesday, and toll could reach 30 dead, said John Plunk, acting director of the Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Agency. Officials said another Plainfield man died of carbon monoxide poisoning from a generator he used when power was lost in his home. More than 300 people were treated at hospitals, and authorities said more than 70 remained hospitalized Wednesday. At least 11 of them were listed in critical condition. Wednesday's weather, sunny and cool, gave the area some relief, and the forecast called for fair skies the rest of the week. National Guardsmen in Crest Hill used dogs, foot patrols and infrared photography to search for more victims in a muddy corn field, but found none. Six people were believed missing from a seven-building apartment complex next to the field. The infrared scan from a helicopter was intended to detect differences in temperature that might lead them to victims. At least nine of the storm's deaths occurred near the apartments, where some victims were blown 400 feet out of the building, said Chief Dave Martis of the Lockport Fire District, which includes Crest Hill. Downed power lines were scattered across several streets and nearly 7,000 customers remained without power Wednesday in Joliet, Plainfield and the Aurora area. The smell of fresh wood permeated the air as residents used chain saws to remove trees tossed like matchsticks across their yards. ``I've got lots of family members helping, and some four or five guys from surrounding towns,'' said Don Kinley, 53, of Plainfield, who lost most of the second floor of his home. ``I don't know them _ they just want to help,'' said Kinley, tears running down his cheeks. Mike Thomas, owner of a Naperville wiring company, said he decided to take the day off to help Kinley and other people because ``They'd probably do it for me.'' Night clothes hung from trees that had leaves ripped from branches. Cars remained in front yards, where they were dumped by the storms. A garbage bin was impaled high in a tree. Mike Dehler, a 26-year-old restaurant manager sifted through the debris outside what used to be his third-floor apartment. ``There's my water bed,'' Dehler said, pointing to a deflated silver mattress. ``Hopefully I'm going to find some clothes in these dressers. All I have is what I have on.''

DOC.HEAD: Big Ben's Bonger Back in Business
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th pvs to CORRECT Big Ben's beginning to 1859 sted 1869.
DOC.TEXT: Big Ben's bell is back in business, tolling the hours as it has done for 131 years. The famous, booming tone of the 13{-ton bell resumed at 10 p.m. Tuesday for the first time since March 26, the Department of the Environment said. Inspectors found earlier this year that the hammer which strikes the bell was suffering metal fatigue, so repairs were made. Big Ben, named after Sir Bejamin Hall, a government works commissioner, first sounded May 31, 1859. It is normally silenced twice a year when the hands of the four-faced clock are moved foward in the spring for daylight savings time and back again in the fall. Big Ben properly is the name of the bell, but it has become the nickname for the entire 20-story tower of the Houses of Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Calls Self Porn Star Kills Off-Broadway Producer
DOC.TEXT: A young man who calls himself a pornographic movie actor has been charged in the stabbing death of an off-Broadway producer, police said Wednesday. Michael Kelly, 20, was charged with second-degree murder, first-degree robbery and criminal possession of a weapon in the death of Michael Frank, 46, said Officer Janice Swinney. The officer accused Kelly of robbing Frank, an acquaintance, of an undetermined amount of money and killing him in Frank's apartment on Aug. 23. At the time of his arrest Tuesday, Kelly identified himself as a ``porn star,'' said Officer Hugh J. Barry. However, a check of the 1990 Directory of Adult Films doesn't list Kelly.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Knocks Out Power at 45-story NYC Hotel
DOC.TEXT: An electrical fire beneath the 45-story New York Hilton led to the voluntary evacuation of 1,000 people Wednesday, interrupted business meetings and snarled rush-hour traffic. No injuries were reported. Hilton spokeswoman Lola Preiss said the hotel has 2,039 rooms, but she didn't know how many were occupied because the hotel computers were down after power was cut. Fire Lt. Jim Powell said the blaze, put out within two hours, was confined to a switching room one level below the street. Guests were evacuated because the fire knocked out most of the hotel's power, including air conditioning and lights, authorities said. The blackout lasted from 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. ``We're telling the occupants of the building that there is no danger; if they want to leave, they can,'' said Assistant Fire Chief Matthew Murtaugh of Manhattan Central Command. An emergency generator kept one elevator running. It wasn't clear how many guests decided to stay. The lobby was filled with the acrid smell of burning electrical cable. The fire was contained to a room of electrical switching gear and did not affect any transformers, so there was no danger of released PCBs, said Fire Chief Ellsworth Hughes and Con Edison spokeswoman Pat Richardi. PCBs are a toxic chemical formerly used in some cooling and insulating applications. Hundreds of people lined the sidewalks outside the hotel on Sixth Avenue between 53rd and 54th streets. Side streets around the hotel were closed for most of the morning, and traffic slowed to a crawl on Sixth Avenue. The Red Cross handed out beverages outside the hotel and Preiss said flashlights were given to guests who chose to remain in their rooms or lobby. She said the emergency generators provided dim lighting, but not enough to read by. Among those who left the hotel was Bill McKay of Stamford, Conn., who was having breakfast with colleagues in a lower level restaurant, near the switching room, when the fire broke out. McKay heard two ``booms,'' about five seconds apart. The lights flickered. Then smoke began to fill the area. As patrons made their way upstairs, ``We could barely see the escalator,'' said McKay. ``We were wondering, `Are we going to get a free meal out of this?' '' he joked. They did.

DOC.HEAD: Army, Mohawks Tear Down Bridge Barricade Together in Canada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new material throughout. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Masked Mohawks on Wednesday helped soldiers tear down barricades set up seven weeks ago to block the Mercier Bridge to the island of Montreal, avoiding a bloody confrontation. But other Mohawks said the dispute remains unsettled and barricades will stay up at nearby Oka. After a meeting in front of one barricade leading to the community of Chateauguay and the Kahnawake reservation, army officers and unarmed members of the Mohawks' Warriors Society began tearing down the Mercier Bridge barrier with heavy equipment. They then began dismantling a barricade near Chateauguay on a highway blocked since July 11, when Mohawks at Oka fought a gun battle with provincial police in a dispute over land the community of Oka earmarked as a golf course. The Indians said it was ancestral land. A police officer was killed. Responsibility in the death has not been fixed. Other Indians shut down Mercier Bridge in sympathy with the Oka natives, infuriating commuters and local businesses and leading to outbreaks of violence. The bridge blockade has meant long commuting hours for residents across the St. Lawrence River from Montreal. Residents had thrown rocks and bricks at police who responded with tear gas. On Tuesday, they hurled stones and bottles at cars full of Mohawks leaving the reservation in anticipation of a confrontation between Warriors and soldiers. Dan David, a Mohawk spokesman at the Kahnesatake community in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, said the barricades there will remain. He said the agreement in Kahnawake affects only that reservation. ``This place holds the key to everything,'' David said. ``Everybody knows this is where everything started and this is where everything must end.'' Prime Minister Brian Mulroney cautioned at Meech Lake, Quebec, after an inner Cabinet meeting: ``It's an encouraging sign but the problem is not solved yet. Hopefully that . . . very positive attitude will be contagious.'' Native leaders applauded Wednesday's developments. In Winnipeg, Phil Fontaine, leader of the Assembly of Manitoba Chiefs, said ``We're really very pleased and relieved. The Mohawks have done us proud.'' Earlier Wednesday, trucks, front-end loaders and two armored personnel carriers moved toward Mohawk barricades near the bridge. Reports said a government ultimatum to Indian negotiators warned: settle or face army guns. A Mohawk spokesman, Jack LeClaire, said Wednesday at one barricade, ``The decision was taken to avoid bloodshed. We have reached an honorable settlement between the military and the community of Kahnawake.'' Kahnawake leaders were negotiating with army and government representatives when news came that the barricades at the bridge were being destroyed. Just before dismantling began, two soldiers got out of a truck, advanced to the barricade, went behind and emerged with two masked members of the Mohawk Warriors group. A Mohawk in civilian clothes operated a mechanical shovel one side of the barricade while two army bulldozers worked on the other side to bring it down. About 20 masked but unarmed Warriors helped with the dismantling. At the same time, the army began filling in a large trench in front of the barricades. LeClaire said, ``The bridge will be inspected. If the Quebec Department of Transport says it is passable, we hope it will be open by the weekend.''

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Supporters Arrested in Raids in Troubled Province
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Moslem leader vowing to form alliance with Ms. Bhutto. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 supporters of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto have been arrested in the latest crackdown against ethnic violence in her home province, police said Wednesday. A Moslem leader said he will join forces with the ousted leader to compete in October elections and fight a mounting ``get-Benazir'' campaign. A week of raids across southern Sindh Province began after Aug. 22-23 sniper shootings in Karachi killed at least 31 people, police said. The military-backed caretaker government that replaced Ms. Bhutto's government three weeks ago blamed her Pakistan People's Party for the attacks. It has not provided proof of the allegations. Ms. Bhutto's supporters say many People's Party activists, including members of the former Sindh provincial government, have gone into hiding. The former prime minister has accused the caretaker government of trying to force her out of politics before the Oct. 24 general elections. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed Ms. Bhutto and her government Aug. 6, citing a variety of charges that included inability to curb ethnic violence in Sindh. More than 500 people have been killed since late May in gang warfare between native Sindhis belonging to the People's Party and members of the militant Mohajir Qami Movement, or Refugee People's Movement. The army has been called out to restore peace and maintain order. The Mohajir Movement represents Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan following the 1947 partition that ended British colonial rule of the subcontinent. It aligned itself with the People's Party in the November 1988 elections and helped Ms. Bhutto become prime minister. But Mohajir members withdrew their support a year later, claiming Ms. Bhutto had reneged on a variety of promises. In Islamabad on Wednesday, Malik Qasim, head of a small renegade faction of the conservative Pakistan Moslem League, said, ``There is a dangerous polarization taking shape in the country.'' While opposing Ms. Bhutto on many ideological points, Qasim said he would ally his small faction with Ms. Bhutto's left-of-center People's Party in order to see that she gets a fair chance in the elections. He said the caretaker government is ``based on partisanship.'' Many analysts say the military could seize power during the political uncertainty. The military had ruled for 25 of Pakistan's 43-year history. Qasim also questioned judicial tribunals set up last weekend to investigate charges of widespread corruption under Ms. Bhutto. Ms. Bhutto has said she will boycott the tribunals and accused her successors of launching a witch hunt against her party and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari. Qasim said the allegations cited to justify Ms. Bhutto's dismissal could apply to her opponents, some of whom now sit in the caretaker government. ``This caretaker government cannot run fair elections,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: West African Force Requests Aid for Monrovia
DOC.TEXT: The West African force sent to Liberia to end the 8-month-old civil war there appealed Wednesday to international donors to send food and medicine to help the residents of Monrovia. The Ghana News Agency, which has a reporter with the 3,000 soldiers of the five-nation force, said its commanders also want to restore electricity, water and communications to the Liberian capital. Troops from Ghana, Nigeria, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia landed in Monrovia on Friday. They have been welcomed by President Samuel Doe and the rebel group led by Prince Johnson, who together control most of Monrovia. The biggest rebel force, led by Charles Taylor, has attacked the West African troops, but so far have been outgunned and driven off, the Ghana said. Taylor, whose forces control most of Liberia, opposes the West African intervention and accuses Nigeria and Guinea of supporting the embattled Doe. Monrovia has been without basic services and cut off from deliveries of food and other supplies since rebels surrounded the capital more than two months ago. The task force commanders urged donors to contact representatives of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States to offer aid. The civil war has left 5,000 people dead, mainly civilians slaughtered for their tribal affiliations. The war began in December when Taylor's forces invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast, accusing Doe of corruption and mismanagement. Johnson later split with Taylor. About 400,000 Liberians from the nation of 2.3 million people have fled to neighboring countries to escape the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawks Waited for Battle, Then Came Word
With AM-Mohawks
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk Warriors at Oka were waiting behind a barricade with automatic rifles on Wednesday for a confrontation that didn't take place. An electric surge raced through the scene as word spread that the army had set a 2 p.m. deadline for a signed agreement or an assault at the Mercier Bridge farther down the St. Lawrence, south of Montreal. A masked member of the Mohawk Warrior Society puffed up the blacktop road to the barricade of logs and wrecked car bodies to spread the word and alert the Indian forces facing the Canadian army 325 feet farther down the hill. ``Shake ratttle and roll,'' muttered one of the men on the barricade, armed with an automatic weapon. Moments later, Mohawk spokeswoman Kahn-Tineta Horn drove up to brief a band of reporters with what she said was information from secret, last-ditch talks at a suburban Montreal hotel. An army officer had interrupted the talks and announced the deadline, she said. ``It appears the army and (the provincial police) have gone out of control,'' she said, adding that a human rights observer was working to get the assault called off. A gray-haired Indian in a camouflage poncho pulled up in a golf cart. ``Don't do nothin' drastic,'' he told the fighters who huddled around him. ``You've all got minds of your own.'' Two o'clock passed with no word of an assault. Three o'clock. Three-thirty. ``We're going to be here when they get here,'' said a Mohawk Warrior who calls himself Hunter. ``We're not going to fire first.'' Hunter is a 20-year-old American Mohawk, a former student at the University of Minnesota. What will he do if the army rolls up and starts pushing down the barricade with tanks fitted with bulldozer blades? ``It's going to be decided on the spot, the decision on how we react,'' he said. The army said it would not shoot first. The Mohawks, who first threw up a barricade March 11 and repulsed an assault by the provincial police on July 11, said they would not shoot first. So what would happen if the army marched up the hill, not shooting, and that barricade suddenly started moving backward? ``That's gonna be wild, huh?'' said a Warrior known as Black Jack, smiling. ``A bulldozer? Then we'll have to put a bulldozer on them, right? You can't give up.'' The original dispute at Oka over the proposed expansion of a golf course onto land claimed by the Indians was solved. The federal government bought the land and is ready to turn it over to the Mohawks. But the standoff, now seven weeks old, has gone far beyond a mere golf course in this tranquil village along the shores of the St. Lawrence River. The Indians seized the occasion, and public attention, to air the whole range of their grievances. The situation at Oka was less dramatic than at the Mercier bridge near Chateauguay, where thousands of suburbanites have been cut off from their jobs in Montreal, forced to make long detours to get into the island city. There, anger rose steadily and the considerable capital of public sympathy for the Mohawks and their cause burned up fast, leading to numerous violent incidents. Down the hill, the army waited. And waited. ``All is calm,'' said a corporal on the forward-most army sandbag bunker. ``We're just waiting. We're just like you, watching the television.'' ``It's long,'' said another soldier. ``Waiting for something.'' Will they really attack? ``It's hard to believe. I'm just waiting for something here,'' he said, picking up up a radio handset. Capt. Yvon Desjardins, army spokesman in the Oka area, said that after the order from Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa to tear down the barricades, the army continued to patrol and carry out aerial surveillance. Oka is nearly a ghost town. A few residents remain, but not many. ``That's gonna be wild, huh?'' another Warrior known as Black Jack said, smiling. ``A bulldozer? Then we'll have to put a bulldozer on them, right? You can't give up.'' Black Jack, wearing fatigues, a baseball cap and peering through blue sunglasses, didn't look too worried about imminent danger. ``We're a military force,'' he said, ``not a bunch of terrorists. We're here until the final minute. ``The women are strong. They'll be here (when the assault comes). If the men get shot, we die here, the women will pick up the guns. The women are warriors, too.'' But as the day wore on, there was no sign of army movement against the Mohawks at Oka. The warriors at the barricade sat back and sipped cold Pepsis. ``We're just waiting.''

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped 25 cents an ounce on Hong Kong markets Thursday, opening at $386.11. It closed at $386.36 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Medic Says Prisoner Made Threatening Gesture
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. master sergeant on trial for killing a Panamanian prisoner shot when the prisoner made a threatening gesture, a medic testified Wednesday. Army prosecutors rested their case in the court-martial of Master Sgt. Roberto Bryan, 42, who is charged with unpremeditated murder and could face life in prison if convicted. The Army alleges that Bryan, a 19-year veteran member of the 82nd Airborne Division, shot the Panamanian without provocation on Dec. 23, 1989 _ three days after the United States invaded to oust Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega. Bryan led troops who stopped five Panamanians at a roadblock. The Panamanians were being searched when a grenade exploded, wounding 10 American soldiers. The soldiers opened fire, killing four of the Panamanians. The fifth man was injured and lying on the ground when Bryan shot and killed him. Testimony in the case has centered on whether Bryan had good reason to do so. Staff Sgt. James Miller, a medic, testified Wednesday that he was caring for an injured U.S. soldier in the area and saw the surviving Panamanian making a motion. Miller said there were several grenades lying in the area. ``I perceived it as a threat,'' Miller said. He was unarmed at the time and yelled that the man was alive. Miller said Bryan ``identified what I was pointing at, raised his weapon and fired. Just perfect infantry skills. Just textbook.'' Several soldiers have testified that Bryan didn't get along with Lt. Brandon Thomas, the Army's chief witness, who helped bring charges against Bryan. Thomas testified Tuesday that he was stationed elsewhere when the gun battle broke out and drove to the area in time to see Bryan shoot the injured Panamanian. He said he approached Bryan, grabbed his M-16 rifle and said, ``What the hell are you doing? He was almost dead anyway. You didn't have to empty a magazine (row of bullets) into him.'' Bryan stepped back with a startled look on his face and said, ``He injured my people,'' Thomas testified. An eight-member military panel is hearing the case in a tiny base courtroom. Two soldiers have testifed that a civilian told them a day before the shooting that his yellow Daihatsu four-wheel drive vehicle had been stolen. The five Panamanians were driving such a car, and the soldiers said they believed the men to be non-uniformed members of the Panamanian Defense Force. The military has never identified the Panamanian whom Bryan killed; no forensic inspection was done.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader Convicted in Family Slayings; Wife Sentenced to Life in Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Parks set...,' to CORRECT sentencing options.
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader was convicted Wednesday of killing a family of five and burying them on a farm where his group lived, and his wife was sentenced to life in prison for her role. A Lake County Common Pleas Court jury deliberated a little more than three hours before convicting Jeffrey Lundgren, 40, of five counts each of aggravated murder and kidnapping. He could be sentenced to death. He showed no emotion when the verdict was read by Judge Martin O. Parks. Earlier in the same courthouse, Lundgren's wife, Alice, 39, was sentenced to five consecutive life terms. She was convicted Aug. 1 on five counts each of conspiracy and complicity to commit aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. Defense lawyers admitted that Lundgren shot Dennis Avery; his wife, Cheryl, and three daughters ages 7, 13 and 15. Each victim was lured to a barn in April 1989 at the Lundgrens' rented farm in Kirtland, 30 miles east of Cleveland, and gagged, shot and dumped in a common grave. Authorities searching the barn found the bodies in January. The Lundgrens' 19-year-old son, Damon, also was among 13 cult members arrested early this year. His trial on the same charges as his father is pending. Five other cult members have pleaded guilty and are awaiting sentencing, and five more are awaiting trials. Lundgren had been a lay minister in Kirtland for the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. He was defrocked in 1988 for inappropriate conduct and later founded his own sect. Parks set a sentencing hearing for Sept. 10. Jurors are to consider which of three sentences to recommend to the judge: life in prison with parole eligibility after 20 years, life with parole eligibility after 30 years, or death. Prosecutor Steven LaTourette said he expected the verdict. He noted that Lundgren appeared calm when the verdict was read. ``I noticed Mr. Lundgren was smiling _ sort of a day-at-the-beach attitude,'' he said. Lundgren did not comment on the verdict. Authorities led him out of the courtroom. Defense lawyer Charles Grieshammer said he was not surprised with the verdict. He said he was looking forward to the hearing to argue for a sentence other than the death penalty. ``Now it's time to move on to our part of the trial,'' he said. Lundgren did not testify, and defense lawyers did not call any other witnesses. Mrs. Lundgren smiled an talked with her lawyers before her sentencing and appeared quiet and still during the proceedings. After Mrs. Lundgren was sentenced, she read a statement to reporters criticizing the prosecution's portrayal of her as cold and an active player in the killings. Instead, she said she was abused by her husband and stayed with the group out of fear for herself and her children. ``I'm not a coldblooded murderer. He is,'' she said, referring to her husband. ``I, too, was numbered on the list (of intended victims). I am not the `Angel of Death.' I am the mother of four. ... I was found guilty of a crime I had no knowledge would occur,'' said Mrs. Lundgren. She testified she was not at the farm when the Averys were killed. Other cult members testified that Mrs. Lundgren attended regular prayer meetings at which the pending murders were discussed. Testimony also indicated she prepared a final meal for the victims and looked through their belongings to see what might be taken. The cult members left the Kirtland farmers shortly after the murders for wildness homes in West Virginia and Missouri. The Lundgrens were arrested in January in a motel near San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: Screenwriter Edmund North Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Edmund North, the Oscar-winning co-author of ``Patton'' and a lifelong crusader for the Writers Guild of America, has died from complications following surgery. He was 79. North died Tuesday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center, said guild spokeswoman Cheryl Rhoden. With James Gow, North wrote his first movie, ``One Night of Love'' starring Grace Moore, at the age of 21. It was voted one of the best-written films of the year by the newly former Screen Writers Guild, a union with which North would have a productive relationship. In a career spanning 60 years, his credits included ``The Day the Earth Stood Still,'' ``Sink the Bismarck,'' ``Cowboy,'' ``Young Man With a Horn'' and ``Damn the Defiant.'' Born in New York City to stage performers Robert North and Stella Maury, North's first writing jobs were at Fox and RKO. His early films were ``I Dream Too Much'' with Henry Fonda and Lucille Ball; ``All the King's Horses,'' ``Murder on a Bridle Path,'' ``Bunker Bean'' and ``I'm Still Alive.'' He served in the signal corps in World War II. Upon his return to Hollywood, North was president of the guild's screen branch, president of the pension fund and frequently chairman of the contract negotiating committee. In all, he served on more than 40 guild committees. ``For many of us, Eddie was the guild, the most beloved of all our members,'' said David Rintels, a former president of the WGA West. ``He was the fairest-minded man I ever met. A man of great, old-fashioned virtues.'' North's other film credits include ``Dishonored Lady,'' ``Flamingo Road'' (dialogue only), ``Colorado Territory,'' ``In a Lonely Place,'' ``Only the Valiant,'' ``The Outcasts of Poker Flat,'' ``Destry,'' ``The Far Horizons,'' ``The Proud Ones'' and ``The Fiercest Heart.'' In 1982, North wrote and produced ``Race to Oblivion,'' an anti-war film made for Physicians for Social Responsibility. He also served on the board for the National Captioning Institute, a group created in 1979 to provide closed captioning for television programs. North co-wrote 1970's ``Patton'' with Francis Ford Coppola. Starring George C. Scott as the flamboyant World War II general, the film won Oscars for best picture, best actor for Scott, best director for Franklin Schaffner and best script. North is survived by his wife Collette, daughters Bobbie and Susan and two grandchildren. A memorial service is pending.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Shooting Spree in Sydney
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Thursday cq for time of shootings
DOC.TEXT: A man with a shotgun killed five people Thursday in an apartment building, police said. A suspect surrendered after buying cigarettes and a soft drink at a nearby store. A police spokesman said four victims were killed instantly in a public housing building in the Sydney neighborhood of Surry Hills. The fifth died after being taken to a hospital. All five were believed to be residents of three apartments in the building. Police Executive Chief Superintendent Alf Peat said it appeared the gunman, in his early 30s, had walked into the building and killed a young woman relative. The man then turned his shotgun on other residents, firing indiscriminately, Peat said. Neighbor Annette McDonald said she heard three or four shots as she was walking out of her apartment. ``It was just the shots _ no screaming, no arguing,'' she said. Police received the emergency call around 9 a.m. Ambulance station officer George Smith said he found three men and two women lying on the ground and first floors of the building. Four were already dead from single gunshot wounds to the head, Smith said. The fifth was unconscious with head wounds. Don Bryson, storekeeper at a local grocery store, said a young man who appeared ``really nervous'' came in the shop just after a resident mentioned the shootings. Bryson said the man bought cigarettes and a soft drink before leaving the store and walking to police cars, which had just arrived. A police spokesman said on condition of anonymity that the man was taken into police custody. He was not identified.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Convicts Cruise Boat Owners in Shipwreck
DOC.TEXT: A navy tribunal fined and revoked the license of the owners of a cruise boat that sank on New Year's Eve in 1988, killing 55 people. The tribunal ruled the Bateau Mouche Rio Turismo Ltda. company was negligent in operating the boat, which was overloaded and in open sea when it sank. The flat-bottomed boat was licensed to operate only in Rio's Guanabara Bay. The Bateau Mouche IV, with a capacity of 62 passengers, was carrying about 150 revelers when it sank in 65 feet of water minutes before midnight on Dec. 31, 1988. The company was banned from all maritime activity and ordered to pay $1,320 in fines. Mechanic Edson Goncalves de Carvalho, responsible for the boat's pumps, was fined $130 and lost his ship's pilot license. Charges were filed against six navy officers and two sergeants for ``negligence and laziness'' in inspecting the boat.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-President Cleared of Embezzlement
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Wednesday found former President Leon Febres Cordero innocent of embezzling $150,000 in public funds, ending a dramatic case that riveted Ecuadoreans. Febres Cordero had no immediate reaction. However, he has denied the accusation in the past, saying he is the victim of political enemies who want to smear his reputation. ``Since the crime of embezzlement was not proved, the case is declared closed,'' Justice Jorge Gonzalez told a news conference Wednesday. The charge, leveled in January, accused Febres Cordero of embezzling $150,000, stunning this small Andean nation of 10 million people. It dates back to Febres Cordero's actions in 1987, when his private secretary and son-in-law Miguel Orellana received $150,000 in cash from Ecuador's Central Bank. Orellana later said the money was used to pay an Israeli anti-terrorism expert for advice in fighting a small leftist guerrilla group. Febres Cordero said the case against Orellana was meant to embarrass him politically and assumed responsibility for the spending of the money. The judge said Wednesday's ruling cleared both Febres Cordero and his son-in law. ``We consider them both innocent,'' Gonzalez said. He said the ruling cannot be appealed. Febres Cordero, a 59-year old archconservative with a fiery temper, governed from 1984 to 1988. He was regarded as a favorite of the Reagan administration because of his outspoken defense of free-market economic policies. President Rodrigo Borja, a moderate leftist and bitter foe of Febres Cordero, had said he did not believe the money was paid to an Israeli anti-terrorism specialist. For his part, Febres Cordero accused Borja and Osvaldo Hurtado, another former president, of being behind the embezzlement charge. Borja denied his government was involved. He said it was a judicial case.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Leaders Get Gulf Briefing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 11th graf: ``Those sources,'' report of additional block of 24 F-15s planned for sale; ADDs graf on additional congressional trips
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Plans for a new U.S. sale of weapons to Saudi Arabia were revealed Tuesday, as congressional leaders expressed support _ at least for now _ of the Bush administration's intervention in the Middle East. The United States intends to sell nearly $3 billion in new weapons to Saudi Arabia, including 24 F-15 fighter planes and 150 M-60 tanks, congressional sources said. The administration notified Congress of the plans as about 170 lawmakers returned from a summer break for their first face-to-face briefing from President Bush since he began sending troops to the Persian Gulf three weeks ago. ``So far, so good,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., reflecting near unanimous congressional backing for the military moves and wariness about the future. ``There is a sense of awe at how brilliantly Bush has handled this,'' said House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga. Rep. William Gray, D-Pa., the third-ranking House leader, said the nation will continue to support the presence of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia ``provided we do not get into a protracted struggle with loss of life, with no prospect for victory.'' ``I am convinced that no matter how this ends, we will have an added presence there for a long time, and I think the American people need to be made aware of that,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis. During the hour-long meeting other lawmakers said they expressed concern that the nation lacks an energy policy to cope with oil shortages. Some also said U.S. allies must bear a bigger share of the military and financial burden in deterring Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The Saudi military sale would include 15,000 rounds of depleted uranium antitank ammunition and 200 stinger antiaircraft missiles. Those items cannot be sold to Riyadh unless Bush certifies it is in America's national security interest. The arms package is designed to bolster Saudi defenses against neighboring Iraq and further sales are possible, said the sources, who requested anonymity. Those sources did not detail what the future possibilities are. The Washington Post said in Wednesday editions that a second sale of 24 F-15s was planned for 1991. The 48 additional F-15s would bring the total sold to Saudi Arabia to 110 compared with the current congressionally imposed limit of 62. Saudi Arabia has welcomed Bush's troop deployment and has agreed to increase oil production to help offset losses from Iraqi oil fields. In opening remarks to about 170 members of Congress who returned to Washington from their summer recess for the briefing, Bush appealed for support and added: ``Let no one at home doubt my commitment to work with the Congress, and let no one abroad doubt our national unity or our staying power.'' Bush also said Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait. But he did not publicly address a question on the minds of some lawmakers _ whether Hussein himself must be deposed. In advance of the White House briefing, Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said that was a clear requirement for settling the crisis. Lugar, a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, also said Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has demonstrated the United States is the world's lone remaining superpower with the military and political clout to find a solution. He also urged President Bush to spell out the costs of what could be a long-term military commitment. Military force probably will be needed to force Saddam from power, Lugar said. ``He does have to leave the leadership of the country, and many of the forces he has aggregated have to be removed as a threat,'' he said. Bush met briefly first with a group that included Sen. George Mitchell, D-Maine, and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., Gephardt, and Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. That was followed by a briefing for other members of Congress, including those on the Armed Services, Foreign Affairs, Intelligence and Appropriations committees. Also briefing the members were Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, CIA Director William Webster, Secretary of State James A. Baker III _ who cut short a Wyoming vacation _ and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Colin Powell. Afterward, Gephardt said the increased cost of the deployment _ $2.5 billion through September, and possible more for a longer stay _ will affect budget talks between Congress and the White House. The first-year savings target of $50 billion may have to be scaled back to $35 billion or so, but the overall five-year total savings should still reach the original $500 billion goal, he said. Two separate bipartisan congressional delegations, one from the House led by Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and one from the Senate led by Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Foreign Relations Committe, will leave Friday on an inspection trip to Saudi Arabia, returning Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President's Wife Rescued from River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CLARIFY both Marilyn and Dan Quayle were on raft.
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, fell into the Colorado River during during a whitewater rafting expedition through the Grand Canyon over the weekend, a park spokesman said Wednesday. She was thrown from the raft when it hit Lava Falls rapids, one of the roughest stretches in the river, said Chuck Lundy, spokesman for Grand Canyon National Park. John Reed, assistant superintendent for the park, pulled Mrs. Quayle back into the raft, Lundy said, adding that she was uninjured and was wearing a life jacket at the time as required. The Quayles were accompanying a U.S. Park Service patrol on a rafting expedition of several days, said Lundy, who didn't know if the mishap occurred Saturday or Sunday. Lava Falls is about 60 miles west of park headquarters here. Lundy said there were about four or five rafts on the trip.

DOC.HEAD: University Resumes Work Toward Construction of Telescopes
DOC.TEXT: A crew resumed work Wednesday on an access road to the site for the University of Arizona's Mount Graham observatory, after a federal judge rejected environmentalists' pleas to stop the project. The National Audubon Society called on Arizona's congressmen to halt work on the $200 million telescopes until a new biological study can be conducted of its effects on the endangered Mount Graham red squirrel. A contracting firm, which last summer began building the two-mile access road on Emerald Peak, resumed work on the final 200 feet of the road Wednesday. A university crew on Thursday was to begin transplanting several hundred tiny trees from the construction site on the 10,500-foot peak, said university spokesman Steve Emerine. Later, larger spruce and fir trees will be cleared from the site. The site to be cleared will be used for the German Max Planck Institute's Sub-Millimeter Telescope, the first of three telescopes to be built in the Mount Graham forest. Tuesday, U.S. District Judge Alfredo C. Marquez refused to issue a temporary restraining order to halt the project. Chuck Stury, the Forest Service manager for the telescope project, said Friends of the Earth had requested a group camping permit for 50 people from Friday to Monday near the observatory site, and he hoped there wouldn't be trouble. ``I thought maybe there'd be a protest or something going on; I haven't heard of anything,'' he said. Six women calling themselves Wrathful and Outraged Mothers for Biodiversity (WOMB) staged a theatrical demonstration at the Tucson office of Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz. They carried basketballs under their clothing to give the appearance of pregnancy _ the symbolic result, they said, of the federal rape of the environment.
