Oil prices rebounded from their tumultuous slide, rising almost $1 per barrel as traders speculated on diplomatic efforts to resolve the Middle East crisis. Traders also were monitoring OPEC discussions Tuesday that could lead to higher crude production, offsetting the shortfall caused by the international boycott of Iraq and Kuwait. The price of light sweet crude, the benchmark U.S. grade of oil, rose 97 cents to $27.88 per barrel for October contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

OPEC's oil ministers delayed formal endorsement of a plan for production increases to give more time to hear from absent members Iraq and Libya. Iran, which has refused to back the tentative agreement, made a surprise call Tuesday for a joint meeting between the cartel and nearly two dozen oil-consuming Western nations, including the United States, to discuss the oil crunch caused by the Persian Gulf crisis.

The United States recorded its smallest quarterly trade deficit in 6{ years in the spring, the government reported. Analysts forecast widening deficits in coming months as the Persian Gulf crisis boosts America's foreign oil bill. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that the trade gap from April through June narrowed a sharp 14.1 percent, to $22.6 billion, reflecting a big drop in oil prices and record U.S. exports.

The United Auto Workers union will focus national contract bargaining on General Motors Corp., the world's largest and most profitable automaker, union President Owen Bieber said. Tuesday's decision naming GM as the UAW's pattern bargaining target was greeted warmly by the company which, like Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., had sought to be in the union's focus. Contracts between the union and the Big Three automakers cover more than 450,000 workers and expire Sept. 14.

Perrier will replace the label on its sparkling water in Europe because it doesn't meet European Community criteria for naturally carbonated water, officials said. The label that describes Perrier as ``Naturally Carbonated'' will be replaced in Europe Nov. 1 with one reading ``Natural Mineral Water Fortified With Gas From The Spring.'' This marks the second label change in six months for Perrier. Earlier this year, traces of benzene were discovered in some bottles, leading to a worldwide recall of 160 million bottles.

The projected value of U.S. farm exports is holding steady at $40 billion despite a decline in the volume of wheat shipments, the Agriculture Department said. At $40 billion, the value of agricultural exports for the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1 is up slightly from $39.6 billion in 1988-89. The department's Economic Research Service said Tuesday that total export quantity is expected to be 148.5 million metric tons. Officials said that while the tonnage will be up from last year it is expected to be down from the 150 million tons forecast in May.

Donald Trump has pledged his 27.2 percent stake in Alexander's Inc. as collateral for his $65 million financial rescue from casino and bank debt, according to new documents. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Trump revealed Tuesday that as part of the restructuring of some $2 billion in debt last week, he pledged more than 1.35 million shares in the New York department store chain as security. Three New York banks to which the stock was pledged were not identified.

A federal appeals court overturned a Federal Trade Commission ruling that would have prevented states from banning such operations as shopping mall stores that combine optometric practice with eyeglass sales. The FTC ``acted beyond its statutory authority'' in its so-called Eyeglasses II ruling last year, a federal judge wrote in Tuesday's ruling.

Apple Computer Inc. will introduce a lower-priced line of Macintosh personal computers in October, but some of the machines won't be widely available until early 1991. In introducing the new Macintoshs, Apple won't completely discontinue its existing cheap Macintosh computers, the Macintosh Plus and the Macintosh SE _ a move that could leave computer owners with obsolete machines, a spokesman said Tuesday.

Stock prices rose modestly Tuesday, with the Dow Jones average up 3.22 to 2,614.85. The dollar was mixed in domestic trading after finishing mostly higher overseas. Gold prices were back up. Bond prices slipped in lackluster trading. Precious metal futures fell, grain and soybeans were mixed, and livestock and pork futures fell.

DOC.HEAD: As Air Bag Use Rises, Automakers Find Drivers Care About Safety
DOC.TEXT: Whether just the latest advertising strategy or a genuine concern for driver safety, U.S. automakers are touting air bags, motorized seat belts and anti-lock brakes in selling cars. Europeans carmakers have used safety as a sales pitch for years. Now that the federal government is ordering passive restraint systems in all U.S.-built cars, automakers believe it pays to advertise safety. ``Initially, it was tough getting customers to talk about safety,'' Chrysler Corp. spokesman Tony Cervone said Tuesday. ``It becomes a discriminating factor in buying a car now.'' Chrysler, which has trumpeted the planned production today of its one millionth air-bag equipped car, hits safety hard in radio advertisments calling the air bag ``an incentive that just might save your life.'' Air bags are standard in all model 1990 U.S.-built cars at Chrysler, the first of the Big Three to commit to the device. Air bags for Chrysler's popular minivans are about two model years away, Cervone said. General Motors Corp. announced Monday it will equip all U.S.-built passenger cars with driver's-side air bags by the fall of 1995, but the company has yet to work them into safety-related advertising. Donald Postma, spokesman for GM Technical Staffs, said the upscale Cadillac division is expected to be the first to promote air bags. Ford Motor Co. has air bags in about half its U.S.-built vehicles, but the company doesn't go to lengths to promote them or motorized passive restraint seat belts. Under federal law, all cars made in the United States after Sept. 1, 1989, must have either an air bag or automatic seat belt for drivers and front-seat passengers. GM's announcement to go with air bags reversed initial plans to install motorized seat belts in most of its cars. According to Insurance Institute for Highway Safety in Arlington, Va., air bags were equipped in 1 percent of the estimated 10 million 1987 model cars sold in the United States, including imports sold here. By 1996, 90 percent of cars are expected to have air bags, the institute said. European carmakers Mercedes Benz, BMW and Volkswagen long have incorporated safety promotion into advertising, in part because buyers of their more expensive vehicles could be counted on to ask such questions. ``When you deal with a small market niche such as ours is in the United States, you have to be very attentive to what customers say they want in a car,'' said John Chuhran, a spokesman for Mercedes Benz of North America in Montvale, N.J. In one 30-second television commercial, Mercedes, which sells about 75,000 cars a year in the United States, promotes its standard safety features. ``Of course you want a safe car for your family. But what is safe? Well, only your authorized Mercedes-Benz dealer offers (a) . . . system with driver's-side air bag and anti-lock brakes on every new model. Standard. That's safe,'' the announcer says. Postma said GM's initial objection to air bags was based on research showing that drivers would ignore manual seat belts, which must be used in conjunction with an air bag to make the device effective. ``What we are looking at now is that air bags have come of age,'' Postma said. ``People indicate they want them. We have worked on them enough so we know that they are reliable.'' An air bag, usually concealed in the steering wheel or beneath the driver's side dashboard, inflates upon a head-on impact or one 30 degrees to the left or right of center of the steering wheel. Chrysler doesn't emphasize seat-belt use as a major part of its air bag promotion. But Cervone said: ``An air bag is a supplemental safety device. It's there in all the (advertising) copy. It's not going to be the headline.'' Mercedes Benz's Chuhran said: ``In terms of advertising, safety is a relative term. There is no such thing as an absolutely safe automobile.''

DOC.HEAD: Futures Regulators Consider Rules Changes After Stotler Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Following the collapse of Stotler Group Inc., federal futures regulators are going to look into new ways for handling the liquidation of a brokerage's customer accounts. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said Tuesday it would develop procedures for how to handle bulk transfers or liquidations of customer accounts in unusual circumstances such as the cessation or suspension of a brokerage's business. Such a rapid decline came last week as Stotler Group Inc., a firm once linked with former Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten ``Cash'' Mahlmann, announced it was filing for liquidation under Chapter 7 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. Previously, Stotler Group was forced into involuntary bankruptcy reorganization by some of the commodity funds it managed. Those funds claimed Stotler owed them millions of dollars in unredeemed loans and investments. On July 31, the CFTC filed fraud charges against a Stotler subsidiary, Stotler Funds Inc., accusing it of misusing $5 million customer funds by lending it to the cash-strapped parent company. A day later Mahlmann resigned as head of Stotler Group and as chairman of the world's largest futures exchange. He has not been accused of any wrongdoing. Last week, the CFTC and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees the stock and bond markets, filed separate administrative actions against another Stotler subsidiary, Stotler and Co.. They accused the subsidiary of failing to maintain enough net capital, the minimum amount of cash and assets to offset risks. Stotler and Co. settled the CFTC action and late last week said it was offering to settle with the SEC without admitting or denying any wrongdoing. In a statement Friday, Stotler President Thomas M. Eagan said it was ``now in the best interests of all creditors that the further administration of these companies' affairs be handled in an orderly manner by the bankruptcy court.'' The CFTC's trading and markets division, which will research how such situations should be handled in the future, is scheduled to present its findings next year. The proposed rules change was announced at a regular CFTC meeting to consider quarterly objectives.

DOC.HEAD: Sweet and Sour Have Different Meanings For Oil Buyers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: When they ask if you want ``light sweet'' in the oil trading business, they're not talking about a coffee break. Light sweet is a generic term that can be used for a variety of crude oils traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a leading petroleum market, although traders often erroneously refer to the mix as West Texas Intermediate or WTI, the benchmark U.S. crude. The Mercantile Exchange has sought to change this entrenched habit, partly by insisting that traders use ``light sweet'' instead of WTI. But old ways die hard. ``It's WTI,'' said John Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. ``WTI is the oil traded on the Merc. Practically speaking, it is WTI.'' Advised of the Merc's position on what the oil should be called, Lichtblau said any label used by the exchange is ``sort of irrelevant,'' because traders in that market are only speculating on which direction oil prices will go. Like traders in other futures markets, oil traders rarely take delivery of the actual oil, but gamble on its price by buying and selling contracts for delivery in upcoming months. These oil-futures contracts are commonly called ``paper'' barrels. Real oil, on the other hand, comes in what the industry calls ``wet'' barrels. Regardless of what they're called, Merc traders have been buying and selling barrels of oil since 1983, when the exchange first offered a market in crude oil futures. Initially, the Merc listed 13 grades that it classified as light sweet crude. The menu is now down to seven domestics and three foreign oils. Merc officials say the the most commonly traded light sweet crude was WTI. Eventually, the contract for other crudes also became known as WTI. Confusion over what is sold has led to problems, Merc officials say. Some buyers who thought they were getting WTI have discovered they were getting a different grade. The errors have become a bigger headache for the Merc officials recently, as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices into wild gyrations that thrust the Merc into a larger-than-usual public spotlight. In an effort to clear up any misunderstanding, the Merc sent members a memo this week asking that they refer to light sweet crude instead of WTI. WTI has for years been used as a reference point for measuring other crudes, partly because it once was the most important grade of crude in the lower 48 states, extracted from the Permian Basin in West Texas. But the industry's shifting exploration to other areas has made other grades just as prominent. ``Today, Alaskan North Slope crude is the most important,'' said Bernard Picchi, a Salomon Brothers Inc. managing director who follows domestic oils. ``A lot of people think WTI is losing whatever relevance it once had in the industry, because we're just running out of the stuff.'' The foreign oils that can be included in a Merc contract are Brent Blend, Bonny Light and Oseberg. The domestic crudes, other than WTI, are Mid Continent Sweet, Low Sweet Mix (Scurry Snyder), New Mexican Sweet, North Texas Sweet, Oklahoma Sweet and South Texas Sweet. ``Sweet'' refers to a crude's low sulphur content, which is desirable because it's less polluting and more cheaply refinable than so-called high-sulphur ``sour'' grades. ``Light'' refers to a higher proportion of hydrogen compared with carbon, with ``heavy'' oil often requiring an infusion of hydrogen before it can be refined, Picchi said. For anyone confused by all of this, the Merc will soon have another item on the menu. Merc officials plan to begin trading on a sour oil contract in about a year.

DOC.HEAD: FTC To Appeal Ruling Clearing Way for $568 Million Deal
DOC.TEXT: Parties to Meredith Corp.'s planned sale of its printing business to R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co. say they are disappointed with continued government challenges to the nearly $570 million transaction. A federal judge this week rejected a Federal Trade Commission request for an order blocking the sale pending an antitrust hearing by the FTC. The FTC then said it would appeal. The government raised the antitrust challenge after Meredith and the Burda family of West Germany agreed last December to sell their jointly held Meredith-Burda printing business to Donnelley, the leading commercial printer in North America. ``Donnelley was disappointed to learn that the FTC is appealing the court's decision,'' the company said in a statement. ``Donnelley continues to believe that the acquisition is legally proper.'' Donnelley, with 1989 sales of $3.12 billion, has about 6 percent of the U.S. market for the magazine, catalog and newspaper insert business. Meredith-Burda has about 1 percent. ``We continue to believe the transaction is both proper and legal,'' Meredith President Jack Rehm said. Meredith and the Burdas agreed to sell the printing business for $487.5 million in cash. Donnelley also agreed to assume $80 million in Meredith-Burda debt. In July, the FTC asked U.S. District Judge Stanley Harris in Washington to issue an order blocking the sale pending the outcome of an antitrust hearing before the regulatory agency. Harris on Monday refused to issue the preliminary injunction. The FTC then said would appeal. Meredith has interests in publishing, broadcasting and real estate and is best known for its Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies' Home Journal magazines. Donnelley prints and binds many national publications, including Time, Newsweek and TV Guide. It also prints telephone books, encyclopedias and school and religious books. Meredith-Burda was founded in 1969 and generated just over $10 million in earnings for Meredith in the fiscal year ended June 30. Meredith finished the the year with a $26.4 million loss, reflecting one-time losses from the sale of discontinued television advertising and real estate businesses. If the sale had been completed as planned, Meredith's share of the proceeds would have offset the loss. Meredith said late last year it wanted to focus on its core businesses by expanding and strengthening its magazines, TV stations and real estate holdings. Meredith-Burda has printing plants in Des Moines; Newton, N.C.; Lynchburg, Va.; and Casa Grande, Ariz. Its photo preparation centers are in Lynchburg and at Hickory and Greensboro, N.C.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Picks GM as Primary Target as Talks Shift Into High Gear
DOC.TEXT: National contract bargaining shifts into high gear after the United Auto Workers union picked General Motors Corp. as its primary target. Negotiators for the union and the world's largest and most profitable automaker are working under a 17-day deadline to arrive at a new three-year contract. About 300,000 GM workers are covered by the contract. While negotiations continue on their contract, talks between the union and Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. will creep ahead. In all, more than 450,000 active workers are covered by the three UAW contracts, all of which expire Sept. 14. GM spokesman John Maciarz said Tuesday the company was happy with the UAW's selection and that the bargaining pace would speed up now. He said the union and the company are close to agreement on some non-economic issues. UAW President Owen Bieber said Tuesday the UAW chose GM as its target because the automaker had more to offer the union than the other two companies. Spokesmen for Ford and Chrysler said they were disappointed that the UAW passed them over, but subcommittee meetings would continue while talks proceed between the union and GM. If everything goes according to the union's plan, a contract reached with GM will be used as a pattern for agreements with Ford and Chrysler. Automakers seek to be the union's bargaining target so they can reach an agreement more tailored to their needs. The selection of GM as the target had been anticipated. One of the things analysts said may have contributed to pushing the UAW toward choosing GM was Robert Stempel taking over as chairman on Aug. 1. Employees hailed the selection of Stempel because he came up through GM's engineering and marketing ranks and is perceived as understanding them better than former chairman Roger Smith, an accountant. Stempel made several upper-level management changes immediately after taking office that shortened the lines between top executives and GM's car- and truck-making divisions. When he took over, Stempel said GM was on the road back to regaining lost market-share profitably. For the first half of this year, GM reported it earned $1.6 billion, down 47 percent from last year, but better than the $1.4 billion earned by Ford, down 57 percent, and the $251 million earned by Chrysler, down 64 percent. Bieber said major factors in picking GM included that the company was the only one to present a full contract proposal, delivered last Thursday, and reports from the union's vice presidents in charge of its GM, Ford and Chrysler departments. Union and company officials have declined to discuss any company's proposal, but GM's reportedly included a 2 percent increase in the base wage in the first year and 2 percent lump sum payments in the next two years. Perhaps more important, the proposal contains no changes in health-care coverage, a major union concern, and the company said it was willing to discuss job security, the union's primary aim in this set of negotiations. This is the first year the UAW has had common expiration dates with all three automakers in 11 years. In 1988, the union bargained only with Chrysler. In 1987, the UAW chose Ford as a target company and reached an agreement without a strike. The last UAW walkout over a national contract occurred in 1985, when the union staged a 12-day strike against Chrysler.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Plans To Introduce Cheaper Macintosh Computers
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. plans to introduce a lower-priced line of Macintosh personal computers in October, but some of the machines won't be widely available until early 1991. John Cook, spokesman for Apple's products division, said Tuesday that the company plans large production of the new line and wants to ensure supply levels before market introduction. In introducing the new Macintoshs, Apple won't completely discontinue its existing cheap Macintosh computers, the Macintosh Plus and the Macintosh SE _ a move that could leave computer owners with obsolete machines. ``One of the things we haven't done since 1984, when we first introduced Macintoshes, was to obsolete anything,'' Cook said. ``You can buy a 1984 Macintosh and with a couple of upgrades run the present software. Customers demand this.'' Computer analysts say Apple, one of the most popular personal computer makers, could lose market share if it doesn't get enough of the new lower-cost machines in stores during the prime computer buying time, November through January. Apple executives have been saying for months that one of their top priorities was introducing cheaper versions of the Macintosh, the company's mainstay product. But analysts have said the Cupertino-based company waited too long to make the move. They say the company has been losing sales to cheaper personal computers based on International Business Machine Corp. models. Apple's Cook wouldn't comment on the details of the new Macintosh line. According to the San Francisco Chronicle, the cheapest of the new machines will be called the Macintosh Classic and will have a built-in black-and-white monitor similar to that on the Macintosh Plus and SE. The Mac Classic is expected to be priced between $1,300 and $1,400, according to industry sources quoted in the article. That compares with the $1,799 list price for a Mac Plus, the current lowest-price Mac. Apple also will introduce a new low-cost color-screen model that will be called the Macintosh LC. The color monitor will be made by Sony Corp. The LC is expected to have a list price of $2,800, compared with $4,669 for the current cheapest color Mac. The LC also will have room for a chip board that Apple will introduce to allow the machine to run software designed for the Apple II computer, which can be found in more than two-thirds of school classrooms that are equipped with computers. Industry analysts have said Apple needs to find a way to allow software written for the millions of Apple IIs to be used on the newer Macintosh line. Otherwise, Apple II users will be reluctant to upgrade to Macintoshes.

DOC.HEAD: New Merv Griffin Casino Chief Faces Tough Road
DOC.TEXT: Former Trump executive Jack O'Donnell takes over the helm of Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel at a time when the casino is emerging from bankruptcy and this city's gambling market is flat. But O'Donnell, who quit as Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino president in April, said he is challenged by his appointment Tuesday as Resorts' executive vice president and chief operating officer. O'Donnell replaces Al Luciani, who resigned to pursue other interests, said David Hanlon, president and chief executive officer of Resorts International, the casino's parent. Luciani, who leaves office Friday, could not be reached for comment. Resorts, which recently reorganized under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, has a strong future, O'Donnell said, pointing to the casino's refurbishment and his expectation of a resurgence in flat gaming profits in Atlantic City. ``Many people in this town are beginning to suffer a financial crunch,'' O'Donnell said. ``We're starting to emerge out of it and we're well positioned.'' O'Donnell, who left the Trump Plaza in a difference of opinion about Donald Trump's ``style of running the company,'' did not appear to enjoy his former boss's recent financial troubles. After failing to make a payment to bondholders in June, Trump sought permission from state gambling regulators for an emergency $65 million bailout package. This month, the state Casino Control Commission approved the rescue loan but threatened to revoke licenses for Trump's three casinos unless he can demonstrate by October proof of financial stability. ``Donald Trump is faced with a unique set of problems that he's going to have to sort through in the next couple of years,'' O'Donnell said. ``I don't take any gratification from it. I'm not out to compete against Trump.'' Resorts is located next to Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort, and Resorts officials had hoped to lure away some of the Taj clientele after the casino's glitzy April 2 opening. O'Donnell said the presence of the Taj Mahal could attract customers to Resorts but is not essential to its profitability. ``There will be some benefit as we improve our product,'' he said. ``People dissatisfied with the Taj Mahal will find us as an alternative.'' The appointment comes after the commission and U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Rosemary Gambardella on Aug. 17 approved Resorts International's proposed restructuring of its massive debt. Under the plan, Resorts bondholders holding $911 million in bonds are to receive 78.5 percent of Griffin's ownership and $434 million in new notes. The plan also includes a $5 million fund for bondholders to pursue a lawsuit against Trump, if they should desire. Bondholders claim Trump left Resorts in poor shape when he traded it for the Taj Mahal in 1988. Trump says Griffin bears the responsibility for the company's indebtedness. For the latest quarter ending June 30, Resorts' Atlantic City property recorded a net profit of $2.7 million on gross revenue of $59.2 million. Overall, Resorts International posted net earnings of $803,000 on revenues of $109.1 million for the second quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Sides with RTC in Arkansas Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court says the Resolution Trust Corp. can override an Arkansas banking law to sell insolvent thrifts and their branches to banks. An RTC attorney said the ruling has nationwide implications. On Tuesday, a three-judge panel from the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 2-1 to overturn a lower court ruling that the sale of Independence Federal Savings Bank of Batesville to Worthen Bank and Trust Co. of Little Rock would violate Arkansas's branch-banking law. That law prohibits banks from having branches outside their home counties. The RTC, a government agency created to clean up insolvent thrifts, argued that it was granted broad rule-making authority by Congress in its mission to maximize returns and minimize the losses. RTC attorney Dorothy Nichols said the case had nationwide implications because 26 states have similar laws. The RTC's authority to override state laws has been challenged in New Mexico and Colorado, RTC spokesman Steve Katsanos said. A district court judge in New Mexico sided with the RTC earlier this year, he said. In Colorado, a hearing on the case is scheduled Sept. 5, Katsanos said. The District Court there has issued a restraining order to keep the RTC from going ahead with any transaction that would involve overriding Colorado state law. Tuesday's appeals court ruling was welcomed by Worthen President and Chairman Curt Bradbury. ``We consider today's ruling to be a significant victory for the taxpayers of the United States,'' he said. ``We are strongly committed to assisting in the resolution of the S&L crisis in Arkansas and consider our opportunity to purchase Independence to be a beneficial stabilizing force for the financial-services segment of our economy,'' Bradbury said. The acquisition would bring assets of Worthen's parent company, Worthen Banking Corp., to $2.1 million, according to a news release from Worthen. That would make it the largest bank holding company in the state. In arguments before the appellate court, the RTC's Nichols argued that most of Independence's branch offices would be shut down by the RTC if the institution were sold piecemeal. ``The most valuable assets of S&Ls in dire straits aren't their loan portfolios,'' she said. ``The most valuable asset of a failed thrift is its branches.'' Arkansas State Bank Commissioner Bill J. Ford argued that the state's 1988 branching law, which would permit statewide branches gradually over 10 years, was necessary to ensure fair competition. Ford and the Arkansas Independent Bankers Association had filed suit June 28 to block the proposed sale to Worthen. Tuesday's opinion overruling a decision by U.S. District Judge Stephen M. Reasoner of Little Rock was written by Circuit Judge John R. Gibson for Circuit Judge Frank J. Magill. Senior Circuit Judge Gerald W. Heaney dissented. He agreed with Arkansas officials that the RTC's regulation referred only to the ability of the savings associations to operate branches and not to the ability of a bank to retain and operate branches. At issue is an RTC regulation that permits banks making emergency acquisitions of insolvent thrifts such as Independence to operate the branches of the thrift as bank branches. Independence has 20 branches in 15 counties.

DOC.HEAD: FundAmerica To Challenge $8.2 Million Fine For Alleged Violations
DOC.TEXT: FundAmerica Inc. said it was challenging an $8.2 million fine for alleged securities violations levied by the Florida comptroller. The Irvine-based buying club accused of operating a pyramid scheme also said Tuesday it has filed court papers challenging the Florida attorney general's decision to stop it from conducting business in that state. ``We want to move to get both these actions into the courts as quickly as possible,'' said Mitchell G. Blumberg, the company's president and chief executive. ``The serious nature of the charges made by the Attorney General and Comptroller deserve to be heard in a court, where we will have an impartial forum and all the legal remedies and rights available to us under the law,'' he added. FundAmerica said it had filed papers with the Florida State Circuit Court in Miami challenging the state attorney general's motion to forbid FundAmerica from doing business in Florida. Florida officials have accused FundAmerica's founder, Robert T. Edwards, of allegedly bilking $8.2 million from Florida members of the buying club. Edwards and FundAmerica have denied the accusations. FundAmerica has about 100,000 members. But critics say its discounts on goods and services are available free through other channels or are subsidized by its membership fees and complain it uses high-pressure tactics to sell memberships. FundAmerica announced Monday it had overhauled its sales procedures to curb alleged sales abuses and had begun talks with regulators in two of the eight states in which it has conducted business. ``We are trying to sort out our problems and resolve the regulatory, legal and business challenges we face,'' Blumberg said. ``New management is committed to making sure we are or are getting into compliance in the states in which we operate and to resume operations as soon as practicable.'' On Aug. 17, FundAmerica filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors. That action followed a $150 million class-action lawsuit against FundAmerica filed July 24 in federal court in San Francisco.

The stock market was little changed in light trading today as traders awaited developments in the Persian Gulf. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 2.47 to 2,612.38 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. But gainers outnumbered losers by about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 630 up, 548 down and 468 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 35.50 million shares at midmorning. Over the last couple of days, analysts say, stocks appear to have found an equilibrium level pending further events in the showdown that has followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on increased production quotas to compensate for the absence of shipments from Iraq and Kuwait. The news initially sent oil prices lower. But it was unclear how much lasting effect that might have on the worldwide oil market. Doubts persisted, too, about the outlook for the domestic economy. The Commerce Department reported that its index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in July. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose [ to 45[; General Motors gained ] to 40|; American Express lost [ to 23{, and McDonald's was down { at 27]. Long Island Lighting added ] to 19{. The company raised its quarterly dividend from 25 cents a share to 37.5 cents a share. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed stocks dropped .10 to 176.36. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .47 at 322.25.

DOC.HEAD: UK's Laura Ashley To Sell 15 Percent Stake to Japan's Aeon
DOC.TEXT: Laura Ashley Holdings PLC will sell a 15 percent stake in itself to a Japanese retailing group for $58.3 million, the company Wednesday. The British retailer said it would sell 35.2 million newly issued shares of its stock to the Aeon Group of Japan for 29.9 million pounds. The price represented a 73 percent premium over what its shares closed at Tuesday. The agreement is being carried out through Aeon's British subsidiary Jusco Co. Ltd. Laura Ashley will also sell 53 percent of its equity in its U.S. retailing subsidiary, Revman Industries Inc., the companies said. Aeon will take 48 percent and Revman management 5 percent. The deal values the whole of Revman at $35 million, they said, and leaves Laura Ashley with a 47 percent stake. Laura Ashley lost 4.6 million pounds, or $8.97 million, before taxes for the year ended Jan. 27. It also reported debts of about 100 million pounds, or $195 million, and did not recommend a final share dividend. Jusco Chairman and Chief Executive Takuya Okada said the Aeon Group's stake ``will contribute to the improvement of Laura Ashley's financial position and to the stabilization of the business.'' Aeon will pay 85 pence, or $1.65, a share in cash for the 15 percent stake in Laura Ashley. This represents a 73 percent premium over Tuesday's closing price for the stock on the London Stock Exchange. The two companies agreed to extend their Japanese and Asian retail joint venture, Laura Ashley Japan Co. Ltd. Aeon will increase its stake in the joint venture to 60 percent from 50 percent, although Laura Ashley will retain control of brand names and receive increased royalties. Laura Ashley Holdings has 171 shops in Britain and total of 460 worldwide. It also manufactures furniture, wallpaper and other furnishings, and much of the clothing it sells.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Mixed in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders say there is not much news to spur movement in the market in either direction. Recently, the market has been heavily influenced by the crisis in the Middle East and by the fortunes of the energy and precious metals markets. The hot, dry conditions in the fields are putting pressure on corn and soybean futures. The weather is seen as beneficial to those crops. Wheat prices are getting some support from news the U.S. Agriculture Department will boost the amount of wheat in the food security reserve. In early trading, wheat was 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.80 a bushel; corn was a { cent lower to a \ cent higher with September at $2.54} a bushel; oats were a { cent to } cent lower with September at $1.20{ a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to a { cent higher with September at $6.19} a bushel. Livestock futures were down and pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were pushed lower by sluggish retail beef demand. Pork futures were pressured by lower-than-expected cash hog prices, along with expectations of increased hog marketings. Pork belly prices were pushed lower by lighter-than-expected drawdown of frozen belly stocks last week. Live cattle were .10 cent to .60 cent lower with October at 76.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .40 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 88.65 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent lower to .22 cent higher with October at 48.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .08 cent to .30 cent higher with February at 52.45 cents a pound. Livestock and pork futures settled lower in Tuesday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Index of Leading Indicators Remains Unchanged
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 6th graf, In another... to UPDATE with home sales report. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government said today its main forecasting gauge of future economic activity was flat in July, indicating widespread weakness in the U.S. economy even before the Persian Gulf crisis increased the chances of a recession. The Commerce Department said the lack of any change in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators followed revised gains of 0.1 percent in June and 0.6 percent in May. But analysts said they expected a steep drop in August because of the oil price spike and consumer jitters spurred by fears of war in the Middle East following the Aug.2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Typically, three consecutive declines in the index are viewed as a fairly reliable, although not infallible, signal that the economy is headed for a recession. Following Iraq's invasion, many economists believe a recession is looming, as an already sluggish U.S. economy falls victim to rising inflation and consumer worries about a possible war. In another economic report today, the Commerce Department said sales of new homes fell 2.3 percent in July, giving up half of their gain the previous month. The government said new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 548,000 after advancing a revised 4.7 percent in June. While the leading index normally forecasts economic activity six to nine months in advance, some analysts believe the next recession may start sooner, with the most pessimistic believing the country may already be in a downturn. Already, the stock market, one of the components which makes up the index, has staged a sharp retreat and consumer confidence is on the skids. ``Initial reports from the University of Michigan (which measures consumer sentiment for Commerce) indicate that the consumer's first reaction to the Iraqi invasion was near panic,'' according to economist Mark M. Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``The sentiment index fell 15 points (more than after the 1987 stock market crash) to a level consistent with previous recessions,','' he said. ``Although sentiment has likely improved in recent days ... the risks of a consumer retrenchment are rising.'' Since consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, many analysts fear the Persian Gulf crisis could cause further retrenchment leading to a recession. However, after falling in May and June, the consumer index rose slightly in July. Other positive contributors to the index were an increase in orders for new plants and equipment and an increase in the price of raw materials. Negative contributors were faster business delivery times, a decline in the money supply, a drop in manufacturers' unfilled orders, a shorter average workweek, a drop in building permits, an increase in weekly unemployment claims and a decline in the stock market. One of the components, orders for consumer goods, was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 146.1 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and up 1.4 percent from its level a year ago. If a recession can be avoided through November, the economic expansion, already the nation's longest in peacetime, will have reached its eighth anniversary. But it has been growing sluggishly for two years and some analysts contend that, if the economy is not in a recession now, it soon will be. ``The U.S. economy was stagnating well before the Persian Gulf crisis,'' Merrill Lynch economists wrote in their Weekly Economic & Financial Commentary. They noted the economy grew at a meager 1.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter and said third-quarter indicators so far ``have been uniformly weak.'' ``For July,'' they said, ``employment declined, industrial production was flat, retail sales did not keep pace with inflation, and housing starts dropped to the lowest level since 1982 _ and that covered the period before the Persian Gulf crisis.'' Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and economists worry that a major cutback could halt economic growth altogether and even push the nation into recession. Even before the invasion, many analysts were citing consumer concerns over rising interest rates, a lack of job growth, high levels of debt, the savings and loan crisis and other adverse economic news. ``Consumer spending is only up about 1 percent year over year,'' said Merrill Lynch's Bruce Steinberg. ``That is typical of a recession.'' Since then, numerous polls have shown consumers growing even more cautious. Just Monday, the New York-based Conference Board reported its survey of 5,000 households nationwide showed confidence plummeted nearly 18 points to a seven-year low of 83.8 in August. The index had remained virtually unchanged at 101.7 in July. ``A war situation causes consumer confidence to fall'' explained Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. ``People become unwilling to take on major responsibilities like buying a new house.'' In addition, the surge in oil prices forces individuals to spend more for gasoline and heating costs and leaves them with less discretionary income for such items as cars and refrigerators. And with major sectors such as automobiles and housing already weak, analysts say it would not take much of a shove to force the economy into a decline.

The stock market eked out a small gain in light trading today as traders awaited developments in the Persian Gulf. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.24 to 2,616.09 by noontime on Wall Street. But gainers outnumbered losers by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 732 up, 515 down and 511 unchanged. Over the last couple of days, analysts say, stocks appear to have found an equilibrium level pending further events in the showdown that has followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Most oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on increased production quotas to compensate for the absence of shipments from Iraq and Kuwait. The news initially sent oil prices lower. Crude oil futures for October delivery fell more than $1.50 a barrel to just above $26 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. But it was unclear how much lasting effect the OPEC plan might have on the worldwide oil market. Doubts persisted, too, about the outlook for the domestic economy. The Commerce Department reported that its index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in July. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose [ to 45[; General Motors gained ] to 40|; American Express lost \ to 23], and McDonald's was down { at 27]. Long Island Lighting added ] to 19{. The company raised its quarterly dividend from 25 cents a share to 37.5 cents a share. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed stocks rose .56 to 176.82. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .89 at 322.67. Volume on the Big Board came to 53.56 million shares at noontime, down from 63.16 million at the same point Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Endorses Higher Crude Output During Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 new graf after 6th graf pvs, Oil prices . . . to include prices from today's trading in New York. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Sheik Ali . . .
DOC.TEXT: OPEC's oil ministers today approved a plan allowing Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other member countries to pump more oil and help hold down crude prices during the Persian Gulf crisis. Iran refused to back the deal, and Iraq and Libya did not show up for the meeting of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Indonesian Oil Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita predicted the agreement could free up to an additional 3 million barrels of oil a day. An international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude has wiped 4 million barrels a day off world markets and caused oil prices to skyrocket. The U.N. sanctions were imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The extra oil from OPEC ``should be primarily directed toward the countries of the Third World which are those that will be most immediately and adversely affected by any supply disruption,'' the cartel said in a statement. Oil prices, which soared last week above $30 a barrel, have dropped slightly in anticipation of greater OPEC production. In late morning trading today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, October contracts for light sweet crude dropped $1.83 to $26.05 per barrel. Futures contracts for other months were also down. Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, the finance minister for the Kuwaiti government-in-exile, said the added flow of oil should help stabilize prices. ``We simply cannot accept that the countries that came to our help in the gulf should suffer,'' he said. ``We cannot accept that prices go up because of Iraqi aggression and occupation of our country,'' said the official, who was his government's oil minister until July. In opposing the deal, Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh said Western industrialized nations must draw down some of their oil stocks before seeking help from the cartel. ``After that we can do something,'' he said. He said Iran, one of OPEC's leading producers, will not increase output above its quota of 3.1 million barrels a day. Analysts say it's unclear how much more Iran could produce because of the heavy damage inflicted on its oil industry during an eight-year war with Iraq. But Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates and a few others were expected to take steps immediately to help fill the oil gap. Saudi Arabian Oil Minister Hisham Nazer left shortly after the meeting and did not announce his country's plans. But earlier he said the nation will boost output by 2 million barrels a day. Some sources say the Saudis have already lifted production beyond its OPEC supply quota of 5.4 million barrels a day. Venezuela's oil minister, Celestino Armas, said his country could initially add an extra 300,000 barrels a day to its ceiling of 1.9 million barrels. ``We are taking the position to supply another 200,000 barrels (a day) by the end of the year,'' he said. The United Arab Emirates was expected to raise production by as much as 500,000 barrels a day above its quota of 1.5 million barrels. In July, all 13 nations agreed on a limit of 22.5 million barrels a day in an effort to boost prices to $21 a barrel. In a statement, the cartel said it decided to ``increase production, in accordance with need, in order to maintain'' market stability and a regular flow of crude to consumers. It also urged major oil-consuming nations to draw down some of their oil inventories. Ten of the 11 nations worked out the agreement early Tuesday but delayed endorsing it to give Iraq and Libya time to act. Sources requesting anonymity said Iraq claimed the meeting was held on too short notice and questioned its legality. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota to Triple Non-Automotive Sales
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp., Japan's largest automobile manufacturer, plans to triple the sales of its non-automotive divisions by 1994, the company said Wednesday. Executive Vice President Masami Iwasaki made the disclosure at a news conference where he also reported Toyota's consolidated profit had risen 27.4 percent in its latest fiscal year. Iwasaki said Toyota will raise the output of its non-automotive divisions from roughly 2 percent of its sales to 6 percent. Though small in percentage terms, 6 percent of Toyota's total domestic sales would be 479.9 billion yen, or $3.1 billion, based on the company's latest annual sales figures. In addition to cars, Toyota also produces industrial vehicles such as forklifts and shovel loaders, builds homes and manufactures factory automation equipment. Toyota and other Japanese automobile manufacturers have traditionally devoted a much smaller part of their operations to non-automobile sectors than their European or American counterparts. The move is thought to represent Toyota's decision to begin diversifying away from automobiles as world demand for cars shrinks and competition intensifies. It also comes at the same time that American auto makers have been selling off their non-automobile subsidiaries. Iwasaki said Toyota would revise its charter to permit the company to enter new fields such as aerospace, medical equipment and ceramics. But he said it expected greatest growth in housing, industrial vehicles and factory automation. The company also announced Wednesday that its consolidated net profit rose 27.4 percent to 441.3 billion yen, or about $2.85 billion, in the fiscal year ended June 30 from 346.3 billion yen a year earlier. Its pre-tax earnings were up 33.9 percent to 837.8 billion yen, or $5.5 billion, from 625.7 billion yen the previous year. The consolidated statement includes 39 subsidiaries and related companies. Consolidated sales totaled 9.19 trillion yen, or $60.0 billion, up 14.6 percent from 8.02 trillion yen in sales last year. The manufacturer said robust domestic sales, coupled with moderate expansion in Southeast Asia and steady growth in North America underlined its strong showing. Unconsolidated exports fell 11.0 percent to 1,608,484 vehicles for the year, while overseas production rose by 83.5 percent. Toyota said intensifying competition within Japan, an expected slowdown in growth of automobile demand in the United States plus any impact from the Middle East crisis might make it more difficult to achieve similar results in the future. Nevertheless, the car maker said it plans to increase vehicle sales within Japan by 4.0 percent and exports by 7.6 percent during the next fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Plans 3-Month Freeze In Prices For Petroleum Products
With AM-Gulf-Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: Italian finance officials proposed Wednesday to freeze prices of petroleum products for three months to fight inflationary fallout from the Gulf crisis. Treasury Minister Guido Carli, Finance Minister Rino Fomica and Budget Minister Paolo Cirino Pomicino will ask the cabinet Friday to approve a price freeze that would go into effect from September through November. The freeze is aimed at buffering the Italian economy, which is highly oil dependent, from the impact of the higher oil prices caused by the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait on Aug. 2. According to preliminary industry estimates, the jump in oil prices could add a half percentage point to the inflation rate, depending on the level of the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Names New Stations Division President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Johnathan cq.
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. said Wednesday that Johnathan Rodgers, vice-president and general manager of CBS-owned WBBM-TV in Chicago, has been named as the new president of its television stations division. In that post, he will oversee CBS' five TV stations. Rodgers, 44, is a former news executive who has been at WBBM-TV since March 1986. He succeeds Eric Ober, who last week became CBS News' president after the forced resignation of David Burke. Burke had held the job for two years. Rodgers, who will remain in Chicago, will be the highest-ranking black executive at any of the three major networks. He joined CBS in 1976 as assistant news director at WBBM. He worked at what now is KCBS-TV, a CBS-owned station in Los Angeles, from 1978 to 1983, serving successively as an executive news producer, news director and then as the station's manager. He later became executive producer of CBS News' ``Nightwatch,'' and then was executive producer of the ``CBS Morning News'' in 1985 before rejoining WBBM. Before joining CBS, Rodgers was a reporter for WKYC-TV in Cleveland, and a news producer at WNBC-TV in New York. CBS Broadcast Group president Howard Stringer said in a statement that Rodgers ``has proven himself throughout his career at CBS to be an outstanding manager, competitor, strategist and programmer.'' In addition to WBBM and KCBS-TV, Rodgers will be responsible for WCBS-TV in New York, WCIX-TV in Miami and WCAU-TV in Philadelphia. A native of San Antonio, Texas, he is married to former ABC News correspondent Royal Kennedy. The couple has two children.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished slightly lower on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday in quiet trading. Traders had expected Wall Street to drift downward during the course of London dealing. But an about-turn in early New York trading helped the London market to its flat finish, dealers said. A lack of genuine buying interest was again a main feature, traders said. ``The market is in for a long stalemate,'' one trader said, adding that volume is unlikely to pick up soon. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 0.4 points at 2,125.7. The day's low was 2,110.1, and the high, 2,128.1. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 1.5 points at 1,658.9. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 0.39 points to close at 1,140.34. Volume came to a slim 297.3 million shares, up from Tuesday's 281.6 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Volvo Profits Decline, Work Force to be Reduced
DOC.TEXT: The Swedish car maker Volvo said Wednesday it is cutting 5,000 jobs this year and next because profits during the first six months of 1990 have declined by half. A reduction in demand for cars and trucks in North America was a major cause of the profit decline, according to Volvo's interim report, released Wednesday. An 11 percent decline in domestic demand and a 17 percent drop in the British market also contributed to the lower profits, the report said. Profits dropped from 4.2 billion kronor, or $744 million, in the first six months of 1989 to just over 2 billion kronor, or $359 million, this year, the interim report said. The company has already dropped 1,000 employees in the car and truck sector this year, and plans to reduce the work force by another 4,000 through 1991. The major cuts in the number of employees will be made in Sweden, the company's executive Christer Zetterberg said in a radio interview. ``It is due to the development of the cost of production in Sweden that has not been favorable for several years now and it has been difficult to increase the production in a way that compensates for the increase of salaries,'' Zetterberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Shipping Company Shifts Base to Dubai
DOC.TEXT: The Kuwaiti-based United Arab Shipping Co., jointly owned by six Gulf Arab countries including Kuwait and Iraq, has shifted its base to Dubai, shipping executives said Wednesday. The company's board of directors has completed a plan to continue operations from the southern gulf port city, said the shipping executives, who spoke on condition that they not be named. The UASC is a gulf shareholding company established in 1976 by the governments of the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Qatar. All 48 of its vessels, including 15 container ships, were out of Kuwait waters when Iraq invaded the country on Aug. 2, the executives said. The company was trying to sort out its critical position following the invasion and resulting embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait, said the executives. Issues facing the company after the invasion included the status of Iraqi shares and the shifting of company headquarters from Kuwait, which means reflagging the vessels. The sources said that with Dubai as the company's base, ships could be registered under the U.A.E. flag to avert the dangers of embargo enforcement they would encounter under the Kuwaiti flag. The company would not violate the United Nations embargo on goods to Iraq or occupied Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Rover Goes on 24-Hour Production
DOC.TEXT: Rover Group PLC is introducing 24-hour car production, becoming the first British company to make vehicles around the clock, the firm said Wednesday. The company said trade unions have agreed to the schedule change, which will create an extra 1,200 jobs at its Longbridge factory, near Birmingham. The round-the-clock work is needed to meet production demands for the new Rover 200 hatchbacks, Rover 400 sedans and for the manufacture of the new K-series engine and gearbox, Rover said. Production will be increased progressively to more than 5,000 vehicles a week from the current level of about 3,000, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Litton Fourth-Quarter Profits Fall 2 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Litton Industries' fourth-quarter earnings fell 2 percent despite increased sales, the conglomerate said Wednesday. Litton's shipbuilding division reported higher sales and profits. Results also improved at its Resource Exploration Services, which compiles and sells data on oil and gas reserves, Litton said. But its defense electronics and automated assembly line businesses suffered from tightening military spending and softness in the automotive market. For the quarter ending July 31, Litton earned $45.5 million or $1.91 per share, compared to $46.6 million or $1.86 per share during the 1989 period. The company said per-share earnings rose because a stock repurchase program reduced the number of shares. Litton plans to continue the stock buyback, purchasing another 2.5 million of its common shares, the company said Wednesday. Quarterly revenue rose 7 percent, from $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion. For the year, earnings rose fractionally, from $178.3 million or $7.05 per share to $178.8 million or $7.26 per share. Sales rose by about 3 percent, from $5.02 billion to $5.16 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Good Growing Conditions Send Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with aggressive commodity fund selling late in the session. The sharp selloff was attributed to the continuing good growing conditions in the Midwest and the perception that crop yields will be larger than predicted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. ``There is also the perception that the Soviet Union will not enter the U.S. market for grains and soybeans until October,'' Biedermann said. Also contributing to the fall in prices was the diminishing of inflationary pressures as indicated by a drop in energy futures prices. Biedermann said the light volume of trading on the Board of Trade allowed the selloff to begin and accelerate toward the close of business. At the close, wheat prices were 3 cents lower to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.79{ a bushel; corn was a \ cent to 2} cents lower with September at $2.53{ a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 2} cents lower with September at $1.05} a bushel; soybeans were 3\ cents to 10\ cents lower with September at $6.10} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Yields on Treasury Notes Rise
DOC.TEXT: Yields on five-year Treasury notes rose in Wednesday's auction to the highest level in 15 months. The average yield was 8.57 percent, up from 8.54 percent at the last auction last May 24. It was the highest rate since five-year notes averaged 8.72 percent on May 25, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8{ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,964.40. A total of $8.56 billion in notes-bonds were sold out of bids totaling $26.35 billion.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 23.52 to 2,638.37 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,020 up, 467 down and 456 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Second Prototype of Advanced Tactical Fighter Rolls Out
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. on Wednesday unveiled its version of a futuristic fighter proposed for the 21st century, as Air Force officials cited the Middle East crisis as the need for such a craft. The Lockheed YF-22 prototype of the Advanced Tactical Fighter followed Monday's launch of a prototype made by Northrop Corp. The two designs are competing for a multibillion-dollar contract. The plane Lockheed unveiled at its Palmdale manufacturing plant was much more compact than the Northrop version. Both planes have smooth contours to help them evade radar and are built of advanced composite materials. The Lockheed aircraft has stubby wings, while the Northrop plane is longer, with a cigar-like fuselage and a wingspan that looks like a kite. A music system blared Wagner's ``Flight of the Valkyries'' as the Lockheed plane was rolled out, although unlike its competition, the YF-22 stayed on the ground after its rollout. Officials would not say when it would be flown. Lockheed chairman Daniel M. Tellep said it will not matter that Northrop got its aircraft up first. ``It is not he who flies first, it is he who flies best,'' he said. The contract calls for 750 fighter planes for the Air Force and approximately 500 for the Navy at a cost of $51 million apiece. The price tag is about twice the cost of the F-15 Eagle, the current front-line fighter deployed in the Middle East. The ATF program faced fading prospects for approval in Congress before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, but the crisis has enhanced prospects for approval of major defense projects. Air Force Maj. Gen. Joseph W. Ralston said he is optimistic about congessional funding for the ATF program desspite recent defense spending cuts. In building the YF-22 prototype, Lockheed teamed with the Boeing Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. Northrop teamed with McDonnell Douglas Corp. for its test version of the futuristic fighter. The winner must give the Pentagon a fighter plane that can fly twice the speed of sound, is highly maneuverable and uses radar-evading stealth technology. If Northrop gets the contract, ATF planes will be built in Southern California. Lockheed has said if it wins the competition, the fighters will be made in Marietta, Ga.

DOC.HEAD: New Home Sales Down Once Again
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: New homes sales in July fell for the fifth time in seven months, the government said Wednesday, and industry observers said rising mortgage rates linked to the Mideast crisis will compound the decline in months ahead. ``We will be facing a few months of significant weakness because of the runup in rates,'' said Robert Villanueva, forecasting director for the National Association of Home Builders. ``At least for the remainder of the year, it's difficult to be optimistic,'' said James Nelson, president-elect of the Mortgage Bankers Association and chief executive officer of Eberhardt Co., a Minneapolis mortgage banking company. The Commerce Department said new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 548,000 units, down from 561,000 units in June and 741,000 in July 1989. At the same time, the department offered evidence of even more sluggishness earlier, revising downward the sales totals in both May and June. It said sales edged up just 0.6 percent in May rather than the 2.3 percent reported last month, and 4.7 percent in June instead of the 8 percent in the earlier report. For the first seven months of the year, sales have fallen 12.4 percent below the pace of 1989. The department also said inventories of new homes showed a 7.8 month backlog at the July sales pace. It had been 7.7 months in June. Analysts had expected a pickup in sales in July as fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage rates continued to slide from their 1990 peak of 10.67 percent in May to 9.98 percent by the end of the month. But Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said consumer confidence was waning even before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait because of uncertainty over the economy. ``When that happens, they tend to postpone purchases of high-priced things,'' he said. Nevertheless, sales of existing homes did rise in July, up 3.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.44 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. John A. Tuccillo, the association's chief economist, said sales of existing homes advanced because of their lower prices. The median price of a new home was $121,000 in July, Commerce said. That was down 4.7 percent from June but still $22,600 more than the $98,400 median price for an existing home in the Realtors' survey. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. But analysts also expect resales to drop as mortgage rates increase. By last Friday, the average rate was 10.29 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. New home sales in the Northeast, which have been sluggish for more than a year, fell 10.1 percent to an annual rate of 80,000 units. The department also revised the June increase downward, from 36.9 percent to 25.3 percent. Sales fell in the West, down 4.9 percent to 135,000 units, while they were unchanged at 237,000 units in the South. Sales rose 2.1 percent to 96,000 units in the Midwest.

DOC.HEAD: Management Team Named in Bank Merger
DOC.TEXT: The Citizens and Southern Corp. and Sovran Financial Corp., which on Saturday plan a merger creating the nation's 13th largest bank, have named a nine-member management team for the new company. C&S Chairman Bennett A. Brown will serve as chairman and chief executive officer. Dennis C. Bottorff, currently president of Sovran, will become president and chief operating officer. Other top officials in the new company include Albert B. Gornto, chairman of the executive committee, and Hugh M. Chapman, vice chairman. The new company, to be called C&S@Sovran Corp., will have more than 1,000 banking offices in seven states and Washington, D.C., and total assets of $50.3 billion. C&S@Sovran will have dual offices in Atlanta and Norfolk, Va., the home bases of the former separate companies. The merger, which was announced last September, cleared its last major regulatory hurdle in July when the Federal Reserve Board approved the deal. It had been challenged earlier by a community group in Atlanta which argued that C&S was not fulfilling its obligation to serve poorer customers. C&S and Sovran operate banking offices in Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Maryland, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia and Washington, D.C. Local banking offices will continue to operate under either the C&S or Sovran name, Brown said.
Stock prices posted a modest gain in light trading today, aided by falling oil prices. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 12.63 at 2,627.48.

DOC.HEAD: Matsushita To Enter Supercomputer Market
DOC.TEXT: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. will enter the supercomputer market with a low cost ``mini supercomputer'' specially designed for scientific applications, a company spokesman said Wednesday. The computer, to be test produced this year and marketed within a few years, will cost about $1.04 million, or one-tenth the price of supercomputers on the market today, the spokesman said. In addition to being less expensive, Matsushita's machine, at one cubic meter, will be between one-tenth and one-twentieth the size of current supercomputer systems since it won't require a massive cooling unit, the spokesman said. With a speed of 25 gigaflops, or 25 billion operations per second, Matsushita's model will be among the fastest supercomputers, the spokesman said. Supercomputers typically are used for operations such as weather forecasting and computer simulation that require huge numbers of calculations. The machine's applications will be limited compared with more expensive models, the spokesman said. But he said the company is studying the possibility of adding more versatile models. Universities and research centers will be the prime market for Matsushitas machine. The current leaders of the supercomputer market in Japan include Cray Research Inc. of the United States and Fujitsu Ltd., Hitachi Ltd. and NEC Corp. of Japan. Matsushita, which quit the computer business in 1964, has re-entered the field over the last two years, emphasizing workstations and personal computers. The company is best known in the United States for its Panasonic and Quasar brand consumer electronics.
