DOC.HEAD: One-A-Day Vitamin to Stop Certain Health Claims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds two new grafs at end to UPDATE with comment from Miles Inc. spokeswoman.
DOC.TEXT: The makers of One-A-Day vitamins have agreed to stop advertising that its product can reverse the effects of air pollution, stress and strenuous exercise, New York's attorney general announced Wednesday. Attorney General Robert Abrams said there was no conclusive and scientific proof that any vitamins could protect people from such ill effects. ``One-A-Day's claims are patently false and only create an unfounded belief in the benefits of the product,'' Abrams said in a statement. Television and radio ads for the vitamins say: ``Defending your lungs against air pollution requires vitamins A, C and E. Daily stress can chip away at your B vitamins. And rigorous physical training can lower your body's supply of essential minerals. That's why One-A-Day vitamins are uniquely formulated to put back what your world takes away.'' In addition to discontinuing the disputed commercials, Miles Inc. of Elkhart, Ind., paid $10,000 each to New York, California and Texas as part of the settlement. Miles is a subsdiary of the big West Germany pharmaceuticals concern Bayer AG. Dionn Tron, a spokeswoman for Miles, said the company had stopped airing the commercials in April due to a change in marketing strategy. ``We continue to believe that the ads were not misleading and the claims in them were well substantiated,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Prevents S&Ls from Leaving Home Loan Bank System
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Wednesday it has issued a ruling effectively barring state-chartered savings and loan associations from withdrawing from the Federal Home Loan Bank System for at least 18 months. The action eases concerns that the FDIC might be on the verge of allowing a giant exodus of S&Ls from the system _ which would cripple the system's ability to finance the savings and loan bailout. The action came on a request by the Wauwatosa Savings and Loan Association of Wauwatosa, Wis., which had asked if it could maintain its federal deposit insurance if it pulled out of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago. In a statement, the FDIC said it could ``make no assurances at this time to Wauwatosa that it would be able to retain its deposit insurance should it withdraw from membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank System.'' Because both banks and S&Ls depend on federal deposit insurance to operate, the FDIC decision effectively blocks any exodus by state-chartered institutions out of the S&L system. The FDIC said its action, which was taken at a closed board meeting on Tuesday, was based on recommendations made by the Office of Thrift Supervision, the agency which regulates the S&L industry. The OTS said that the withdrawal of S&Ls from the home loan bank system would pose safety and soundness concerns. The FDIC did agree to review the matter in 18 months. It said that would give the OTS time to draw up regulations clarifying the situation. The OTS is expected to propose a regulation that would require state-chartered S&Ls to belong to the Federal Home Loan Bank System. Of the 2,505 savings and loans still operating, about half of them are federally chartered and the other half have state charters. Both state and federally chartered S&Ls were members of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., the now-defunct agency which provided insurance of up to $100,000 per deposit at S&Ls. The S&L bailout legislation passed by Congress last year made it clear that federally chartered S&Ls must maintain their membership in the S&L system even though their insurance fund was being administered by the FDIC. However, the legislation was less clear about the status of state-chartered thrifts. The home loan bank system is required to contribute up to $300 million annually as its share of the S&L bailout, a burden which some S&Ls have complained adds to their cost of operation and makes it difficult for them to compete with commercial banks. However, Bush administration officials contended that if the FDIC allowed state-chartered S&Ls to leave, it would make it difficult for the home loan bank system to come up with its required contribution to the bailout.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market staged a moderate advance Wednesday with encouragement from falling oil prices. Trading remained light, however. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 17.58 to 2,632.43. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 972 up, 508 down and 512 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 134.24 million shares, against 127.65 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 165.67 million shares. Over the last couple of days, analysts say, stocks appear to have found an equilibrium level pending further events in the showdown that has followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Most oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on increased production quotas to compensate for the absence of shipments from Iraq and Kuwait. The news sent oil prices lower. Crude oil futures for October delivery fell nearly $2 a barrel to just under $26 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. But enthusiasm over that development was muted by uncertainty over how much lasting effect the OPEC plan might have on the worldwide oil market. Doubts persisted, too, about the outlook for the domestic economy. The Commerce Department reported that its index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in July. Energy stocks were steady to mostly higher despite the oil price drop. Mobil gained | to 63~; Atlantic Richfield 1| to 135}; Texaco { to 63\, and Schlumberger 1[ to 64]. Other gainers among the blue chips included Boeing, up ~ at 48}; Bristol-Myers Squibb, up 1] at 60}; Philip Morris, up { at 45{; American Telephone & Telegraph, up ] at 32{, and General Motors, up ] at 40|. By contrast, many prominent technology issues in the over-the-counter market came under renewed selling pressure. MCI Communications fell 1| to 31}; 3Com Corp. 3~ to 8}; Intel | to 35, and Microsoft 2] to 60{. The drop in 3Com was attributed to negative appraisals of the company's prospects following a conference-call meeting with analysts Tuesday. Wyle Laboratories, traded on the Big Board, rose 1[ to 12[. The company said it expected higher earnings for its fiscal second half and for the full fiscal year ending Jan. 31. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $19.26 billion, or 0.63 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.52 to 177.78. Standard & Poor's industrial index gained 2.87 to 384.45, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.85 at 324.19. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 1.08 to 381.78. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 324.23, up 2.45.

DOC.HEAD: Central American Nations Ask Oil Discount; Venezuela Boosts Capacity
DOC.TEXT: Five Central American countries have asked Mexico and Venezuela for relief from the increase in oil prices prompted by the Middle East crisis. ``The military invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, which deeply concerns our people, will affect the world petroleum market and will bring inevitable political and economic consequences for Central America,'' President Rafael Leonardo Callejas told The Associated Press. Meanwhile Wednesday, Venezuela said it planned to increase oil production capacity, and Brazil said it would receive more oil from Iran to make up for shortages due to the embargo on oil from Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Under the 10-year-old San Jose Agreement, five Central American countries have been buying Venezuelan and Mexican oil for an average $17 a barrel, paying 80 percent in cash. Mexico and Venezuela allow the other 20 percent to be used as loans for development projects, or to finance imports from Venezuela and Mexico. Under the proposal by Honduras and four other nations, the countries would pay 70 percent of their oil bills in cash as long as prices remain high, Callejas said. The other 30 percent would be covered as credits for purchases of Mexican or Venezuelan goods and services, or as loans for development projects. The other four nations are El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Guatemala. The San Jose Agreement also covers Belize, Panama, Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and Barbados. Meanwhile, Venezuela plans to increase its oil production capacity to 2.86 million barrels per day in 1990, a 60,000-barrel increase, Petroleos de Venezuela said Wednesday. Venezuela is actually pumping only about 2 million barrels daily and has said it intends to bring up to 500,000 more by the end of the year to make up for the oil lost by the embargo. And in Brazil, Iran's ambassador told reporters his country will increase oil sales to Brazil by 200,000 barrels a day to cover the loss of imports from Iraq and Kuwait. Mahmoud Movahedi said Iran would sign a deal with the Brazilian government oil monopoly Petrobras for the sale of an extra 100,000 barrels of oil a day. Weeks before the Gulf crisis, Petrobras had agreed to buy 100,000 barrels daily from Iran at below-market prices.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher in U.S.; Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved mostly higher in U.S. trading Wednesday after a mixed performance overseas as currency dealers began adjusting their holdings ahead of the long holiday weekend in the United States. Gold prices gained modestly in domestic dealings. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $385.30 a troy ounce, up 30 cents from Tuesday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a bid of $386 for an ounce of gold bullion, $1.50 higher than Tuesday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Domestic currency dealers said the dollar's advance came as a byproduct of trading in German marks and Japanese yen, which captured most of the attention. Dealers sold marks and bought yen. The buying interest in the Japanese currency coincided with an OPEC agreement to increase oil output to compensate for lost exports from Iraq and Kuwait. At a meeting this week in Vienna, Austria, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided on the action in response to the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Earlier this month, dealers had dumped yen amid speculation that Japan's heavily oil import-dependent economy would suffer due to a disruption in oil supplies caused by the Middle East conflict. A nervous tone continued to prevail in foreign exchange markets as traders awaited developments in the Persian Gulf. Most financial markets have been volatile since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Michael Schaufler, a currency trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office, said foreign exchange markets were preparing for the three-day U.S. Labor Day weekend. Efforts are being made to balance currency holdings in case any market-moving developments occur while U.S. trading is closed. European foreign exchange dealers similarly reported that with prospects uncertain for a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis, trading focused more on consolidating accounts before the end of the month. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.35 yen, up 1.15 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 143.65 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 143.55 yen, down from 143.75 yen on Tuesday. The British pound was quoted at $1.9475 late in London, up from $1.9470 Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.94575 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.9429. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late quotes included: 1.55925 German marks, up from 1.5560; 1.28875 Swiss francs, up from 1.2860; 5.2300 French francs, up from 5.2175; 1,155.00 Italian lire, up from 1,149.25; and 1.13865 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1416. Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's levels, were: 1.5562 West German marks, up from 1.5525; 1.2740 Swiss francs, down from 1.2815; 5.2170 French francs, up from 5.2065; 1.7525 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7470; 1,151.50 Italian lire, up from 1,149.25; and 1.1385 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1416. Gold bullion prices were mixed overseas. In London, gold was quoted at a late price of $385.25 a troy ounce, up from late Tuesday's bid of $383. In Zurich, the late bid was $384.25, up from $382 late Tuesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold dropped $3.25 an ounce on Wednesday, to close at $389.34. Silver prices moved lower here and abroad. It traded late in London at $4.83 a troy ounce, slightly below the late bid of $4.85 on Tuesday. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.826 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's settlement of $4.840.

DOC.HEAD: Slide As Traders Gamble on Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices of crude oil, heating oil and unleaded gasoline dropped sharply Wednesday on news of higher OPEC output and trader speculation that peace finally seemed possible in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude, the benchmark grade, fell $1.96 to $25.92 per barrel for October contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a leading market for petroleum. ``Right now, we've gone from war-time psychosis last Friday, when the price was $32, back to no war,'' said David D. Hale, chief economist with Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. Contracts for crude-oil delivery in later months also fell following word that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had approved a plan allowing Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other producers to boost output. The international boycott of crude from Iraq and Kuwait has kept about 4 million barrels per day off the world markets, which last week jacked oil prices up to the highest level in five years. Sources in Vienna, where the OPEC officials met, estimated the new OPEC oil might come to 3 million barrels per day, making up most of the shortfall. ``The only real thing that has happened is it looks like OPEC has kind of blessed the increasing of output by producers,'' said Stephen Smith, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. ``It's still looking like no hostilities for the time being, and no extreme shortage of oil.'' Home heating oil fell 7.88 cents to 71.64 cents per gallon on September contracts traded on the Mercantile Exchange. Unleaded gasoline dropped 3.81 cents to 84.72 cents per gallon on September contracts. Both products were also down for other future months, with heating oil futures for October through January dropping their maximum limit of 6 cents per gallon. The limit, which offers traders on the Merc a degree of protection, applies to all contract months except the nearest, or spot month. Natural gas was up from $1.500 to $1.505 per 1,000 cubic feet on October contracts. Other natural gas futures months were down. A Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. trader, Ed Kevelson, said investors were responding partly to reports that the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, might take a softer stance on his claims to Kuwait during a meeting Thursday with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. ``We just heard the story that Hussein is supposedly going to propose federated self-rule for Kuwait,'' Kevelson said. Traders were not quite sure what type of rule that would be for the oil-rich nation seized by Iraq Aug. 2. Kevelson said he doubted anything would come from such a proposal, but nonetheless it helped depress petroleum prices. ``People tend to focus now on the bearish news and the OPEC news instead of the tension,'' Kevelson said. ``The possibility of peace, that's it,'' said Sal Gilbertie, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Despite cheaper wholesale oil traded on the Merc and elsewhere, gasoline prices were rising at the pump, figures from the American Automobile Association showed. Self-serve regular unleaded averaged $1.307 a gallon nationwide, an increase of 3.3 cents over Friday, the AAA reported Wednesday. Retail gasoline prices have risen 23.2 cents per gallon since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, AAA said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Production Increase, Iraqi Overtures Send Oil Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Another round of selling pushed energy futures prices lower Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as OPEC ministers agreed to suspend production restraints and allow members to boost the flow of oil. On other markets, precious metals were steady; grain and soybean futures fell; and livestock and pork futures closed mixed. Light sweet crude settled 33 cents to $1.96 lower with the contract for delivery in October at $25.92 a barrel; heating oil was 5.39 cents to 7.88 cents lower with September at 71.64 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.50 cents to 5.82 cents lower with September at 84.72 cents a gallon. Initial selling of energy futures was set off by reports that Saudi Arabia was already producing 7.5 million barrels a day, said Michael Rothman, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Captial Markets Inc. in New York. He said indications are Saudi Arabia will boost output to 8 million barrels by the end of September and 8.5 million barrels by the end of the year. Further selling pressure came on reports that Iraqi said it would pull out of Kuwait if the United Nations sanctions were dropped and the country was guaranteed access to the Persian Gulf and sole control of a Kuwaiti oil field. The United States has refused to confirm or deny the report, which Rothman said set off another round of peace selling. In Vienna, ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to boost oil production by 3 million to 3.5 million barrels a day to offset the loss of 4 million barrels due to the embargo of Iraq. Precious metal futures halted their plunge on New York's Commodity Exchange, largely disregarding plunging energy futures prices. Trading volume fell from Tuesday's level due to increased margins on gold and silver contracts demanded by the exchange. The move makes trading more expensive and dampened market enthusiasm, said Don Tierney, an analyst with Stanley Bell & Co. in New York. Tierney said selling hit the market early in the session as energy prices fell. But moderate buying by speculators and investors in London helped stablize prices. After losing over $30 in recent trading sessions, gold is coming out of its oversold condition, with some new buying beginning to support the market, Tierney said. Gold was 10 cents lower to 30 cents higher with August at $385.30 a troy ounce; silver was 1.6 cents to 1.8 cents lower with August at $4.826 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices were lower on the Chicago Board of Trade, with aggressive commodity fund selling coming late in the session. The sharp selloff was attributed to the continuing good growing conditions in the Midwest and the perception that crop yields will be larger than predicted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. ``There is also the perception that the Soviet Union will not enter the U.S. market for grains and soybeans until October,'' Biedermann said. Also contributing to the fall in prices was the diminishing of inflationary pressures as indicated by a drop in energy futures prices. Biedermann said the light volume of trading on the Board of Trade allowed the selloff to begin and accelerate toward the close of business. Wheat was 4 cents to 6 cents lower with September at $2.75} a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 5} cents lower with September at $2.50 a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 3} cents lower with September at $1.04} a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 16\ cents lower with September at $6.05\ a bushel. Livestock futures were lower and pork futures mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle prices were pressured by light retail demand for beef and expectations of a decline in cash prices. Pork futures were higher on ideas that demand for pork products will increase. Live cattle were .13 cent to .58 cent lower with October at 76.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 88.77 cents a pound; hogs were .02 cent to .37 cent higher with October at 48.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .22 cent to .35 cent higher with February at 52.60 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Tandy, Matsushita To Produce PCs Jointly
DOC.TEXT: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. of Japan and Fort Worth-based Tandy Corp. will produce personal computers at a Texas plant under a joint venture, according to a newspaper report Wednesday. The size of the planned investment was not known, The Dallas Morning News reported. Tandy Corp., the parent of the Radio Shack chain, had no comment on the report, spokesman Tony Magoulas said Wednesday. A factory to be built in Tarrant County, west of Dallas, will produce desktop and portable computers for Tandy and Matsushita, the Morning News reported. Tandy already makes a full line of desktop and portable computers, including models it sells to Matsushita for sale under its Panasonic name. Tandy also sells under its name a laptop computer that is made by Matsushita. Cooperation between the two companies dates back to at least 1988. Japanese and American industry sources told the newspaper that the latest agreement, reached in the past few weeks, has not been formalized. ``We have had discussions with Tandy on a number of matters,'' said Justin Camerlengo, chief spokesman at Matsushita's main U.S. subsidiary. ``There is a genuine interest in doing things with Tandy. But we have no announcements to make.'' Sources told the Morning News that production at the plant largely will be based on manufacturing processes that Matsushita developed. The company already makes computer workstations at a plant in Illinois.

DOC.HEAD: Former Exxon Valdez Tanker Leaves for Sea Trial
LaserPhotos GO-2, 3
DOC.TEXT: The repaired and renamed ship that caused the country's worst oil spill left San Diego Bay for sea trials Wednesday after a multimillion-dollar repair job to its mangled hull. The rebuilt Exxon Mediterranean, formerly named the Exxon Valdez, got underway at 6:45 a.m. as tugboats pulled the ship from a pier and guided it through the harbor. There were no protesters trailing the ship as there were when the 32,000-ton tanker, with its severely damaged hull, was towed into harbor from Alaska 13 months ago. Workers at National Steel & Shipbuilding Co. replaced 3,000 tons of steel in the mangled hull during the 11-month, $30 million repair job. The 987-foot-long tanker was floated out of dry dock last month and underwent dock trials at a NASSCO pier. The ship, which was built at NASSCO and delivered to Exxon in 1986, will head for international waters about 100 miles from the San Diego coast and some 25 miles past San Clemente Island, said NASSCO spokesman Fred Hallett. Officials from NASSCO, the Coast Guard and the American Bureau of Shipping will be aboard the ship during the sea trials, which are expected to last between a week and 10 days, Exxon spokeswoman Carrie Chassin said Wednesday. ``All the structural work has been approved, but this sea trial is to make sure everything is in perfect operating condition,'' Chassin said. ``They will be testing all the systems of the ship, the steering, a comprehensive review until everyone is satisfied.'' During sea trials, the crew will run the tanker at full speed, make maximum turns and test machinery and equipment, Hallett said. ``Typically, when we repair a ship, we don't put it through a shakedown,'' Hallett said. ``But because of the extensive repairs and the problems it had, Exxon will put it through a shakedown as if it were a new ship.'' Exxon officials deny that the tanker's renaming in July was related to the spill of nearly 11 million gallons of oil when the ship ran aground on Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989. Officials say the tanker will transport crude in the Mediterranean. The vessel holds nearly 1.4 million barrels of crude, and is too big for any U.S. Pacific ports when fully loaded, Exxon officials have said. They also say tankers that big aren't needed for West Coast shipping routes because of declining production from Alaskan oil fields. Coast Guard Lt. Bill Uberti certified the ship's seaworthiness after testing its machinery and engines. He will be aboard during the sea trials. After the trials are finished, Chassin said the ship and its 20-member crew will return to San Diego for supplies before sailing to Singapore. ``In Singapore, it will take on additional fuel and provisions and then go to Egypt and the Middle East, load crude and then unload in France, the United Kingdom and Rotterdam,'' Chassin said. ``It will not load Iraqi crude in Turkey.''

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Endorses Higher Crude Output During Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ^SUBS 9th graf, Since Iraq, and ADDS new 10th graf to UPDATE with new gasoline, crude oil prices. Picks up 10th graf pvs, Sheikh Ali. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers Wednesday endorsed higher crude production to make up most _ but not all _ of the shortfall caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. The accord, worked out during four days of discussions, temporarily suspends the cartel's quota system to permit higher output by nations with spare capacity. An agreement worked out last month by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had set production at 22.5 million barrels per day. But an embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait four weeks ago has reduced supply by about 4 million barrels. The shortfall has led to increased prices for crude oil on world markets as well as hefty hikes for gasoline and heating oil sold on the retail level. Analysts predicted the surge in output of about 3 million barrels of crude by heavyweight Saudi Arabia and other producing nations could help hold down prices in the next few weeks. But they cautioned prices could shoot even higher with a further escalation of hostilities in the Gulf and stronger demand for oil as winter approaches. ``The market may pull back some, but the trend continues to remain on the up side as long as the military option in the Gulf remains a viable one,'' said Michael Rothman, an energy specialist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris, said gasoline prices at the pump should hold steady as long as crude prices do. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the average price of a gallon of unleaded regular gasoline in the United States has increased by more than 23 cents at the pumps, according to a survey released Wednesday by the American Automobile Association. The price of light sweet crude for October delivery was $25.92 on the New York Mercantile Exchange Wednesday, down $1.96 a barrel from the day before. Sheikh Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, the finance minister of Kuwait's government-in-exile, pressed for the agreement by the 13-nation OPEC. ``We simply cannot accept that countries that came to our help in the Gulf should suffer (from high prices),'' said the official, who was his government's oil minister until early July. Iran opposed the deal, arguing that Western nations should release oil from their inventories before asking OPEC for more. ``If they do something, after that we can do something,'' said the nation's oil minister, Gholamreza Aqazadeh. Iraq and Libya never showed up for the meeting, which Iraq said was held illegally. Indonesia's oil minister, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, predicted that OPEC nations would pump an additional 3 million or more barrels of oil a day into the market. But, he said, ``OPEC production will not be able to meet the loss.'' In a final statement, the ministers said they decided to ``increase production, in accordance with need, in order to maintain'' stable markets. The extra oil from OPEC and consuming countries, they said, should go primarily to developing countries that would be hurt most by a disruption in supplies. They called on consuming nations to ``actively participate'' in calming the markets and urged them to draw down some of their stocks. Saudi Arabia's influential minister, Hisham Nazer, left immediately after the meeting. But he has said his country's output will increase by 2 million barrels a day. One OPEC source, demanding anonymity, said the kingdom's production has already risen to more than 7 million barrels a day, well over its cartel quota of 5.4 million barrels. Iran, a leading producing nation, has no plans to boost production, Aqazadeh said. Venezuela's oil minister, Celestino Armas, said his country initially could add 300,000 barrels a day to its ceiling of 1.9 million barrels. ``We are taking the position to supply another 200,000 barrels by the end of the year,'' he said. The United Arab Emirates was expected to raise production by as much as a half million barrels a day above its quota of 1.5 million barrels. Jibril Aminu, the Nigerian oil minister, said his country, if it wanted, could produce 250,000 to 280,000 barrels a day beyond its limit of 1.6 million barrels. Libya could increase production about 100,000 barrels a day over its cap of 1.2 million barrels, analysts say. It takes about four to six weeks for oil to work its way onto the market. The OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Embargo Doesn't Affect Many Ships That Already Left
DOC.TEXT: Despite the embargo against Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, crude oil from those Persian Gulf nations is still reaching the United States, and will be for probably another few weeks. Jonathan Cogan of the Energy Information Administration, an independent statistical branch of the Energy Department, said Wednesday that ships loaded with oil prior to the U.S. trade restrictions have until Oct. 1 to arrive in the United States. When President Bush enacted the embargo on Aug. 2, the day Iraq invaded Kuwait, the government exempted from the restrictions delivery of crude that was already en route. ``It was kind of unfair for those refiners who ordered this crude, and perhaps already paid for it, to not receive it,'' Cogan said. Authorities believe they have provided enough time for the grandfathered tankers to complete the journey, which can take a month or more. But any tanker that misses the deadline will be barred from unloading its oil, Treasury Department spokeswoman Barbara Clay said. An Energy Department spokesman, Philip Keif, estimated that 40 million to 45 million barrels of Iraqi crude were already in the pipeline at the time of the embargo. ``A lot of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude was loaded right up to the invasion,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``The second week of September, that's when we're going to feel the crunch.''

DOC.HEAD: Pump Prices Up 3.3 Cents To $1.30 Per Gallon in Latest Check
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores dropped word `began' in lead
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices at the pump have risen more than 23 cents to crack $1.30 per gallon since the Middle East crisis began, the American Automobile Association said Wednesday. The AAA said a nationwide spot-check of service stations found that the price of self-serve regular unleaded gasoline increased 3.3 cents per gallon between last Friday and Wednesday. Retail prices have jumped by 23.2 cents to $1.307 per gallon since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, sending world petroleum prices shooting up, the AAA said. In the most recent spot-check, gasoline prices rose the most, 6.4 cents per gallon, in the Southwest. Prices were up 3.7 cents in the Midwest, 3.6 cents in the Southeast, 2.4 cents in New England, 2 cents in the West and 0.1 cent in the Great Lakes region. No change was noted in the Mid-Atlantic region, the AAA said.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Developer Unveils Homesite Incentive Plan
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp., the developer accused of swindling thousands of people out of homesites, Wednesday unveiled a comprehensive plan designed to keep customers and help rebuild the company. The developer, which pleaded guilty to fraud conspiracy in a March and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April, presented its plan to U.S. Bankruptcy Judge A. Jay Cristol. The plan would create a land trust to give deeds to customers who pay off their contracts; financial incentives for homesite buyers to continue making payments; and a lot transfer program in which homesite owners of undeveloped lots could swap their sites for developed lots. ``I for one am favorably impressed,'' the judge said after the presentation by Gordon Pfersich, senior vice president of land operations for General Development. ``What the customer really wants to know is, `If I keep paying, am I going to get anything?' '' Pfersich said. ``We say yes.'' Robert Roth, an attorney representing the city of Palm Bay, was not as sure. ``I think it's very pretty ... and very well presented,'' he said. ``But it doesn't give me enough substance.'' General Development has offered the state of Florida and cities and counties involved undeveloped lots in most cases in return for settling development obligations. The company also is turning over the utilities it operated to the cities and counties. The plan would offer 35,300 purchasers with contracts on undeveloped lots the option of transferring their lots to developed ones at no additional cost. ``Our problem is we don't know which lots they're talking about and in which cities, so we can't evaluate the plan,'' Roth said. ``We have our doubts about whether these lots are as developed as they are saying.'' General Development has about 13,000 unsold, developed lots to which customers could be transferred, many in retirement communities, company officials said. The 54,600 purchasers with contracts for developed lots would be offered financial incentives to keep paying on their contracts, such as a 5 percent cut on the original selling price, which would lower monthly payments. General Development believes its current portfolio, taking into account historical cancellation of contracts, is worth about $648 million. Subtracting accounts sold to investors, its portfolio is about $434 million. But taking into account the number of homesite buyers who were continuing to make payments as of July, the company estimates its share of the entire portfolio is worth about $126 million. Company officials believe that by assuring customers they will get a deed to a developed homesite, along with providing financial incentives, the company could more than double the value of its share of the accounts to about $279 million. Last month, the percentage of more than 77,000 people still owing on properties but who have stopped making payments jumped to 51 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Exchange Plans For 21st Century
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board of Trade should develop an electronic trading system, create new products, and attract new members and capital as it heads into the 21st century, an report released Wednesday said. ``As the world continues to change and competition in our markets increases, the Chicago Board of Trade will face many new challenges and opportunities,'' Board of Trade Chairman William F. O'Connor said. ``As an institution, we must be prepared to act boldly to meet the changes head-on,'' he said. The report was prepared by a task force headed by Robert S. Hamada, deputy dean of the University of Chicago business school. It said the Board of Trade must pursue a diverse set of new futures _ contracts to buy or sell everything from orange juice to wheat to securities at a specific date _ because of advantages in launching a product and intense competition. The study said that despite the introduction of a number of new trading products in recent years, 51 percent of the exchange's volume comes from Treasury bond futures. The study also concluded that paperless trading is essential to the future of pit trading and recommended pursuing new technology to that end. The Board of Trade should use electronic systems that most closely duplicate the open outcry auction trading, the study concluded. The task force contended that the auction system adds to the liquidity of the market. Although the Board of Trade is negotiating with the rival Chicago Mercantile Exchange to join in the Globex trading system developed by the Merc, the task force said that should not interfere with experimentation with the Aurora trading system being developed by the CBOT. The task force also recommended better incentive systems to attract members and capital to new products. The study concluded that a mix of capital pools, permits, fee rebates and electronic trading systems should be developed and used to accomplish the goal. The study also concluded that the current trading floor for financial futures is overcrowded, and that the exchange should remedy the problem. The report comes as the exchange battles some present-day problems. The Board of Trade and the Mercantile Exchange received a black eye when an investigation into illegal trading activity resulted in the indictment of 48 people. The exchange is also faced with a desire by regulators in Washington to increase federal oversight of the commodities industry. Industry leaders say that could reduce the competitiveness of U.S. futures market as foreign competition increases. The task force recommended the exchange delegate authority to allow it to make quicker decisions. The study said such a move would allow exchange leaders to focus on broad policy issues, not operational details.

DOC.HEAD: Government Agrees To Hear New Anti-Dumping Case
DOC.TEXT: The government decided Wednesday to investigate whether some Japanese-made electronic equipment are imported at less than fair value into the United States, threatening the domestic industry. The International Trade Commission ruled 4-0 that there is reasonable indication that imports of some electronic display screens used in computers and their subassemblies materially injure U.S. industry. The finding means the Commerce Department will conduct an anti-dumping investigation with hearings. A preliminary decision is due Dec. 28, the ITC said. The procedure could result in import duties on the Japanese products representing the margin of underpricing. The equipment, known as high-information content displays, display in color or black-and-white text, graphics or images the output of computers, data-processing machines, word processors, television receivers and scientific instruments. The commission took action in response to a petition filed by the Advanced Display Manufacturers of America, a trade group, and its member companies. It said the U.S. industry makes the devices in Beaverton, Ore.; Waukegan, Ill.; Milbury and Northwood, Ohio, and Troy, Mich. The announcement did not include data about the U.S. market and the extent of import penetration, which it said was confidential business information.
